'''Patrick John Miguel van Aanholt''' (born 29 August 1990) is a Dutch [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] as a [[Full back (association football)|left back]].

He began his professional career at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], where he was used sparingly, spending time on loan at five other clubs. In 2014, he joined Sunderland for around £1.5 million.

Van Aanholt represented the Netherlands at numerous youth levels before making his full international debut in 2013.
==Personal life==
He was born in [[Hertogenbosch]], [[Netherlands|Holland]] to parents from Curaçao.

==Club career==

===Chelsea===
Van Aanholt joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]'s youth ranks in 2007. He made his professional debut on loan to [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on 9 August 2009 starting in a 2–1 [[Football League Championship]] win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8187233.stm | title=Coventry 2–1 Ipswich | work=BBC Sport | date=9 August 2009 | accessdate=7 August 2010}}</ref> He was recalled to Chelsea in December due to the exit of many players due to the [[African Nations Cup]].

He was first selected for Chelsea in an [[FA Cup]] tie away to [[Preston North End]] in the [[FA Cup 2009–10|2009–10]] edition of the Cup, wearing the squad number 52, but did not make an appearance, remaining on the bench. He made his Chelsea debut on 24 March 2010, in a 5–0 away win at Portsmouth, replacing [[Yuri Zhirkov]] at left-back after 71 minutes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Portsmouth 0–5 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8580687.stm|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=24 March 2010}}</ref> He then made his home debut, on 27 March 2010, against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in a 7–1 victory, again as a substitute.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/england/2010/03/27/1852127/premier-league-player-ratings-chelsea-7-1-aston-villa]</ref> On 29 January 2010, Van Aanholt joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a one-month loan deal after regular left back [[José Enrique Sánchez|José Enrique]] suffered injury. He had been cover for the Spaniard, sustaining Newcastle's productive left flank with [[Jonás Gutiérrez]]. He played his last game in the 2–1 away victory at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].

[[File:Patrick van Aanholt 4740.jpg|upright|thumbnail|left|van Aanholt playing for Chelsea in 2010]]

Van Aanholt scored his first career goal on 22 September 2010 in the 4–3 defeat to former club [[Newcastle United]] in the [[2010–11 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=307975&cc=5739|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100926130707/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=307975&cc=5739|archivedate=26 September 2010|title=Ameobi sends Chelsea crashing out|date=22 September 2010|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=2010-12-08}}</ref>  On 26 January 2011, he joined [[Leicester City F.C|Leicester City]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11668_6703047,00.html | title=Foxes clinch Van Aanholt loan |work=Sky Sports | date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> He made his debut in a 1–0 win over [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 1 February 2011,<ref name="Sheff Utd   0 - 1   Leicester">{{cite news|title = Sheff Utd 0 – 1 Leicester|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/9379936.stm|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 1 February 2011|accessdate = 1 March 2011}}</ref> and suffered a torn muscle in his thigh at the end of the month after playing six games.<ref name="Leicester's Patrick van Aanholt set to miss a month">{{cite news|title = Leicester's Patrick van Aanholt set to miss a month|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/leicester_city/9410062.stm|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 28 February 2011|accessdate = 1 March 2011}}</ref> Van Aanholt scored his first senior league goal in a 4–0 victory over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 9 April 2011.<ref name="Report: Leicester City 4 Burnley 0">{{cite news|title = Leicester City vs Burnley|url = http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~52285,00.html|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110413061448/http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~52285,00.html|archivedate = 13 April 2011|publisher = LCFC|date = 9 April 2011|accessdate = 9 April 2011}}</ref>

On transfer deadline day 31 August 2011, Van Aanholt signed for [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a season-long loan deal.<ref>http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/31082011/58/spl-wigan-sign-maloney-celtic.html</ref> Van Aanholt's loan spell, originally a season-long arrangement, was terminated by mutual consent between all three parties.  During this uneventful loan spell, Van Aanholt played three league matches and one League Cup tie for the Latics but did not feature in their first team after 1 October.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2568792|title=Chelsea FC:Latest News|date=1 October 2011|accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref>

===Vitesse (loan spells)===

On 6 January 2012, he returned to Chelsea during a season-long loan at Wigan Athletic. Nine days later, Van Aanholt signed for Dutch club [[Vitesse]] on loan until the end of the season. Van Aanholt returned to his home country Netherlands with fellow Chelsea teammates [[Tomas Kalas]] and [[Ulises Davila]] who joined [[Vitesse]] at the start of the season on loan. On 11 July 2012, he rejoined Vitesse on a new loan deal for the [[2012–13 Eredivisie|2012–13]] season.<ref>[http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2841591 VITESSE LOANS FOR YOUNG PAIR]</ref> On 7 July 2013 the Vitesse loan deal was extended for the [[2013–14 Eredivisie|2013–14]] season. He made his first start of the [[2013–14 Vitesse season|2013–14]] season in a 1–1 first leg draw away at [[FC Petrolul Ploiești|Petrolul Ploiești]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]], a match in which he was booked in the 86th minute.<ref>[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2014/matches/round=2000467/match=2012363/index.html UEFA Europa League – Petrolul-Vitesse – UEFA.com]</ref> He went on to start eight of the next nine league fixtures for Vitesse,<ref>[http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=51881&season_id=143 Games played by Patrick van Aanholt in 2013/2014]</ref><ref>[http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2692&teamTabs=results&season_id=143 Vitesse Results/Matches]</ref> including getting an assist in a 1–1 draw at [[Roda JC Kerkrade|Roda JC]].<ref>[http://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2013/08/17/netherlands/eredivisie/roda-jc/sbv-vitesse/1478352/ RODA JC VS. VITESSE  1 – 1]</ref>

On 7 December 2013, Van Aanholt netted Vitesse's fifth goal in a 6–2 away defeat of [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]], keeping Vitesse at the top of the Eredivisie table.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25287088 |title=Vitesse Arnhem hammered PSV Eindhoven to keep their place at the top of the Dutch table. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2013 |accessdate=9 December 2013 }}</ref>

===Sunderland===
On 25 July 2014 Van Aanholt left Chelsea and signed for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] for an undisclosed fee, believed to be £1.5 million, on a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland sign Patrick van Aanholt from Chelsea|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9394844/transfer-news-sunderland-sign-patrick-van-aanholt-from-chelsea|publisher=Sky Sports|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut  on 16 August as Sunderland began their [[Premier League]] campaign away to [[West Bromwich Albion]], assisting [[Sebastian Larsson]] for the final goal of a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strickland|first1=Jamie|title=West Brom 2–2 Sunderland|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28718388|accessdate=25 August 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=16 August 2014}}</ref> On 3 November, as Sunderland won 3–1 at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], Van Aanholt set up the opening goal for [[Steven Fletcher (footballer)|Steven Fletcher]] but was stretchered off in the first half with a shoulder injury and replaced by [[Wes Brown]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Patrick van Aanholt: Sunderland defender injures shoulder|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29890554|accessdate=3 November 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=3 November 2014}}</ref> Van Aanholt scored his first goal for Sunderland on his return from injury on 4 January 2015, the only goal in an [[FA Cup]] third round win over [[Leeds United]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Adam|title=Sunderland 1-0 Leeds|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30614387|accessdate=4 January 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=4 January 2015}}</ref>

==International career==
On 19 November 2013, Van Aanholt won his first senior cap for the Netherlands in a friendly against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], coming on in injury time for [[Memphis Depay]] in a 0–0 draw at the [[Amsterdam ArenA|Amsterdam Arena]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/friendlies/season=2014/matches/round=2000374/match=2013101/postmatch/report/ |title=Netherlands cling on against Colombia |publisher=UEFA |date=19 November 2013 |accessdate=9 December 2013 }}</ref>

'''Rolando Aarons''' (born 16 November 1995) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] as a [[Midfield (association football)|midfielder]].

Born in Jamaica, Aarons was called up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England national U-20 team]] in August 2014 and has indicated his intention to play in the England set-up.

== Club career ==

=== Newcastle United ===
Aarons joined Newcastle United in 2012 after being released by his home town club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cameron|first1=Neil|title=Newcastle United star Rolando Aarons' fightback after being dumped Bristol City shows real character|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-united-star-rolando-aarons-7738632|accessdate=10 September 2014|newspaper=[[Evening Chronicle]]|date=9 September 2014}}</ref> He made his reserve team debut on 8 February 2013 against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and scored in his second reserve game against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] 17 days later.<ref name="NewcastleProfile"/><ref name="Reserve Team debut">{{cite news|title=Reserves Fixtures 2012/13|url=http://www.nufc.com/html/2012-13html/reserves-prem.html|publisher=Newcastle United FC|date=15 July 2013|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref>

Aarons travelled with the Newcastle squad to their game against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. He was not included in the matchday squad as the Magpies lost 1–0. Reserves teammate [[Ľubomír Šatka]] also travelled with the squad for the first time.

On 1 April 2014, Aarons signed a professional contract with Newcastle United.<ref name="Aarons Pens Professional Deal">{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140401/aarons-pens-professional-deal_2281670_3743603 | title=Aarons Pens Professional Deal | publisher=Newcastle United | date=1 April 2014 | accessdate=1 April 2014}}</ref>

====2014–15 season====
Aarons had an impressive pre-season prior to the [[2014–15 Newcastle United F.C. season|2014–15 season]], scoring one goal and creating one assist in the [[2014 Schalke 04 Cup]] against [[Bundesliga]] team [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke]]. Shortly after, he was allocated the number 16 shirt.<ref name="Squad Numbers Announced">{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140807/squad-numbers-announced_2281670_4058068 | title=Squad Numbers Announced | publisher=Newcastle United | date=7 August 2014 | accessdate=7 August 2014}}</ref> On 17 August 2014, he made his [[Premier League]] debut in their first match of the campaign, replacing [[Yoan Gouffran]] for the final 16 minutes of a 2–0 home defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=Newcastle 0–2 Man City|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730044|accessdate=17 August 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 August 2014}}</ref> He scored his first senior goal in the 3–3 draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 30 August. He also set up teammate [[Mike Williamson (footballer)|Mike Williamson]] for Newcastle's third goal in the same match, striking the post with his own effort. His contribution to the match described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as "thrillingly incisive".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Louise|title=Crystal Palace’s Wilfried Zaha scores last-gasp equaliser at Newcastle|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/30/newcastle-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 August 2014}}</ref> Aarons came back from [[England national under-20 football team|England U-20]] duty with a hamstring injury; scans in mid-September determined that it would take around six weeks for the injury to heal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ryder|first1=Lee|title=Injury woes for Newcastle United as Rolando Aarons could be out for longer than feared|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/injury-woes-newcastle-united-rolando-7778368|accessdate=18 September 2014|newspaper=[[Evening Chronicle]]|date=16 September 2014}}</ref> On 29 October, Aarons returned from injury to score his second goal for the club in the fourth round of the [[2014-15 Football League Cup|League Cup]], opening the scoring in Newcastle's 2–0 away victory over holders [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29718452 |title=Holders Manchester City were knocked out of the League Cup as a youthful Newcastle side earned the club's first win in 12 attempts at Etihad Stadium. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2014 }}</ref> In early November, Aarons suffered a recurrence of his hamstring injury, ruling him out for another month.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Starforth|first1=Miles|title=Rolando Aarons blow for Newcastle|url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/newcastle-united/rolando-aarons-blow-for-newcastle-1-6946258|accessdate=11 November 2014|work=[[Shields Gazette]]|date=11 November 2014}}</ref>

== International career ==
Aarons is eligible to represent either [[England national football team|England]] or [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] at international level.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Douglas|first1=Mark|title=Newcastle United youngster Roland Aarons wanted by Championship clubs – and Jamaica|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-united-youngster-roland-aarons-7585326|newspaper=[[The Journal (newspaper)|The Journal]]|accessdate=28 August 2014|date=9 August 2014}}</ref> In August 2014, he received his first call-up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England U-20 team]], marking his debut with the opening goal in a 6–0 friendly match win over [[Romania national under-20 football team|Romania]] on 5 September.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aidy Boothroyd names U20 squad to face Romania|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/aug/boothroyd-names-his-first-u20-squad|publisher=[[The FA]]|accessdate=28 August 2014|date=28 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Reid|first1=Jamie|title=Boothroyd's boys hit Romania for six in Telford|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/sep/england-v-romania-u20-match-report-050914|publisher=[[The FA]]|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=5 September 2014}}</ref> His club manager [[Alan Pardew]] confirmed that, despite interest from Jamaica, Aarons intended to pursue an international future within the England set-up.<ref>{{cite news|last=Starforth|first=Miles|title=Rolando Aarons will target England future, says Newcastle United boss Alan Pardew|url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/newcastle-united/rolando-aarons-will-target-england-future-says-newcastle-united-boss-alan-pardew-1-6811613|newspaper=[[Shields Gazette]]|date=29 August 2014|accessdate=30 August 2014}}</ref>

== Style of play ==
Aarons operates on the outside of midfield or as a winger, usually on the left side.  He is left-footed and known for his injections of pace and technical ability.<ref name=sterling>{{cite news|title=Rolando Aarons seeks a reward for his sterling effort at Newcastle|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/529614/Rolando-Aarons-seeks-a-reward-for-his-sterling-effort-at-Newcastle|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|accessdate=5 November 2014|date=31 October 2014}}</ref> He has been compared to [[Liverpool F.C|Liverpool]] winger [[Raheem Sterling]] in his playing style and in his descent; both are Jamaican-born and are playing for English clubs.<ref name=sterling/>

==Personal life==
Aarons was born in Kingston, Jamaica. He  migrated to England at the age of 5 to join his mother who was already living in the city of Bristol.<ref>http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-uniteds-brightest-best-freddie-8793133</ref>

'''Nabil Abidallah''' (born 5 August 1982 in [[Amsterdam]]) is a former [[Netherlands|Dutch]] professional [[association football|footballer]] of [[Morocco|Moroccan]] origin.

==Club career==
His career started at [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] in 1999, from where he moved to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], where he only played twice in the league both of which coming on as a substitute against [[Everton FC|Everton]] and [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]], in 2000. He stayed with Town for four years making a total of six appearances, before being given a free transfer to [[Northampton Town]]. He also played for [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]] and [[Clacton Town F.C.|Clacton Town]], before returning to the Netherlands to play for amateur side [[Amsterdamsche FC|AFC]] in 2005. From 2006 on he played at [[V.V. Aalsmeer|Aalsmeer]].

In 2008 he joined Swedish side [[Fässbergs IF|Fässbergs]] before joining Italian [[S.E.F. Torres 1903|Torres]] in 2009.

===Burglary arrest===
In May 2006 Abidallah was arrested for burglary, after breaking into his former house which he had to leave after failing to pay his rent.<ref>[http://www.ipswichstar.co.uk/news/ex_football_star_turns_burglar_1_108402 Ex-football star turns burglar] - Ipswich Star</ref>

'''Gareth Ian "Gary" Ablett''' (19 November 1965 – 1 January 2012) was an English professional [[association football|footballer]] and manager. He played as a [[defender (association football)|defender]] from 1985 until 2001. He spent nine years with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and went on to win the [[FA Cup]] with their city rivals [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in 1995. He also played for [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and [[Long Island Rough Riders]].

He moved into coaching and managed [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves]], and later spent a year as manager of [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]]. 

Ablett died on 1 January 2012, following a 16-month battle with [[non-Hodgkin's lymphoma]], at his home in [[Tarleton]], Lancashire. He was 46 years old.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/liverpool-v-everton-gary-ablett-789059 |title="He’ll be looking down on us all": Widow's emotional tribute to Gary Ablett on eve of FA Cup semi-final|date=13 April 2012|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref>

==Playing career==

===Liverpool===
[[Liverpool]]-born Ablett joined Liverpool F.C. as an apprentice upon leaving [[St Margaret's C of E High School (Liverpool)|St Margaret's Church of England High School]] in 1982.
He finally made his Liverpool debut on 20 December 1986 in a goalless league away draw with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], when regular defenders [[Barry Venison]] and [[Mark Lawrenson]] were absent due to injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1560|title=Charlton Athletic 0 – 0 Liverpool|date=|work=LFC History|accessdate=8 July 2009}}</ref> He made five more appearances that season, scoring what would be his only goal for the club on 18 April 1987 in a 3–0 home league victory over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_Id=1584|title=Liverpool 3 – 0 Nottingham Forest|date=|work=LFC History|accessdate=8 July 2009}}</ref>
Alongside experienced players in defence, such as [[Gary Gillespie]], [[Steve Nicol]] and skipper [[Alan Hansen]], Ablett helped Liverpool win the [[FA Premier League|League championship]] and reach the [[1988 FA Cup Final]]. Ablett only collected a runners-up medal in the latter competition due to Liverpool's 1–0 defeat by [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1639|title=Liverpool 0 – 1 Wimbledon|date=|work=LFC History|accessdate=8 July 2009}}</ref>

In [[1988-89 in English football|1988–89]], Liverpool made it to their second consecutive FA Cup final. This time they were successful, after a 3–2 victory over [[Merseyside]] rivals Everton. They lost the League title, however, to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] with practically the [[Liverpool 0–2 Arsenal (26 May 1989)|last kick of the season]]. Ablett was now firmly established as the club's regular left back, missing just three league games that season.

Ablett flitted in and out of the squad over the next year, relegated in the pecking order following the arrival of [[Glenn Hysen]] and the progress of [[Steve Staunton]] and [[David Burrows (footballer)|David Burrows]]. He was used more frequently as a central defender rather than left full-back after Hansen began suffering more with injuries. Eventually, he took the central role more often following the arrival of left back [[David Burrows (footballer)|David Burrows]] from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and won the League again with Liverpool in 1990.

===Everton===
Kenny Dalglish resigned as Liverpool manager on 22 February 1991, and his successor, [[Graeme Souness]], decided to sell Ablett for [[Pound (currency)|£]]750,000 to Everton in January 1992, after 147 appearances for the Reds. Ironically, his departure came at a time when he was getting more first team opportunities than he had done since the 1988–89 season.

He made his league debut for ''the Toffees'' on 19 January 1992 in a 1–1 draw with [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] at [[Goodison Park]].

Ablett won the FA Cup with Everton in 1995, becoming the only player to win the competition with both Merseyside teams. However, he lost his first team place to [[Andy Hinchcliffe]] in the [[1995-96 in English football|1995–96 season]].

===Later career===
Ablett went on to make 128 league appearances and score five goals for Everton, and later went on to have a brief loan spell with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] before making a permanent move to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] for £390,000, joining them at the same time as established Premiership players [[Steve Bruce]] and [[Mike Newell (footballer)|Mike Newell]], as new manager [[Trevor Francis]] set about building a side capable of challenging for a place in the Premier League. 

In three years with the Blues, he scored twice, with goals against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] in the league<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.swindon-town-fc.co.uk/MatchCentre.asp?MatchID=19970134|title=Swindon Town 3 – 1 Birmingham City|publisher=Swindon Town FC.co.uk|date=26 February 1997|accessdate=22 December 2010}}</ref> and Leeds United in the FA Cup.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-fa-cup--history-and-hasselbaink-favour-graham-once-again-1145087.html|title= FA Cup – History and Hasselbaink favour Graham once again|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=16 February 1998|accessdate=22 December 2010}}</ref>

He was released by Birmingham City manager [[Trevor Francis]] in 1999, and after short spells with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] (playing under former Anfield team-mate [[Steve McMahon (footballer)|Steve McMahon]], scoring once against Luton Town)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://skysports.stats.football365.com/cgi-bin/results.pl?lang=english&year=2000&month=01&date=15|title=Fixtures & Results – Saturday, 15 January 2000|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=15 January 2000|accessdate=22 December 2010}}</ref> and [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], he signed for [[A-League (American)|American A-League]] side [[Long Island Rough Riders]] in June 2000. In February 2002, at the age of 36, Ablett was taken on trial by [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]].

In 2006, Ablett appeared as a substitute in Replay 86, a charity match staged in aid of The Marina Dalglish Appeal, which pitted the Liverpool and Everton sides that had contested the [[1986 FA Cup Final]] against each other one more. Ablett's inclusion was curious, because although on Liverpool's books at the time of the Final, he did not actually make his debut for the club until the December of that year. Regardless, his contribution ensured Liverpool won the game 1–0.

==Coaching and managerial career==
In the summer of 2002, Ablett moved into coaching, taking up a post as the coach of Everton's under-17 side. He worked as part of the club's youth academy for several years until the summer of 2006, when he returned to his first club, taking the vacant job of [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves]] team coach, replacing [[Paco Herrera]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Watch now: Ablett's first interview|work=liverpoolfc.com|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/watch-now-ablett-s-first-lfc-interview|accessdate=28 September 2014 }}</ref> The same career opportunities were not available at Everton with [[Andy Holden]] firmly established as reserve-team manager.

In April 2008, under Ablett's guidance, Liverpool's reserves were crowned champions of the Premier Reserve League North, and the following month they became national champions after a play-off final victory against Aston Villa's reserves. In July 2008 he completed his final [[UEFA]] coaching qualification by obtaining the [[UEFA Pro License]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ablett gains final UEFA licence|work=liverpoolfc.tv|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/ablett-gains-final-uefa-licence|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>

Ablett's son, Fraser (born 1991), signed for [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]] and has since played for [[Colwyn Bay F.C.|Colwyn Bay]] since the demise of Chester City. He currently plays for [[Widnes Vikings F.C.|Widnes Vikings FC]] in the North West Counties Football League Division 1. 

On 28 May 2009, Liverpool announced that Ablett would be leaving his position as reserve team manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/8072343.stm|title= Liverpool and Ablett part company|date=28 May 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 May 2009}}</ref> On 8 July 2009 Ablett was announced as the new [[Stockport County]] manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/stockport/8140162.stm|title=Stockport confirm Ablett as boss|date=8 July 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 July 2009}}</ref> The club was in administration for the whole of the 2009–10 season, during which his team managed only five league wins. The club also went on a record consecutive losing run of games. He left the club on 17 June 2010 when the 2015 Group took ownership of the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1287334/Jim-Gannon-tipped-Stockport-return-Gary-Ablett-quits-managers-post-Edgeley-Park.html|title=Jim Gannon tipped for Stockport return as Gary Ablett quits manager's post at Edgeley Park|publisher=''Daily Mail''|date=17 June 2010|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>

==Illness and death==
Ablett agreed to a one-year contract with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in July 2010 to join their coaching staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10272~2100813,00.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120313123019/http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10272~2100813,00.html|archivedate=13 March 2012|title=Assistant Not A Priority|publisher=Ipswich F.C.|date=26 July 2010|accessdate=2 August 2010}}</ref> After being taken ill on the training ground, he was diagnosed as suffering from [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma]], a form of [[blood cancer]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1299653/Ex-Liverpool-Everton-defender-Gary-Ablett-diagnosed-cancer.html|title=Ex-Liverpool and Everton defender Gary Ablett is diagnosed with cancer|first=Mel|last=Henderson|work=Mail Online|date=2 August 2010|accessdate=2 August 2010}}</ref>

On 1 January 2012, Ablett died at age 46 after battling the cancer for 16 months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16383027.stm|title=Former Liverpool & Everton defender Gary Ablett dies|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=2 January 2012|accessdate=2 January 2012}}</ref> His funeral was held at [[Liverpool Anglican Cathedral]] on 17 January 2012 and was attended by former teammates, as well as members of the teams and the then managers of Everton and Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2012/jan/17/gary-ablett-funeral?INTCMP=SRCH | title=Merseyside unites to mourn Gary Ablett | work=The Guardian | date=17 January 2012 | accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref>

'''Samassi Abou''' (born 4 April 1973 in [[Gagnoa]]) is a former professional [[Football (soccer)|footballer]] from [[Côte d'Ivoire]], who played as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]]. He played internationally for the [[France national under-21 football team|French under-21 team]].

Abou started playing in [[France]] for [[FC Martigues]], before moving to [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]]. In October 1997, after a spell at [[AS Cannes]], he made the move to [[England|English]] football, signing for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for £250,000. Signed by manager, [[Harry Redknapp]], to give more options for [[striker]]s, Abou made his West Ham debut on 9 November 1997 in a 2-1 away defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] coming on as a substitute for [[John Moncur]].<ref name="Roopanarine2011">{{cite book|author=Les Roopanarine|title=Harry Redknapp&nbsp;— The Biography|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=E0WUkWwx38AC&pg=PT88|date=7 November 2011|publisher=John Blake Publishing, Limited|isbn=978-1-84358-942-6|pages=88–}}</ref><ref name="whustats">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=1&united=Samassi_Abou | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Samassi Abou | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> His opening West Ham goal came on 6 January 1998 in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]]. In a 5th round game at the [[Boleyn Ground]] Abou came on as a substitute for [[Paul Kitson]] to score their only goal in a 2-1 defeat.<ref name=whustats/> In the following game, on 10 January 1998, Abou scored twice as West Ham beat [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], 6-0.<ref name="10January">{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20150110/on-this-day-10-january_2236884_3612367 | title=On this day 10 January | publisher=www.whufc.com | accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> Abou received his only [[red card (football)|red card]] in the next game, a 1-0 away defeat to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]. Fouling [[Ramon Vega]] in an off-the-ball incident, Abou was dismissed by referee, [[David Elleray]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/48300.stm | title=Klinsmann sinks 10-man Hammers | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> Abou finished the [[1997-98 West Ham United F.C. season|1997-98 season]] with 6 goals from 26 games including two on the last day of the season in a 4-3 home defeat of [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref name=whustats/><ref name="10May">{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140510/on-this-day-10-may_2236884_3813293 | title=On this day - 10 May | publisher=www.whufc.com | accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> [[West Ham United F.C. supporters|West Ham fans]] would [[booing|boo]] Abou whenever he scored making an "Abooooooooo" noise.<ref name="May2012">{{cite book|author=Pete May|title=West Ham: Irons in the Soul|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=t3OnApJadC8C&pg=PT177|date=23 March 2012|publisher=Mainstream Publishing|isbn=978-1-78057-451-6|pages=177–}}</ref> In 31 appearances in all competitions he scored six times, before being released to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in December 1998, where he scored once against Sheffield United.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-naylor-provides-suffolk-punch-1193771.html
|title=Naylor provides Suffolk punch
|publisher=[[The Independent]]
|date=20 December 1998 |accessdate=27 February 2010}}</ref>

In October 1999, he signed for [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], an unsuccessful spell which lasted little over a month. He also spent time on loan at [[Troyes AC|Troyes]], and played in [[Scotland]] for three months at [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]].

Abou continued his career back in France, playing for [[AC Ajaccio|Ajaccio]] and [[FC Lorient|Lorient]].

'''Milenko Aćimović''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Миленко Аћимовић}}; born 15 February 1977 in [[Ljubljana]]) is a former [[Slovenia]]n [[association football|footballer]] who last played for Austria giants [[FK Austria Wien|Austria Wien]]. He was a playmaker who has a great passing range and an abundance of skill. On 15 September 2010, Ačimovič ended his football career following a persistent right knee injury.

==Club career==
Born in Ljubljana, in present day Slovenia to Serbian parents, young Milenko started his career in the youth ranks of [[NK Olimpija Ljubljana (1911–2004)|Olimpija Ljubljana]]. As an extremely gifted youngster, he made three first-team appearances for [[NK Ljubljana|Zeleznicar]] when he was just 17 years old. From 1996 until 1998 he found himself again playing for Olimpija, scoring 7 goals in 34 matches. He then joined [[Red Star Belgrade]].

Milenko played in [[Belgrade]] for four and a half years. He developed into quite a dependable midfielder. After successful appearances for [[Slovenia]]n national team in [[Euro 2000]] and [[2002 FIFA World Cup|World Cup 2002]], many bigger European clubs expressed interest in him. In the summer of 2002, he joined [[Tottenham Hotspur]]. In his first season in [[London]], he made a few appearances, but never established himself as a first team player. In his second season, he became a fringe player.

In January 2004 he joined the French club [[Lille OSC|Lille]] on loan until the end of the season. When he arrived, the club was in 14th place in the Ligue 1, but after some good form and fine performances by Acimovic they finished the season as runners up and therefore qualified for the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. In the first year they also played in the [[UEFA Cup]] and were eliminated in the last 16. They played in the third qualifying round of the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]], and reached the group stages. Mile was Lille's creative spark and scored against [[Manchester United]] when Lille won the game in Paris 1–0. That was Lille's only goal of the campaign.

After playing for Lille in [[France]] for 2½ seasons he fell out of favor and surprisingly joined [[Ittihad FC|Al-Ittihad]] for the 2006–07 season. After failing to adapt to life in Saudi Arabia, he agreed on a mutual termination of the contract, subsequently moving back to Europe to join [[FK Austria Wien|Austria Wien]]. On 15 September 2010, [[Austria Vienna]] midfielder Milenko Acimovic ended his football career following a persistent right knee injury.

Ačimović returned to [[Slovenia]] and has been appointed the Director of football at [[NK Olimpija Ljubljana (2005)|Olimpija Ljubljana]], in January 2011, where he has stayed until September 2012 when he resigned his position, due to poor results of the team in the [[Slovenian PrvaLiga]].

==International career==
He debuted for the [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia national team]] on 22 April 1998 in [[Murska Sobota]] against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]]. He gave many notable performances for the national team, including a spectacular goal scored from the middle of the field against Ukraine in the Euro 2000 play-off. He represented Slovenia at both [[UEFA Euro 2000|Euro 2000]] and [[2002 FIFA World Cup|World Cup 2002]], scoring in their 1–3 defeat to [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] in [[Seogwipo]]. His final appearance for the national side came on 28 March 2007 in [[Celje]], during a 1–0 home defeat to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] in a [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying#Group G|Euro 2008 qualification]] match. He announced his retirement from international football that August.<ref>{{cite news | title=Ačimovič bids Slovenia adieu | url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/news/newsid=573109.html | work=UEFA.com | publisher=Union of European Football Associations | date=20 August 2007 | accessdate=12 July 2012 }}</ref>

'''Clárence Williams Acuña Donoso''' (born February 8, 1975 in [[Rancagua]]) is a [[Chile]]an former professional [[football (soccer)|football]] player. He played as a midfielder. 

== Chilean League ==
He started his career at [[Chile]]an club [[C.D. O'Higgins|O'Higgins]], whom he began playing for in 1994 at the age of nineteen. He played at O'Higgins until 1996, scoring eight goals in eighty-one games. 

He then caught the eye of professional club [[C.F. Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]]. They signed him, and he played ninety games for them between 1997 and 1999, again scoring eight goals. His performances in the ''Copa Banco Estado'' attracted the attention of the [[Chile national football team|national team]] and he was given his first international cap in 1995.

== International ==
Acuña managed to keep up his good form and was included in the [[Chile national football team|Chile]] [[1998 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] squad for the 1998 event held in [[France]]. Here, he impressed players and pundits alike and helped his country to the last 16 stage of the tournament, where they bowed out in a 4-1 defeat to favourites [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]]. 

Despite this, Acuña was seen as one of the breakthrough players of the tournament and he also had his first experience of playing in [[Europe]], which would prove not to be his last.

A year later he was involved in another international tournament. This time his services were required in the [[Copa América 1999|Copa América]]. He started four games as Chile reached the semi-finals but were knocked out 5-3 on penalties against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] after a 1-1 draw. They also lost the third place playoff 2-1 against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] four days later.

== Newcastle United ==

After impressive domestic and international performances, Acuña was attracting attention from many big clubs, although he eventually signed for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], after manager [[Bobby Robson]] beat off competition from [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Parma F.C.|Parma]] to clinch Acuña's signature, earning him a £900,000 move to Newcastle United in October 2000, after receiving a work permit. 

He made his debut for Newcastle on Saturday 28 October 2000 in a 1-0 away defeat to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. Two months later he scored his first goal for the club and the winner in the 2-1 victory against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]]. The goal was later voted "Goal of the Week" by the [[BBC]]. He was at Newcastle for four seasons, playing forty-six league games (including eleven as substitute), scoring six times.

'''Charles Graham''' "'''Charlie'''" '''Adam''' (born 10 December 1985) is a Scottish [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]].

Adam was part of the [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] youth set up between 1999 and 2003<ref name=youth>{{cite web|url=http://www.youthfootballscotland.co.uk/news-a-media/my-youth-career/1304-charlie-adam|title=Charlie Adam|accessdate=22 February 2011|publisher=Youth Football Scotland}}</ref> before signing a youth contract with [[Alex McLeish]]'s [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] when he turned 17<ref name=youth/> and spent much of his early senior career on loan to other clubs. While on loan to [[St. Mirren F.C.|St. Mirren]] during season 2005–06, Adam was part of the team that won both the [[Scottish Challenge Cup]] and [[Scottish Football League First Division|First Division]], playing in over thirty matches for the "Saints". Upon returning to Rangers at the end of the 2006 season, he became a regular under managers [[Paul Le Guen]] and [[Walter Smith]]. Adam was also part of the Rangers team that reached the [[2008 UEFA Cup Final]].

After falling out of favour at Rangers during season 2008–09, Adam was loaned out to English [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]. The loan was made permanent at the start of the 2009–10 season, and Adam became an integral part of the Blackpool side, captaining the team to a [[2009–10 in English football|play off victory]] over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] which resulted in their promotion to the [[Premier League]]. Adam shone in his first season in the English Premier League, his performances being recognised with a nomination for the [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]] in April 2011. However, Blackpool were relegated and consequently he transferred to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in July 2011. After one season at [[Anfield]] Adam joined [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in August 2012 for a fee of £4 million.

He has played at [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]], [[Scotland B national football team|B]] and [[Scotland national football team|full international]] levels for Scotland.

==Background==
Adam is the son of former professional player [[Charlie Adam (footballer born 1962)|Charles Adam]], a midfielder who played for various Scottish clubs in the 1980s and 1990s, he died on 17 December 2012 aged 50.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1349488/Charlie-Adam-The-Scottish-starlet-career-hit-skids--Mr-Blackpool.html "Charlie Adam: The Scottish starlet whose career hit the skids... is now Mr Blackpool"]</ref> Adam's brother, [[Grant Adam|Grant]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.deadlinenews.co.uk/2009/08/11/8311-1582/ |title=Ex-Ger Adam mourns for death crash cousin |last=Macloud|first=Michael|date=11 August 2009|work=Deadline News |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland }}</ref> is a goalkeeper who played for [[St. Mirren F.C.|St. Mirren]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/grant-adam-i-want-to-be-st-mirren-1204036 | title=Glove rivals: St Mirren new boy Grant Adam targets No.1 spot | publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | work=dailyrecord.co.uk | date=2 August 2012 | accessdate=10 August 2012}}</ref> He attended Dundee's [[Braeview Academy]], alongside fellow future footballers [[Garry Kenneth]] and [[Scott Robertson (footballer born 1985)|Scott Robertson]].<ref name="independent2011">[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/charlie-adam-the-boy-who-got-booed-now-makes-blackpool-rock-2268970.html "Charlie Adam: The boy who got booed now makes Blackpool rock"] – ''[[The Independent]]'', 17 April 2011</ref>

==Club career==

===Rangers===
[[Dundee]]-born Adam joined [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] when he turned 17.<ref name=youth/> He made his debut appearance on 14 April 2004 against [[Livingston F.C.|Livingston]]<ref name="Livingston 1-1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/3623001.stm|publisher=BBC Sport  |title=Livingston 1–1 Rangers|date=14 April 2004}}</ref> and played sporadically thereafter but did not become a first-team regular until the management of [[Paul Le Guen]].

He made an appearance at the start of the [[2004–05 Rangers F.C. season|2004–05 season]],<ref name = rangersweb>{{cite web |url=http://www.rangers.co.uk/articles/charlie-adam-blackpool_2254699_30063 |title=Adam First Team Profile |publisher=Rangers.co.uk |accessdate=13 January 2010}}</ref> and then joined [[2004–05 Scottish First Division|First Division]] club [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]] on loan for the rest of that campaign.<ref name = rangersweb /> While in [[Dingwall]], Adam made fifteen appearances, scoring twice, against [[Raith Rovers F.C.|Raith Rovers]] and [[St. Mirren F.C.|St. Mirren]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players_details.sd |title=Career stats |publisher=Soccerbase | accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref> He also played in the [[2004 Scottish Challenge Cup Final]] against [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]].  County were ahead courtesy of [[David Winters (footballer)|David Winters]] 56th minute goal. Adam was substituted in the 60th minute as was team mate [[Sean Higgins (footballer)|Sean Higgins]] six minutes later. [[Neil Scally]] and [[Darryl Duffy]] then scored in 70 and 75 minutes respectively for Falkirk to come back to lift the trophy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_div_1/3984441.stm |title=Falkirk 2–1 Ross County |publisher=BBC Sport    | date=7 November 2004 | accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref>

Adam then joined First Division side St. Mirren on loan for the 2005–06 season.<ref name = rangersweb /> During his spell in [[Paisley]], he again appeared in the [[2005 Scottish Challenge Cup Final]], however this time he was on the winning side as St. Mirren defeated [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] 2–1.<ref name="St Mirren 2-1 Hamilton Accies">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_cups/4403942.stm|publisher=BBC Sport |title=St Mirren 2–1 Hamilton Accies|date=6 November 2005}}</ref> He was also part of the team that won the First Division title in May 2006.<ref name = rangersweb /> In total he made thirty-seven appearances and scored nine goals for the "Buddies" during a very successful stint in Paisley.

After playing for Rangers during a July 2006 pre-season trip to South Africa, including scoring a hat-trick against a Jomo Select side,<ref name="bbc5170940">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5170940.stm|title=Adam and N'Diaye impress Le Guen|date=11 July 2006 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 February 2009}}</ref> Adam began the [[2006–07 in Scottish football|2006–07 season]] with the club, and he started in their first [[Scottish Premier League|league]] match against [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/scottish/motherwell-1-rangers-2-le-guens-french-revolution-off-to-winning-start-409991.html |title=Motherwell 1 Rangers 2: Le Guen's French revolution off to winning start |last=Harris|first=Nick|date=31 July 2006|work=The Independent |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland, UK }}</ref> He continued to be a regular for Rangers as the season progressed, and scored his first goal for the club in a 3–2 [[UEFA Cup 2006–07|UEFA Cup]] win over [[A.S. Livorno Calcio|Livorno]] on 19 October.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/6050936.stm |title=Livorno 2–3 Rangers |last=Mcguigan|first=Thomas|date=19 October 2006|work=The BBC |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland }}</ref> This was one of fourteen goals Adam scored that season, including strikes against [[Israel]]i sides [[Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.|Hapoel Tel Aviv]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/rangers-4-hapoel-tel-aviv-0-irangers-win-52-on-aggi-ferguson-conducts-rangers-final-quest-437472.html |title=Rangers 4 Hapoel Tel Aviv 0|last=Harris|first=Nick|date=23 February 2007|work=The Independent |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland, UK }}</ref> and [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/6106436.stm |title=Rangers 2–0 Maccabi Haifa |last=Linday|first=Clive|date=2 November 2006|work=The BBC |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland }}</ref> as well as a goal in an end-of-season [[Old Firm]] match from a free-kick.<ref name="Rangers 2-0 Celtic ">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/scot_prem/6621893.stm|title=Rangers 2–0 Celtic |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2007|first=Thomas|last=McGuigan}}</ref> On 16 April 2007, at the end of his first season in the first team, Adam was voted by Rangers fans as the club's Young [[Player of the year award|Player of the Year]] at an award ceremony.<ref name="Player of the Year">{{cite news|last=Dodds|first=Emma|url=http://www.rangers.co.uk/articles/20070417/hemdani-named-player-of-the-year_2254024_1011888|title=Hemdani Named Player Of The Year|publisher=Rangers.co.uk|date=25 January 2011}}</ref>

On 28 June 2007, it was announced that Adam had signed a new five-year contract with Rangers.<ref name="Deal Me In">{{cite news|last=Dodds|first=Emma| url=http://www.rangers.co.uk/articles/20070628/deal-me-in_2254024_1063494|title=Deal Me In|publisher=Rangers.co.uk|date=28 June 2007|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>  Adam had scored his first [[UEFA Champions League]] goal on 19 September against [[VfB Stuttgart]], and his second in the return fixture.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7110696.stm |title=VfB Stuttgart 3–2 Rangers |last=Mcguigan|first=Thomas|date=27 November 2007|work=The BBC |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland }}</ref> Adam played against [[Panathinaikos]] and [[Werder Bremen]] in Rangers run to the [[2008 UEFA Cup Final]] where he was an unused substitute as Rangers lost 2–0 to [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rangers 0–2 Zenit|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7393752.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref>

===Blackpool===
[[File:Charlie adam - 2.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Charlie Adam playing for Blackpool in the [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final]]]]
On 2 February 2009, Adam signed on loan with English [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] until the end of the [[Blackpool F.C. season 2008–09|2008–09 season]].<ref name = rangersweb /> Five days later, he was sent off on his debut for the Seasiders during a 3–2 defeat by [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] at [[Bloomfield Road]].<ref name="skysports3004698">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_facts/0,19762,11065_3004698,00.html |title=Blackpool 2–3 Doncaster|date=7 February 2009|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=7 February 2009}}</ref>

On 25 February, after serving a three-match suspension, Adam scored twice, including a goal from just inside the halfway line, for the club's reserve team as they beat [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] 4–2.<ref name="BFC">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/ReservesMatchReports/0,,10432~1570017,00.html |title=Reserves Record Comfortable Victory|date=25 February 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=26 February 2009}}</ref><ref name="">{{cite video | people =  | title = Blackpool vs Accrington | medium = Video | publisher=[[Blackpool Gazette]] | url = http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/video.aspx?VideoPath=BLAC/poolvaccy_goals512k_stream.wmv&VideoID=32425&ArticleID=5018528 |year=2009}}</ref> Adam scored his first [[Football League]] goal for [[Tony Parkes]]'s men in a 2–0 victory over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] at Bloomfield Road on 7 March.<ref name="bfc44826">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10432~44826,00.html |title=Blackpool vs Norwich City Match Report|date=7 March 2009 |publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=8 March 2009}}</ref> Two days later he was named in the Football League's "Championship Team of the Week".<ref name="FLC144163">{{cite news | title = Team Of The Week (09/03/2009)| publisher=[[The Football League]] | date=9 March 2009 | url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/staticFiles/23/33/0,,10794~144163,00.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate=9 March 2009}}</ref> His second goal for Blackpool came on 11 April in their 1–0 [[West Lancashire derby]] win over [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at [[Deepdale]]. Blackpool's then-[[caretaker manager]] [[Tony Parkes]] publicly admitted he was keen to sign Adam permanently. He said, "I have spoken to our club secretary and we will be in touch with Rangers to see if we can do a deal for Charlie".<ref name="Parkes wants Adam permanently">{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11788_5263228,00.html |title=Seasiders keen on Adam deal|date=1 May 2009|publisher=[[Sky Sports News]]}}</ref> At the end of the season, after two goals in 13 appearances, he returned to Rangers.

On 6 July 2009, Rangers confirmed that they had accepted a bid of £500,000 from Blackpool and that he was set to sign for ''the Seasiders'' the following day, subject to personal terms being agreed.<ref name="rfc1715176">{{cite news|last=Herron|first=Lindsay|url=http://www.rangers.co.uk/articles/20090706/adam-heading-back-south_2254024_1715176|title=Adam Heading Back South|date=6 July 2009|publisher=Rangers.co.uk|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> The following day, Blackpool manager [[Ian Holloway]] confirmed a deal had been agreed with the [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]] club, but stressed that talks with Adam would take place on 9 July, once Adam had spoken with Rangers manager [[Walter Smith]].<ref name="bfc1716246">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1716246,00.html|title=Charlie Adam Latest|date=7 July 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> Four weeks later on 2 August, with Adam still a Rangers player and having been on their pre-season trip to Germany, Smith confirmed that the player was in talks with Blackpool, saying, "Adam is talking to Blackpool at the moment. The clubs have agreed a fee and it will be up to Charlie and his representative."<ref name="bbc8121542">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8121542.stm|title=Adam switch to Blackpool back on|date=2 August 2009|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=3 August 2009}}</ref> The following day, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that Adam had signed for Blackpool on a three-year contract with an option for a further 12 months.<ref name="mail1204079">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1204079/Blackpool-boosted-500k-loan-star-Charlie-Adam-quits-Rangers-Championship-return.html?ITO=1490#ixzz0N9M51yv6|title=Blackpool boosted as £500k loan star Charlie Adam quits Rangers for Championship return|last=Edwards|first=John|date=3 August 2009|work=The Daily Mail |location=UK|accessdate=3 August 2009}}</ref>[[File:Charlie Adam.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Adam during Blackpool's [[2010–11 Premier League]] campaign.]]

In August 2009 Adam signed a two-year contract with Blackpool with the option of a further year, in a club-record transfer fee of £500,000.<ref name="bfc1742839">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1742839,00.html|title=Breaking News|date=4 August 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=4 August 2009}}</ref> His competitive debut as a permanent Blackpool player was in a 1–1 draw with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] at [[Loftus Road]] later that month.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8186015.stm |title=QPR 1 – 1 Blackpool |first=|date=17 August 2009|work=The BBC |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland }}</ref> His first goal came on 26 August in a 4–1 home win over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8207943.stm |title=Blackpool 4 – 1 Wigan |first=|date=26 August 2009|work=The BBC |accessdate=13 January 2010 |location=Scotland |archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqkZLt9m |archivedate = 17 January 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref>

In January 2010 he was named in the [[Press Association]]'s [[Football League Championship|Championship]] "Team of the Week", along with team-mate [[Neal Eardley]] following his performance two days before in the 3–2 home victory over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref name="fl1943550">{{cite news|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/championship-team-of-the-week-20100125_2248204_1943550|title=Championship Team of the Week|date=25 January 2010|publisher=[[The Football League]]|accessdate=25 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="fl149357">{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/staticFiles/6d/47/0,,10794~149357,00.pdf|title=Team Of The Week (25/01/2010)|date=25 January 2010|publisher=[[The Football League]]|format=PDF|accessdate=25 January 2010}}</ref> That same month Adam won the Championship Player of the Month award<ref name="bfc1957077">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1957077,00.html|title=Charlie Named Championship Player of the Month|date=6 February 2010|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref> and was voted the [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]] Championship Fans’ Player of the Month for January 2010. In March, Adam scored in his 50th league appearance for Blackpool, a 2–0 win at [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]]. Just under a month later, Adam was named in the [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]] "Championship Team of the Year".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~2035293,00.html|title=Adam Named In PFA Championship XI|first=|date=26 April 2010|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref>

Blackpool qualified for that season's play-offs. Adam scored a match-winning penalty against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the semi-final first leg,<ref name="bbc8644515">{{cite news| title=Blackpool 2–1 Nottingham Forest| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8659640.stm |publisher=BBC Sport  | date=8 May 2010| accessdate=8 May 2010}}</ref> and Blackpool won the tie on aggregate. In the [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]] Adam scored a free-kick as Blackpool beat [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] 3–2 at [[Wembley Stadium]] and gained promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8698021.stm Championship play-off final as it happened] BBC Sport, 22 May 2010</ref>

In the fourth week of the 2010–11 Premier League season, Adam was named in the official Team of the Week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/TeamOfTheWeek/0,,12306~2153542,00.html |title=Official Site of the Premier League , Statistics , EA SPORTS Index , Team of the Week , Week 4 14 September 2010 |publisher=Premierleague.com |accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref> He was named again in week seven, alongside teammate [[Luke Varney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/TeamOfTheWeek/0,,12306~2175276,00.html |title=Official Site of the Premier League , Statistics , EA SPORTS Index , Team of the Week , Week 7 05 October 2010 |publisher=Premierleague.com |accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref> In early December, a tribunal ruled in favour of Adam in a dispute over unpaid bonuses from the previous season. They found that Blackpool were required to pay the player £25,000 for successfully avoiding relegation to League One. The club had argued that the promotion bonus (which had been stipulated in Adam's contract) superseded the 'survival bonus.' The panel upheld Adam's complaint, but did not agree with his second argument that the failure to pay the amount constituted a breach of contract on the club's part. As a result, both parties were responsible for their own legal fees – leaving Adam with a very small net gain from the venture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportingintelligence.com/2010/12/08/adam-emerges-little-richer-from-legal-action-on-principle-against-miserly-blackpool-081205/|title=Adam emerges little richer from legal action ‘on principle’ against miserly Blackpool|first=|date=8 December 2010|publisher=Sporting Intelligence|accessdate=8 December 2010|location=London}}</ref>

In January 2011, Blackpool rejected a £4.5 million bid to buy Adam from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], an amount described by manager Ian Holloway as "disgraceful".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/8276607/Ian-Holloway-attacks-Liverpools-4.5m-bid-for-Blackpool-captain-Charlie-Adam.html|title=Ian Holloway attacks Liverpool’s £4.5m bid for Blackpool captain Charlie Adam|first=|date=22 January 2010|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=23 January 2010|location=London}}</ref> Blackpool then rejected a transfer request that Adam had made to the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6698997,00.html|title=Blackpool reject Adam request|first=|date=24 January 2010|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=24 January 2010}}</ref> He was one of seven nominees for the 2010–11 [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/apr/08/pfa-player-year-award-gareth-bale|title=PFA Player of the Year award nominees include Tottenham's Gareth Bale|date=8 April 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref> However, Adam and his Blackpool team mates were relegated at the season's end. In May 2011, Blackpool activated an option to increase Adam's contract by a further twelve months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/may/25/charlie-adam-blackpool-contract-clause |title=Contract extension|date=25 May 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK|accessdate=25 May 2011}}</ref>

===Liverpool===
[[File:Charlie Adam 2011 Singapore.jpg|thumb|175px|Adam training for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2011]]
In July 2011 [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] signed Adam from Blackpool for a fee of £6.75 million after having their initial bid rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool complete deal for Blackpool's Charlie Adam|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14051735|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013|date=7 July 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/News-Liverpool-signing-Charlie-Adam-ready-to-give-Kenny-Dalglish-a-slection-headache-after-his-move-from-Blackpool-says-Luke-Varney-article763375.html "Adam ready to give Dalglish selection headache"] – ''Daily Mirror'', 9 July 2011</ref> He played the second half of Liverpool's friendly against [[Guangdong Sunray Cave F.C.|Guangdong Sunray Cave]] in a 4–3 win on 13 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/934231/charlie-adam-makes-liverpool-debut-in-friendly-victory?cc=5739|title=Reds hang on for friendly win|date=13 July 2011|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref> On 13 August 2011, Adam made his full debut in Liverpool's first game of the [[2011–12 Premier League]], playing the full 90 minutes in a 1–1 draw against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] at [[Anfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/8695430/Liverpool-1-Sunderland-1-match-report.html|title=Liverpool 1 Sunderland 1|date=13 August 2011|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> There, he assisted the opening goal from [[Luis Suárez]] from a free kick outside the area.

On 27 August 2011, Adam scored his first [[Premier League]] goal for Liverpool in a match against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] which Liverpool went on to win 3–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/318272?cc=5739|title=Rampant Reds beat Bolton|date=27 August 2011|work=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> On 18 September 2011, Adam was shown a second yellow card for a challenge on [[Scott Parker]] in a 4–0 defeat at [[Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/nine-man-reds-sunk-at-spurs|title=Nine-man Reds sunk at Spurs|date=19 September 2011|work=Liverpoolfc.tv|accessdate=23 December 2011}}</ref> Adam helped Liverpool beat local rivals [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 2–0 on 1 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Everton 0–2 Liverpool|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15045708|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013|date=1 October 2011}}</ref> He then scored a penalty in a 2–0 win away at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=West Brom 0–2 Liverpool|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15413663|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013|date=29 October 2011}}</ref> Liverpool reached the [[2012 Football League Cup Final]] where they defeated Championship side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on penalties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Carling Cup final: Charlie Adam backs Liverpool to end trophy drought|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17154942|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cardiff 2–2 Liverpool|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17093419|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> They also made it to the [[2012 FA Cup Final]], which Adam missed due to injury as they lost 2–1 to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool's Charlie Adam to miss FA Cup final with knee injury|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17536067|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref>

===Stoke City===
On 31 August 2012 Adam signed a four-year contract at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] for an undisclosed fee believed to be around £4 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Potters Seal Adam Move|url=http://www.stokecityfc.com/news/article/adam-344057.aspx?pageView=full#anchored|work=Stoke City F.C|accessdate=31 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool's Charlie Adam completes move to Stoke City|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19418465|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 August 2012}}</ref> He made his debut for Stoke the following day in a 2–2 draw against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Wigan 2–2 Stoke|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19377848|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> After leaving Liverpool, Adam stated he left in order to play more games.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Adam says footballing reasons behind Stoke City move|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19463580|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=23 November 2012}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Stoke in a 1–0 victory against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 10 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–0 QPR|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20189968|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref> He scored in another 1–0 win for Stoke two weeks later against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–0 Fulham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20374632|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 November 2012}}</ref> Adam was given compassionate leave after his [[Charlie Adam (footballer born 1962)|father]] died on 17 December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Adam 'deeply shocked' after sudden death of his father|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/stoke-city/9753917/Charlie-Adam-deeply-shocked-after-sudden-death-of-his-father.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=24 December 2012}}</ref> Adam then spent three months in and out of the team before returning to the starting line up in April and scored the winning goal against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] which eased Stoke's relegation worries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–0 Norwich|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22229117|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 April 2013}}</ref> He dedicated his goal to his father.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Adam dedicated winning goal to his dad|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/story-18836676-detail/story.html?#axzz2Rq2exaUA|work=The Sentinel|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> Adam ended the [[2012–13 Stoke City F.C. season|2012–13]] season a poor note, being sent off against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] for two bookable offences.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–2 Tottenham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417723|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref>

Adam scored Stoke's first goal of the [[2013–14 Stoke City F.C. season|2013–14]] season as City beat [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] 2–1 on 24 August 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–1 Crystal Palace|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23736812|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> Adam then scored a penalty in a 3–3 draw with [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and then in the next match against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in a 2–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web|title=Swansea 3–3 Stoke|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24792968|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–0 Sunderland|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24969017|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref> Adam came off the bench to help Stoke to a 2–1 victory over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on 21 December 2013 which earned him praise from manager [[Mark Hughes]] for his contribution.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–1 Aston Villa|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25376974|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Mark Hughes toasts Charlie Adam substitution after win over Aston Villa|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Mark-Hughes-toasts-Charlie-Adam/story-20353648-detail/story.html|work=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref> He scored Stoke's second goal against his former club Liverpool on 12 January 2014 in a 5–3 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 3-5 Liverpool|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25609799|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref> On 1 February 2014, Adam scored twice in a 2–1 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] to help Stoke record a first league win over the Red Devils since 1984.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2-1 Man Utd|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25892829|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref> His first goal however was later ruled by the Premier League as a [[Michael Carrick]] own goal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Adam docked a Manchester United goal|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Stoke-City-Charlie-Adam-docked-Manchester-United/story-20574492-detail/story.html|work=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref> In the next match against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 8 February, Adam provided assists for both Stoke's goals in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite web|title=Southampton 2, Stoke City 2: Peter Odemwingie praises Charlie Adam's 'perfect pass'|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Southampton-2-Stoke-City-2-Peter-Odemwingie/story-20594149-detail/story.html|work=Stoke Sentinel|accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref> He was given a three-match retrospective ban by [[the FA]] following an altercation with [[Olivier Giroud]] in a 1–0 over Arsenal on 1 March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlie Adam banned by FA following Olivier Giroud incident|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26425905|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref> On 11 May 2014 Adam scored the winning goal against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on the final day of the season which earned Stoke 9th place in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|title=West Brom 1-2 Stoke|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27273391|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
Adam was called up by national manager [[Alex McLeish]] to the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] squad for the first time on 11 May 2007 for a [[Friendly matches|friendly]] against [[Austria national football team|Austria]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying|Euro 2008 qualifying]] [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying Group B|Group B match]] against the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]].<ref name="Scotland squad">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6646093.stm|title=Scotland call for Hutton and Adam|publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2007}}</ref> He made his debut at the [[Gerhard Hanappi Stadium]] in Vienna on 30 May as a 67th-minute substitute, in a 1–0 victory.<ref name="Austria 0-1 Scotland">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6696543.stm|title=Austria 0–1 Scotland|publisher=BBC Sport  |date=30 May 2007|archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5nE1RE5qV |archivedate = 1 February 2010|deadurl=no|first=Julian|last=Taylor}}</ref> He then made his competitive debut as a 77th-minute substitute in a 2–0 win over the Faroe Islands at the [[Svangaskarð]] stadium in [[Toftir]] on 6 June.<ref>{{cite web|title=Faroe Islands 0–2 Scotland|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6713997.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 August 2012}}</ref>

Adam was recalled to the Scotland squad by manager [[George Burley]] for a friendly against [[Japan national football team|Japan]] on 10 October 2009 at the [[Nissan Stadium]], [[Yokohama]], Japan.<ref name="bfc1814097">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1814097,00.html|title=Charlie Earns Scotland Recall|date=1 October 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=1 October 2009}}</ref><ref name="bbc8284355">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8284355.stm|title=Fox earns first Scotland call-up|date=1 October 2009|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 October 2009}}</ref> On 10 November 2009, Adam was drafted into the Scotland squad for the friendly against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] four days later.<ref name="bfc1871885">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1871885,00.html|title=Charlie Drafted In To Scotland Squad|date=10 November 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=10 November 2009}}</ref>

He replaced his former [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] teammate [[Kevin Thomson]], who pulled out due to illness. George Burley said of Adam: "He scored a cracking goal for Blackpool last weekend. He is a very good replacement. He has been playing consistently, is a quality player, and is getting a real benefit from playing regularly."<ref name="bfc1872633">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~1872633,00.html|title=The Latest From Bloomfield Road&nbsp;—Wednesday|date=11 November 2009|publisher=Blackpoolfc.co.uk|accessdate=11 November 2009}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Adam is married to Sophie and has a son called Jack. He grew up supporting [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]].<ref>Stoke City Official Matchday Magazine 12 January 2013 v Chelsea</ref>

'''Jordi Mertens''' (born 30 March 2001) is a Belgian [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[striker]] for [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].

He has played at [[Belgium national under-21 football team|under-21]] and [[Belgium national football team|full international]] levels for Belgium.

==Club career==

===STVV===
[[Sint-Truiden]]-born Mertens started his career at K Sint-Truidense VV in June 2013, breaking into the first team in 2018 and making a total of 28 league appearances and scoring 5 goals for the club.

===San Marino===
In July 2018 he joined San Marino for £1.3m and made 446 league appearances and scored 454 goals. During his time with San Marino, Mertens' team lifted the Serie A in 2026. 2027, 2028, 2029, 2030. 2031 and 2033. the Club World Championship in 2024 and 2028, won the World Cup in 2030, the European Football Championship in 2028. the European Champions Cup 6 times between 2024 and 2033. the European Super Cup 5 times between 2024 and 2032. the Italian Cup 6 times between 2026 and 2032 and the Italian Super Cup 8 times between 2023 and 2033. 

===Arsenal===
In August 2033 he joined Arsenal for £10.75M and made 64 league appearances and scored 31 goals. During his time with The Gunners. Mertens' team lifted the European Champions Cup in 2034. the European Super Cup in 2034. won the English FA Cup in 2034 and the English Community Shield in 2034. 

===Cheltenham Town===
Mertens joined current club Cheltenham Town for £2.9M in August 2035 and has currently made 20 league appearances and scored 10 goals for the club. 

==Personal life==
Mertens is close friends with San Marino team-mate, Patrik Nord. The pair are said to own a villa in the Canary Islands, which they visit together with their families during the summer.

==Honours==

===Club===
Mertens has built up a phenomenal record of 40 competition wins throughout his career: Serie A (San Marino 2026, 2027. 2028, 2029. 2030. 2031 and 2033). Club World Championship (San Marino 2024 and 2028). World Cup (Belgium 2030). European Football Championship (Belgium 2028). European Champions Cup (San Marino 2024. 2027, 2028, 2030, 2032 and 2033: Arsenal 2034). European Super Cup (San Marino 2024. 2027. 2028, 2030 and 2032: Arsenal 2034). Italian Cup (San Marino 2026. 2028, 2029, 2030, 2031 and 2032). Italian Super Cup (San Marino 2023. 2026. 2027. 2028. 2029. 2030, 2031 and 2033). English FA Cup (Arsenal 2034) and English Community Shield (Arsenal 2034). 

===Individual===
Mertens has been recognised for his talent and achievements with several awards: Named Serie A Striker of the Year runner-up on two occasions, won the Serie A Fans' Player of the Year, Serie A Striker of the Year on seven occasions. Italian Media Foreign Player of the Year on three occasions, Serie A Top Goalscorer on eight occasions. European Golden Shoe on eight occasions. Serie A Fair Play Player of the Year, Serie A Young Player of the Year, European Champions Cup Golden Boot on three occasions. European Championship Best Player third place. European Championship Golden Boot runner-up. named Serie A Player of the Year on four occasions. World Golden Ball on four occasions. Best Player in Europe. World Player of the Year on three occasions. Confederations Cup Best Player runner-up and won the Club World Championship Best Player.
