'''Neil James Adams''' (born 23 November 1965) is a former professional [[Association football|football]]er and former manager of [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]. He played for [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] and Norwich City.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City">{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=Tony|title=The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City|year=1994|publisher=Lion Press|isbn=0-9524151-0-0}}</ref>

Adams began his career playing for his local club Stoke City, where he earned a reputation of being a promising winger. This prompted Everton to pay a fee of £150,000 for his signature in June 1986. Injuries prevented him from reaching his potential at [[Goodison Park]] and after three years he moved on to Oldham Athletic. At Oldham, Adams played a major role in helping the club gain promotion to the newly formed [[Premier League]] in 1992 and also helped the Latics to reach the [[1990 Football League Cup Final|1990 League Cup Final]]. He signed for Norwich City in February 1994 for a fee of £250,000. He became a regular in the Norwich for the next six seasons before ending his playing career with another two years at Oldham. After retiring from playing, Adams became a pundit for [[BBC Radio Norfolk]], before taking up a coaching role at the Norwich City Academy – guiding them to victory in the [[2012–13 FA Youth Cup]]. In April 2014 Adams was appointed first-team manager following the departure of [[Chris Hughton]].

==Playing career==
Adams was born in [[Stoke-on-Trent]] and began his career with local side [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] making his professional debut against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] in the [[Full Members Cup]] in [[1985–86 Stoke City F.C. season|1985–86]].<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> He made a huge impression with his performances for Stoke in his debut season, with his attacking creativity and deadly accurate crossing ability earning him a call up to the [[England under-21 national football team|England U21]] side for their European Championship semi-final tie in Italy.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/> With Stoke's finances poor and many top-flight sides showing an interest in signing him, he was sold to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in June 1986 for a fee of £150,000 after the Toffees beat off competition from Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur, much to the annoyance to the Stoke supporters who feared that their club was becoming a 'selling club'.<ref name="The Encyclopaedia of Stoke City"/>

In his first season at Everton he helped the side win the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] title in [[1986–87 in English football|1986–87]]. During his three years on Merseyside he also won two Charity Shield medals and earned his first England U-21 cap in an away game against Sweden. In June 1989 he rejected the offer of a new contract at Goodison Park and joined [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in a £100,000 deal. The five seasons that Adams spent at [[Boundary Park]] was to coincide with the club's golden period. In 1990 he played for the Latics in the League Cup Final against Nottingham Forest, and the following season he helped the team win the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] title as Oldham won promotion to the newly formed [[Premier League]].

Adams' contribution from the right flank helped Oldham establish themselves against the best sides in the country, and he was influential in helping the Latics maintain their top-flight status during their 1992–93 campaign by scoring 9 goals – including crucial strikes against Liverpool, Everton, Chelsea and most memorably the only goal in a 1–0 defeat of soon-to-be-crowned double winners, Manchester United.

Whilst at Oldham he also picked up a Carling No. 1 Award – selected by a Premiership committee before the start of the 1993–94 season. In early 1994 [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] made inquiries about acquiring his services, and after protracted negotiations between the two clubs he eventually signed for the Canaries for a fee of £250,000 in mid-February. Adams was to become a regular in the Norwich side during his time at [[Carrow Road]]. He assumed the role of penalty taker and dead ball specialist for the Canaries, and in his career he only missed from the spot once, in a league cup game against Swansea.

He started in all but one of Norwich's games during the 1996–97 campaign, and completed that season as the Canaries' second top-scorer with a total of 16 goals. In 2002, Norwich fans voted Adams into the [[Norwich City F.C. Hall of Fame]]. After leaving Norfolk in the summer of 1999, Adams returned to former club Oldham for two seasons before a knee injury forced him to retire.

==Managerial career==
A holder of the UEFA 'A' Coaching Licence, he returned to Norwich where was appointed as manager of the club's U-18s. Adams guided the side to victory over [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the [[2012–13 FA Youth Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|title=FA Youth Cup final: Norwich beat Chelsea 4–2 on aggregate|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22519280|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref> On 6 April 2014 he was appointed Norwich City first-team caretaker manager following the departure of [[Chris Hughton]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ADAMS REPLACES HUGHTON AS BOSS|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140406-adams-hughton-norwich-city-manager-1471649.aspx|work=Norwich City F.C|accessdate=6 April 2014}}</ref> On 22 May 2014 he was appointed permanent manager of Norwich City, signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Neil Adams: Norwich City hand caretaker boss permanent job|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27530377|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> Adams resigned from his position on 5 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Neil Adams resigns as Norwich City manager|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30685075|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref>

'''Tony Alexander Adams''', [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 10 October 1966) is an English [[Association football|football]] manager and former Arsenal player.

Adams spent his [[One club man|entire playing career]] of 22 years as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="testimonial">{{cite news
| url        = http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2002/may/14/newsstory.sport1
| title      = A night out for the Adams family
| work       = [[The Guardian]]
| date       = 14 May 2002
| accessdate = 2008-10-28 | first=Jon | last=Brodkin | location=London}}</ref> He is considered one of the greatest Arsenal players of all time by the club's own fans <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arsenal-land.co.uk/columns/?col=96 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060422044844/www.arsenal-land.co.uk/columns/?col=96 |archivedate=22 April 2006 | title=Referendum: Is Thierry Henry Arsenal's greatest ever player? | work=Arsenal Land }}</ref> and was included in the [[Football League 100 Legends]]. With Arsenal, he won four top flight division titles, three [[FA Cup]]s, two [[Football League Cup]]s, a [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]], and three [[FA Community Shield]]s. A statue honouring Adams was unveiled at Emirates stadium on 9 December 2011, along with statues of [[Thierry Henry]] and [[Herbert Chapman]].

When his playing career finished Adams went into football management, spending periods in charge of [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] and [[Azerbaijan]] side [[Gabala FK|Gabala]].

==Early life==
Born in [[Romford]], Adams grew up in [[Dagenham]] and was a pupil at Hunters Hall Primary School from 1971 to 1978 and then [[Eastbrook Comprehensive School]] from 1978 to 1983.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lbbd.gov.uk/MuseumsAndHeritage/LocalHistoryResources/Documents/Infosheet52FootballpersonalitiesofBD.pdf|title=Football personalities of Barking and Dagenham|publisher=London Borough of Barking & Dagengham|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>

==Club career==
Adams signed for Arsenal as a schoolboy in 1980. He made his first team debut on 5 November 1983 against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]], four weeks after his 17th birthday. Adams became a regular player in the [[1985–86 in English football|1985–86 season]], winning his first major trophy in 1987 when playing in the [[Football League Cup]] Final win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]].

Together with [[Lee Dixon]], [[Nigel Winterburn]] and [[Steve Bould]], Adams was part of the "famous four" that lined up in Arsenal's defence, which under [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] was renowned for its well-disciplined use of the [[Offside law (football)|offside trap]]. On 1 January 1988, he became Arsenal captain at the age of 21;<ref name="greatest">{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/gunners-greatest-players-no-3.-tony-adams|title=Gunners' Greatest Players – 3. Tony Adams|
author=Arsenal.com|work=Official Arsenal Website|date=5–19 May 2008|accessdate=2008-11-24}}</ref> he would remain club captain for the next 14 years until his retirement.

Adams's strong discipline of the defence was considered a factor in Arsenal winning the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] in [[1986–87 in English football|1986–87]] and then the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] championship twice; the first in [[1988–89 in English football|1988–89]] after a [[Liverpool 0–2 Arsenal (26 May 1989)|win]] over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the final game of the season; the second in [[1990–91 in English football|1990–91]], losing once all season.

In [[1992–93 in English football|1992–93]] Adams gained the distinction of being the captain of the first English side to win the League Cup and [[FA Cup]] double, lifting the [[European Cup Winners' Cup]] the following year.

Despite this success, a battle with [[alcoholism]], which started in the mid-1980s, increasingly blighted his life as he was reportedly often involved in fights in [[nightclub]]s. On 6 May 1990, Adams crashed his [[Ford Sierra]] into a wall in [[Rayleigh, Essex|Rayleigh]] and when breathalysed his blood alcohol level was found to be more than four times the legal drink-drive limit. On 19 December that year, at [[Southend]] [[Crown Court]],<ref name="greatest" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.askmen.com/top_10/sports/top-10-stupid-criminal-acts-by-footballers_4.html|title=Tony Adams|publisher=Ask Men|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=519627|title=Stick Your Two Points Up Your Arsenal|first=Tim|last=Stillman|publisher=Vital Football|date=25 July 2010|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> he was imprisoned for four months (being freed after half of his sentence on 15 February 1991) but after being released, his alcoholism continued and he was involved in further alcohol-related incidents, including playing through a match during the [[1993–94 in English football|1993–94 season]] despite being drunk, falling down stairs and needing 29 stitches to a head wound when drunk, and letting off fire extinguishers and firing a flare gun into a disabled lavatory with team-mate [[Ray Parlour]] at [[Pizza Hut]] in [[Hornchurch]] where they were being taunted by supporters of rival clubs.

Finally, on 14 September 1996, Adams admitted to the public that he was an [[alcoholic]] and, after seeking treatment, found a more sensitive side to his character emerging, which included a return to education and an attempt to learn the [[piano]]. He became one of the most high-profile [[recovering alcoholic]]s in the UK;<ref name="ias">{{cite web|url=http://www.ias.org.uk/What-we-do/Publication-archive/Alcohol-Alert/Issue-3-1998/Adams-turns-his-back-on-alcohol.aspx|title=Adams turns his back on alcohol|author=Paul Whittaker|work=Alcohol Works|date=March 1998|accessdate=2014-02-22}}</ref> his battle with alcohol is detailed in his [[autobiography]], ''Addicted'', which was released in May 1998 to enormous critical acclaim.<ref name="ias"/>

[[File:Tony Adams Statue.jpg|thumb|200px|Tony Adams statue outside the [[Emirates Stadium]].]]His recovery and rehabilitation were helped in no small part by the arrival of [[Arsène Wenger]] as Arsenal manager in October 1996. Wenger reformed the club's [[Diet (nutrition)|dietary]] practices and the players' lifestyles. Wenger stuck by Adams following his confessions about his drink problem, and the improvements in the regime probably extended Adams's career by several years. Adams rewarded his manager's understanding handsomely, captaining the club to two [[FA Premier League|Premiership]] and FA Cup [[Double (association football)|Doubles]], in [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98]] and [[2001–02 in English football|2001–02]]; he is the only player in English football history to have captained a title-winning team in three different decades.

In August 2002, just before the start of the [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03]] season, Adams retired from professional football after a career spanning almost 20 years, his last match being the last league game of the season at home to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] (the 2002 [[FA Cup Final]] was unusually played ''before'' the last league fixtures). He played 674 matches for Arsenal (only [[David O'Leary]] has played more) and was the most successful captain in the club's history. The number 6 shirt that Adams wore when playing was not used again until the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07 season]], when it was assigned to [[Philippe Senderos]], it currently is the squad number of French defender [[Laurent Koscielny]]

Just before his retirement as a player, Adams had applied to become manager of [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] (who had just missed out on promotion to Division One) after the resignation of [[Steve Coppell]], but his application was rejected.<ref>{{cite news
| url        = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/2069118.stm
| title      = Brentford snub Adams
| publisher  = [[BBC Sport]]
| date       = 27 June 2002
| accessdate = 8 January 2009
 | location=London}}</ref>

Nicknamed "Mr Arsenal", he was honoured by Arsenal with a testimonial game against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in May 2002 with many Arsenal legends playing, including [[Ian Wright]], [[John Lukic]] and Adams's fellow back four stalwarts, Dixon, Winterburn and Bould. The game finished 1–1 with Lee Dixon, in his final appearance for the Gunners, getting their goal.

In March 2003, just seven months after his retirement and with Arsenal [[BBC Sport]] named Adams as the former Arsenal player that the club would most benefit from returning.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2872203.stm | work=BBC News | title=Blast from the past: Part one | date=24 March 2003 | first=Tom | last=Fordyce}}</ref>

In 2004, Adams was inducted into the [[English Football Hall of Fame]] in recognition of his impact on the English game, and in 2008 he was placed third in the 50 Greatest Gunners poll on the club's website.

A statue of Adams was placed outside Emirates Stadium in celebration of the club's 125th anniversary on 9 December 2011. Manager Herbert Chapman and Arsenal's all-time top goal scorer [[Thierry Henry]] and later [[Dennis Bergkamp]] were also immortalised with statues outside the ground.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2072146/Arsenal-statues-unveiled-Thierry-Henry-tears.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Teary Henry as Arsenal unveil statues to former French star, Adams and Chapman | date=10 December 2011}}</ref>

==International career==
Adams made his debut for [[England national football team|England]] against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in 1987, and played in [[1988 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 88]], scoring one of England's two goals. He was the first player to represent England who had been born after the 1966 World Cup win.

After a highly promising start to his international career, Adams suffered a series of setbacks during the early 1990s. He was surprisingly left out of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] squad by manager [[Bobby Robson]], and missed [[1992 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 92]] due to injury. However, he still maintained a regular place in defence, and after the retirement of [[Gary Lineker]] in 1992, Adams unofficially shared the captaincy of England with [[David Platt (footballer)|David Platt]], though Adams became England captain outright before [[1996 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 96]], as Platt's place in the side became less secure. England reached the semi-finals of Euro 96, before losing on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalties]] to [[Germany national football team|Germany]].

When England manager [[Glenn Hoddle]] took the Captain's armband from Adams and gave it to [[Alan Shearer]] it was a bitter pill for Adams to swallow. Speaking at a fans' forum in 2008 Adams remarked "I have some resentment over the way Glenn Hoddle gave the captaincy to Alan Shearer instead of me but I can let that go. I reacted positively. I disagreed with him [Hoddle] and he thought Alan could get more penalties being a centre forward. People know my reaction to that".{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}

Adams continued to play for the national side, however and he finally appeared in a World Cup finals in [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998]]. His international swansong was England's largely unsuccessful [[2000 European Football Championship|Euro 2000]] campaign. With Shearer retiring from international football after the tournament, Adams regained the captaincy. However, within months, England lost a World Cup qualifier to [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in October 2000, the match being the last to be staged at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] before the stadium was torn down for rebuilding. That match was Adams's 60th Wembley appearance, a record. With [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] eventually taking the helm and under increasing pressure for his place from the emerging and improving [[Rio Ferdinand]], Adams retired from international football before Eriksson picked his first squad. He was the last England player to score at the old Wembley Stadium when he scored England's second goal in a 2–0 friendly win over Ukraine on 31 May 2000. This was also his first goal since he scored in a friendly against Saudi Arabia in November 1988, thus making the record for the longest gap between goals for England.

Adams was the first, and remains to date the only, England player to make tournament appearances in three separate decades.

In total Adams appeared 66 times for England, scoring 5 times.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/adams-intl.html| title = Tony Alexander Adams – International Appearances| accessdate = 2008-10-24}}</ref>

==Managerial and coaching career==
After starting a [[sports science]] degree at [[Brunel University]], Adams became the manager of [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] in November 2003. He was unable to prevent the club's relegation to [[Football League Two|League Two]] that season, and although the club were top of the table in August 2004, a loss of form saw them fall down the table.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wycombe_wanderers/3995677.stm | title=Adams resigns as Wycombe manager | work=BBC Sport | date=9 November 2004 | accessdate=25 March 2010 | location=London}}</ref> He resigned from Wycombe in November 2004, citing personal reasons. He was succeeded by [[John Gorman (footballer)|John Gorman]].

In July 2005, Adams accepted a trainee coaching role with [[Netherlands|Dutch]] side [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] with special responsibility for its Jong team, which is a reserve/junior side. Adams later had a short spell seconded to [[FC Utrecht|Utrecht]] as a first team trainee coach in January and February 2006. While at Feyenoord he also worked part-time as a scout for Arsenal, watching games in Italy, France, and the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.setanta.com/US/Articles/Football/2009/06/03/Exclusive-Adams-on-Arsenal-interest/gnid-55518/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607082940/http://www.setanta.com/US/Articles/Football/2009/06/03/Exclusive-Adams-on-Arsenal-interest/gnid-55518/|archivedate=7 June 2009|title=Exclusive: Italian job for Gunners|first=Chris|last=Stanton|publisher=Setanta|date=3 June 2009|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>

Adams joined [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] as assistant manager to [[Harry Redknapp]] in June 2006, a position left vacant by the departure of [[Kevin Bond (footballer)|Kevin Bond]]. In his first season as assistant, Portsmouth finished ninth in the [[Premier League]] – their highest standing since the 1950s and won the [[2007–08 FA Cup|2007–08]] [[FA Cup]]. Adams was appointed caretaker manager of Portsmouth in October 2008, alongside [[Joe Jordan (footballer)|Joe Jordan]],<ref name="portsmouth_manager">
{{Cite news
| url        = http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/oct/28/portsmouth-premierleague
| title      = Adams set to be unveiled as new Portsmouth manager
| work       = [[The Guardian]]
| date       = 28 October 2008
| accessdate = 2008-10-28
 | first=John | last=Ashdown | location=London}}
</ref> following the departure of [[Harry Redknapp]] to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]. He was subsequently appointed full-time manager.<ref name="portsmouth_manager" /><ref>{{cite news
| url        = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/portsmouth/7693323.stm
| title      = Adams appointed new Pompey boss
| work       = [[BBC]]
| date       = 28 October 2008
| accessdate = 2008-10-28
 | location=London| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqgVzc83 |archivedate = 17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> He was sacked in February 2009 after just 16 games in charge in which Portsmouth picked up only 10 points.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ron Parrish|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_4906973,00.html|title=Pompey confirm Adams axe|publisher=Sky Sports News |date=9 February 2008 |accessdate=2009-02-11}}</ref>

In May 2010, Adams signed a three-year contract to manage [[Azerbaijan]]i club [[Gabala FK|Gabala FC]] of the [[Azerbaijan Premier League]].<ref name=aze>
{{Cite news
| url        = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8675874.stm
| title      = Tony Adams' grand plans for Azerbaijan football club
| work       = [[BBC]]
| date       = 11 May 2010
| accessdate = 12 May 2010
| first=Tom
| last=Esslemont}}
</ref> He departed as coach of Gabala due on 16 November 2011, before the end of the [[2011–12 Azerbaijan Premier League|2011–12 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/tony-adams-quits-as-manager-of-fc-gabala-6264409.html|title=Tony Adams quits as manager of FC Gabala|publisher=''Independent''|date=18 November 2011|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>

==Charitable work==
In September 2000, as a result of his own experiences with [[alcoholism]] and [[drug addiction]], Adams founded the [[Sporting Chance Clinic]], a charitable foundation aimed at providing treatment, counselling and support for sports men and women suffering from drink, drug or [[gambling addiction]]s.<ref>
{{Cite news
| url        = http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/tony-adams-to-provide-safe-haven-for-alcoholic-and-drugaddict-footballers-710805.html
| title      = Tony Adams to provide safe haven for alcoholic and drug-addict footballers
| work       = [[The Independent]]
| date       = 21 August 2000
| accessdate = 2008-10-28
| location=London
| first=Kim
| last=Sengupta
}}
</ref> The clinic, which works to the [[twelve-step programme]] philosophy of [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] is based near [[Liphook]] in [[Hampshire]] and includes [[Kate Hoey]], [[Alex Rae (footballer born 1969)|Alex Rae]] and [[Elton John]] as patrons, and is supported by the [[Professional Footballers' Association]]. Adams's former Arsenal and England team mate [[Paul Merson]], himself a recovering alcoholic, is also a patron of the charity.

His Arsenal testimonial match helped raise [[Pound sterling|£]]500,000 for his charity, the [[Sporting Chance Clinic]].<ref name="testimonial" />

Adams is a Patron for NACOA&mdash;a charity that provides information, advice and support for anyone affected by their parents' drinking.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nacoa.org.uk/about-nacoa/patrons/tony-adams.html|title=Tony Adams|publisher=NACOA|date=15 April 2009|accessdate=2014-02-22|location=Bristol}}</ref>

==Post-football career==
Adams remains a popular figure with Arsenal fans. In December 2008, more than six years after he left the club, Adams led out his Portsmouth side onto the pitch at Arsenal to be greeted with the chant "There's only one Tony Adams" by Arsenal fans.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1102323/Arsenal-1-Portsmouth-0-Same-old-song-Tony-Adams-falls-short.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Arsenal 1 Portsmouth 0: Same old song as Adams falls short | first=Simon | last=Cass | date=29 December 2008}}</ref>

On 30 December 2009 Adams was the guest editor on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Today (BBC Radio 4)|Today]]'' programme.

==In popular culture==
*In the 1997 motion picture ''[[The Full Monty]]'', Horse (played by [[Paul Barber (actor)|Paul Barber]]) specifically mentions Adams while attempting to explain that a particular part in their dance routine was similar to the "Arsenal offside trap."

*In the debut album ''[[Rock Art and the X-Ray Style]]'' by [[Joe Strummer and the Mescaleros]], the opening track is named 'Tony Adams'.

*"Ali in the Jungle", a song by the English rock band [[The Hours (band)|The Hours]], refers to him in its lyrics.<ref>http://www.songmeanings.net/songs/view/3530822107858638101/</ref>

*In [[Robert Muchamore]]'s  [[CHERUB]] series, protagonist [[James Adams (character)|James Adams]] chooses the middle name Anthony and last name Adams after Tony Adams when he joins CHERUB.<ref name="Recruit">{{cite book | author=Muchamore, Robert | title=[[CHERUB: The Recruit]] | series=CHERUB | volume=1 | year=2004 | publisher=Hodder | isbn=978-0-340-88153-8}}</ref>

'''Miles Vivien Esifi Addison''' (born 7 January 1989) is an English [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. He can play as both a central defender or a central midfielder.<ref name="Missedchance">{{cite web | title=Addison: I feared I'd missed my chance with the Rams| work=Derby Telegraph | url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Addison-feared-d-miss-chance-Rams/story-11617547-detail/story.html| accessdate=12 November 2013 }}</ref>

==Club career==

===Derby County===
Though born in London, Addison moved to [[Nottingham]] at the age of 3,<ref name="Missedchance"/> where he was spotted by scouts from the Derby County youth system. Addison was handed his first team debut by interim manager [[Terry Westley]], who he had worked closely with in the youth and reserve teams, towards the end of the [[2005-06 in English football|2005–06]] season, in the 1–1 [[Football League Championship|Championship]] draw with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on 17 April 2006,<ref name="Missedchance"/> where he played in the centreback position alongside side another academy graduate [[Lewin Nyatanga]]. He kept his place for the following match, a 2–0 defeat away to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich]] 5 days later.

With the appointment of [[Billy Davies]] as Derby manager, Addison found himself frozen out of the first team at Derby and didn't appear in the starting eleven again until Davies' successor, [[Paul Jewell]], gave him a surprise start, again at centreback, in a 3–1 defeat away to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn]] in the penultimate game of the [[2007–08 Premier League]] season.<ref name="Missedchance"/>

Derby's poor start to the [[2008–09 Derby County F.C. season|2008–09]] season saw Addison given a chance to cement a place in the first team and he was given his first start of the campaign in the 1–0 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] win at [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston]] on 26 August 2008. Starting in his preferred position of central midfield for the first time, Addison impressed enough to retain his place for the subsequent match away to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]]. This was the start of a run of 15 consecutive appearances in the first team, which was only ended when suspension for reaching five yellow cards ruled him out of the League Cup 4th round tie against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]]. Addison formed a formidable midfield partnership with [[Paul Green (footballer born 1983)|Paul Green]] during this time as the Rams embarked on a run of only 2 defeats in 13 matches and moved from the bottom of the table to the fringes of the playoff places. Addison's form earned high praise from Jewell as an example to the club's other academy players<ref name="PJPleased">{{cite news | title=Jewell pleased with Addison effort| work=bbc.co.uk | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7596066.stm| accessdate=3 September 2008 | date=3 September 2008}}</ref> and saw him sign a new three-and-a-half year deal with the club on 2 September to keep him at the club until 2011.<ref name="Signsdeal">{{cite news | title=Addison signs new deal with Rams| work=bbc.co.uk | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7593285.stm| accessdate=2 September 2008 | date=2 September 2008}}</ref> November saw Addison linked with a £2 million move to [[Premier League]] [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke]].<ref name="Stoke">{{cite news | title=Wednesday's gossip column| work=bbc.co.uk | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/gossip_and_transfers/7710088.stm| accessdate=5 November 2008 | date=5 November 2008}}</ref> However, Jewell denied this, saying "I spoke to Tony (Pulis, Stoke manager) about another matter and he never mentioned it. We are not going to sell Miles Addison. He won't be getting sold. Everybody has their price I guess, but we have worked too hard over the past year and gone through too many tortures to now start selling our best players".<ref name="stoke">{{cite web | title=Jewell: Addison won't be sold| work=Skysports.co.uk| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11696/4469038/| accessdate=12 November 2013 }}</ref> Addison was denied his first goal for the club in the controversial [[Derby County F.C.–Nottingham Forest F.C. rivalry|East Midlands derby]] on 2 November 2008 when [[Stuart Attwell]] incorrectly<ref name="robbed">{{cite web | title=Jewell: Referees rang to say late Miles goals was OK| work=Derby Telegraph | url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Jewell-Referees-official-rang-say-late-Miles-goal-OK/story-11613829-detail/story.html| accessdate=12 November 2013 }}</ref> ruled two late Addison headers which would have given Derby a 2–1 win, with the match instead finishing 1–1.<ref name="crapref">{{cite news | title=Rams were robbed of win: Jewell| work=bbc.co.uk | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7705741.stm| accessdate=3 November 2008 | date=3 November 2008}}</ref> but eventually got his first professional goal with the second in a 3–0 home win over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on 15 November 2008.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7711448.stm | work=BBC News | title=Derby 3–0 Sheff Wed | date=15 November 2008 | accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> On 20 December 2008 he captained the winning side against Watford. Addison said "it was a dream to captain the side who I support". Addison was substituted during Derby's 4–1 win over [[Blackpool F.C.]], an injury which was later diagnosed to be a stress fracture of his foot, which ruled him out for the rest of the 2008–09 season.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7922879.stm | work=BBC News | title=Addison injury blow rocks Derby | date=4 March 2009 | accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> Despite missing the latter part of the campaign Addison's form was such that he won the [[Sammy Crooks]] Trophy – Derby County's Young Player of the Season award – for the 2008/09 season.

Addison had a great start to the 2009/10 season with goals against [[Peterborough United]] and [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], but a succession of foot problems restricted him to just five starts between October 2009 and February 2010 and he underwent specialist surgery in America.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11696/5953415/ | work=Sky Sports | title=Addison blow for Rams | date=16 February 2010}}</ref> The surgery was successful but he was ruled out for the remainder of Derby's 2009/10 season as well as the entirety of the 2010/11 campaign.<ref name="addisonfootop">{{cite web | title=Clough pleased with Addison op| publisher=Sky Sports| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11696/6053550/| date = 25 March 2010 }}</ref><ref name="outforseason">{{cite web | title=Addison facing long recovery| publisher=Sky Sports| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11696/6107606/| date = 21 April 2010 }}</ref> However, Addison made a quicker than expected recovery, with Clough suggesting he may be back in first team action as early as January 2011. He was pencilled in to play a reserve game against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on 26 October 2010<ref name="addisonpencilledin">{{cite web | title=Reserves chance for Miles Addison against the Owls today| publisher=''Derby Telegraph''| url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Reserves-chance-Miles-Owls/story-11625293-detail/story.html| date = 26 October 2010 }}</ref> but was later withdrawn as a precaution after admitting he felt "a bit stiff".<ref name="addisonprecaution">{{cite web | title=Addison Not Risked In Reserve Game | publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2196577,00.html| date = 26 October 2010 }}</ref> He eventually took to the pitch in a competitive capacity when he came on as an 81st minute substitute in a 2–0 home win over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 6 November 2010, his first appearance in 10 months, as Derby reached 4th in the table.<ref name="addisonappearance">{{cite web | title=Addison's return to squad a massive boost, says Nigel | publisher=''Derby Telegraph''| url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Addison-s-return-squad-massive-boost-says-Clough/story-11603523-detail/story.html| date = 8 November 2010 }}</ref>

On 21 June 2011, Addison signed a contract extension, extending his stay at Pride Park until summer 2013.<ref name="addisoncontract">{{cite web | title=Addison Extends His Derby Contract | publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2379712,00.html| date = 21 June 2011 }}</ref>

====Loan at Barnsley====
On 24 June 2011, Addison joined fellow Championship club, [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on six-month loan deal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Barnsley sign four players |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/barnsley/9521856.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 June 2011}}</ref> At Barnsley, Addison struggled with injuries and made a total of 9 appearance during his loan spell. However on 2 January 2012, Addison's loan was extended until 28 January 2012.<ref name="addisonbarnsleyextension">{{cite web | title=Addison Extends Barnsley Loan | publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2562994,00.html| date = 2 January 2012 }}</ref> Addison returned to Derby in January 2012 after making 13 appearances for Barnsley, 11 of which were starts.<ref name="addisonreturntoderby">{{cite web | title=Addison Back From Barnsley Loan | publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2593957,00.html| date = 30 January 2012 }}</ref>

====Loan at Bournemouth====
After his loan spell finish at Barnsley, Addison found first-team appearances hard to come by at Pride Park due to the form of central defenders [[Shaun Barker]] and [[Jason Shackell]]. On 21 February 2012, Addison joined [[Football League One]] side [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref name="Bournemouth agree loan deal for Derby's Miles Addison">{{cite web | title=Bournemouth agree loan deal for Derby's Miles Addison | publisher=BBC Sport| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17113349| date = 21 February 2012 }}</ref> Following his loan move to Bournemouth, Addison hinted that he would be open to a permanent move and said his calling his treatment by Derby as "strange".<ref>{{cite news|title=Miles Addison eyes permanent transfer to Bournemouth|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17145665|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 February 2012|accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref> On 25 February 2012, Addison made his first start and played 90th minutes for Bournemouth in a 1-0 loss against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C|MK Dons]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stats: Bournemouth 0 - 1 MK Dons|url=http://www.bournemouth.vitalfootball.co.uk/stats.asp?a=274038|publisher=Bournemouth Vital Football|date=25 February 2012|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> On 10 March 2012, Addison scored an own goal to put [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] 1–0 ahead and the result was 3-0 for Sheffield Wednesday.<ref>{{cite news| title=Sheffield Wednesday 3 - 0 Bournemouth|url=http://www.afcbournemouth-mad.co.uk/rprt/mtch/march_10__sheffield_wednesday_30_afc_bournemouth__att_19416_734011/index.shtml|publisher=AFC Bournemouth-Mad|date=10 March 2012|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> On 17 March 2012, Addison scored his first goal for Bournemouth in the 83rd minute in a 1–1 draw against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] to end a run of five defeats for Bournemouth.<ref>{{cite news|title=AFC Bournemouth 1 - 1 Carlisle United|url=http://www.afcbournemouth-mad.co.uk/rprt/mtch/march_17__afc_bournemouth_11_carlisle_united__att_5240_735091/index.shtml|publisher=AFC Bournemouth-Mad|date=17 March 2012|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> On 13 April 2012, Addison expressed an interest to make his move to Bournemouth permanent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Miles Addison keen on Bournemouth stay| publisher=BBC Sport|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17701894|date=13 April 2012|accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref> Derby manager [[Nigel Clough]] said on 16 April 2012, that Addison was free to leave the club, stating the form of [[Craig Bryson]], [[Jeff Hendrick]], [[Mark O'Brien (footballer born 1992)|Mark O'Brien]], [[Jake Buxton]] and [[Jason Shackell]] as the reason, with Bournemouth stating an interest in a permanent deal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Addison & Croft set to leave Derby County in summer| publisher=BBC Sport|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17732249|date=16 April 2012|accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref> Addison featured 14 times for Bournemouth, who ended the season 11th as their play-off hopes faded in April. Upon his return to Derby, Bournemouth stated their interest in making the transfer permanent in the summer<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9707101.Cherries__Groves_set_to_launch_bid_for_Addison/|publisher=Bournemouth Echo|title=Cherries: Groves set to launch bid for Addison|date=16 May 2012|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref> and on 22 May 2012, Addison was transfer listed by the club with a year left on his contract.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2778560,00.html|publisher=dcfc.co.uk|title=Clough Confirms Davies Could Leave |date=22 May 2012|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref> As well as Bournemouth there was reported interest from several Championship clubs according to [[Nigel Clough]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18159304?|publisher=BBC Sport|title=Championship clubs track Derby County's Miles Addison|date=22 May 2012|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>

===Bournemouth===
On 12 July 2012, Addison joined [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for an undisclosed fee.<ref name="bournperm">{{cite web | title=Addison Heads To AFC Bournemouth| work=dcfc.co.uk | url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~2818212,00.html|date=12 July 2012|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref>

==International career==
Addison was called up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] for the team's UEFA U21 European Championship Qualification games against [[Macedonia national under-21 football team|FYR Macedonia]] and [[Greece national under-21 football team|Greece]] on 27 August 2009.<ref name="engu21">{{cite web | title=Eng U21 Call-Up For Addison| publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://origin-www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~1777273,00.html| date = 28 August 2009}}</ref> Addison came on as a substitute against Greece to earn his first international cap.

==Achievements==
''with [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]''
*Sammy Crooks Young Player of the Year Award 2008/09

'''Sheyi Emmanuel Adebayor''' ({{IPA-fr|ɛmanɥɛl adəbɛjɔʁ}}; born 26 February 1984), known as '''Emmanuel Adebayor''', is a [[Togo]]lese [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and the [[Togo national football team|Togo national team]]. Adebayor previously played for [[FC Metz|Metz]], [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. He was voted [[African Footballer of the Year]] for 2008.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/adebayor-named-africa-s-best-player-for-2008
|title=Adebayor named Africa's best player for 2008
|date=11 February 2009
|accessdate=22 April 2009
|publisher=Arsenal F.C.}}</ref> 

Adebayor represented the [[Togo national football team]] at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in [[Germany]], the country's début, and to date only, appearance at the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. In January 2010, Adebayor was one of the players involved when the Togo team's [[Togo national football team attack|bus came under gunfire]] on the way to the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]] in [[Angola]], after which he retired from national team duty. In 2013 he returned to the Togo team for the [[2013 African Cup of Nations]] in South Africa, where he helped them to qualify for the quarterfinals. He is currently Togo's [[Top international association football goal scorers by country|all-time top goalscorer]] with 28 goals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/match/97162/togo-vs-tunisia/preview|title=Togo vs Tunisia Preview|date=30 January 2013|accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref>

A towering striker, Adebayor is described as being "tall, skilful, strong in the air and with the ability to score and create."<ref>{{cite web|title=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/first-team-profiles/emmanuel-adebayor/|publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref>

==Club career==
===Early career===
Born in [[Lomé]] to parents of [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] ethnicity, Adebayor spent most of his youth in [[Togo]] where he attended the Centre de Développement Sportif de Lomé (English: Sports Development Centre of Lomé), also known as Sporting Club de Lomé.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=The Observer|title=Big Interview: Emmanuel Adebayor|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/oct/28/newsstory.arsenal1|date=28 October 2007}}</ref> Adebayor was spotted playing for Sporting Club de Lomé by scouts from Metz, who brought him to France in 1999. He made his Ligue 1 debut against FC Sochaux-Montbéliard on 17 November 2001. Following Metz's relegation he played a season in Ligue 2, where 13 goals in 34 league matches prompted a summer 2003 move to Monaco. He featured nine times in Europe as Monaco reached the [[2004 UEFA Champions League Final]] against Porto in Gelsenkirchen, for which he was an unused substitute.<ref>{{cite web|title=http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/players/player=72538/profile/index.html|publisher=UEFA.com|accessdate=18 May 2009}}</ref>

===Arsenal===
On 13 January 2006, Arsenal signed Adebayor for a reported [[Pound sterling|£]]3m. He was given the nickname ''"Baby Kanu"'' due to his resemblance to former Arsenal star [[Nwankwo Kanu]], whom Adebayor had idolised as a youth.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20070405204051/http://arsenal-mania.com/player/Emmanuel-Adebayor/60/profile.html Arsenal-Mania.com – The Arsenal website for Arsenal fans – Emmanuel Adebayor Profile]. arsenal-mania.com</ref> On 4 February 2006, Adebayor made his Arsenal debut in a Premiership match at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and scored after 21&nbsp;minutes, with Arsenal winning 2–0.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/birmingham-city-0-arsenal-2-diaby-and-adebayor-hint-at-brighter-arsenal-future-465684.html
|title=Liverpool 5 Arsenal 2: Diaby and Adebayor hint at brighter Arsenal future|accessdate=22 April 2009
|newspaper=The Independent
| location=London
| first=Guy
| last=Hodgson
| date=6 February 2006}}</ref> At the end of his first season for the Gunners he had scored four goals in ten matches. However, Adebayor was cup-tied for Arsenal's [[UEFA Champions League 2005–06|2005–06 Champions League]] campaign as they reached the final against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], having appeared for Monaco in the qualifying rounds of the competition.

Adebayor scored Arsenal's winning goal against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] to give Arsenal a 1–0 win at [[Old Trafford (football ground)|Old Trafford]], their first league win of the 2006–07 season. Earlier in the game, Adebayor was brought down in the six-yard box to earn Arsenal a penalty, which was taken by [[Gilberto Silva]] and saved.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/5330078.stm
|title=Man Utd 0–1 Arsenal
|date=17 September 2006
|accessdate=22 April 2009
|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]
| first=John
| last=May}}</ref> On 8 November 2006, Adebayor scored the only goal of the match to send Arsenal into the quarterfinals of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].

[[File:Adebayor arsenal.jpg|thumb|left|125px|upright|Adebayor with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]]]
He was sent off in Arsenal's 2–1 [[Football League Cup Final 2007|League Cup final]] loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. He was shown a [[Red card (sports)|red card]] after a fracas towards the end of the match involving both Chelsea and Arsenal players. It was alleged that he had thrown a punch at [[Frank Lampard]]. The FA subsequently gave him an additional one-match ban and a fine of £7,500 for failing to leave the field of play immediately, as well as a three-match ban for the red card.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUKL0946047120070309
|title=Adebayor gets extra one match ban
|date=9 March 2007

|date=1 March 2007

===Manchester City===
[[File:Adebayor Man City.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Adebayor in Manchester City colours.]]
On 18 July 2009, Adebayor signed a five-year contract with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], for a transfer fee believed to be in the region of £25million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_5440128,00.html|title=City Seal Adebayor Swoop|date=18 July 2009|accessdate=18 July 2009|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]}}</ref> He scored a goal on his debut for City against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], with a shot from 18&nbsp;yards in the third minute.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8197359.stm|title=Blackburn 0–2 Man City|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=24 August 2009 | date=15 August 2009 | first=Ian | last=Hughes}}</ref> On his home debut, Adebayor scored the only goal in the 17th minute in a 1–0 in over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], assisted by fellow summer signing [[Carlos Tevez]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8210640.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|title=Man City 1–0 Wolverhampton|accessdate=24 August 2009 | date=22 August 2009 | first=Phil | last=McNulty}}</ref> He scored in his third consecutive league match, heading the winner in a 1–0 away victory against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8222249.stm|title=Portsmouth   0 – 1   Man City|author=Ian Hughes|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=30 August 2009|accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref> 

He then scored in his fourth consecutive match, this time against his former team, [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in a 4–2 victory at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>[http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/report?id=269759&cc=5739&league=ENG.1 Adebayor scores against former club]. Retrieved 12 September 2009</ref> As a result, he is one of only six players to score in their first four games for a club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coyle happy to take a loan|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/wanderers/wanderersnews/8888933.Coyle_happy_to_take_a_loan/?|work=Bolton News|publisher=Newsquest Media|date=4 March 2011|accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref> In the match against Arsenal, Adebayor's former team mate [[Robin van Persie]] accused him of deliberately kicking him in the face,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/van-persie-reaction-to-adebayor-incident |title=Van Persie reaction to Adebayor incident |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=12 September 2009 |accessdate=20 June 2010}}</ref> and he was later handed a three-match ban after being found guilty of violent conduct.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8258287.stm |title=Adebayor handed three-match ban |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=20 June 2010}}</ref> Adebayor was also criticised for running almost the full length of the pitch to the Arsenal supporters and celebrating in front of them after scoring his goal causing an angry reaction from the Arsenal supporters who had been singing racist chants and insulting his mother for the majority of the game. He was booked for this, but did later apologise.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/8252649.stm|title=Adebayor says sorry for goal celebration|date=12 September 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 September 2009}}</ref> Manchester City manager [[Mark Hughes]] suggested Adebayor did it because he wanted to be loved by City fans.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/sep/13/emmanuel-adebayor-manchester-city-arsenal | newspaper=The Guardian | location=London | title=Greater Manchester police blame Emmanuel Adebayor for crowd trouble | first=Daniel | last=Taylor | date=13 September 2009 | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> Also Arsenal's former [[Cameroon|Cameroonian]] defensive midfielder [[Alex Song]], who is one of Adebayor's closest friends in football, alleged he was slapped in the face by Adebayor during City's 4-2 victory, additionally, [[Cesc Fàbregas]], former Arsenal captain, felt that Adebayor had tried to stamp on him too.<ref>http://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/sep/14/emmanual-adebayor-robin-van-persie-manchester-city-arsenal</ref>

For the start of the 2010–11 season he was given the number 9 shirt instead of his favoured number 25 which he previously wore at Arsenal and City. He scored his first hat-trick for Manchester City on 21 October in a [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Lech Poznań]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000128/match=2002961/index.html | publisher=UEFA | location=France | title=Manchester City 3 – 1 Lech | date=21 October 2010 | accessdate=21 October 2010}}</ref> In doing so, he became the first Manchester City player to score a hat-trick in a European competition. However during the 2010–11 season, Adebayor fell down the pecking order at Manchester City following the club purchasing [[Edin Džeko]] with [[Carlos Tevez]] and [[Mario Balotelli]] also being chosen ahead of him. In August 2011, [[Roberto Mancini]] confirmed that Adebayor, along with [[Craig Bellamy]], were no longer part of his plans and could leave [[Manchester City]].

====Real Madrid (loan)====
[[File:Adebayor.jpg|thumb|200px|Adebayor with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]]]
On 25 January 2011, Adebayor signed a loan deal to play for [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/25012011/58/la-liga-adebayor-joins-real-madrid-loan.html|title=La Liga – Adebayor joins Real Madrid on loan|publisher=Yahoo! Sports|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Adebayor scored his first goal for Real Madrid in the second leg of the [[Copa del Rey]] semi-final against [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] at the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium|Santiago Bernabéu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsrss.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/9386083.stm|title=Adebayor savours first Real goal|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=3 February 2011| accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> The game ended 2–0 with an aggregate score of 3–0.

The following weekend, he scored his first goal in [[La Liga]] against [[Real Sociedad]], again at the Santiago Bernabéu. The game ended 4–1 and Adebayor scored the last goal within the last 3&nbsp;minutes of the game. On 6 March 2011, Adebayor scored the opening goal in the 24th minute against [[Racing de Santander|Racing Santander]] from a [[Mesut Özil]] pass. [[Real Madrid]] won the match 3–1. Adebayor was heavily criticised for his performance against [[Sporting de Gijón|Sporting Gijón]], especially for missing many chances. The game ended 0–1 to Sporting Gijón. Adebayor added two goals to his European tally for Madrid with goals against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in a 4–0 win on 5 April 2011. 

Adebayor scored his first hat-trick for Real Madrid on 21 May 2011, in the last round of the [[2010–11 La Liga]] season, against [[UD Almería|Almería]]. In that match, Real Madrid beat Almería 8–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1438877.html|title=Ronaldo: I owe record to my team-mates|publisher=[[FIFA]]|date=22 May 2011| accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>

Adebayor returned to Manchester City after the Spanish season had finished, but was omitted from their pre-season tour of the USA on 11 July 2011 and later risked a £300,000 fine for refusing to train with the club's reserve and youth teams.<ref>{{cite news|title=Insulted Emmanuel Adebayor return Manchester City training|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2014203/Insulted-Emmanuel-Adebayor-return-Manchester-City-training.html?TO=1490|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=23 May 2011|location=London|work=Daily Mail}}</ref>

=== Tottenham Hotspur ===
On 25 August 2011, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] signed Adebayor on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/articles/adebayor-completes-loan-switch-250811.html|title=Adebayor completes loan switch|publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|date=25 August 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref> On 10 September 2011, Adebayor scored on his debut against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the 67th minute.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/sep/10/wolverhampton-wanderers-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league|title=Emmanuel Adebayor scores on his debut to get Tottenham off the mark|work=The Guardian|first=Richard|last=Rae|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=10 September 2011|location=London}}</ref> On 18 September 2011, he scored twice on his home debut in a 4–0 win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], his second strike marking the 100th league goal of his senior career.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tottenham 4 Liverpool 0: Spurs run riot as nine-man Reds crumble at White Hart Lane |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2038770/Tottenham-4-Liverpool-0-Spurs-run-riot-man-Reds-crumble-White-Hart-Lane.html|date=18 September 2011|accessdate=18 September 2011|work=Daily Mail|first=Matt|last=Barlow|location=London}}</ref>

Adebayor also provided the assist for [[Rafael van der Vaart]]'s goal in their 2–1 [[North London derby]] win against former club Arsenal on 2 October.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gunners press self-destruct |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,,11065_3422897,00.html|date=2 October 2011|accessdate=21 November 2011|publisher=Sky Sports|first=Peter|last=Fraser}}</ref> He scored his fourth and fifth goal for Tottenham in their 2–0 win against [[Aston Villa F.C|Aston Villa]] on 21 November, the first with an overhead kick and the second after a mistake from Villa defender [[James Collins (footballer born 1983)|James Collins]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tottenham 2 – 0 Aston Villa|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/15716030.stm|date=21 November 2011|accessdate=21 November 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Arindam|last=Rej}}</ref> He scored another two goals in Tottenham's 3–1 win over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/26/west-brom-spurs-premier-league?newsfeed=true | title=West Bromwich Albion 1–3 Tottenham Hotspur | work=The Guardian | date=26 November 2011 | accessdate=27 November 2011 | location=London | first=Paul | last=Doyle}}</ref> Later on Adebayor went on to score a further two goals, one was a penalty at Stoke and one came in a derby against Chelsea where the scores ended up 1–1.

On 11 February 2012, Adebayor scored on a volley and supplied four assists in the 5–0 win over [[Newcastle United]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16884811 BBC Sport – Tottenham 5–0 Newcastle]. Bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref>
On 26 February his 28th Birthday, Adebayor converted a penalty against Arsenal to bring Spurs 2–0 up at the Emirates which ended in a 5–2 defeat for Tottenham.<ref>McNulty, Phil. (26 February 2012) [http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17093405 BBC Sport – Arsenal 5–2 Tottenham]. Bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref>
On 1 April Adebayor scored two goals in a 3–1 win over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tottenham 3 – 1 Swansea|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17503279|date=26 February 2012|accessdate=26 February 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 15 April 2012, Adebayor provided an assist for Gareth Bale in Tottenham's only goal in the 5–1 loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the FA Cup Semi-Final.<ref>McNulty, Phil. (15 April 2012) [http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17649443 BBC Sport – Tottenham 1–5 Chelsea]. Bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref>
Adebayor then went on to score goals in back to back games for Tottenham, scoring two against [[Bolton Wanderers]] in a 4–1 win at the Reebok Stadium<ref>Magowan, Alistair. (2 May 2012) [http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17836014 BBC Sport – Bolton 1–4 Tottenham]. Bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref> and converting a penalty against [[Aston Villa]] where the game ended 1–1.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17885326 BBC Sport – Aston Villa 1–1 Tottenham]. Bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref>

In the final game of his loan spell with Tottenham,<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/9257026/Tottenham-Hotspur-2-Fulham-0-match-report.html Tottenham Hotspur 2 Fulham 0: match report]. Telegraph. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref> Adebayor opened the scoring as Spurs defeated London rivals [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] 2–0 on 13 May to secure fourth place.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2012/may/13/tottenham-hotspur-fulham-premier-league Tottenham Hotspur 2–0 Fulham | Premier League match report | Football]. The Guardian. Retrieved 30 June 2012.</ref>

Adebayor finished the season as Tottenham's top goalscorer, with 18 goals (17 in the Premier League).

On 21 August 2012, Adebayor signed a permanent deal with Tottenham Hotspur in a deal worth £5m, after a protracted period of negotiations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ade Returns|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/spurs/News/ade-returns-21082012.page|publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tottenham Hotspur |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/9490747/Tottenham-confirm-signing-of-Emmanuel-Adebayor-from-Manchester-City-for-5m.html |title=Tottenham confirm signing of Emmanuel Adebayor from Manchester City in deal worth £5m |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=31 May 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref>

On 17 November 2012, Adebayor scored an early goal for Tottenham in a North London derby match against Arsenal to put them 1–0 up, but seven minutes later his challenge on [[Santi Cazorla]] saw him sent off by referee [[Howard Webb]]. Arsenal went on to win the match 5–2.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arsenal 5–2 Tottenham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20278355|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 November 2012}}</ref> On 1 January 2013, Adebayor scored his first home goal of the season for Spurs against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], with a header from an [[Aaron Lennon]] cross. Spurs eventually won 3–1. On 14 March 2013 Adebayor scored the decisive away goal that put Spurs through to the quarter final of the Europa League in an aggregate win against [[Internazionale]]. <ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21696151 BBC Sport – Inter Milan 4–1 Tottenham (agg 4–4)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He went on to shoot over the bar following a run-up with a decisive penalty in the following round against [[FC Basel]], which ultimately resulted in Spurs' elimination from the tournament.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22023547 BBC Sport – FC Basel 2–2 Tottenham (agg 4–4)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He scored a goal on 8 May against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in a 2–2 draw from outside the penalty box to bring the game level to 1–1.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22363107 BBC Sport – Chelsea 2–2 Tottenham<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He then scored the winning goal on the following Sunday (12 May 2013) to give Tottenham a 2–1 win at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on a cross from [[Clint Dempsey]] in the 83rd minute.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417723 BBC Sport – Stoke 1–2 Tottenham<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

After the sacking of [[André Villas-Boas]], who had told the striker to train with the youth team at the start of the [[2013–14 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2013–14]] season,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/10524275/Emmanuel-Adebayor-brought-in-from-cold-by-Tottenham-for-Capital-One-Cup-clash-with-West-Ham.html|title=Emmanuel Adebayor brought in from cold by Tottenham for Capital One Cup clash with West Ham|date=17 December 2013|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
Adebayor returned to the Tottenham team under [[Tim Sherwood]], scoring in a 2–1 [[2013–14 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]] quarter-final defeat at home to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25328568|title=Tottenham 1 2 West Ham|date=18 December 2013|work=BBC}}</ref> He went on to score eight goals in his next ten [[2013–14 Premier League|Premier League]] matches, with goals in wins against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jan/19/swansea-city-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league-match-report|title=Tottenham Hotspur's Emmanuel Adebayor stars in win at Swansea City|date=19 January 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref> [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26004450|title=Tottenham 1 0 Everton|date=9 February 2014|work=BBC}}</ref> and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26043687|title=Newcastle 4 0 Tottenham|date=13 February 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>

On 7 April 2014, Adebayor reached ten goals for the Premier League season, scoring twice in a 5–1 home win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26814762|title=Tottenham 5–1 Sunderland|date=7 April 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>

He ended the season as Spurs' top goalscorer with 14 goals from 25 appearances after scoring in in their final Premier League match on 11 May 2014, a 3–0 defeat of Aston Villa at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/first-team-profiles/emmanuel-adebayor/|title=Emmanuel Adeboayor|accessdate=14 May 2014|work=Tottenham Hotspur Football Club}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:Emmanuel Adebayor1.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Adebayor playing for [[Togo national football team|Togo]] in May 2006]]
Adebayor was also eligible to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] but chose to represent the country of his birth.<ref>''The list of Nigeria qualified players who, for various reasons, preferred to play for foreign countries is endless. Among them are [[Emmanuel Olisadebe]], [[Ugo Ehiogu]], [[Gabriel Agbonlahor]], [[Patrick Owomoyela]], Ugochukwu Onyewu, [[Stefano Okaka]] and Emmanuel Adebayor.'' ngrguardiannews, 12 April 2009</ref> Adebayor helped [[Togo national football team|Togo]] qualify for the [[2006 Africa Cup of Nations]] by scoring 11 goals in the qualifiers, more than any other player in the African qualifiers. On 10 February 2009, the Confederation of African Football (CAF) picked Adebayor as the [[African Footballer of the Year]] for 2008 at an awards ceremony held in Lagos, Nigeria. Adebayor beat final nominees [[Mohamed Aboutrika]] of [[Egypt]] and [[Ghana]]'s [[Michael Essien]] in a vote that involved the national team coaches of CAF's 54 member-nations. It was the first time a Togolese won the award as Africa's best player.

Adebayor helped Togo to qualify for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] in Germany and started all three group matches against [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]], [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] and [[France national football team|France]], but did not score any goals and Togo ended up in last place. Adebayor was made team captain after the finals.

He was called up for the [[2006 Africa Cup of Nations]], where he was a substitute for the country's first match, following a row with the coach. Adebayor first vowed to leave the tournament and return home, although he later resumed training with the side.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/4636070.stm |title=Adebayor future with Togo unclear |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2006 |accessdate=20 June 2010}}</ref>  Togo were eliminated after losing all three matches. He was dropped by Togo following the row over bonus payments.<ref name="Togo axe Adebayor and two others">{{cite news|title=Togo axe Adebayor and two others|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/6494073.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 March 2007|accessdate=25 March 2007}}</ref> However, Adebayor was brought back into the Togo team in September 2007. On 11 October 2008, he scored four goals in Togo's 6–0 hammering of [[Swaziland national football team|Swaziland]] during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|World Cup qualification]] rounds.

Despite being injured, Adebayor played for Togo against [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]]. Within this match he scored the only goal for Togo to seal the win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/2009/03/29/togo-1-cameroon-0-arsenal-s-emmanuel-adebayor-back-on-target-115875-21237638/ |title=Togo 1 Cameroon 0: Arsenal's Emmanuel Adebayor back on target |work=Daily Mirror |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=20 June 2010}}</ref>

On 8 January 2010, Adebayor was one of the players involved when the [[Togo national football team attack|Togo national team's bus came under a gunfire attack]] on the way to the [[Africa Cup of Nations]] in [[Angola]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8449319.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Togo footballers shot in ambush | date=8 January 2010 | accessdate=2 May 2010|archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqwKEcZV |archivedate = 17 January 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> The fatal attack, in which all the players survived but three other people were killed, led to Togo withdrawing from the tournament.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8449611.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Togo pulls team out of Africa Cup | date=9 January 2010 | accessdate=2 May 2010|archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqwKIFdd |archivedate = 17 January 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref> Adebayor consequently announced his retirement from international football on 12 April 2010 in a statement which read, "I have weighed up my feelings in the weeks and months since the attack and I am still haunted by the events which I witnessed on that horrible afternoon on the Togo team bus. We were just footballers going to play a football match and represent our country, yet we were attacked by people who wanted to kill us all. It is a moment I will never forget and one I never want to experience again."<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City striker Emmanuel Adebayor retires from international football |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=12 April 2010 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/mancity/7583196/Manchester-City-striker-Emmanuel-Adebayor-retires-from-international-football.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100416162450/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/mancity/7583196/Manchester-City-striker-Emmanuel-Adebayor-retires-from-international-football.html|archivedate=16 April 2010|accessdate=12 April 2010 | location=London}}</ref>

Adebayor subsequently returned to international duty in November 2011 following assurances from the Togo Football Federation regarding safety,<ref>{{cite news|last=Sannie |first=Ibrahim |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15661001.stm |title=Tottenham's Adebayor comes out of Togo retirement |publisher=BBC News |date=10 November 2011 |accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref> making his comeback in a 1–0 win over [[Guinea-Bissau national football team|Guinea-Bissau]] in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|2014 World Cup qualifier]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/15/emmanuel-adebayor-world-cup-qualifying |title=Emmanuel Adebayor in winning return for Togo in World Cup qualifying |work=The Guardian |date= 15 November 2011|accessdate=22 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>

==Punditry==
Adebayor was a [[Pundit (expert)|pundit]] for the [[BBC|BBC Sport]]'s [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] coverage.<ref>{{Cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jun/05/tv-radio-guide-world-cup-2010 | title=TV and radio guide: The best ways to follow the World Cup | first=Owen | last=Gibson | newspaper=[[The Guardian]]  | date=4 June 2010 | accessdate=21 June 2010 | location=London}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Adebayor is married and has a daughter named Kendra (born June 2010).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/emmanuel-adebayor-no-regrets-2377271.html |title=Emmanuel Adebayor: No Regrets |publisher=The Independent |date=29 October 2011 |accessdate=29 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/22/tottenham-emmanuel-adebayor-togo-federation |title=Tottenham's Emmanuel Adebayor blames Togo federation for late return |publisher=The Guardian |date=23 February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2013}}</ref>

Adebayor is a [[Christianity|Christian]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Adebayor on life, death and Lionel Messi|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/danwalker/2010/02/adebayor_chat_bowls_me_over.html}}</ref> Adebayor has spoken about his faith saying, "Everything I do in life I put in the hands of [[God in Christianity|God]], my creator. He gave me the chance to be where I am today and He’s the one that can take it all away from me. There is nothing more important for me than God." Adebayor could not walk for the first four years of his life. His mother took young Adebayor around Africa looking for a cure. Adebayor then spoke about his 'miracle' saying, "... I was in the church laying down and, around nine or ten o’clock on the Sunday morning, I could hear children playing outside. Suddenly somebody kicked a ball into the church. And the first person to stand up and run was me, because I wanted to get that ball."<ref>{{cite web|title=Arsenal striker Emmanuel Adebayor's football 'miracle' taught him to walk|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/arsenal/4444076/Arsenal-striker-Emmanuel-Adebayors-football-miracle-taught-him-to-walk.html}}</ref>
