'''Germaine "Kemy" Agustien''' (born 20 August 1986) is a Dutch-Curacaoan professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. He previously played for [[Willem II Tilburg|Willem II]], [[AZ (football club)|AZ]], [[Roda JC]] and [[RKC Waalwijk]] in the Netherlands and for [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in [[Football in England|English football]].<ref name=ClubStats>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootball.net/spieler_profil/kemy-agustien/2/ |title=Kemy Agustien » Club matches |work=WorldFootball.net |publisher=Heimspiel Medien |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref> An adaptable player, capable of playing anywhere in midfield, his preferred position is as one of two central midfielders.<ref name=interview>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1353878,00.html |title=Kemy Agustien Interview |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |date=30 July 2008 |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref>

== Club career ==
Born in [[Willemstad]], Netherlands Antilles,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootball.net/spieler_profil/kemy-agustien/ |title=Kemy Agustien |work=WorldFootball.net |publisher=Heimspiel Medien |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref> Agustien began his career in the youth system of Dutch club [[Willem II Tilburg|Willem II]].<ref name=Nieuws/> He played two seasons in that club's first team in the [[Eredivisie]], and appeared twice in the [[2005–06 UEFA Cup]].<ref name=ClubStats/> He signed for AZ in 2006, and was loaned to [[Roda JC]] for the 2006–07 season to gain more experience.<ref name=Nieuws>{{cite news |url=http://archive.is/Jah06 |title=AZ verhuurt aankoop Agustien aan Roda JC |language=Dutch |trans_title=AZ loan new signing Agustien to Roda JC |work=nieuws.nl |date=24 June 2006 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>

Agustien joined English [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in July 2008 on a season loan, with an option to make the deal permanent at the end of the [[2008-09 in English football|2008–09 season]] for a fee of €2&nbsp;million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/birmingham_city/7532995.stm |title=Birmingham land Agustien on loan  |publisher=BBC |date=30 July 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> He made his first-team debut in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] defeat at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 26 August 2008,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7576413.stm |title=Southampton 2-0 Birmingham |publisher=BBC |date=28 August 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> and played his first match in [[the Football League]] four days later in a 1–1 draw at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10412~43794,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120218033635/http://www.bcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10412~43794,00.html |archivedate=18 February 2012 |title=First Team Match Report: Norwich 1 Birmingham 1 |publisher= Birmingham City FC|date=30 August 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> Having missed pre-season training because of a [[athletic pubalgia|hernia]] operation, he did not adapt immediately to the pace and physicality of English football.<ref name=interview/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/im-getting-there-says-kemy-69157 |title=I'm getting there, says Kemy Agustien |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |first=Colin |last=Tattum |date=11 September 2008 |accessdate=13 October 2013}}</ref> He played 20 games in all competitions, but the second half of his season was dogged by injury. Birmingham manager [[Alex McLeish]] "couldn't commit [himself] to bringing him in for the money asked", so Agustien returned to AZ when his contract expired on 26 May 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1652033,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120218025408/http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1652033,00.html |archivedate=18 February 2012 |title=Squad rebuilding begins |publisher= Birmingham City FC|date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>

After his return to AZ, he was loaned to [[RKC Waalwijk]], newly promoted to the Eredivisie, for the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,,11906_5491185,00.html |title=AZ pair loaned to RKC |publisher=Sky Sports |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref> At the end of that season, he was released by AZ.<ref name=SwansTrial/>

Agustien went on trial to Polish [[Ekstraklasa]] side [[Wisła Kraków]] in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wisla.krakow.pl/pl/aktualnosci/kemy_agustien_na_testach/ |title=Kemy Agustien na testach |trans_title=Kemy Agustien on trial |language=Polish |publisher=Wisła Kraków SA |date=3 July 2010 |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref> Later he joined [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] of the English Championship on trial,<ref name=SwansTrial>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6279833,00.html |title=Agustien in Swans trial |publisher=Sky Sports |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=7 October 2010}}</ref> but sustained an injury in a pre-season match which delayed his signing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swanseacity.net/page/Latest/0,,10354~2107750,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120329044808/http://www.swanseacity.net/page/Latest/0,,10354~2107750,00.html |archivedate=29 March 2012 |title=Swans sweat over Kemy injury |publisher= Swansea City FC|date=1 August 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/swansea-city-could-close-signing-1901613 |title=Swansea City could be close to signing Scott Sinclair |first=Blair |last=Wood |newspaper=Western Mail |date=6 August 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> After passing what was described as a "tough" medical, Agustien signed a two-year contract with the Welsh club in October.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swanseacity.net/page/Latest/0,,10354~2176571,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120329050536/http://www.swanseacity.net/page/Latest/0,,10354~2176581,00.html |archivedate=29 March 2012 |title=Swans complete Lemy capture |publisher= Swansea City FC|date=7 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> He made his debut two weeks later, coming on for  [[Andrea Orlandi]] after 69 minutes as Swansea beat [[Leicester City]] 2–0.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Kemy-s-raring-cup-clash/story-12463160-detail/story.html |title=Kemy Agustien's raring to go for Carling Cup clash |first=Chris |last=Barney |work=This is South Wales |date=25 October 2010 |accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref>

By February 2011, Agustien was anxious for regular first-team football, and suggested that there had been interest from clubs in taking him on loan, but manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] considered him part of the Swansea squad.<ref>{{cite news|title=Agustien claims loan interest|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6764554/| publisher=Sky Sports|date=19 February 2011|accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref> Agustien signed on loan for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 8 March for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6801763,00.html|title=Palace take Agustien on loan|accessdate=8 March 2011|date=8 March 2011|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> He made his debut against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] in a 2–1 victory for Palace,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10323~51915,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20111206020235/http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10323~51915,00.html |archivedate=6 December 2011 |title=Crystal Palace vs Barnsley |publisher= Crystal Palace FC|date=2 April 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> and went on to play in the last eight matches of the season.

He made his Premier League debut for the newly promoted Swansea in a 4–0 loss against Manchester City,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/14440546.stm | publisher=BBC Sport |first=Aled |last=Williams | title=Man City 4-0 Swansea | date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref> but suffered a hamstring injury in September, and was restricted to one brief substitute appearance in the next three months.<ref>{{cite news|title=Swans suffer Agustien blow|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7173224/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=12 September 2011|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=48342&season_id=141 |title=Games played by Kemy Agustien in 2011/2012 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref> In the 1–1 draw with [[Queens Park Rangers]] at the end of December, Agustien started in central midfield, but following an injury to [[Àngel Rangel]] he spent the second half at right back, a position he had never played before; he was named man of the match:

{{Quote|I was a little frustrated because I think I was playing well in midfield. But it is not about me, it is about the team. I did my best for the team. If I can help the team by filling in that position, then that's fine|Agustien on his unfamiliar position.<ref>{{cite news|title=Agustien happy to help team |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7398886/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 December 2011|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref>}}

Ankle surgery in early March revealed further problems that kept Agustien out for the remainder of the season.<ref name=March2012>{{cite news|title=Agustien ruled out|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7558899/ |first=Graeme |last=Bailey |publisher=Sky Sports|date=2 March 2012|accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref> Rodgers confirmed that Agustien would be offered a contract extension despite his injuries,<ref name=March2012/> and in May he signed a new two-year deal with Swansea.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18122482|title=Kemy Agustien signs new Swansea City contract|date=18 May 2012|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> In the 2012-13 season was a big change for Swansea City, with change of management and new players. For Agustien, his injuries continued to haunt him, having missed five matches, due to an ankle injury.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kemy Agustien to miss five Swansea games with injury|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21088018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=18 January 2013|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> Despite the injury, he would make 18 appearance, it was his biggest appearance of the season in his Swansea's career.

Ahead of the 2013-14 season, Agustien, along with [[Alan Tate]], [[Luke Moore]] and [[Leroy Lita]], were left-out of the squad for the pre-season tour, which led their future uncertain.<ref>{{cite news|title=Future doubts for clutch of Swansea City stars as they are left out of pre-season tour|url=http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Future-doubts-clutch-Swansea-City-stars-left-pre/story-19477954-detail/story.html#axzz2aqW2LHjw|publisher=This is South Wales|date=4 July 2013|accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref> During July 2013, Agustien transferred to [[Football League Championship]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] signing a two-year contract,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10576394.Albion_capture_Agustien/|title=Albion capture Agustien|publisher=The Argus|date=2013-07-27|accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref> however the deal was delayed for a number of days whilst awaiting international clearance which was finally completed on 1 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/news/article/albion-complete-kemy-deal-959562.aspx|title=Albion complete Kemy deal|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|date=2013-08-01|accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/KemyAgustien/status/362883705586454530|title=Finally International clearance. Wish swansea players all the best tonight. They've more then friends for me. Wish them all the best tonight|publisher=Twitter|date=2013-08-01|accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref> Agustien made his debut for Brighton during a pre-season friendly game against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] which finished 1–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10580566.Agustien_in_line_to_face_Norwich/|title=Agustien in line to face Norwich|publisher=The Argus|date=2013-07-30|accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref>

==International career==
At international level, he was a member of the [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship squads#Netherlands|Netherlands under-20 squad]] for the [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship]], where he played in two of the group-stage matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=104/edition=9102/matches/match=91020002/report.html |title=FIFA World Youth Championship Netherlands 2005: Match Report: Netherlands – Japan |publisher=FIFA |date=10 June 2005 |accessdate=8 October 2010| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mq2FcutT | archivedate = 16 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=104/edition=9102/matches/match=91020032/report.html |title=FIFA World Youth Championship Netherlands 2005: Match Report: Netherlands – Benin |publisher=FIFA |date=18 June 2005 |accessdate=8 October 2010| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mq2FgIBe | archivedate = 16 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> He played for the Dutch Olympic squad that reached the final of the 2006 [[Toulon Tournament]]; Agustien converted his penalty as his team lost in a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/toulon06.html |title=Tournoi Espoirs de Toulon 2006 |first=Antonio |last=Zea |publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation (RSSSF) |date=2 August 2007 |accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref> He played again, and scored, at the [[2007 Toulon Tournament|2007 edition]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/toulon07.html |title=Tournoi Espoirs de Toulon 2007 |first=Erik |last=Garin |publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation (RSSSF) |date=6 June 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2010| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqoQW9tB | archivedate = 17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> and also played for the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|under-21 team]], including two appearances in qualifying matches for the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2009 European under-21 championships]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/printoutfiles/competitions/under21/2009/e/e_01_md.pdf |title=2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship Tournament Stats Pack |format=PDF |publisher=UEFA |date=13 June 2009 |accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref> Named in the Netherlands' preliminary 37-man squad for the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics - Men's team squads#Netherlands|2008 Olympics]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vi.nl/Nieuws-item/147779/Vormer-en-De-Ruiter-nieuw-in-olympisch-elftal.htm |title=Vormer en De Ruiter nieuw in olympisch elftal |language=Dutch |trans_title=First callups for Vormer and De Ruiter to the Olympic squad |work=Voetbal International |date=25 January 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref> he was not selected for [[Beijing]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Agustien%27s+Olympic+letdown+a+spur+to+do+well+for+Blues%3b+FOOTBALL%3a...-a0182055473 |title=Agustien's Olympic letdown a spur to do well for Blues |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Post |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref>

In 2014, Agustien decided to represent his country of birth, receiving his first call-up for the [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] senior team ahead of the [[2014 Caribbean Cup]] in Jamaica. He was however forced to withdraw from the final squad for the tournament due to injury, having yet to make his debut for the national team.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thefootballwelike.com/en/previews-reviews/preview-2014-caribbean-cup-group-a/ |title=Preview: 2014 Caribbean Cup – Group A |first=Maxi |last=Lozzo |newspaper=The Football We Like |date=12 November 2014 |accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Agustien revealed he almost died from a serious car accident after his car start flipping twice following a loss of control.<ref>{{cite news|title=Swansea City star Kemy Agustien reveals near-death crash behind recent absence|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/swansea-city-star-kemy-agustien-2017392|publisher=Wales Online|date=15 November 2012|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> In April 2013, Agustien was banned from driving for 12 months and picked up 39 points.<ref>{{cite news|title=No longer in the engine room: Swansea midfielder Agustien banned from driving for picking up a staggering 39 points... that's just two less than his team!|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2310465/Swanseas-Kemy-Agustien-picks-39-driving-points.html|publisher=Daily Mail|date=17 April 2013|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref>

'''Patrick Agyemang''' (born 29 September 1980) is an English-born [[Ghana|Ghanaian]] professional footballer who plays as a [[Striker (association football)|striker]].

Agyemang began his career at [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]], progressing through the club's youth system. He was loaned out to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in October 1999 for three months, before returning to his parent club. Agyemang went on to play regularly for Wimbledon for the next four seasons. He joined [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] in January 2004, spending ten months with the club. He attracted the interest of [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in November 2004, who signed Agyemang for a fee of £350,000. He spent four seasons at Preston, before joining [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in 2008. He was part of the QPR team that earned promotion to the [[Premier League]] during the [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11 season]]. During the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]], Agyemang was loaned out to Championship side [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on a one-month loan deal. He was loaned out for a second time in January 2012, this time joining Stevenage on loan until the end of the 2011–12 season. Agyemang signed for Stevenage on a permanent basis in August 2012. In February 2013, Agyemang joined Portsmouth on loan for the rest of the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13 campaign]]. He signed for the club permanently in May 2013. He has also been [[Cap (sport)|capped]] twice by the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana national team]], scoring one goal.

==Club career==
===Early career===
Born in [[Walthamstow]], [[London]], Agyemang began his career at [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]], where he came through the [[Youth system|youth ranks]].<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> In October 1999, having made no [[first team]] appearances for Wimbledon, Agyemang was loaned out to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on a three-month loan deal. He made his debut in a 2–1 home defeat to [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] on 19 October 1999, coming on as a 56th minute substitute in the match. Agyemang made 12 appearances for Brentford during the three-month spell, of which three were starting appearances.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 1999/2000"/> He returned to Wimbledon in January 2000.<ref name="Patrick Agyemang – ESPN">{{Cite web
| title = Patrick Agyemang – ESPN
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/5289/patrick-agyemang?cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| accessdate = 8 March 2012}}</ref>

The [[2000–01 in English football|2000–01 season]] was Agyemang's breakthrough season at Wimbledon, with the player starting the first game of the season, a 0–0 home draw with [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]].<ref name="Millwall sign QPR's Patrick Agyemang on loan">{{cite news
| title = Millwall sign QPR's Patrick Agyemang on loan
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15260300
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 13 October 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang was almost ever-present during the campaign, and he scored his first professional goal in February 2001, scoring in a 2–2 away draw against [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]]. The goal sparked a run of five goals in nine appearances for Agyemang, as he ended the season with five goals in 37 appearances.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2000/2001"/> The following season, Agyemang scored four goals in 35 games as Wimbledon finished in ninth place in [[2001–02_in_English_football#Nationwide_League_Division_One|Division One]] despite financial difficulties.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2001/2002"/><ref name="» English Division One 2001–2002 : Table">{{cite web
| title = » English Division One 2001–2002 : Table
| url = http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/division-one/2001-2002
| publisher = Statto.com
| accessdate = 22 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang scored six goals in 36 games during the 2002–03 season,<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2002/2003"/> before scoring seven goals during the first half of the 2003–04 season.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2003/2004"/> Due to Wimbledon's financial problems, Agyemang was sold to Division One rivals [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] in January 2004 for a fee of £150,000.<ref name="On this day">{{cite news
| title = On this day
| url = http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/page/OnthisDayArticle/0,,10416~2258520,00.html
| publisher = Gillingham F.C
| accessdate = 22 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Gills complete Agyemang swoop">{{cite news
| title = Gills complete Agyemang swoop
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11737/2288082/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 2 January 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang stated he "never wanted to leave Wimbledon", but understood the financial problems the club were facing.<ref name="Agyemang in Gills talks">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang in Gills talks
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11737/2288184/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 2 January 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> Wimbledon manager [[Stuart Murdoch (football manager)|Stuart Murdoch]] revealed he was told he could not play Agyemang in certain games towards the end of his time at the club "in case injury jeopardised the deal", with the club desperately in need of the funds from his sale.<ref name="Agyemang in Gills talks"/>

Agyemang made his Gillingham debut in a 2–1 away loss to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 17 January 2004,<ref name="Derby County 2–1 Gillingham">{{cite news
| title = Derby County 2–1 Gillingham
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=108778&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 17 January 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> and scored his first goal for the club two weeks later &mdash; netting the only goal of the game as Gillingham beat [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] 1–0 at [[Priestfield Stadium|Priestfield]].<ref name="Gillingham 1–0 Bradford City">{{cite news
| title = Gillingham 1–0 Bradford City
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=108873&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 31 January 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He went on to score a further five goals during the latter stages of the 2003–04 season, which included the first brace of his career against [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]],<ref name="Gillingham 3–0 Walsall">{{cite news
| title = Gillingham 3–0 Walsall
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=109552&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 12 April 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> as well as the winner against his former employers, Wimbledon.<ref name="MK Dons 1–2 Gillingham">{{cite news
| title = MK Dons 1–2 Gillingham
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=109675&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 24 April 2012
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> The following season, Agyemang scored twice for Gillingham in 14 appearances in the opening months of the campaign,<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2004/2005"/><ref name="Coventry 2–2 Gillingham">{{cite news
| title = Coventry 2–2 Gillingham
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=152545&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 15 September 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> before attracting the interest of fellow Championship side [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref name="Preston agree Agyemang fee">{{cite news
| title = Preston agree Agyemang fee
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11697/2316660/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 14 November 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref>

===Preston North End===
In November 2004, Preston announced they had agreed a fee for Agyemang, with the transfer worth in the region of £350,000.<ref name="Preston agree Agyemang fee"/> The transfer was officially completed on 16 November 2004.<ref name="North End seal striker deal">{{cite news
| title = North End seal striker deal
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11697/2316941/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 16 November 2004
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Preston agree deal for Agyemang |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/p/preston/4008161.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 November 2004 |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref> He made his Preston debut in a 1–0 away win against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 19 November 2004, playing the first 73 minutes of the match.<ref name="Cardiff 0–1 Preston">{{cite news
| title = Cardiff 0–1 Preston
| url = http://www.pnefc.net/page/MatchReport/0,,10362~27373,00.html
| publisher = Preston North End F.C.
| date = 19 November 2004
| accessdate = 24 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang scored his first goal for Preston in the club's 3–0 home win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in December 2004.<ref name="Preston 3–0 Reading">{{cite news
| title = Preston 3–0 Reading
| url = http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10306~27193,00.html
| publisher = Reading F.C.
| date = 28 December 2004
| accessdate = 24 April 2012}}</ref> He went on to make 31 appearances in his first season with the Lancashire side, chipping in with four goals, but ultimately finished the campaign behind [[Richard Cresswell]] and [[David Nugent]] in the pecking order.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2004/2005"/> Agyemang was almost ever present in Preston's 2005–06 campaign, scoring six times in 49 matches, including playing in both of Preston's play-off games &mdash; with Preston losing by a 3–1 aggregate scoreline to [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].<ref name="Leeds 1–1 Preston">{{cite news
| title = Leeds 1–1 Preston
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4972588.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 5 May 2005
| accessdate = 24 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Preston 0–2 Leeds (agg 1–3)">{{cite news
| title = Preston 0–2 Leeds (agg 1–3)
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4972964.stm
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 8 May 2005
| accessdate = 24 April 2012}}</ref> The six goals he scored during the season meant he was the club's second highest goalscorer for the season.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2004/2005"/>

Agyemang spent much of his first seasons at [[Deepdale]] making appearances from the substitute's bench.<ref name="Patrick Agyemang – Soccerbase">{{cite news
| title = Patrick Agyemang – Soccerbase
| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=16754
| publisher = Soccerbase
| accessdate = 26 April 2012}}</ref> However, injuries to key players saw him start games early in the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07 season]], scoring a memorable winner against [[West Bromwich Albion]].<ref name="Preston 1–0 West Brom">{{cite news
| title = Preston 1–0 West Brom
| url = http://www.wba.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10366~33043,00.html
| publisher = West Bromwich Albion F.C.
| date = 12 September 2006
| accessdate = 26 April 2012}}</ref> He scored seven times in 33 appearances during the campaign,<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2006/2007"/> with Preston narrowly missing out on the play-offs by a point.<ref name="English League Championship 2006–2007 : Table">{{cite news
| title = English League Championship 2006–2007 : Table
| url = http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/league-championship/2006-2007
| publisher = Statto.com
| accessdate = 26 April 2012}}</ref> The [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]] witnessed Agyemang score four goals in 22 appearances for Preston, including a brace in a 5–1 home win against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref name="Preston 5–1 Southampton">{{cite news
| title = Preston 5–1 Southampton
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7019679.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 2 October 2007
| accessdate = 26 April 2012}}</ref>

===Queens Park Rangers===
In January 2008, Agyemang was linked to both [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], with his Preston contract set to expire in the summer of 2008.<ref name="Foxes in hunt for Agyemang">{{cite news
| title = Foxes in hunt for Agyemang
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11688/2969730/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 13 December 2007
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="QPR line up North End striker">{{cite news
| title = QPR line up North End striker
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11676/3015816/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 2 January 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He ultimately signed for Queens Park Rangers, for a nominal fee on 3 January 2008, on a four and a half-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |title=Agyemang's QPR transfer confirmed |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/p/preston/7167699.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 January 2008 |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Agyemang joins Rangers">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang joins Rangers
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/news/11062/3019131/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 3 January 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang made his QPR debut just two days after signing for the club, coming on as a second-half substitute in the club's narrow 1–0 [[FA Cup]] defeat away to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref name="Chelsea 1–0 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Chelsea 1–0 QPR
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=232336&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 5 January 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> In the club's next match, he scored his first goal in a 2–1 away defeat against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].<ref name="Sheff Utd 2–1 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Sheff Utd 2–1 QPR
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=220159&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 12 January 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He went on to score a further seven goals in five league games, the richest goalscoring form of his career.<ref name="QPR 2–0 Barnsley">{{cite news
| title = QPR 2–0 Barnsley
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=220202&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 19 January 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="QPR 3–0 Bristol City">{{cite news
| title = QPR 3–0 Bristol City
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=220318&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 2 February 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Southampton 2–3 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Southampton 2–3 QPR
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=220368&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 9 February 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="QPR 2–4 Burnley">{{cite news
| title = QPR 2–4 Burnley
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=220400&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 12 February 2008
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He made 18 appearances for QPR during the second half of the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]], scoring nine goals.<ref name="QPR 2007/2008 Player Appearances">{{cite news
| title = QPR 2007/2008 Player Appearances
| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2093&teamTabs=stats
| publisher = Soccerbase
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> The [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09 season]] witnessed Agyemang struggle for starts at QPR, with the forward making just twelve starting appearances during the campaign, and 23 appearances in total, scoring two goals.<ref name="QPR 2008/2009 Player Appearances">{{cite news
| title = QPR 2008/2009 Player Appearances
| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2093&teamTabs=stats
| publisher = Soccerbase
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref>

In January 2010, after struggling for first-team appearances at QPR, Agyemang signed on loan for Championship side [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] until the end of the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10 season]].<ref name="Bristol City sign QPR striker Patrick Agyemang on loan">{{cite news
| title = Bristol City sign QPR striker Patrick Agyemang on loan
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_city/8478927.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 25 January 2010
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Robins swoop for Agyemang">{{cite news
| title = Robins swoop for Agyemang
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/5884354/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 25 January 2010
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He made his first start for Bristol City in a 6–0 home defeat to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]],<ref name="Bristol City 0–6 Cardiff City">{{cite news
| title = Bristol City 0–6 Cardiff City
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8470722.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 26 January 2010
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> and went on to make seven appearances during an injury-hit four months with the club.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2009/2010"/> He returned to the QPR team for their successful [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11 season]], scoring his first goal of the season in a 2–2 draw away at [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]<ref name="Derby County 2–2 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Derby County 2–2 QPR
| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=308289&cc=5739
| publisher = ESPN Soccernet
| date = 28 August 2010
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> &mdash; the goal came in injury time and helped QPR maintain their unbeaten start to the season.<ref name="Derby 2–2 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Derby 2–2 QPR
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8940387.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 28 August 2010
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> A stress fracture of his tibia would ultimately rule Agyemang out for the majority of the season.<ref name="Agyemang set for lengthy lay-off">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang set for lengthy lay-off
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6638130/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 6 January 2011
| accessdate = 23 April 2012}}</ref> He went on to make 19 appearances in the league, all of them coming off the bench, as QPR won promotion to the Premier League.<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2010/2011">{{cite web
| title = Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2010/2011 
| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=16754&season_id=140
| publisher = Soccerbase
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref>

Following the signing of new strikers [[DJ Campbell]] and [[Jay Bothroyd]],<ref name="Jay Bothroyd joins Queens Park Rangers on free transfer">{{cite news
| title = Jay Bothroyd joins Queens Park Rangers on free transfer
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14135536
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 13 July 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="QPR sign DJ Campbell from Blackpool on two-year deal">{{cite news
| title = QPR sign DJ Campbell from Blackpool on two-year deal
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14340681
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 4 August 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang found first-team football hard to come by, although he did start in the club's first away game of the season, a 1–0 win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] at [[Goodison Park]].<ref name="Everton 0–1 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Everton 0–1 QPR
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14514555
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 20 August 2011
| accessdate = 25 April 2012}}</ref> The following week, on 27 August 2011, he played the whole match as QPR lost 2–0 away to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], which would ultimately be Agyemang's final QPR appearance for the season.<ref name="Wigan 2–0 QPR">{{cite news
| title = Wigan 2–0 QPR
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14600485
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 27 August 2011
| accessdate = 25 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang was made available for loan in October 2011.<ref name="Agyemang available for loan">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang available for loan
| url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7223039/
| publisher = Sky Sports
| date = 4 October 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref> He subsequently joined Championship team [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on a 28-day loan deal on 13 October 2011.<ref name="Millwall sign QPR's Patrick Agyemang on loan"/><ref name="Agyemang pens Lions loan deal">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang pens Lions loan deal 
| url = http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~2480579,00.html
| publisher = Queens Park Rangers F.C.
| date = 13 October 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang made his Millwall debut two days after signing, on 15 October, playing the first 45 minutes in a 1–1 away draw against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref name="Middlesbrough 1–1 Millwall">{{cite news
| title = Middlesbrough 1–1 Millwall
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15226050
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 15 October 2011
| accessdate = 15 April 2012}}</ref> He made one further appearance during his loan spell, a late substitute appearance against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], and returned to QPR in November 2011.<ref name="Millwall 1–1 Brighton">{{cite news
| title = Millwall 1–1 Brighton
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15252395

===Stevenage===
In March 2012, after four months without first-team football, Agyemang joined [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]], on loan until the end of the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]].<ref name="Stevenage complete loan move for QPR striker">{{cite news
| title = Stevenage complete loan move for QPR striker
| url = http://www.stevenagefc.com/page/LatestNewsDetail/0,,10839~2641129,00.html
| publisher = Stevenage F.C.
| date = 8 March 2012
| accessdate = 8 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Pat pens Stevenage loan">{{cite news
| title = Pat pens Stevenage loan
| url = http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~2639489,00.html
| publisher = Queens Park Rangers F.C.
| date = 8 March 2012
| accessdate = 8 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Stevenage sign Patrick Agyemamg on loan from QPR">{{cite news
| title = Stevenage sign Patrick Agyemamg on loan from QPR
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17304317
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 8 March 2012
| accessdate = 8 March 2012}}</ref> The move re-united Agyemang with [[Gary Smith (footballer born 1968)|Gary Smith]], who had previously coached him at Wimbledon.<ref name="Stevenage complete loan move for QPR striker"/> He made his Stevenage debut two days after joining the club, on 10 March, playing the first 61 minutes in Stevenage's 2–2 home draw against [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]].<ref name="Stevenage 2–2 Chesterfield">{{cite news
| title = Stevenage 2–2 Chesterfield
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17243587
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 10 March 2012
| accessdate = 10 March 2012}}</ref> Agyemang scored his first goal for Stevenage in a 6–0 away win against [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]], latching onto [[Jamaal Lascelles]] through pass before scoring with a "tidy finish".<ref name="Yeovil 0–6 Stevenage">{{cite news
| title = Yeovil 0–6 Stevenage
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17643247
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 14 April 2012
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Yeovil Town 0–6 Stevenage FC">{{cite news
| title = Yeovil Town 0–6 Stevenage FC
| url = http://www.stevenagefc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10839~58970,00.html
| publisher = Stevenage F.C.
| date = 14 April 2012
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> He also assisted [[Luke Freeman]]'s first goal in the same match.<ref name="Yeovil Town 0–6 Stevenage FC"/> Agyemang's fitness improved vastly during his time at Stevenage, and he went on to make 15 appearances for the club as they narrowly lost in the play-off semi-final to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2011/2012"/><ref name="Sheffield United 1–0 Stevenage">{{cite news

| accessdate = 21 May 2012}}</ref> On returning to QPR, it was announced that Agyemang would leave the club when his contract expired in June 2012.<ref name="Hill offered new deal">{{cite news
| title = Hill offered new deal
| url = http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~2778621,00.html
| publisher = Queens Park Rangers F.C.
| date = 21 May 2012
| accessdate = 21 May 2012}}</ref>

Agyemang spent the early stages of pre-season ahead of the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13 season]] training with Stevenage, and went on the club's pre-season tour of [[Ireland]].<ref name="Stevenage 7–0 St James's Gate">{{cite news
| title = Stevenage 7–0 St James's Gate
| url = http://www.stevenagefc.com/news/article/st-james-gate-match-report-257999.aspx

| publisher = ExtraTime
| date = 24 July 2012
| accessdate = 31 August 2012}}</ref> In August 2012, he went on a week's trial with [[Wits University F.C.|Bidvest Wits]] of the [[Premier Soccer League]] in [[South Africa]].<ref name="Ex-QPR striker Patrick Agyemang at Bidvest Wits">{{cite news

===Portsmouth===
Having made 16 appearances for Stevenage during the first half of the season, without finding the scoresheet, Agyemang joined [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on a one-month loan deal in February 2013.<ref name="Therry Racon, Patrick Agyemang, John Akinde join Portsmouth">{{cite news
| title = Therry Racon, Patrick Agyemang, John Akinde join Portsmouth
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21369414
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 8 February 2013
| accessdate = 16 February 2013}}</ref> He made his first appearance for Portsmouth in a 2–0 defeat to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on 9 February, playing the first 65 minutes of the match.<ref name="Bournemouth 2–0 Portsmouth">{{cite news
| title = Bournemouth 2–0 Portsmouth
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21311502
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 9 February 2013
| accessdate = 3 March 2013}}</ref> Agyemang scored his first goal for the club during his sixth appearance, on 2 March, finding the bottom corner of the goal after shooting on the turn in a 2–1 away victory against [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]].<ref name="Crewe 1–2 Portsmouth">{{cite news
| title = Crewe 1–2 Portsmouth
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21556921
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 2 March 2013
| accessdate = 3 March 2013}}</ref> He also assisted Portsmouth's other goal in the match, as they ended a run of 23-games without a win.<ref name="Crewe 1–2 Portsmouth">{{cite news
| title = Crewe 1–2 Portsmouth
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21556921
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 2 March 2013
| accessdate = 3 March 2013}}</ref> Agyemang's loan deal was extended for a further month on 8 March 2013.<ref name="Agyemang extends loan stay">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang extends loan stay
| url = http://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/LatestNews/news/Agyemang-Extends-Loan-Stay-4199.aspx
| publisher = Portsmouth F.C.
| date = 8 March 2013
| accessdate = 8 March 2013}}</ref> He scored his second goal for the club in his tenth appearance on 23 March, heading in [[Liam Walker]]'s cross with fifteen minutes to go in a 2–0 victory over [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] at [[Fratton Park]].<ref name="Portsmouth 2–0 Coventry">{{cite news
| title = Portsmouth 2–0 Coventry
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21811726
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 23 March 2013
| accessdate = 23 March 2013}}</ref> Agyemang added a third goal to his Portsmouth tally on the final day of the 2012–13 season, scoring from close range in Portsmouth's 3–2 away defeat to [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on 27 April 2013.<ref name="Shrewsbury 3–2 Portsmouth">{{cite news
| title = Shrewsbury 3–2 Portsmouth
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22228989
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 27 April 2013
| accessdate = 28 April 2013}}</ref> Although Portsmouth were relegated to [[Football League Two|League Two]] during his time on loan with the club,<ref name="Portsmouth relegation: Guy Whittingham remains positive">{{cite news
| title = Portsmouth relegation: Guy Whittingham remains positive
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22182724
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 17 April 2013
| accessdate = 29 April 2013}}</ref> his impressive performances were described as a "critical reason for the marked improvement" as Portsmouth ended the season in good form.<ref name="Agyemang: Fans’ faith in me is key">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang: Fans’ faith in me is key
| url = http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/agyemang-fans-faith-in-me-is-key-1-4931884
| publisher = ''The News''
| date = 25 March 2013
| accessdate = 29 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="Agyemang is main man for Pompey">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang is main man for Pompey
| url = http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/agyemang-is-main-man-for-pompey-1-4936566
| publisher = ''The News''
| date = 26 March 2013
| accessdate = 29 April 2013}}</ref> He made 15 appearances during the loan spell,<ref name="Games played by Patrick Agyemang in 2012/2013"/> and expressed a desire to remain at Portsmouth on a permanent basis.<ref name="Agyemang keen on Pompey stay">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang keen on Pompey stay
| url = http://www.football-league.co.uk/league1/news/20130423/agyemang-keen-on-pompey-stay_2293324_3154377
| publisher = The Football League
| date = 23 April 2013
| accessdate = 28 April 2013}}</ref> Shortly after the end of the season, Agyemang agreed a two-year deal with Portsmouth, joining the club officially on 1 July, after his Stevenage contract expired.<ref name="Striker agrees two-year Pompey deal">{{cite news
| title = Striker agrees two-year Pompey deal
| url = http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/striker-agrees-two-year-pompey-deal-1-5053797
| publisher = ''Portsmouth News''
| date = 4 May 2013
| accessdate = 4 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="Portsmouth agree deals for Patrick Agyemang and Phil Smith">{{cite news
| title = Portsmouth agree deals for Patrick Agyemang and Phil Smith
| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22449947
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 8 May 2013
| accessdate = 8 May 2013}}</ref>

On 24 March 2015, after a period on loan at [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]], Agyemang was left Pompey in a mutual consent.

==International career==
Agyemang made his international debut for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] against [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] on 30 May 2003,<ref name="England-based Duo To Play For Stars">{{cite news
| title = England-based Duo To Play For Stars
| url = http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=37090
| publisher = GhanaWeb
| date = 30 May 2003
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> in the 4-Nation LG Cup in [[Abuja]], with Nigeria winning the match 3–1.<ref name="LG Cup Four Nations Tournament (Nigeria) 2003">{{cite news
| title = LG Cup Four Nations Tournament (Nigeria) 2003
| url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesl/lgcup1-03.html
| publisher = RSSSF
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="Ghana Debut For England-Based Duo">{{cite news
| title = Ghana Debut For England-Based Duo
| url = http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=37304
| publisher = GhanaWeb
| date = 3 June 2003
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> He scored Ghana's solitary goal in the match, netting just three minutes into his debut.<ref name="LG Cup Four Nations Tournament (Nigeria) 2003"/> 

He was named in Ghana's 40-man preliminary squad ahead of the [[2006 Africa Cup of Nations]], although failed to make the [[2006_African_Cup_of_Nations_(squads)#.C2.A0Ghana|final squad]].<ref name="Agyemang call-up delight">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang call-up delight
| url = http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=99471
| publisher = GhanaWeb
| date = 16 February 2006
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> In February 2006, Agyemang was called up to play for Ghana in the pre-[[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] international friendly against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] on 1 March 2006, played in the [[United States]].<ref name="Agyemang call-up delight"/><ref name="Mexico 1 Ghana 0">{{cite news
| title = Mexico 1 Ghana 0
| url = http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=100267
| publisher = GhanaWeb
| date = 2 March 2006
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> He started the match, playing 74 minutes before being substituted for [[Alex Tachie-Mensah]].<ref name="Mexico 1 Ghana 0"/> Despite impressing in the friendly,<ref name="Agyemang bids for Ghana place">{{cite news
| title = Agyemang bids for Ghana place
| url = http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=102710
| publisher = GhanaWeb
| date = 14 April 2006
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref> Agyemang did not make Ghana's [[2006_FIFA_World_Cup_squads#Ghana|23-man squad]].<ref name="World Cup 2006 – Ghana">{{cite news
| title = World Cup 2006 – Ghana
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/teams/ghana/default.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| accessdate = 14 April 2012}}</ref>

'''Gareth Ainsworth''' (born 10 May 1973) is an [[English people|English]] former professional [[association football|footballer]] who is manager at [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]].

A former youth player at [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], the [[midfielder]], who is known for his crossing ability, won a move to [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in 1992 after impressing at non-league [[Northwich Victoria F.C.|Northwich Victoria]]. He moved on to [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]], who in turn loaned him back to Northwich Victoria. He returned to Preston North End in 1993, and established himself in the first team during his second spell at the club. Sold on to [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] in October 1995 for a £25,000 fee, his performances at Lincoln earned him a place on the PFA [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]] in [[1996–97 Football League|1996–97]], and also won him a £500,000 move to [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in September 1997. After being named as the [[Port Vale F.C. Player of the Year]] in 1998, he was sold on to [[Premier League]] [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] for £2 million in October 1998. He was dogged by injuries at the club, and following loan spells with Preston North End and [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], he moved on to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] for a nominal fee in March 2003. He signed with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in June 2003, after went on to spent seven years with the club. During his time at QPR he helped the club to win promotion out of the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] in [[2003–04 Football League|2003–04]], and twice served as caretaker-manager.

He joined Wycombe Wanderers in February 2010, following a short loan period. He was named in the PFA [[Football League Two|League Two]] Team of the Year in [[2010–11 Football League|2010–11]], as Wycombe won promotion out of the division. He was appointed as the club's manager in November 2012, after a short period as caretaker-manager. He retired as a player to concentrate on his management duties in April 2013.

==Playing career==

===Early career===
Ainsworth started his career as a trainee with [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] club [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], but despite forming a useful partnership with [[Peter Thorne (footballer)|Peter Thorne]] he was not offered professional terms at the end of his two year training period.<ref name="double">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/2854921.stm|title=Cardiff make double signing|date=17 March 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He dropped into the [[Football Conference]] with [[Northwich Victoria F.C.|Northwich Victoria]], scoring his first goal in the 3–1 home victory over [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] on 26 October 1991. His form attracted the attention of [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] club [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] and, in January 1992, they offered him a second chance at the professional game. Released at the end of the [[1991–92 Football League|1991–92]] season, Ainsworth joined [[Football League First Division|First Division]] [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] under the management of [[John Beck (footballer)|John Beck]]. Ainsworth had a spell on loan with former club Northwich Victoria, making his second debut for the "Vics" in a 2–1 home victory over [[Bromsgrove Rovers F.C.|Bromsgrove Rovers]] on 5 September 1992. Beck was sacked by Cambridge in October 1992 but was swiftly appointed manager at Preston North End, and in December returned to the Abbey Ground to sign Ainsworth.

===Preston===
Ainsworth's second spell with Preston lasted three years. Preston reached the Third Division play-off final in [[1994 Football League Third Division play-off Final|1994]], and Ainsworth played in the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]] final, but could not prevent [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] winning the game 4–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chairboys.ndirect.co.uk/history/1993-1994/may1994-preston.htm|title=Retro - A look back on the 1993/94 season May 1994 - Promotion via the Play-off's at Wembley|work=chairboys.ndirect.co.uk|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> Preston reached the play-offs again the following year, but exited at the semi-final stage with a 2–0 aggregate defeat to [[Bury F.C.|Bury]].

Beck left Preston following the disappointments at the play-offs, and was appointed manager at Third Division rivals [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]].

===Lincoln===
In October 1995 he signed Ainsworth for a third time, this time for a fee of £25,000. In [[1996–97 Football League|1996–97]], Ainsworth scored 22 goals to make him the division's second-highest goalscorer after [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]]'s [[Graeme Jones]]. For this achievement he was named on the PFA's Third Division [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. A popular player at [[Sincil Bank]], Ainsworth was twice Player of the Season and was voted fourth in the club's top 100 legends after a poll conducted in May 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redimps.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LeagueLegends/0,,10440~1022830,00.html|title=#4 – Gareth Ainsworth|publisher=Lincoln City F.C. Official Website|accessdate=12 September 2008}}</ref>

===Port Vale===
In September 1997 he signed for [[John Rudge]]'s First Division [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] for a [[List of Port Vale F.C. records and statistics|club record]] £500,000 fee. He became the club's [[Port Vale F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] for his performances in the [[1997–98 Port Vale F.C. season|1997–98]] season. He was though criticized for an 'ugly' tackle on [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]'s [[Dane Whitehouse]] in November that resulted in the player's early retirement due to a serious leg injury sustained from the challenge.<ref>{{cite web|title=Port Vale 0 Sheffield United 0|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/sheffu/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/97/11/22/SOCCER_Port_Vale_Lead.html&TEAMHD=sheffu&DIV=nat1&TEAM=SHEFFIELD--UNITED&RH=Sheffield--United&PREV_SEASON=1996&BID=|work=sportinglife.com|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Riley|first=Catherine|title=Football: Wright set to miss FA Cup semi-final|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-wright-set-to-miss-fa-cup-semifinal-1153613.html|accessdate=8 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=31 March 1998}}</ref>

===Wimbledon===
He moved to [[Premier League]] side [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] in November 1998 for a £2 million fee, again a [[List of Port Vale F.C. records and statistics|club record]] for Port Vale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/news/Port-Vale-Rudge-huge-influence-career-says-Ainsworth/article-2916367-detail/article.html|title=Port Vale: Rudge was huge influence on career, says Gareth Ainsworth|last=Shaw|first=Steve|date=20 November 2010|work=The Sentinel|accessdate=20 November 2010}}</ref> His time at Wimbledon would be dominated by struggles again injury. He played just eight times in the [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99]] season, failing to score. He was limited to just two appearances in [[1999–2000 in English football|1999–2000]], though in the first of these, a 3–3 draw with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] at [[St James' Park]], he scored two goals, including a last minute equaliser.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/426645.stm|title=Gullit rocked by late leveller 
|publisher=BBC|date=21 August 1999|accessdate=15 October 2012}}</ref> At the end of the season the "Dons"' were relegated into the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].

He regained his fitness by January 2001, and managed twelve league and six [[FA Cup]] games in [[2000–01 in English football|2000–01]]. After missing the entire first half of the [[2001–02 in English football|2001–02]] campaign, he returned to fitness only to find that he had lost his first team place due to the form of promising youngster [[Jobi McAnuff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/2533743.stm|title=Ainsworth eyes QPR switch|date=2 December 2002|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> Ainsworth was told that he was to be released in summer 2002,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wimbledon/1834442.stm|title=Dons quartet face exit|date=21 February 2002|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> and was allowed to join former club [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] on loan in April 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/1898478.stm|title=Ainsworth back at Preston|date=28 March 2002|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He played five games for Preston, scoring one goal against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/1901138.stm|title=Preston 4-0 Coventry|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=6 April 2002 |accessdate=15 October 2012}}</ref> He returned to Wimbledon to find that he was to be offered a new contract, after the club announced it was considering [[Relocation of Wimbledon F.C. to Milton Keynes|a potentially lucrative move to Milton Keynes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wimbledon/2119942.stm|title=Dons talk to key pair|date=10 July 2002|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>

After six appearances for the "Dons" in [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03]], he was allowed to join [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on loan in December. He scored for the "Saddlers" against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/2606727.stm|title=Forest 1–1 Walsall|publisher=BBC|date=1 January 2003 |accessdate=1 February 2010}}</ref> but his loan deal was not extended. He scored twice in nine games upon his return to Wimbledon, before March 2003, when he moved to [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on a short-term deal for a "small fee".<ref name="double" /> The "Bluebirds" won promotion to the First Division as play-off winners, though Ainsworth played no part in the victory over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the [[2003 Football League Second Division play-off Final|final]] at the [[Millennium Stadium]]. His stay with the club was brief, as manager [[Lennie Lawrence]] told him that he could not guarantee him a first team spot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/3028504.stm|title=Ainsworth set for QPR switch|date=28 June 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> Both before and after his release from Cardiff he was linked with a permanent move back to Walsall,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/walsall/2660473.stm|title=Lee back in for Ainsworth|date=15 January 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/walsall/2944946.stm|title=Lee cool on Ainsworth|date=28 May 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> but manager [[Colin Lee]] had limited funds available for new players.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/walsall/2664549.stm|title=Lee admits cash woe|date=16 January 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>

===QPR===
[[File:Gareth Ainsworth.png|right|200px|thumb|Ainsworth playing for QPR in 2005]]
Ainsworth signed for [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in July 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/3036102.stm|title=Ainsworth joins QPR|date=1 July 2003|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He scored twice on his debut, in a 5–0 win over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 9 August 2003. Sixteen days later he made it five goals in four games with a brace against [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]], one a volley from 35&nbsp;yards, and another a powerful drive from the same distance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10373~22090,00.html|title=Rushden & D vs QPR|date=25 August 2003|work=qpr.co.uk|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> QPR won promotion to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] as Second Division runners-up at the end of the [[2003–04 Football League|2003–04]] season.

Despite suffering with a knee injury in [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]] that limited him to 23 appearances, manager [[Ian Holloway]] offered him a new contract at the end of the season after telling the media that "he's an important player to have around".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/4382509.stm|title=Holloway praises winger Ainsworth |date=25 March 2005|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> During the disappointing campaign of [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]], Ainsworth came second in the Player of the Year awards behind [[Danny Shittu]], and finished [[List of Queens Park Rangers F.C. seasons|joint-top-scorer]] on eleven goals with [[Marc Nygaard]].

During the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season, Ainsworth struggled with injuries, and his season ended in April after a scan revealed that he had broken his leg in a win over [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/6542529.stm|title=Ainsworth to miss rest of season |date=10 April 2007|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> During the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08]] season, he assisted new manager [[Luigi De Canio]] in addition to his 25 games, and stated his intention to move into coaching once his player career is over.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7332871.stm Ainsworth reveals management aim], bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 6 April 2008.</ref>

In May 2008, Ainsworth accepted a player coach role under new QPR boss [[Iain Dowie]]. Dowie was sacked in October 2008, and Ainsworth was appointed as caretaker-manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7689062.stm|title=QPR part company with boss Dowie |date=24 October 2008|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> On taking up the reins, Ainsworth announced that "QPR is very strong with the result of what happened and will stay strong, nothing is going to break us".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7693225.stm|title=Ainsworth proud to hold QPR reins |date=27 October 2008|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> During his time in charge QPR managed to test [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]] in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] encounter that was only settled by a 76th minute [[Carlos Tevez]] goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7708789.stm|title=Man Utd 1-0 QPR |last=Lywon|first=Sam|date=11 November 2008|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> This performance caused Ainsworth to believe that the club could achieve promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7724388.stm|title=Ainsworth eyes top flight for QPR |date=12 November 2008|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He remained on the club's coaching staff after [[Paulo Sousa]] was appointed as manager in November.<ref>{{cite news| title = Sousa is new QPR first team coach| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7736118.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 19 November 2008| accessdate = 19 November 2008| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqgVxWKW | archivedate = 17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> Sousa's reign did not last long however, and on 9 April 2009, Ainsworth again took the role of caretaker-manager.<ref name="QPR axe Sousa after just 26 games">{{cite news| title = QPR axe Sousa after just 26 games| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/7993079.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 9 April 2009| accessdate = 9 April 2009| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqgZleyR |archivedate =17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref>

He was considered for the vacant management position at former club [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] in September 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/lincoln_city/8238892.stm|title=Imps target 'up-and-coming' boss |date=4 September 2009|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>

===Wycombe Wanderers===
On 20 November 2009 Ainsworth joined [[Football League One|League One]] outfit [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] on a month long loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12875_5706796,00.html|title=Ainsworth heads to Wycombe|date=20 November 2009|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He went on to sign an eighteen month contract with Wycombe in February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wycombe_wanderers/8489702.stm|title=Wycombe Wanderers bag Gareth Ainsworth and Kevin McLeod |date=1 February 2010|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in a 2–2 draw with [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on 20 March 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8560663.stm|title=Wycombe   2–2   Exeter|publisher=BBC|date=20 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010}}</ref> However the club were relegated at the end of [[2009–10 Football League|the season]].

The club achieved promotion out of [[Football League Two|League Two]] at the first attempt in [[2010–11 Wycombe Wanderers F.C. season|2010–11]], after finishing in the third automatic promotion spot, a single point ahead of [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]]. Ainsworth scored eleven goals in 46 appearances, and captained Wycombe to the 3–1 victory over [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] that ensured the club promotion on 7 May 2011. Later that month Ainsworth signed a new one year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13361390.stm|title=Gareth Ainsworth avoids Wycombe Wanderers shake-up|date=11 May 2011|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> For his performances he was named on the PFA League Two [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. However the "Chairboys" were relegated straight back down in [[2011–12 Wycombe Wanderers F.C. season|2011–12]], with Ainsworth scoring twice in 32 games. 

He retired from professional football on 27 April 2013, after playing his final game against his former club, Port Vale at [[Adams Park]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Osborne|first=Chris|title=Gareth Ainsworth 'tearful' before Wycombe Wanderers retirement|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22301237|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=26 April 2013}}</ref> Although he agreed to sign a two-year contract to remain as Wycombe manager.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/ainsworth-commits-to-the-chairboys-786413.aspx |title=Ainsworth commits to the Chairboys |publisher=Wycombe Wanderers | date=22 April 2013}}</ref>

==Managerial career==

===Wycombe Wanderers===
Following the sacking of [[Gary Waddock]], Ainsworth was appointed as [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]]'s caretaker-manager on 24 September 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Statement: Ainsworth named caretaker|url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/statement-ainsworth-named-caretaker-386884.aspx|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=wycombewanderers.co.uk|date=24 September 2012}}</ref> Before he took charge, Wycombe had picked up just four points from their seven league games.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wycombe Wanderers: Gareth Ainsworth made caretaker boss|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19701501|accessdate=24 September 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=24 September 2012}}</ref>

After a loss and a draw, he led the team to victory over [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] on 6 October, and provided the cross himself for the opening goal of the game.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wycombe 2 - 1 Torquay|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19768612|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=6 October 2012}}</ref> In October, he signed Portuguese winger [[Bruno Andrade (Portuguese footballer)|Bruno Andrade]] on loan from QPR.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wycombe Wanderers bring in QPR winger Bruno Andrade|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19888165|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=9 October 2012}}</ref> A further win over [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]], Andrade scoring the only goal of the game, lifted the club out of the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fleetwood 0 - 1 Wycombe|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19854823|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 October 2012}}</ref> Ainsworth was appointed as the club's manager on a permanent basis on 8 November.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ainsworth appointed permanent manager |url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/ainsworth-appointed-permanent-manager-474512.aspx |accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=8 November 2012}}</ref> In December 2012, the "Chairboys" gained ten out of a possible 15 points to rise ten points clear of the relegation zone – Ainsworth was recognized for this achievement by being nominated for the [[Football League Two Manager of the Month|division's manager of the month award]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Reece|title=Gaz nominated for manager of the month|url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/gaz-nominated-for-manager-of-the-month-585813.aspx|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=wycombewanderers.co.uk|date=8 January 2013}}</ref> In April 2013, Ainsworth signed a new two-year managerial contract, and also announced his retirement as a player.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ainsworth commits to the Chairboys |url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/ainsworth-commits-to-the-chairboys-786413.aspx |accessdate=22 April 2013|newspaper=Wycombe Wanderers|date=22 April 2013}}</ref>

Ainsworth lost striker [[Joel Grant]] to [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] at the start of the [[2013–14 Wycombe Wanderers F.C. season|2013–14]] season,<ref>{{cite web|title=Grant joins Championship Yeovil|url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/grant-joins-championship-yeovil-881798.aspx|work=wycombewanderers.co.uk|accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref> and signed attackers [[Jon-Paul Pittman]], [[Steven Craig]], and [[Paris Cowan-Hall]] to replace him.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jon-Paul Pittman agrees to Wycombe Wanderers return|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23081599|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=27 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23408486|title=Wycombe Wanderers sign Scottish striker Steven Craig|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 July 2013|accessdate=23 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wycombe Wanderers sign winger Paris Cowan-Hall|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23053844|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 June 2013}}</ref> Defenders [[Dave Winfield (footballer)|Dave Winfield]] and [[Charles Dunne]] also left Wycombe for clubs in higher divisions (though Dunne was loaned back to Wycombe for the season as part of the transfer).<ref>{{cite web|title=Dave Winfield: Shrewsbury Town sign Wycombe defender|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22870272|publisher=BBC Sports|accessdate=12 June 2013|date=12 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wycombe defender Charles Dunne completes Blackpool move|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23819402|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=23 August 2013}}</ref> He signed right-back [[Nick Arnold (footballer)|Nick Arnold]] and midfielder [[Billy Knott]] on loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/article/arnold-arrives-at-adams-park-868561.aspx |title=Arnold arrives at Adams Park |publisher=Wycombe Wanderers F.C |accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Knott links up with Wycombe|url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2013/august/knott-heads-to-wycombe|publisher=Sunderland AFC|accessdate=20 August 2013|date=20 August 2013}}</ref> In the January transfer window he sold 18 year-old centre-back [[Kortney Hause]] to [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], and signed 19 year-old former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] winger [[Anthony Jeffrey]] on a free transfer.<ref>{{cite news|title=Transfer Deadline Day: Wolves sign Wycombe's Kortney Premier League deals|publisher=''Daily Mail''|date=1 January 2014|accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> On the final day of the season Wycombe needed to win at [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] and hope results went their way elsewhere in order to stay up; they won their match 3–0 and finished outside of the relegation zone on goal difference.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pilnick|first=Brent|title=Torquay 0 - 3 Wycombe|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27168109|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=3 May 2014}}</ref>

==Style of play==
Ainsworth is able to play on the right-wing or as an attacking midfielder, and has good crossing ability; he was also known as a pacey player in his 20s and early 30s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/walsall/2546163.stm|title=Ainsworth joins Walsall|date=5 December 2002|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>

==Personal life==
During his playing days Ainsworth picked up the nickname 'Wild Thing' due to his appearance and his rock star ambitions; he was in a band called 'APA' with Wimbledon teammates [[Chris Perry (footballer)|Chris Perry]] and [[Trond Andersen]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/sport/article-6138971-ainsworths-life-on-the-wild-side.do|title=Ainsworth's life on the wild side |last=Curtis|first=Adrian|date=8 August 2003|work=London Evening Standard|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> he was also in a band called 'Dog Chewed the Handle'. He is considered a cult hero at Preston, Wimbledon, QPR, Port Vale, Lincoln City, and Wycombe Wanderers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/football_focus/4063429.stm|title=Port Vale's cult heroes |date=3 December 2004|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/football_focus/3656862.stm|title=Lincoln's cult heroes|date=16 September 2004|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=250107&tcmuri=98223 |title=Player Profile: Gareth Ainsworth |date=|work=Wycombe Wanderers|accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref>

On 21 October 2010, he represented [[The Football League]] at the unveiling of the [[Association football during World War I|Footballers' Battalions]] memorial on the site of the [[Battle of the Somme]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/footballleaguenews/20101022/league-honours-war-dead_2246528_2192753|title=League Honours War Dead|publisher=The Football League Official Site|accessdate=22 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/8079101/Footballers-Battalions-remembered-on-Somme-battlefield.html|title=Footballers' Battalion remembered on Somme battlefield – Telegraph|publisher=Henry Winter, The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=22 October 2010|location=London|date=21 October 2010}}</ref>
