'''Samuel James''' "'''Sam'''" '''Aiston''' (born 21 November 1976) is an English retired professional footballer who played as a midfielder He made over 200 appearances in the [[Premier League]] and the [[The Football League|Football League]], particularly for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]], [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]], [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] and [[Wrexham F.C.|Wrexham]].

==Career==
Aiston began his career at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 1994 but made no appearances for the club before joining [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in 1995, where he made over 20 first-team appearances, most as substitute.<ref name="sbase" /> He was loaned to [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]], [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]],<ref name="sbase" /> before joining Shrewsbury for a £50,000 transfer fee in the summer of 2000.<ref name="sbase">{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players_details.sd?playerid=8943|title=Sam Aiston  |work=Soccerbase|publisher=Racing Post|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> Aiston made 165 league appearances for Shrewsbury, scoring seven goals,<ref name="sbase" /> helping the club to promotion from the [[Football Conference]] at the end of the [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04]] season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/3713971.stm|title=Shrews secure promotion|date=16 May 2004|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> Whilst at [[Shrewsbury Town]] Aiston endeared himself to the Shrewsbury faithful owing to his style of play.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shrewsbury Town dressing room was spilt – Aiston|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/shrewsbury/9398537.stm|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref>

He was released by Shrewsbury at the end of the 2004–05 season and joined [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] in July 2005,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/t/tranmere_rovers/4640957.stm|title=Tranmere complete double signing|date=1 July 2005|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> where he made over 40 league and cup appearances in the 2005–06 season.<ref name="sbase" /> He was released by Tranmere at the end of the season, and joined [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/northampton_town/5121922.stm|title=Aiston and Holt join Northampton|date=27 June 2006|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> Injuries meant he struggled to command a regular first team place and he dropped into the [[Conference National]] for a loan spell with [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burton_albion/7018740.stm|title=Burton pair's loan deals extended |date=28 September 2007|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref>

In November 2007, Aiston joined [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]] on loan, having previously played for Wrexham manager [[Brian Little (footballer)|Brian Little]] at [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wrexham/7107914.stm|title=Wrexham get winger Aiston on loan |date=22 November 2007|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> Aiston made his debut in a 2–2 draw with [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]] three days later. In January 2008, Aiston's move to Wrexham was made into a permanent signing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wrexham/7177703.stm|title=Aiston completes permanent switch |date=28 January 2008|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 June 2008}}</ref> He was transfer listed by Wrexham in May 2008 following the club's relegation to the [[Football Conference]].

Aiston went on to play for [[Stafford Rangers F.C.|Stafford Rangers]] and [[Hednesford Town F.C.|Hednesford Town]] before joining [[Gainsborough Trinity F.C.|Gainsborough Trinity]] in February 2010. He was released in May 2011.

==Personal life==
After retiring from playing football Aiston became a primary school teacher.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/news/2010/07/08/ex-shrews-player-sam-aiston-to-become-a-sir/|title=Ex-Shrews player Sam Aiston to become a ‘sir’|last=Pinnington|first=Sam|date=8 July 2010|work=Shropshire Star|accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> He got married in August 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Shrewsbury Town winger Sam Aiston nets stunning Hollie|url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/news/2012/08/28/former-shrewsbury-town-winger-sam-aiston-nets-stunning-hollie/|work=Shropshire Star|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref>

'''Nathan Benjamin Aké''' (born 18 February 1995) is a Dutch professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for English club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and for the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands under-21 team]].

==Club career==

===Chelsea===

Aké agreed to join the Chelsea youth system from [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] in late 2010 at the age of just 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1340603/Chelsea-lure-15-year-old-Nathan-Ake-spark-Feyenoord-fury.html |title=Chelsea spark Feyenoord fury as Blues lure 15-year-old defender Nathan Ake to London|publisher=Daily Mail|date=22 Dec 2010}}</ref> He had played at Feyenoord since the age of 12 after joining the club from [[ADO Den Haag]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vvwilhelmus.nl/nieuws/2011/december/nathan-ak%C3%A9,-oud-wilhelmus-jeugd-speler,-definitief-naar-chelsea-fc/ |title=Nathan Aké, oud Wilhelmus Jeugd speler, definitief naar Chelsea FC |publisher=V.V. Wilhelmus |accessdate=16 May 2013 |language=Dutch }}</ref>

====2012–13 season====

Aké made his [[Premier League 2012-13|Premier League]] début on 26 December 2012 against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] as a 17-year-old, replacing [[Juan Mata]] in added time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Owen|title=Norwich 0–1 Chelsea|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20779143|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 December 2012}}</ref> He made his first start for the club in the [[2012-13 FA Cup|FA Cup]] on 27 February 2013, in a 2–0 win against Championship side [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21515665 "Middlesbrough 0–2 Chelsea"] BBC Sport. 27 February 2013. Retrieved 27 February 2013.</ref> He was chosen to start in a defensive midfield position for Chelsea in the second leg of their [[2012-13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] quarter-final clash with [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] in Russia on 11 April, a match that finished in a 3–2 loss for Chelsea but resulted in a 5–4 aggregate victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2013/apr/11/rubin-kazan-chelsea-europa-league |title=Chelsea struggle to finish off Rubin Kazan but reach semi-finals |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 April 2013 }}</ref>  He made his second European appearance for the club on 2 May, replacing [[David Luiz]] in the 3–1 second-leg defeat of [[FC Basel|Basel]], securing Chelsea a spot in the Europa League final.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22289791 |title=Chelsea secured their place in the Europa League final against Benfica with an ultimately comfortable win over FC Basel at Stamford Bridge |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2013 }}</ref> Aké was an unused substitute for Chelsea in the [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final|Europa League]] final against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in Amsterdam on 16 May, which Chelsea won 2–1 on the night.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/4929206/Benfica-1-2-Chelsea-Match-report-and-pictures.html |title=Benfica 1 Chelsea 2 |publisher=The Sun |date=15 May 2013 }}</ref> He was voted<ref>http://www.chelseafc.com/javaImages/94/36/0,,10268~11941524,00.jpg</ref> Chelsea's Young Player of the Year on 16 May 2013. He made his first Premier League start for Chelsea on 19 May 2013 in the 2–1 win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and played the whole match on the last day of the season at Stamford Bridge.

====2013–14 season====

On 8 August 2013, Aké signed a new five-year contract with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] which keeps him at the club until 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3342358/title/new-deal-for-ake |title=New Deal for Aké|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|date=8 Aug 2013 }}</ref> He continued his development with the U-21's side and made his single appearance in the 2013–14 season as a substitute in Chelsea's final Premier League match on 11 May, a 2–1 win over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27273463 |title=Cardiff City 1–2 Chelsea|publisher= BBC Sport|date=11 May 2014 }}</ref>

====2014–15 season====

Following his permanent promotion to the first team, Aké made his first appearance of the season and first start under [[José Mourinho]] in Chelsea's 2–1 [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] Third Round victory over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 24 September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29233095 |title=Chelsea 2–1 Bolton|publisher= BBC Sport|date=24 September 2014 }}</ref> 

On 21 October 2014, Aké made his [[2014-15 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] debut from the bench, coming into the game for [[Cesc Fàbregas]] in the 60th minute during the 6–0 win over [[NK Maribor|Maribor]] at Stamford Bridge. In his 30-minute appearance, he provided an assist for [[Eden Hazard]]'s second goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29362738 |title=Didier Drogba scored his first goal since rejoining Chelsea as they recorded their biggest Champions League win with a dominant victory against Maribor at Stamford Bridge. |work=BBC Sport |date=21 October 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2014 }}</ref>

On 25 March 2015, Aké was loaned to [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] for a month.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/royals-sign-nathan-ake-on-loan-from-chelsea-2358756.aspx|title=Royals Sign Nathan Ake on Loan|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref>

==International career==

===Youth===

Aké has represented the Netherlands at every youth level since his Under-15 début in 2009, making 54 appearances in total.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://au.soccerway.com/players/nathan-ake/182930/? |title=N. AKÉ | publisher = SOCCERWAY |accessdate=26 Sep 2014}}</ref>
He has captained both the U-17 and the U-19 sides. Aké was selected into both squads that won the UEFA European under-17 championships in 2011 and 2012 in Serbia and in Slovenia respectively.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/news/newsid=1796817.html |title=Captain Aké learns from Chelsea stars | publisher = UEFA |accessdate=14 May 2012}}</ref>

==Style of play==
Aké has been praised for his versatility due to be being able to play at left back, centre back and in a defensive midfield role. This versatility is a result of his good work ethic and professionalism combined with his gifted technique. His playing style and appearance have led to comparisons being drawn with former Dutch legend and Chelsea player [[Ruud Gullit]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2278552/Chelsea-youth-player-Nathan-Ake-looks-like-Ruud-Gullit-plays-like-David-Luiz.html |title=Ruud boy: Chelsea youth star Ake is a mini Gullit with his dreadlocks and cool head| publisher = Daily Mail |accessdate=14 Feb 2013}}</ref>

'''Bülent Akın''' (born 28 August 1978 in [[Brussels]]) is a [[Belgian]]-born Turkish former [[Association football|footballer]].<ref name="Yeni Malatyaspor"/>

==Club career==
Akin's potential was noticed after [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]] legend [[Gheorghe Hagi]] remarked on how well the young midfielder had marked him in a match between Galatasaray and Akin's club, Denizilispor. Galatasaray subsequently signed Akin, but he failed to live up to the expectation.<ref name="Yeni Malatyaspor">http://www.sabah.com.tr/Spor/2010/08/12/bir_zamanlar_8_milyon_dolardi</ref> Nonetheless, he managed to win the [[UEFA Super Cup]] in [[2000 UEFA Super Cup|2000]] with the club.

'''Adeola Oluwatoyin "Ade" Akinbiyi''' (born 10 October 1974) is a [[Association football|footballer]] who is currently a player-coach at [[Colwyn Bay F.C.|Colwyn Bay]].

Akinbiyi has had a much-travelled career with many different clubs with transfer fees totalling more than £11.5 million during his career, including being [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]'s record signing (at £5.3 million).<ref name="Notts County swoop for Akinbiyi">{{cite news| title = Notts County swoop for Akinbiyi| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/n/notts_county/8276493.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 26 September 2009|accessdate = 13 October 2009}}</ref>

Born in England, Akinbiyi qualifies to play for the [[Nigeria national football team]] through his parents, and earned one [[cap (sport)|cap]] for Nigeria.

==Club career==

===Early career===
Akinbiyi began his career as a trainee at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], where he worked his way up into the first team in 1992. He made his début on 3 November 1993 as a substitute against German giants [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] in the [[UEFA Cup 1993-94|UEFA Cup]]. [[Bayern Munich v Norwich City|The match]] ended 1–1, meaning that Norwich won the second round tie 3–2 on aggregate and went on to face [[Inter Milan]], who eliminated them.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Daily Telegraph|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2001/11/02/sfnwin03.xml|title=On the Spot: Ade Akinbiyi|date=2 November 2001 | first=Henry | last=Winter | accessdate=23 April 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
He was loaned to [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] before completing a £250,000 move to [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] in 1997. He scored 29 goals in 67 league and cup games for the Gills and was quickly transferred to newly promoted [[Football League First Division|Division One]] side [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] for £1.2m.

===Big money moves===
Akinbiyi's stock continued to rise and after scoring 21 goals for Bristol City in the [[1998-99 in English football|1998–99 season]], [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] paid a club record £3.5million for him in September 1999 in an attempt to replace [[Robbie Keane]]. He played only one season at [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]], finishing as the club's top goalscorer with 16 goals but Wolves just missed out on a playoff place.

Ten months after arriving at Wolves, he departed to [[Premier League]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for £5.5 million,<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4624182.stm  |title=Akinbiyi swaps Wolves for Foxes |date=25 July 2000}}</ref> a decision he would later regret.<ref name="Akinbiyi reveals Leicester regret">{{cite news |title=Akinbiyi reveals Leicester regret |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/4448704.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 November 2005 |accessdate=1 June 2008}}</ref> Brought in as a replacement for [[Emile Heskey]] (who left for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] for £11 million), he failed to live up to expectations, scoring only 11 goals in 58 league appearances.

His spell at Leicester hit rock bottom in a 4-1 defeat at home to Liverpool. He missed four easy chances, including a miss from six yards in the last minute. He was booed by Leicester fans whose patience with Akinbiyi had run out.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/oct/22/match.leicestercity |title=Fowler returns to finishing school |date=22 October 2001 |accessdate=3 January 2014 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> Soon after, he scored his first goal of the season in a crucial 1-0 win at home to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], which prompted him to say that "hopefully this will start a flood of goals for me".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/nov/05/match.leicestercity |title=First Ade patches up struggling Foxes |date=5 November 2001 |accessdate=3 January 2014 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref>

Leicester transferred Akinbiyi to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] for £2.2m in February 2002.<ref>{{cite web |title=Palace clinch Akinbiyi deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/1801306.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=5 February 2002 |accessdate=3 January 2014}}</ref> On arrival he took the surprisingly high number 55 shirt, adding a very small plus sign between the numbers to signify his preferred shirt number, 10, which was already taken. Having scored just one goal in 14 league and cup appearances, he was loaned out to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |title=Deadline-day transfers |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/2891031.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=27 March 2003 |accessdate=3 January 2014}}</ref> He scored twice&nbsp;– the second goal coming in the last game of the [[2002-03 Stoke City F.C. season|2002–03]] season, when the Potters beat [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] 1–0 to retain their second tier status.<ref>{{cite web |title=Akinbiyi keeps Stoke up |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/2967967.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=4 May 2003 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref> He later joined on a permanent basis, on a free transfer in September 2003.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stoke seal Akinbiyi deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stoke_city/3105718.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2003 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref> He scored ten goals in [[2003–04 Stoke City F.C. season|2003–04]] and won the [[Stoke City F.C. Player of the Year|player of the year award]]. In [[2004–05 Stoke City F.C. season|2004–05]] Akinbiyi scored seven goals in 30 matches and was subject to bids from [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Stoke reject Blades' Akinbiyi bid  |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stoke_city/4195209.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=21 January 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Stoke reject fresh Akinbiyi bid |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stoke_city/4202621.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=25 January 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Blades increase bid for Akinbiyi |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4233157.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=3 February 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref> All of Sheffield United's offers were turned down by Stoke but an offer from [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] was accepted.<ref>{{cite web |title=Burnley beat Blades for Akinbiyi |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/4273937.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=24 February 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2013}}</ref>

===Burnley===
Akinbiyi completed a £600,000 move to [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in February 2005, but marked his debut by getting sent off within two minutes for head butting [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] player [[George McCartney]]. After netting 16 times for ''the Clarets'', he moved to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] for a then club record £1.75 million in January 2006.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/4624182.stm|title=Akinbiyi and Dyer move to Blades|date=26 January 2006}}</ref>

===Sheffield United===
Akinbiyi scored on his debut for ''the Blades'' against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], and endeared himself to fans by scoring in his first [[Steel City derby]] at [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]]. After winning promotion, Akinbiyi made only five appearances for ''the Blades'' in the Premier League in 2006. It was also reported that he was involved in a training ground bust-up with team-mate [[Claude Davis]] in October 2006 following a 2–0 defeat against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in which Davis had been sent off.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/6090316.stm|title=Akinbiyi and Davis resolve feud |date=27 October 2006}}</ref>

===Return to Burnley===
Akinbiyi was soon resold to Burnley in January 2007 for a fee of £650,000 with a further £100,000 to be paid in the summer of 2007.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/6222637.stm|title=Burnley re-sign Blades' Akinbiyi|date=1 January 2007}}</ref> His second debut for the Clarets was more successful, scoring a goal against top flight [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in the [[FA Cup]].

During the rest of the [[2006-07 in English football|2006–07]] season, Akinbiyi was not as successful as during his first spell at [[Turf Moor]], scoring three goals. This was attributed by [[Steve Cotterill]] to Akinbiyi having spent too much time in the weights room at Sheffield United and as a result being too bulky.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Lancashire Evening Telegraph|url=http://archive.lancashireeveningtelegraph.co.uk/2007/1/30/965540.html|title=Ade hit with weights ban|date=30 January 2007}}</ref> He was given the number nine shirt for the [[2007-08 in English football|2007–08]] season but found himself behind [[Andy Gray (footballer born 1977)|Andy Gray]] and [[Robbie Blake]] as a first choice striker. After going back to Burnley, Akinbiyi lacked consistent form, finding goals harder to come by. His hard work and endeavour made him a firm fans' favourite.<ref name="Ade Akinbiyi&nbsp;— An appreciation">{{cite news|publisher=Clarets Mad|url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/loadfeat.asp?cid=EDB5&id=440744|title=Ade Akinbiyi&nbsp;– An appreciation|date=2 April 2009}}</ref> During the [[2008-09 in English football|2008–09]] season, his regular position on the bench was taken by youngster [[Jay Rodriguez]], a player who he had been mentoring.<ref name="Ade Akinbiyi&nbsp;— An appreciation"/> However, Akinbiyi regained his place on the bench in the fifth round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] and in the 69th minute he scored to make the game 1–1 and take it into extra time. Burnley won 5–4 on penalties. While at Burnley, Steve Cotterill, Burnley's then manager, banned him from the gym. "I wasn’t playing at Sheffield so the only thing I was doing was weights. We didn’t even have reserve games and it was something to do. I put on a bit too much muscle and I lost about a yard of pace", he said. "I try to stay away from the weights room now. I’m sort of addicted."

===Houston Dynamo===
On 26 March 2009, Akinbiyi was reported to be in talks about a move to the United States to join [[Major League Soccer]] club [[Houston Dynamo]].<ref name="Chronicle6342699">{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/sports/6342699.html|title=Dynamo close to signing veteran Akinbiyi|last=Fallas|first=Bernardo|date=26 March 2009|publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]]|accessdate=27 March 2009}}</ref> On 30 March, Akinbiyi was officially unveiled as a Houston player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://houston.mlsnet.com/news/team_news.jsp?ymd=20090330&content_id=232988&vkey=news_hou&fext=.jsp&team=t200 |title=Soccer for Success Day|publisher=Houston Dynamo|date= 30 March 2009|accessdate=10 May 2010}}</ref> He made his MLS debut on 3 May, as a late [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a game against [[New England Revolution]].<ref>[http://web.mlsnet.com/scoreboard/game.jsp?match=05032009_HOUNE Major League Soccer]{{dead link|date=May 2010}}</ref>

To make room on the roster for [[Luis Ángel Landín]], the club's first [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player]], the Dynamo released Akinbiyi on 20 August 2009.<ref>[http://web.mlsnet.com/news/team_news.jsp?ymd=20090820&content_id=6522206&vkey=pr_hou&fext=.jsp&team=t200 Major League Soccer]{{dead link|date=May 2010}}</ref>

===Notts County===
After his release by Houston, Akinbiyi agreed terms with [[League Two]] side [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].<ref name="Notts County swoop for Akinbiyi"/> He made his debut on 17 October 2009 in a 0–0 draw against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]], coming on as a substitute for [[Lee Hughes]] in the 82nd minute.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rotherham 0&nbsp;– 0 Notts County|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_3/8295726.stm|work=BBC Sport|date=17 October 2009|accessdate=26 October 2009| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20091021121445/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_3/8295726.stm| archivedate= 21 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

On 10 May 2010 it was announced that he had been released by Notts County along with seven other players.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/notts_county/8672163.stm
|title=Notts County release eight out-of-contract players
|date=10 May 2010
|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>

===Free agent (2010-2013)===

In January 2011, after 9 months without a club, Akinbiyi was on the verge of joining [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] in the [[Conference National]]. He had been training with Premier League club [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], and was recommended to Newport by Stoke's Newport-born manager [[Tony Pulis]]; Pulis had been Akinbiyi's manager at Stoke between 2003 and 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/sport/8776176.County_sign_former_Premiership_star__Ade_Akinbiyi/|title=Akinbiyi joins Newport County|work=South Wales Argus|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref> However, Newport subsequently pulled out of the deal.

Akinbiyi spent the next two years as a free agent; having been without a club for three years, he was widely assumed to have retired from football by the time of his signing for [[Conference North]] side [[Colwyn Bay F.C.|Colwyn Bay]] in the summer of 2013.

===Colwyn Bay===
On 25 July 2013 Akinbiyi joined [[Conference North]] side [[Colwyn Bay F.C.|Colwyn Bay]] as a player-coach, ending his three-year exile from playing football.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.northwalesweeklynews.co.uk/seagulls/2013/07/ex-premier-league-stars-to-pla.html|title=Football: the latest football news from across North Wales|publisher=|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
Born in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], London to [[Nigerian]] parents, Akinbiyi qualified to play internationally for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]], and through his birthplace for [[England national football team|England]]. He was called up on three separate occasions for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]], playing once in 1999 against [[Greece national football team|Greece]] in London<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/intldetails/1999ic.html |title=RSSSF 1999 Internationals |publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation |date=2 February 2005 |accessdate=10 May 2010}}</ref>
.

'''Hope Ini I. Akpan''' (born 14 August 1991) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] as a [[midfielder]].

Born in England, he represents [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] at international level.

==Club career==
Born in [[Childwall]], [[Liverpool]], Akpan made his competitive debut for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] against [[FC BATE Borisov|BATE]] on 17 December 2009 in the [[UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/players/h/ha/hope-akpan|title=Profile|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=Everton F.C.}}</ref>

On 17 March 2011, Akpan moved on loan to [[Football Championship|Championship]] side [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for the remainder of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hull_city/9428168.stm|title=Everton midfielder Hope Akpan joins Hull City on loan|date=17 March 2011|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>

He signed for newly [[promotion and relegation|promoted]] [[Football League Two|League Two]] club [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] on a free transfer on 14 June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13769372|title=Crawley Town bring in midfielder Hope Akpan|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/Ex-Tiger-Akpan-gives-Hope-Crawley/story-12772524-detail/story.html|title=Ex-Tiger Akpan gives Hope to Crawley|date=15 June 2011|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=Hull Daily Mail}}</ref>

Akpan was charged with misconduct by the Football Association in November 2011, after homophobic comments were posted on his Twitter account. Despite insisting that someone else had posted the comments, he admitted the charge after no one came forward to claim responsibility, and he was fined £1,200 by the FA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crawley_town/9637253.stm|title=Crawley Town's Hope Akpan accepts FA misconduct fine|date=15 November 2011|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2011/11/16/footballer-fined-1200-for-fully-homophobic-tweet/|title=Footballer fined £1,200 for "fully homophobic" tweet|date=16 November 2011|accessdate=15 October 2014|author=Stephen Gray|publisher=Pink News}}</ref> In October 2012 Akpan was the recipient of online racist abuse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2012/10/31/crawleys-hope-akpan-backed-by-pfa-after-racial-abuse-on-twitter-611377/|title=Crawley’s Hope Akpan backed by PFA after racial abuse on Twitter|date=31 October 2012|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=Metro}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-20165825|title=Crawley Town footballer Hope Akpan sent racist tweet|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>

Akpan signed for Premier League side [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on a three-and-a-half-year contract on 8 January 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/akpan-signs-080113-586905.aspx|title=Royals sign Akpan|date=8 January 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=Reading F.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/reading-complete-deal-for-hope-akpan-8443235.html|title=Reading complete deal for Hope Akpan|date=8 January 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=The Independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20959076|title=Reading sign Hope Akpan from Crawley Town|date=9 January 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He stated his desire to help his new club avoid relegation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20963789|title=Reading: Hope Akpan ready for relegation battle|date=10 January 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/hope-akpan-buzzing-mark-reading-6527284|title=Hope Akpan 'buzzing' to get off the mark for Reading FC|date=19 January 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|author=Charles Watts|publisher=Get Reading}}</ref>

==International career==
Although he was born in England, in 2013 Akpan declared his intention to represent [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] – the country of his parents – at international level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21720672|title=Reading's Akpan targets Nigeria call-up|date=11 March 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/4078/exclusives/2013/04/23/3915555/readings-hope-akpan-sets-sight-on-reclaiming-nigerian-roots|title=Reading's Hope Akpan sets sight on reclaiming Nigerian roots|date=23 April 2013|accessdate=15 October 2014|author=Ed Dove|publisher=Goal.com}}</ref>

Akpan received his first call-up to the Nigerian national team in October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/reading-fc-star-hope-akpan-7902060|title=Reading FC star Hope Akpan proud to get first Nigeria call-up|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|author=Charles Watts|publisher=Get Reading}}</ref> He made his debut later that month, on 15 October 2014, in an African Cup of Nations qualifying match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/reading-s-akpan-lauds-influence-chelsea-s-mikel-after-nigeria-debut-4044499#.VD7b88t0zIU|title=Reading’s Akpan lauds influence of Chelsea’s Mikel after Nigeria debut|date=15 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|author=Andrew Slevison|publisher=Tribal Football}}</ref>

'''Chuba Amechi Akpom''' (born 9 October 1995) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan from [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He has represented England at youth international levels.

==Early life==
Akpom was born in the [[London Borough of Newham]] and attended [[St Bonaventure's Catholic Comprehensive School|St Bonaventure's School]] in [[Forest Gate]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/news/forest_gate_student_talks_about_being_a_gunners_player_1_3012209 | title=Forest Gate student talks about being a Gunners player | work=Newham Recorder | date=18 November 2013 | accessdate=12 April 2014 | last=Atwal | first=Kay }}</ref> He is of Nigerian descent and is from a family of Arsenal fans.<ref>http://www.arsenal.com/news/features/ahead-of-the-curve</ref><ref>http://www.thefa.com/news/the-fa-cup/2015/feb/chuba-akpom-arsenal-v-middlesbrough-preview</ref>

== Club career ==

=== Arsenal ===
Akpom joined [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at the age of six.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/features/ahead-of-the-curve |title=Ahead of the curve |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=24 April 2013 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="yg">{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/reserves-news/young-guns-chuba-akpom |title=Young Guns: Chuba Akpom |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=9 May 2012 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for the [[Arsenal FC Reserves/Youth Team|Arsenal U18]] side at the age of 15, and signed his first professional contract with Arsenal on 10 October 2012, a day after turning 17.<ref name="yg" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/chuba-akpom-signs-first-professional-contract |title=Chuba Akpom signs first professional contract |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> In December 2012 Akpom received his first call into the Arsenal senior squad, when he was an unused substitute for a 2–1 [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] defeat to [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiakos]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/akpom-ansah-and-monteiro-in-arsenal-squad |title=Akpom, Ansah and Monteiro in Arsenal squad |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> He made 20 [[Professional Development League|U21 Premier League]] appearances during the [[2012–13 Professional U21 Development League|2012/13]] season and scored 13 goals, including 10 goals in 10 games in the [[2012–13 Professional Development League 1#Elite Group|Elite Group stage]]. In the lead-up to the [[2013-14 Arsenal F.C. season|2013/14]] season, Akpom was selected for Arsenal's pre-season tour of Asia and scored once in a 7–0 win against an [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia Dream Team]], two more in a 7–1 win against [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/akpom-tour-has-left-me-wanting-more |title=Akpom – Tour has left me wanting more |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/174359/first-team/indonesia-dream-team-v-arsenal |title=Indonesia Dream Team 0 – 7 Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=14 July 2013 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/174443/first-team/vietnam-v-arsenal |title=Vietnam 1 – 7 Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=17 July 2013 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> and another in Arsenal's final game of the tour against [[Urawa Red Diamonds]].<ref name="espnfc-akpom-victory">{{cite news | url=http://www.espnfc.com/barclays-premier-league/story/1507427/chuba-akpom-goal-sees-gunners-to-victory-over-urawa-red-diamonds | title=Akpom goal sees Gunners to victory | work=ESPN FC | date=26 July 2013 | accessdate=2 September 2014 | publisher=ESPN}}</ref> Akpom made his competitive debut in a 3–1 [[FA Premier League|Premier League]] win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 14 September 2013. He came on in the third minute of [[injury time]] as a substitute for the injured [[Olivier Giroud]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1314/post/first-team/sunderland-1-3-arsenal-match-report |title=Sunderland 1 – 3 Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> Akpom was an unused substitute for the following game against [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] in the Champions League. Akpom's second Arsenal appearance came in a [[League Cup]] third round tie away to West Bromwich Albion on 25 September. He replaced goalscorer Thomas Eisfeld after 82 minutes and with the scores at 1–1 at full-time, the game entered [[Extra time (football)|extra time]]. Akpom played the full scoreless extra time period and scored Arsenal's third penalty in the ensuing [[Penalty shootout (association football)|shootout]], helping Arsenal to a win. Akpom was an unused substitute for a 2–0 Premier League win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 2 November. He scored three goals in four [[UEFA Youth League]] appearances towards the end of 2013. Akpom scored a [[Hattrick (football)|hattrick]] in a 6–1 [[FA Youth Cup]] fourth round demolition of [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on 6 January 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Peterborough United Youth Academy 1 – 6 Arsenal Youth Academy|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1314/post/youth/youth-cup-peterborough-v-arsenal?|publisher=Arsenal F.C.|date=6 January 2014}}</ref>

==== Brentford (loan) ====
On 30 December 2013, it was reported that [[League One]] sides [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], Peterborough United, [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] and [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] were in a four-way battle to sign Akpom on loan.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|title=Brentford line up loan swoop for Arsenal striker|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/brentford-line-up-loan-swoop-6454371|publisher=Get West London|date=30 December 2013}}</ref> Brentford emerged as the favourites to land Akpom, due to club's head of recruitment, Shaun O'Connor, having originally signed Akpom while working for Arsenal.<ref name=":1" /> The loan was thrown into doubt due to injuries suffered by Arsenal strikers [[Theo Walcott]] and [[Nicklas Bendtner]] in early January 2014,<ref>http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/brentfords-bid-sign-arsenal-striker-6474077</ref> but was completed on 9 January, with Akpom signing for a month.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|title=Brentford confirm Akpom deal|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/brentford-confirm-akpom-deal-6483836|publisher=Get West London|date=9 January 2014}}</ref> Manager [[Mark Warburton]] said "Chuba is strong and quick, with a very good first touch. He's greedy and enjoys scoring goals. It's his first loan spell and League One is tough, so he might take some time to adapt. It's a big jump from Under 21 football".<ref name=":2" />

He missed the first match of his loan through illness<ref>{{Twitter status|cakpom9|421953466337337344|Chuba Akpom misses match against Port Vale due to injury|Chuba Akpom|11 January 2014|2 September 2014}}</ref> and Warburton stressed that Akpom would have to "work hard and earn his place like everyone else".<ref>{{cite news|title=Brentford boss fires warning to Arsenal striker|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-boss-fires-warning-arsenal-6523730?|publisher=Get West London|date=17 January 2014}}</ref> Akpom made his debut in a 1–1 league draw at [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on 19 January.<ref>{{cite news|title=Walsall 1 – 1 Brentford|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25692817|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 January 2014}}</ref> He came on for [[Will Grigg]] after 68 minutes and provided a cross for [[Clayton Donaldson]] in the dying moments, which went unconverted.<ref>{{cite news|title=Record attempt ends but Brentford earn a point|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/record-attempt-ends-brentford-earn-6526374|publisher=Get West London|date=18 January 2014}}</ref> After making four substitute appearances, his loan spell ended and he returned to Arsenal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20140901212229/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/chuba-akpom-back-at-arsenal-10.02.14-1350234.aspx|title=CHUBA AKPOM RETURNS TO ARSENAL|publisher=Brentford F.C.|accessdate=1 September 2014|date=10 February 2014|archiveurl=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/chuba-akpom-back-at-arsenal-10.02.14-1350234.aspx|archivedate=1 September 2014| deadurl= no}}</ref> Following the return to Arsenal, Akpom appeared on Arsenal Magazine about his time at Brentford for the March issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20140901212231/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/akpom-arsenal-magazine-mar-2014-1397823.aspx|title=CHUBA AKPOM WRITES FOR ARSENAL MAGAZINE|publisher=Brentford F.C.|accessdate=1 September 2014|date=4 March 2014|archiveurl=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/akpom-arsenal-magazine-mar-2014-1397823.aspx|archivedate=1 September 2014| deadurl= no}}</ref>

==== Coventry City (loan) ====
On 14 February 2014, Akpom joined [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on loan until the end of the [[2013–14 Football League One|2013–14]] season, with an agreement that he would rejoin the Arsenal squad for games in the [[FA Youth Cup]] and [[UEFA Youth League]] during the course of the loan.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Coventry seal Akpom loan from Arsenal |url=http://www.ccfc.co.uk/news/article/chuba-akpom-coventry-city-arsenal-premier-league-league-one-140214-1358816.aspx |work=Coventry City FC |date=14 February 2014}}</ref>

==== Return to Arsenal ====
Akpom began the 2014–15 season by scoring a hat trick for Arsenal in an [[2014–15 Professional U21 Development League|Under-21 Premier League]] Division 2 game against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at the end of August.<ref>{{cite web|title=Barclays U21s: Akpom hat-trick keeps Arsenal flying high|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/aug/barclays-under-21-premier-league-2014-15-review-290814.html|website={{url|premierleague.com/|publisher=The}} Premier League|accessdate=23 September 2014}}</ref> On 23 September 2014, he made his first senior appearance of the season, replacing [[Héctor Bellerín]] for the last four minutes as Arsenal lost 1–2 at home against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Arsenal 1 – 2 Southampton|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29216769|website={{url|bbc.co.uk/|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23}} September 2014}}</ref> He made his first Premier League appearance of the season against [[Southampton F.C.]] on New Year's Day 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Southampton 2 – 0 Arsenal|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30600817|website=www.bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref> Akpom made a telling contribution to Arsenal's 5-0 home win against Aston Villa, coming on as a second-half substitute and winning a penalty, converted by [[Santi Cazorla]], his first assist for the club. On 4 February 2015, Akpom spurned the interest of a number of other clubs from the [[Premier League]] and across Europe to sign a new 4 1/2 year contract with Arsenal.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31120658</ref><ref>http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/arsenal-starlet-chuba-akpom-signs-5096072</ref>

==== Nottingham Forest (loan) ====
On 26 March 2015, he joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan till 31 May 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nottingham Forest have completed the signing of Arsenal’s Chuba Akpom on loan until 31 Ma|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/akpom-joins-on-loan-2360209.aspx|publisher=Nottingham Forest|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref>

== International career ==
On 15 February 2011 Akpom made his debut for [[England national under-16 football team|England U16s]] in a friendly match against [[Slovenia national under-16 football team|Slovenia]], which ended in a 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u16s/News/match-centre/2011/SlovEng |title=Stalemate in Slovenia |publisher=[[The Football Association]] |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> He second and final game for the U16s came in a 3–0 [[Victory Shield|2010/11 Victory Shield]] win over [[Northern Ireland national under-16 football team|Northern Ireland]] on 23 March 2011.<ref name=":3">http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/a/chuba-akpom</ref> On 2 August 2011 Akpom made his [[England national under-17 football team|U17]] debut, scoring once in 4–0 win over the [[Faroe Islands national under-17 football team|Faroe Islands]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2011/FaroeIslandsvEngland |title=Faroes hit for four |publisher=[[The Football Association]] |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> He played in all six games and scored two goals during England's unsuccessful [[2012 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2012 European U17 Championship]] [[2012 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship qualifying round|qualifying campaign]]. He made 13 appearances in total for the U17s and scored five goals.<ref name=":3" /> On 6 September 2012 Akpom made his [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] debut in a 3–1 defeat to [[Germany national under-19 football team|Germany]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/2012/germanyvengland |title=Young Lions lose season opener |publisher=[[The Football Association]] |date=6 September 2012 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the U19s on 26 September 2012, in a 3–0 [[2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|2013 European U19 Championship qualifying]] win over [[Estonia national under-19 football team|Estonia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/2012/englandvestonia |title=Jordi gets England started |publisher=[[The Football Association]] |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref> Two days later, he scored two goals in a 6–0 win over the [[Faroe Islands national under-19 football team|Faroe Islands]]. He played in five of England's six 2013 European U19 Championship qualifying and [[2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship elite qualification|elite stage]] games and scored three goals, as England failed to qualify for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|finals]].

On 11 October 2014, Akpom scored his first goals for [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] coming on as a 87th minute substitute to score a brace against [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands U20]] in a 3–2 victory.<ref>http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/oct/aidy-boothroyd-lauds-young-lions-belief</ref>

== Playing style ==
Akpom has been nicknamed "Titi" by Arsenal player [[Alexis Sánchez]] in comparison with the club's former forward [[Thierry Henry]].<ref>http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chuba-akpom-reveals-alexis-sanchez-has-nicknamed-him-titi-after-legendary-arsenal-striker-thierry-henry-9952033.html</ref>

'''Philippe Julien Albert''' (born 10 August 1967) is a former Belgian [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]]. He played for [[R. Charleroi S.C.|Charleroi]], [[KV Mechelen]] and [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] in his native Belgium, and for English clubs [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. It was at Newcastle that he became known as an attack-minded [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre-back]] for his forward runs from defence in the team dubbed as "the Entertainers".<ref name=moore>{{cite news|last1=Moore|first1=Glenn|title=Football: Albert able to call tune on the Tyne: A Belgian centre-back's attacking verve is delighting the Newcastle faithful. Glenn Moore reports|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-albert-able-to-call-tune-on-the-tyne-a-belgian-centrebacks-attacking-verve-is-delighting-the-newcastle-faithful-glenn-moore-reports-1445613.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=29 October 1994}}</ref>

Albert made 41 appearances for the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]] from 1987 to 1997, and represented his country at the [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990]] and [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] World Cups.

==Club career==
Albert started his career with [[R. Charleroi S.C.|Charleroi]] before moving to [[KV Mechelen]] where his performances won him [[Belgian Golden Shoe]] and a move to [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]]. While playing at Anderlecht, he won the Belgian League twice and helped his national side qualify for the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]].

Albert's exploits at the World Cup earned him a £2.6 million transfer to [[Kevin Keegan]]'s [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]; he was issued the number 27 shirt, and completed the transfer on his 27th birthday.<ref name=pet/> He later claimed he turned down moves to Italian clubs [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] and [[AC Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] the year before as did not like the a hot climate or having to play on Sundays, and moved to Newcastle as he was a fan of Keegan and the team he played for, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], in his youth.<ref name=pet/> He was an immediate success in the side as he helped them win their first six league games of the [[1994-95 Newcastle United F.C. season|1994–95 season]], but missed the later stages of the season through injury and Newcastle finished sixth – not even enough for a [[UEFA Cup]] place.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/clubbyclub-guide-the-prospects-the-players-to-watch-the-arrivals-and-departures-1596119.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Ian | last=Ridley | title=Club-by-club guide: The prospects, the players to watch, the arrivals and departures | date=13 August 1995}}</ref> He became a cult hero at Newcastle United due to his less-than-defensive tendencies in "the Entertainers'" central defence, would often make runs forward and be found roaming on the edge of the opposition box. His most famous moment arguably came when he scored an audacious chip from 20 yards over [[Peter Schmeichel]] in a 5–0 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 20 October 1996.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gibbs|first1=Thom|title=Manchester United v Newcastle United: Five memorable moments including Rooney, Cantona and Phillipe Albert|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/9568715/Manchester-United-v-Newcastle-United-Five-memorable-moments-including-Rooney-Cantona-and-Phillipe-Albert.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=26 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Edwards|first1=Luke|title=Flashback: The day Newcastle United shocked Manchester United with 5-0 victory at St James' Park|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/newcastle-united/10501532/Flashback-The-day-Newcastle-United-shocked-Manchester-United-with-5-0-victory-at-St-James-Park.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=6 December 2013}}</ref>

Fans at Newcastle created a terrace chant for the player, singing "Phillipe, Phillipe Albert, everyone knows his name" to the words of the theme song of 1970s children's TV series ''[[The Adventures of Rupert Bear]]''.<ref name=moore/><ref name=pet/>

Injuries towards the end of the decade limited his first-team chances and he spent 13 games on loan to third-tier club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (managed at the time by his former Newcastle boss Keegan), scoring twice during the [[1998-99 Fulham F.C. season|1998–99 season]] as they were promoted from [[Football League Second Division|Division Two]] as champions.

On leaving Newcastle in 1999, Albert returned to Belgium, rejoining Charleroi for £600,000. He spent one season with the club before retiring from football.

==International career==
Albert made 41 appearances for the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]],<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RSSSF]]|author=Mamrud, Roberto|title=Belgium – Record International Players|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/belg-recintlp.html|date=16 July 2009|accessdate=23 October 2009}}</ref> making his debut in 1987, but came to worldwide prominence at the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]]. There he played in four of Belgium's matches, scoring against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] in his first game and against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in the second round match, which Belgium lost 3–2.

==Post-playing career==
Albert is now working as a pundit for Belgian TV, and also runs a successful fruit and vegetable company.<ref name=pet>{{cite web|last=Marshall|first=Paul|title=Au revoir, pet|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=615010&cc=5901|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=1 February 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Fan 'completes' 1996 Premier League sticker album|date = 19 November 2013|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-24992646|accessdate = 22 November 2013|work = [[BBC News Online]]}}</ref>

'''Martin Albrechtsen''' (born 31 March 1980) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] professional [[association football|football]] player, currently playing for the Danish superliga team [[Brøndby IF]]. He can play in any position across the back four and has played four games for the [[Denmark national football team|Danish national team]]. He is the older brother of [[Jacob Albrechtsen]].

==Career==

===Akademisk Boldklub (AB)===
Born in [[Værløse]] in the [[Capital Region of Denmark]], Albrechtsen started his career at [[Akademisk Boldklub|Akademisk Boldklub (AB)]]. Alongside later Danish international [[Peter Løvenkrands]], he was called up for the Danish under-19 national team in September 1997. In February 1998 they both signed their first professional contracts with AB, joining the senior squad which competed in the [[Danish Superliga]] championship. In the  1998-99 season, he scored 1 league goal in 9 games for tAB, while the following season he scores one goal in 31 league games. 

Albrechtsen was a part of the AB team which won the 1999 [[Danish Cup]], and he was named 2000 [[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish ''under-21 Talent of the Year'']]. He made his debut for the [[Denmark national football team]] under national team manager [[Morten Olsen]] in April 2001. As AB struggled financially, Albrechtsen was sold to defending Superliga champions [[F.C. Copenhagen]] (FCK) in a [[Danish krone|DKK]] 9 million [[transfer deal]] in January 2002.

===F.C. Copenhagen===
Albrechtsen signed a 4½-year contract with Copenhagen, looking to replace former team captain [[Jacob Laursen]] in the central defence. In total he played 14 league games for Løverne in the latter part of the  2001-02-season,  while he made 27 league matches in 2002-03. He helped the club.win the 2003 and 2004 Danish Superliga championships, as well as the 2004 Danish Cup trophy. His performances for the club led to two additional national team matches, but after an unimpressive effort during the 0–2 loss to [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] in April 2003, his national team career went on a hiatus. He made his debut for the club on 3 March 2002 when they played 0–0 against AGF. Albrechtsen made his first European appearance for Copenhagen on 27 November 2003 when they drew 1–1 at Mallorca in a match in the UEFA Cup. 

===West Bromwich Albion===
In June 2004, he moved abroad to play for English club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in the [[FA Premier League]]. He was bought in a £2.5 million transfer deal, making him the most expensive player the club had ever bought at that point.<ref>{{cite news
|date=3 June 2004
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_bromwich_albion/3772715.stm
|title=Baggies sign Albrechtsen
|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]
|accessdate=15 May 2007}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on 28 August 2004, coming on as a substitute in a Premiership match against Everton. Albrechtsen was a regular for Albion during 2004–05, helping them to avoid relegation on the final day of the season. He also figured prominently during the following season, and scored his first ever goal for the club in the 1–0 win against [[Wigan Athletic]] at the [[JJB Stadium]] in January 2006.<ref>{{cite news
|date=15 January 2006
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4590276.stm
|title= Wigan 0–1 West Brom
|publisher=BBC Sport
|accessdate=15 May 2007}}</ref> He stayed with the club as Albion were [[relegated]] to the secondary [[The Football League|English Football League]] in the summer 2006, and he scored his second goal for the club against [[Leeds United]] in September 2006. After an absence of more than three years, he was recalled for the Danish national team in November 2006.

Despite being signed as a central-defender, Albrechtsen had, prior to the [[2007-08 in English football|2007–08 season]], been utilised mainly as a full-back. In August 2007 however, Albion manager [[Tony Mowbray]] decided to move the Danish player back into the centre of defence.<ref name="Ton-up">{{cite news
|date=22 August 2007
|url=http://www.wba.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/0,,10366~1096985,00.html
|title=Ton-up Martin 'central' to boss' plans
|publisher=West Bromwich Albion F.C.
|accessdate=22 August 2007}}</ref> Albrechtsen made his 100th appearance for Albion in the 1–0 defeat at Sheffield United on 25 August 2007.<ref name="Ton-up"/><ref>{{cite news
|date=25 August 2007
|url=http://www.wba.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10366~37490,00.html
|title=Sheffield Utd vs WBA
|publisher=West Bromwich Albion F.C.
|accessdate=26 August 2007}}</ref>

===Derby County===
After failing to agree terms with West Brom on a new deal, Albrechsten joined [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on a [[Bosman ruling|Bosman free transfer]], signing a two-year contract with the club on 30 June 2008.<ref name="Rams agree deal for Albrechtsen">{{cite news|title=Rams wrap up Albrechtsen transfer|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7481734.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 July 2008|accessdate=1 July 2008}}</ref> In the process he become manager [[Paul Jewell]]'s eighth signing of the season. Albrechtsen made his debut for Derby in a 1–0 home defeat to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on the opening day of the 2008–09 season,<ref>{{cite news
| title = Derby County vs Doncaster | url = http://www.dcfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10270~43659,00.html | publisher = Derby County F.C. | date = 9 August 2008 | accessdate = 7 October 2008}}</ref> and in September scored his first goal for the club, against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]<ref>{{cite news | title = ALBRECHTSEN LEADS THE WAY | url = http://www.dcfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~1400233,00.html
| publisher = Derby County F.C. | date = 22 September 2008 | accessdate = 7 October 2008}}</ref> and netted his second in the next match, a 2–0 win at [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Q.P.R.]].
Albrechtsen's fine start to his Derby career saw him nominated for the September Championship Player of the Month award, though he lost out to [[Reading F.C.|Reading's]] [[Kevin Doyle]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/reading/7658638.stm], BBCSport, accessed 15 October 2008</ref> The following month he underwent a [[hernia]] operation and kept him away from first team action for around a month.<ref>{{cite news  | title = Albrechtsen sidelined for a month | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/derby_county/7656566.stm | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 7 October 2008
| accessdate = 7 October 2008}}</ref> On his return from injury, he slotted back into the defence and on 18 February he played in his 300th career league game against Blackpool at Pride Park. He quickly fell out of favour with new manager [[Nigel Clough]], however, and his contract at the club was cancelled by mutual consent on 30 August 2009.<ref name="contractterminated">{{Cite web| title=ALBRECHTSEN AND DAVIS LEAVE RAMS|publisher=dcfc.co.uk| url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~1782791,00.html|date=30 August 2009| accessdate= 30 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> After a few days joining FC Midtjylland, Albrechtsen revealed the motives behind his decision to part ways with Derby County. He claimed to have been annoyed at being handed a number of fines by Clough for breaches of club rules like doing interviews without permission.<ref>{{cite news|title=Albrechtsen glad to leave Rams|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11688/5536375/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 September 2009|accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref>

===FC Midtjylland===
After being released from Derby County, FC Midtjylland announced the club have signed [[FC Midtjylland]] on a free transfer and returned to Denmark after spending 5 years in England.<ref>{{cite news|title=FCM retrieves Albrechtsen homes|url=http://www.fcm.dk/index.php?ID=6&nyhedID=5233&mode=laes_nyhed|language=Danish|date=1 September 2009|accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> Following his move, Albrechtsen was given a number 5 shirt. Albrechtsen made his debut in a FC Midtjylland shirt against [[FC Nordsjælland]] on 12 September 2009 in a 2–0 loss. Albrechtsen scored his first goal for the club against [[AaB Fodbold|Aalborg BK]] in a 3–2 win on 2 May 2010. In his first season, Albrechtsen made 21 appearance and scoring 1. In his second season, Albrechtsen scored his first of the season against [[Silkeborg IF]] in a 2–1 win on 27 November 2010 and scored his second of the season against [[F.C. Copenhagen]] in a 5–2 loss on 19 May 2011. Albrechtsen made 20 appearance and scoring 2.

===Brøndby IF===
He signed an one-year-long contract with Brøndby IF on 15 August 2012. On 2 April 2013 the contract was renewed for another two years.

==Honours==
*[[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish ''U-21 Talent of the Year'']]: 2000
*[[Danish Cup]]: 1999, 2004
*[[Danish Superliga]]: 2003, 2004
*[[Football League Championship]]: 2007–08

==Trivia==
* Albrechtsen's nicknames include ''Dolph'' and ''He-Man'', due to his resemblance to the actor [[Dolph Lundgren]] (who portrayed [[He-Man]] in the movie ''[[Masters of the Universe (film)|Masters of the Universe]]'').

==Personal life==
Albrechtsen has two children, Justin and Cassandra. He had their names displayed on a specially designed pair of football boots, which he wore in a league match against Sheffield United in February 2008. The boots were a present from his girlfriend Camilla.<ref>{{cite news
|date=15 February 2008
|url=http://www.expressandstar.com/2008/02/15/albion-stars-multi-coloured-boots/
|title=Albion star's multi-coloured boots
|publisher=[[Express & Star]]
|accessdate=5 May 2008}}</ref>

'''Marc Kevin Albrighton''' (born 18 November 1989) is an English [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. Before signing with the club, Albrighton had spent his entire career  with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] including a loan spell at [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]]; he has also represented the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] and [[England national under-21 football team|U20]] sides.

==Club career==

===Aston Villa===

====Early career====
Albrighton started his career at hometown club Mile Oak Monarchs,<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.thisistamworth.co.uk/news/Mile-Oak-Moscow-Aston-Villa-star-Marc/article-732908-detail/article.html
|title=From Mile Oak to Moscow for Aston Villa star Marc
|publisher=thisistamworth.co.uk
|date=27 February 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> before he was offered a trial at Villa's local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. He was rejected by Albion, then subsequently signed for Villa at the age of eight.<ref name=profile>{{cite web
|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/PlayerProfiles/0,,10265~46559,00.html
|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120423043733/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/PlayerProfiles/0,,10265~46559,00.html
|archivedate=23 April 2012
|title=Player Profiles
|publisher=[[Aston Villa F.C.]]
|date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref>

After impressing in the under-18 squad and playing in the [[Aston Villa F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserves]],<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/players/profile?id=132107&cc=5739
|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090902061708/http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/players/profile?id=132107&cc=5901
|archivedate=2 September 2009
|title=Marc Albrighton Bio
|publisher=[[ESPN]]
|date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> Albrighton's first taste of senior action came on 10 July 2008, playing 17 minutes as a substitute in the 6–0 pre-season friendly victory over [[FC Wil|Wil]].<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~1342074,00.html
|title=FC Wil 1900 0–6 VILLA
|publisher=[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]
|date=10 July 2008 |accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut in the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] game away at [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]]  on 26 February 2009.<ref name=profile/><ref>{{cite news|title=Albrighton grateful to MacDonald|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/aston_villa/8980936.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 September 2010}}</ref>

====2009–10 season====
During the [[2009–10 Aston Villa F.C. season#Friendly Matches|2009–10 pre-season]], Albrighton was included in the squad which played in the pre-season friendly tournament, the [[2009 Peace Cup]], in which he scored his first goal for the club in a 3–1 win over [[Atlante F.C.|Atlante]].<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/2200/peace-cup-2009/2009/07/29/1411193/aston-villa-see-off-atlante-to-progress-in-peace-cup
|title=Aston Villa See Off Atlante To Progress In Peace Cup
|work=[[Goal]]
|date=29 July 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> He played in the Peace Cup final in which Villa beat Italians [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] 4–3 in a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/aug/03/villa-peace-cup-juventus |title=Aston Villa win Peace Cup after beating Juventus |work=The Guardian |date=3 August 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009 | location=London}}</ref>

Albrighton made his [[Premier League]] debut on the opening day of the 2009–10 season against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at [[Villa Park (stadium)|Villa Park]], coming on as a second-half substitute.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_facts/0,19762,11065_3149182,00.html |title=Aston Villa 0–2 Wigan: Match Facts |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=15 August 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2009}}</ref> On 24 September 2009, Albrighton extended his contract with Villa, his boyhood club, by three years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/5580686 |title=Albrighton signs new Villa deal |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=24 September 2009 |accessdate=30 March 2014}}</ref> On 29 December 2009, he made his second top flight appearance for the Villa first team, coming on as a second-half substitute against Liverpool. Shortly after the game, former Villa boss [[Martin O'Neill]] admitted that Albrighton along with fellow youngsters [[Nathan Delfouneso]] and [[Ciaran Clark]] were the subject of many loan offers from clubs throughout the season. However, he went on to state his belief that the trio were good enough to learn their trade in the fringes of the Aston Villa side.<ref>http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2096821,00.html</ref>

====2010–11 season====
After a good pre-season, Albrighton made his first Premier League start in the first game of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]] against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 14 August 2010. In this game he assisted two goals in Villa's 3–0 win. Albrighton also made a run which led to the assist of the goal by [[Barry Bannan]] in Villa's 1–1 draw against [[Rapid Vienna]] in the 1st leg of their [[UEFA Europa League]] qualification tie on 19 August. He scored his first Premier League goal for Villa against Tottenham Hotspur on 2 October 2010. He was sent off against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] on 27 October 2010 therefore missing a chance to play in the following game against local rivals [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]. On 5 November 2010 Albrighton signed a new contract keeping him at the club until 2014. On 6 November Albrighton scored his second goal of the season in a 1–1 draw away at [[Fulham]]. On 13 November 2010, Albrighton scored his third club goal for Aston Villa against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. He started the game alongside fellow academy products Barry Bannan, [[Jonathan Hogg]] and [[Gabriel Agbonlahor]]. After putting Aston Villa 2–0 up, the game ended 2–2. On 23 November, Albrighton was ruled out of action for three to four weeks after having his appendix removed, but made his return ahead of schedule in a 3–0 defeat to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 6 December, playing 65 minutes before being replaced by [[Robert Pires]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2238278,00.html |title=Match report: Liverpool 3–0 Villa &#124; Aston Villa |publisher=Avfc.co.uk }}</ref>
Albrighton then set up both goals for the home side in the 2–1 defeat of local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion]] in December 2010.

====2011–12 season====
Albrighton scored his first goal of the season on 10 December 2011 away at [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16015783.stm "Bolton 1–2 Aston Villa"] BBC Sport. 10 December 2011. Retrieved 10 January 2012.</ref> On 21 December 2011, he scored the Premier League's 20,000th goal at home against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], winning a £20,000 cheque from league sponsors [[Barclays]], donated to his chosen charity, [[Acorns Children's Hospice]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/sports-news/football/premier-league/1397/98/albrighton-get-20000th-premier-league-goal-special |title=Football premier-league: Albrighton: To get 20,000th Premier League goal is special &#124; Radio talkSPORT |publisher=Talksport.co.uk }}</ref> He then scored the opening goal in a 3–1 win against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] at the [[Memorial Ground]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16372066.stm "Bristol Rovers 1–3 Aston Villa"] BBC Sport. 7 January 2012. Retrieved 10 January 2012.</ref> During the 3–2 victory away at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] on 21 January 2012 Albrighton was one of the best players on the pitch, setting up numerous Villa chances.

====2012–13 season====
He made his first appearance of the season on 25 September, coming on as a substitute for [[Andreas Weimann]] during a 4–2 win away to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the third round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19632327 "Manchester City 2–4 Aston Villa"] BBC Sport. 25 September 2012. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>

====2013–14 season====
A throat operation restricted Albrighton to a single outing, in the League Cup, up to October 2013. He joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a 28-day loan on 30 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24743368|title=Marc Albrighton: Aston Villa winger joins Wigan Athletic on loan|date=30 October 2013|accessdate=30 October 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He made four appearances for Wigan before returning to his parent club on 27 November 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aston Villa recall Marc Albrighton from loan spell at Wigan Athletic|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/9044867/|work=Sky Sports|publisher=BSkyB|accessdate=28 November 2013|date=27 November 2013}}</ref> On 15 March Albrighton came off the bench to assist [[Fabian Delph]] against Chelsea FC in a 1–0 Aston Villa victory.

On the 20th May 2014, [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] announced via their [[Twitter]] page that Albrighton, along with [[Nathan Delfouneso]], had been released from his contract and would be a free agent for the start of the [[2014-15 Premier League|2014–15 Season]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mark Albrighton and Nathan Delfouneso released from Villa |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3845958,00.html |work=Aston Villa Official Website |date=20 May 2014}}</ref>

===Leicester City===
On 23 May 2014 Albrighton joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on a four-year contract following their return to the Premier League for the first time in a decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/230514-city-seal-deal-for-albrighton-1572247.aspx}}</ref> Albrighton made his Leicester City debut as a second-half substitute in the 0–2 defeat, away against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].

==International career==
On 2 April 2009, Albrighton made his debut for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under 20s]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/villa-winger-albrighton-stars-england-victory-over-italy-236169 |title=Villa winger Albrighton stars in England victory over Italy|publisher=tribalfootball.com |date=2 April 2009 |accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for [[England national under-21 football team|U21 team]] in September 2010 during their Euro 2011 qualifying play-offs and scored just fifteen minutes after coming on as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web|title=England U21 3–0 Lithuania U21|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8974671.stm|publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport|date=7 September 2010}}</ref>

==Personal life==

Marc confirmed to the [[Birmingham Mail]] that his dreams have come true in playing for Aston Villa, the team he has supported since a young age.<ref>http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/boyhood-aston-villa-fan-marc-146530</ref> He has named  former Villa players [[David Ginola]], [[Benito Carbone]] and [[Robert Pirès]] as some of his footballing role models,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2154591,00.html|title=Albrighton determined to keep thrilling the claret and blue faithful|publisher=avfc.co.uk}}</ref> along with [[England national football team|England]] legend [[David Beckham]] who he has been compared to due to crossing ability and technique.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2248436,00.html|title=Role model Beckham an inspiration for wing wonder Albrighton &#124; Aston Villa |publisher=Avfc.co.uk }}</ref>

Albrighton became a father for the first time on 19 February 2012 when his partner Chloe Fulford gave birth to a baby daughter, Matilda Beau, in [[Sutton Coldfield]].<ref>http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/aston-villa-star-marc-albrighton-179704</ref>
