'''Antolín Alcaraz Viveros''' (born 30 July 1982) is a Paraguayan professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]].

He rarely settled with a team in his early career, before signing in 2003 with [[S.C. Beira-Mar|Beira-Mar]] and remaining with the club five seasons, after which he joined [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]]. He spent the remainder of his career in the [[Premier League]], mainly with [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].

Alcaraz represented [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] and the [[2011 Copa América]].

==Club career==

===Early years / Beira-Mar===
Hailing from a humble background, Alcaraz worked throughout his teenage years as a [[Construction worker|builder’s assistant]] in his hometown of San Roque González. After starting at amateur football in his country, the 19-year-old moved to [[Argentina]] and signed with [[Racing Club de Avellaneda]], appearing rarely during his spell. In 2002 he was loaned to [[ACF Fiorentina]], but the [[Italy|Italians]] soon faced bankruptcy and regrouped in the [[Lega Pro Seconda Divisione|fourth division]]; he then had a trial at [[U.S. Città di Palermo]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archiviostorico.gazzetta.it/2002/agosto/15/Palermo_fatica_Glerean_non_preoccupa_ga_0_0208151215.shtml|title=Il Palermo fatica, ma Glerean non-si preoccupa|trans_title=Palermo gets tired, but Glerean is not worried|publisher=[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]|author=Massimo Manduzio, Franco Cirici, Valter Leone|language=Italian|date=15 August 2002|accessdate=16 May 2010}}</ref> but nothing came of it.

In January 2003, Alcaraz signed for [[Portugal|Portuguese]] club [[S.C. Beira-Mar]]. After seven appearances in half a [[2002–03 Primeira Liga|season]] he became a defensive mainstay at the [[Primeira Liga|top division]] team, eventually also gaining [[Captain (association football)|club captaincy]]; in [[2005–06 Liga de Honra|2005–06]] he helped the [[Aveiro, Portugal|Aveiro]] outfit return to the top flight, playing 31 matches.

===Brugge===
On 30 April 2007 Alcaraz was signed by [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]] in Belgium, with the deal being effective as of July.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=533434.html|title=Club Brugge capture Alcaraz|publisher=UEFA.com|date=30 April 2007|accessdate=16 May 2010}}</ref>

After a slow [[2007–08 Belgian First Division|first season]] he also eventually became first-choice, helping his team to two third-places and one second.

===Wigan Athletic===
On 14 May 2010 Alcaraz signed with [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] for an undisclosed fee,<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=786554&sec=transfers&cc=5901&campaign=rss&source=soccernet Wigan sign Paraguay defender Alcaraz]; [[ESPN Soccernet]], 14 May 2010</ref> as his contract with Brugge was due to expire at the end of June.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.clubbrugge.be/nl/nieuws/media/5703/Antolin-Alcaraz-ruilt-Club-Brugge-voor-Engelse-Wigan|title=Antolin Alcaraz ruilt Club Brugge voor Engelse Wigan|trans_title=Antolin Alcaraz leaves Club Brugge for English club Wigan|publisher=Club Brugge|language=Dutch|date=15 May 2010|accessdate=28 May 2010}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 11 September 2010, netting in the 86th minute for an eventual 1–1 home draw.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=292847&cc=5739 Alcaraz grabs point as Cattermole sees red]; ESPN Soccernet, 11 September 2010</ref>

On 6 November 2011, Alcaraz caused widespread controversy when replays showed him spitting at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] defender [[Richard Stearman]] during Wigan's 1–3 defeat at [[Molineux Stadium]],<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/980866/wolves-angered-as-wigan's-antolin-alcaraz-accused-of-spitting?cc=5739 Alcaraz accused of spitting]; ESPN Soccernet, 6 November 2011</ref> and served a three-game suspension due to his actions.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15619059 Antolin Alcaraz banned after accepting spitting charge]; [[BBC Sport]], 8 November 2011</ref> He later issued an apology.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15702176 Antolin Alcaraz apologises for spitting on Richard Stearman]; BBC Sport, 11 November 2011</ref>

On 7 May 2012 Alcaraz scored the game's only goal at [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] to retain the Latics' top division safety, whilst relegating their opponent to the [[Football League Championship]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17890899 Blackburn 0–1 Wigan]; BBC Sport, 7 May 2012</ref> He won the [[2012–13 FA Cup|2013 FA Cup]], featuring the full 90 minutes in the [[2013 FA Cup Final|1–0 upset]] against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22409634|title=Man City 0–1 Wigan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 May 2013|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> However, only three days later, with him on the pitch again, Wigan were relegated from the top division following a 1–4 defeat at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22430454|title=Arsenal 4–1 Wigan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 May 2013|accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref>

===Everton===
On 9 July 2013, after his contract at Wigan expired,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/13-07-01-player-exits-confirmed-887540.aspx|title=Player exits confirmed|publisher=Wigan Athletic|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> Alcaraz joined [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on a two-year deal, he and goalkeeper [[Joel Robles]] following their manager [[Roberto Martínez]] to the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23247458|title=Antolin Alcaraz and Joel Robles rejoin Martinez at Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 July 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on 29 December after an injury struck his start to [[2013–14 Premier League|the season]], featuring the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 home win against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25482673|title=Everton 2–1 Southampton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2013|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref>
On 26 April 2014, he scored an own goal in the first minute of a 2–0 loss to Southampton, the fastest own goal ever conceded in the current season by Everton
On 1 January 2015 he received his first sending off as an Everton player receiving two yellow cards in a 2-0 loss away at [[Hull City F.C.|Hull City]] which was Evertons fourth successive defeat of the festive period between 2014–15

==International career==
In November 2008, Alcaraz received his first call-up to the [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguayan national team]] at the age of 26.<ref>[http://www.teledeportes.com.py/notas/2008/11/05/futbollocal/c-00003904.htm ¿Lo conocías? (Did you know him?)]; Teledeportes Digital  {{es icon}}</ref> He was picked for the squad present at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]; on 14 June, in the group stage opener against [[Italy national football team|Italy]], in just his seventh international, Alcaraz scored from a [[Set piece (football)|set piece]] powering home a header in a 1–1 draw in [[Cape Town]],<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_11/default.stm Italy 1–1 Paraguay]; BBC Sport, 14 June 2010</ref> and played all the matches and minutes for the eventual quarter-finalists.

Alcaraz was again first-choice for Paraguay during the [[2011 Copa América]], held in [[Argentina]]. On 13 July, he scored the 1–1 equalizer against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]], in an eventual 3–3 group stage draw;<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/jul/14/paraguay-venezuela-copa-america Nicolás Fedor and Grenddy Perozo seal stunning Venezuela comeback]; [[The Guardian]], 14 July 2011</ref> four days later, in the quarter-finals against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], he was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] after an altercation with [[Lucas Leiva]], and the national team eventually finished runner-up.

'''Tobias Albertine Maurits "Toby" Alderweireld''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈtoːbi ˈɑldərˌwɛːrəlt}}; born 2 March 1989) is a Belgian
professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], on loan from [[Atlético Madrid]], and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]]. Mainly a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]], he can also play as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]].

Alderweireld began his professional career at Dutch club [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]], where he won honours including three consecutive [[Eredivisie]] titles. In 2013 he moved to Atlético, where he won [[La Liga]] and reached the [[UEFA Champions League]] final in his first season.

A full international since 2009, he has earned over 40 caps for Belgium and represented the country at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].

==Club career==

===Ajax===
Born in [[Antwerp]],<ref>{{Citation |title =Toby Alderweireld profile  | url=http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler.htm?dbid=59198&typeofpage=84137 |publisher=VI.nl| date = 18 January 2009 |accessdate= 19 January 2009}}</ref> Alderweireld moved to [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]]'s [[AFC Ajax Youth Academy|youth academy]] in August 2004 from [[K.F.C. Germinal Beerschot|Germinal Beerschot]]. On 22 February 2007, he signed his first professional contract tying him to the club until 30 June 2010.<ref>{{Citation |title =Ajax sign Toby Alderweireld | url=http://english.ajax.nl/web/show/id=154814/contentid=61844 |publisher=AFC Ajax| date = 22 February 2007 |accessdate=19 January 2009}}</ref> He was promoted to the first team for the [[2008–09 Eredivisie|2008–09 season]] but only made his first team debut on 18 January, in the 4–2 victory over [[NEC Nijmegen]].<ref>{{Citation |title =Ajax win spectacular match  | url=http://english.ajax.nl/web/show/id=154814/contentid=68549 |publisher=AFC Ajax| date = 18 January 2009 |accessdate= 19 January 2009}}</ref> On 26 February, he made his [[UEFA|European]] debut during a 1–1 draw against [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] in the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]].<ref>[http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2009-02-26-3286180888_x.htm Leonardo scores to help Ajax advance]</ref> Although he only made several appearances for the remainder of the season, he was awarded a new long-term contract extension until 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alderweireld langer bij Ajax|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/telesport/voetbal/article4222177.ece|publisher=[[De Telegraaf]]|date=22 June 2009|accessdate=10 October 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref>

During the early stages of the [[2009–10 Eredivisie|2009–10 season]], Alderweireld established himself in the first team and starting eleven. He became first choice centre-back along with fellow Belgian [[Jan Vertonghen]] (Jan Vertonghen now plays for Tottenham Hotspur) after the departure of former captain [[Thomas Vermaelen]] to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|title='Wij hebben de beste selctie van Nederland'|last=Zwartkruis|first=Simon|work=Association football|date=30 September 2009|accessdate=30 September 2009}}</ref> New coach [[Martin Jol]] praised the two defenders and kept faith in the duo after a string of good performances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/sport/video/extern-jol-vertonghen-en-alderweireld-dat-ziet-iedereen.aspx|title=Jol: 'Vertonghen en Alderweireld, dat ziet iedereen'|publisher=Gazet van Antwerpen|date=17 October 2009|accessdate=27 October 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Coerts|first=Stefan |title =Ajax Coach Martin Jol Praises Jan Vertonghen And Toby Alderweireld | url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/462/netherlands/2009/09/30/1532572/ajax-coach-martin-jol-praises-jan-vertonghen-and-toby |work=Goal| date = 13 October 2009 |accessdate=30 September 2009}}</ref> During the 4 September win against [[SC Heracles Almelo|Heracles]] that ended 3–0, he scored his first league goal for the club when he opened the scoring with a header from [[Luis Suárez]]'s corner.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=271817&cc=3888&league=NED.1 Report: SC Heracles Almelo vs Ajax Amsterdam]</ref> On 27 January, he scored a late equaliser in extra time during the [[2009-10 KNVB Cup|KNVB Cup]] [[2009-10 KNVB Cup#Quarter finals|quarter final]] against [[NEC Nijmegen]] and [[Siem de Jong]]'s late goal five minutes before the final whistle sealed a 3–2 win for Ajax. At the end of the [[2009–10 Eredivisie|2009–10 season]], Alderweireld was named "Ajax Talent of the Year".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/telesport/voetbal/6550355/__Supporters_Ajax_eren_Suarez__.html |title=Supporters Ajax eren Suarez |publisher=Telegraaf.nl |date=18 April 2010 |accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> He assured himself of a place in the Eredivisie giants' history books on 3 November 2011, heading in Ajax's 100th UEFA Champions League goal in the 2–1 Group G defeat by [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=ned/news/newsid=1590396.html |title=Ajax's Alderweireld thrives on art of defending |publisher=UEFA.com by Berend Scholten|date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> In the [[2010-11 Eredivisie|2010–11 season]], he scored a stunning 25-yard strike at the [[San Siro]] against [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] group rivals [[AC Milan]] in a 0–2 away win. He followed this spectacular goal with an even more impressive 32-yard strike against [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] in a 2–0 home win.
[[File:Basis Elftal Ajax 14Sep2011.jpg|thumb|left|Alderweireld with Ajax teammates in 2011.]]
In the 2011–12 season Alderweireld has made significant strides in his ability as a footballer. He has also formed a formidable partnership in the heart of the Ajax defensive with captain and fellow Belgian Jan Verthongen. Alderweireld has also showed some impressive offensive ability scoring a remarkable goal against [[SC Heerenveen]] in Week 2.

On 5 August 2012, during the [[2012 Johan Cruijff Schaal|Johan Cruijff Schaal]] encounter between [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] and Ajax, Alderweireld managed to score for Ajax in the 44th minute, bringing his club back within a goals difference going into halftime 2–1. Unfortunately, it was a match Ajax would lose 4–2, making it the third Dutch Super Cup that Alderweireld participated in and finished as runners-up. The following 2012–13 season however would be a successful one, marking the third year in a row that Alderweireld would play [[UEFA Champions League]] football, and also winning his third consecutive [[Eredivisie]] title for Ajax and 32nd overall, having played as a starting Center Back for Ajax in all three championship pursuits. Alderweireld scored a further three goals that season for Ajax, including two goals during the regular season against [[PEC Zwolle]] and [[FC Twente]], as well as scoring another goal in a 2–0 home victory against [[Steaua București]] at the [[Amsterdam Arena]], in the first leg of the 32nd Round of the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]]. Having been drawn into a group with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and eventual runners-up [[Borussia Dortmund]] during their Champions League campaign, Ajax had entered into the Europa League at the knockout phase having secured third place in their group, but failed to advance, losing in the second leg match in [[Romania]] 4–2 on penalty kicks after extra time.

With one more year remaining on his contract, Alderweireld opted not to extend his contract with Ajax, and received plenty of interest during the off season, with [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] being mentioned as the most keen to sign the young defender.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.de/bayer-04-leverkusen/alderweireld-soll-kommen-kadlec-wechselt-zu-fenerbahce,3288,23318686.html |title=Alderweireld soll kommen Kadlec wechselt zu Fenerbahce |publisher=Express.de by Lars Werner.com|date=14 June 2013 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nieuws.be/nieuws/Napoli_wil_tien_miljoen_euro_betalen_voor_Toby_Alderweireld_6c3bab42.aspx |title=Napoli wil tien miljoen euro betalen voor Toby Alderweireld |publisher=Nieuws.be by Voetbal4U.com|date=18 June 2013 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>

===Atlético Madrid===
On 2 September 2013, Alderweireld joined [[Atlético Madrid]] on a four-year contract for an estimated €7 million (£6.16 m) transfer fee.<ref>{{cite web|title=Transfer deadline day: Atletico Madrid sign Toby Alderweireld and Josuha Guilavogui|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11838/8903655/transfer-deadline-day-atletico-madrid-sign-toby-alderweireld-and-josuha-guilavogui|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=31 August 2014|date=2 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Corrigan|first1=Dermot|title=Toby Alderweireld rejected Liverpool|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/1543223/toby-alderweireld-rejected-liverpool-move-to-join-atletico-madrid|publisher=ESPN FC|accessdate=31 August 2014|date=3 September 2013}}</ref> He played 12 matches as the club won [[La Liga]]; on 11 May, he headed only goal of the season, an equaliser in a 1–1 home draw with [[Málaga CF]] in the penultimate round of fixtures, ensuring that Atlético remained in the title race.<ref>{{cite news|title=Atlético Madrid 1–1 Málaga|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27301114|accessdate=1 September 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=11 May 2014}}</ref> Alderweireld played the final seven minutes and extra time of the [[2014 UEFA Champions League Final]] for Atlético in place of [[Filipe Luís]]; the team were beating rivals [[Real Madrid]] 1–0 when he entered the field of play but eventually lost 1–4.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title=Real Madrid 4 Atlético Madrid 1|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27383593|accessdate=25 May 2014|newspaper=BBC Sport}}</ref>

====Southampton (loan)====
He was loaned to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], on 1 September 2014 with the option for Southampton to buy for £6.3million at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Agreement with Southampton for the loan of Alderweireld|url=http://en.clubatleticodemadrid.com/noticias/agreement-with-southampton-for-the-loan-of-alderweireld|work=[[Atlético Madrid]]|date=2 September 2014|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Southampton loan Toby Alderweireld from Atletico Madrid|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29025087|accessdate=2 September 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=2 September 2014}}</ref> He made his Southampton debut on 13 September, helping to keep a clean sheet in a 4–0 defeat of [[Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29090536 |title=Striker Graziano Pelle scored twice as Southampton overwhelmed a poor Newcastle side at St Mary's Stadium. |work=BBC Sport |date=12 September 2014 |accessdate=14 September 2014 }}</ref> On 26 December, he scored his first goal for the club, Southampton's third in a 3–1 away win at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] by heading [[James Ward-Prowse]]'s [[corner kick]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Emons|first1=Michael|title=Crystal Palace 1-3 Southampton|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30544147|accessdate=26 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=26 December 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:Match Algérie vs Belgique, Coupe du Monde 2014, Brésil.jpg|thumb|Alderweireld playing at the [[2014 World Cup]] against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]]]]
Alderweireld first represented [[Belgium]] at [[Belgium national youth football team|U17 level]] in October 2005 and took part in the [[2006 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2006 UEFA U17 Championship]]. After the [[2008–09 Eredivisie|2008–09 season]] concluded, he made his senior debut for the [[Belgium national football team|Belgian national team]] in a friendly tournament. However his full senior debut came three months later, in a match against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]]. He was named in several [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2010 World Cup qualifying]] squads, but was mostly an unused substitute. In October 2009, he came on as a second-half substitute for [[Daniel Van Buyten]] in the 2–0 defeat to [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]].

Alderweireld was called up to the [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgian U21 squad]] for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification|2011 UEFA U21 Championship qualifier]] against [[Ukraine national under-21 football team|Ukraine]] on 13 November 2009, with the match finishing 2–0 to Ukraine. He played [[Defender (football)|right back]] during
the [[UEFA Euro 2012|2012 UEFA Euro qualification]] match against [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] on 7 September 2010.

On 13 May 2014, Alderweireld was named in the squad to go to the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Adnan Januzaj included in Belgium's World Cup squad|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27395150|accessdate=15 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 May 2014}}</ref> He started in Belgium's first game of the tournament, a 2–1 win against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in [[Belo Horizonte]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=Belgium 2–1 Algeria|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285127|accessdate=17 June 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 June 2014}}</ref>

'''Rati Aleksidze''' ({{lang-ka|რატი ალექსიძე}}; born 3 August 1978 in [[Tbilsi]]) is a [[soccer|football]] [[striker]] from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], who plays for FC Dila Gori

== Career ==
His club career started in [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] in the 1996/97 season. His goal-scoring abilities helped them win the league titles in 1997, 1998 and 1999 as well as the 1997 cup. During his Dinamo career Aleksidze scored 33 goals in 71 appearances, and especially the 12 goals in 14 games in the 1999/00 season attracted the interest of bigger European clubs. He was taken on trial to English team [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], who decided to buy him. Aleksidze found first team opportunities at Chelsea hard to come by, however, as he only played in two league games and one [[UEFA Cup|European]] match, all as substitute.<ref>http://www.bounder.friardale.co.uk/Appearances/Aa-Az.htm</ref> Released by Chelsea in September 2001, he eventually returned to Dinamo where he scored nine goals in his first season. In 2004 he was bought by Russian team [[FC Rostov]], then retired from his professional career and returned to Georgia.<ref>http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/georgiasoccer/AleksidzeNew.html&date=2009-10-25+22:35:11</ref> In July 2008 he made a comeback, playing for [[FC Lokomotivi Tbilisi]]. Then in January 2009 he joined the Hungarian club [[Győri ETO FC]].<ref>http://forum.nyugat.hu/lofiversion/index.php/t1829.html</ref>

== International ==
Due to career difficulties he lost his place on the [[Georgia national football team|national team]], for which he scored 2 goals in 19 caps between 1998 and 2004.

'''Alex Rodrigo Dias da Costa''', better known as '''Alex''' ({{IPA-pt|aˈlɛks|pron}}; born 17 June 1982), is a [[Brazil]]ian [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] and the [[Brazil national football team]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]]. Alex is known for his physical strength and the power of his shot, which has gained him the nickname of "The Tank".<ref name=Tank/>

Having been bought by the [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2004, he was loaned to Dutch team [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] and he won 3 [[Eredivisie]] titles with them. Alex finally joined the Chelsea squad in the summer of 2007 after three years in the [[Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Chelsea target Alex earns permit | work=BBC Football | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/6274174.stm | accessdate=2 August 2007  | date=2 August 2007}}</ref> In his time at Chelsea, he won the [[2009 FA Cup Final|FA Cup in 2009]] and a [[2009-10 Chelsea F.C. season|league and FA Cup "double" in 2010]], as well as reaching the [[2008 UEFA Champions League Final]]. He joined [[Paris Saint-Germain]] for £4.2 million in January 2012 and won [[Ligue 1]] twice with the club, moving to Milan on the expiration of his contract in 2014.

Alex earned 17 caps for [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] between 2003 and 2008, winning the [[2007 Copa América]] and finishing as runner-up at the [[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].

==Club career==

===Santos===
Alex began his career with [[Santos FC|Santos]] of Brazil, making his first team debut in 2002 before later becoming part of the club's central pillars. Alex made his professional league debut in the 1–1 draw against [[Fluminense Football Club|Fluminense]]. Less than a month after his debut, Alex scored his first goal for the club in a match against [[CR Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] on 18 September 2002. After multiple impressive performances, Alex secured his place in the team's regular starting lineup. In his first season playing, in
2002, Santos won the [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Série A]] title, their first since 1968.

In the 2003 season, Alex participated in 34 matches and, despite playing defense, managed to score nine goals. Also in 2003, Alex helped Santos reach the [[2003 Copa Libertadores|final]] of the [[2003 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores]], where Santos lost 5–1 on aggregate against Argentine side [[Boca Juniors]]. In the second leg of Copa Libertadores Finals, Alex scored the only goal for Santos in a 3–1 loss.

Alex was signed by English [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2004 on the recommendation of famed [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] and Chelsea scout [[Piet de Visser (football manager)|Piet de Visser]], but because of potential problems in attaining a [[work permit]], he was [[loan (football)|loaned out]] to Dutch [[Eredivisie]] club PSV.<ref>{{cite news | title=Piet De Visser – Internationaal Voetbalscout| url=http://www.psvzone.nl/selectie_stafflid.php?id=4 | publisher=PSVZone | accessdate=10 December 2006 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060630150732/http://www.psvzone.nl/selectie_stafflid.php?id=4 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 30 June 2006}}</ref>

===PSV (loan)===
[[File:Alex psv.jpg|thumb|right|125px|Alex with [[Phillip Cocu]] (behind) at PSV.]]
The joint contract of Chelsea and PSV loaned Alex to PSV for three years, with Chelsea having a €1 million buy-out clause. Alex eventually played three years at PSV, donning the number 4 jersey for the [[Eindhoven]] club. While playing for PSV, he earned himself the nickname "The Tank" due to his cannonball-like free kicks and his strong physical stature.<ref name=Tank>{{cite web|url=http://www.depers.nl/sport/83093/De-Tank-rolt-naar-Chelsea.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070911223607/http://www.depers.nl/sport/83093/De-Tank-rolt-naar-Chelsea.html |archivedate=11 September 2007 |title=De Tank rolt naar Chelsea |publisher=DePers.nl |date=16 July 2007 |accessdate=15 October 2010 |language=Dutch}}</ref>

He formally joined PSV in the [[2004–05 in Dutch football|2004–05 season]], helping the club win a domestic double of both the [[Eredivisie]] championship and [[Dutch Cup]] that year. In the [[UEFA Champions League 2004-05|Champions League]], Alex played a key role in the PSV team that was eliminated in the semi-finals against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] on away  goals (PSV won their home game 3–1 but had previously lost 0–2 at the [[San Siro]]). The team eliminated [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] and [[Olympique Lyonnais]] on their way to the semi-finals.

Alex won a second straight Dutch league championship in the [[2005–06 Eredivisie|2005–06 season]] with PSV. Chelsea did not recall Alex, even though [[Piet de Visser (football manager)|Piet de Visser]] and Chelsea Head of Scouting [[Frank Arnesen]] recommended that Alex be brought over to solve the club's defensive problems.<ref name="times">{{cite news | author=Matt Hughes | title='Special One' has suffered a power cut | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,277-2548077,00.html |archiveurl=http://www.joinmust.org/forum/showthread.php?t=32325 |archivedate=15 January 2007|work=The Times | date=15 January 2007 | accessdate=17 January 2007 | location=London}}</ref> Instead, Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]] insisted on the signing of [[Khalid Boulahrouz]] in place of Alex.<ref name="times" /> Therefore, Alex stayed a third season at PSV on loan in [[2006–07 Eredivisie|2006–07]]. He won a third straight Eredivisie title with PSV, after a dramatic final-day finish to the season in which PSV sensationally trumped both [[AFC Ajax]] and [[AZ (football club)|AZ]]. Alex scored in a [[UEFA Champions League 2006-07 knockout stage#First knockout round|UEFA Champions League first knockout round]] against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] for both teams in the second half, turning in an [[own goal]] past his own goalkeeper [[Heurelho Gomes]], but compensating for it with a storming headed goal with eight minutes left to play to redeem himself and in the process ensure PSV a place in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news | title=Arsenal 1–1 PSV (agg 1–2) | work=BBC Football | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/6414959.stm | accessdate=9 March 2007  | date=7 March 2007| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20070308101340/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/6414959.stm| archivedate= 8 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He was later injured, however, and played no part in PSV's [[UEFA Champions League 2006-07 knockout stage#Quarter-finals|UEFA Champions League quarter-final]] against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], which PSV lost 4–0 on aggregate.

===Chelsea===

====2007–08====
[[File:Alex Makélélé.jpg|thumb|Alex and [[Claude Makélélé]] warming up a for a match against [[Manchester United]] in 2008]]
In an interview with Dutch newspaper ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', Alex confirmed that Chelsea were in the process of getting him a work permit and that the possibilities of him joining Chelsea next season were very high.<ref>{{cite web | title=Alex set on Chelsea move| work=[[Sky Sports]] | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11668/2454946/alex-set-on-chelsea-move| accessdate=6 July 2014 }}</ref> Alex later confirmed that Chelsea had almost completed the process of acquiring him a work permit and that he would start the season as a Chelsea player.

Alex was granted a work permit on 2 August 2007, and completed his transfer to Chelsea after agreeing to personal terms and passing a medical, where he then signed a three-year deal with the [[London]] club.

On 14 August 2007, Alex was presented to the English media in a press conference with manager [[José Mourinho]], where he was given shirt number 33. He made his debut on 19 August when he came on as a substitute for [[Florent Malouda]] against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the 85th minute, with the teams tied at 1–1. He also played in the 0–2 defeat away at [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and the 4–0 victory over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Liverpool 1–1 Chelsea|work=BBC SPORT | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6941876.stm| accessdate=19 August 2007 | date=19 August 2007}}</ref>

Alex scored his first goal for Chelsea on 20 October 2007, a 30-yard free kick against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Middlesbrough 0-2 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7043006.stm|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 October 2007}}</ref>  He scored from another free kick on 28 November in a Champions League game against [[Rosenborg BK]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/7110716.stm |work=BBC News | title=Rosenborg 0–4 Chelsea | date=28 November 2007 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> He then scored in Chelsea's 4–4 draw with [[Aston Villa]], scoring his first goal at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] from an [[Andriy Shevchenko]] pass, taking his tally for the season to three goals.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 4-4 Aston Villa|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7157291.stm|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=26 December 2007}}</ref>

====2008–09====
Alex enjoyed his longest spell in the first team during the [[2008–09 Premier League|2008–09 season]]. He was given his chance due to regular starter [[Ricardo Carvalho]] being injured for long periods of the campaign. He scored Chelsea's 1,000th Premier League goal against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 1 November 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 5-0 Sunderland|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7684736.stm|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=1 November 2008}}</ref>  Alex started every game for Chelsea under [[Guus Hiddink]], who managed Alex at [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]], and also scored in an [[FA Cup]] quarter-final victory away to [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Coventry City 0-2 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7910378.stm|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=7 March 2009}}</ref> 

[[File:Alex chelsea 3.jpg|Alex playing for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]|upright|thumb|left]]
In the Champions League quarter-finals second leg at Stamford Bridge against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], Alex scored a free-kick from 30 yards out to level the score at 2–2. The game eventually ended 4–4 and Chelsea won 7–5 on aggregate,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/7977038.stm |work=BBC News | title=Chelsea 4–4 Liverpool (agg: 7–5) | date=14 April 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> but Chelsea were eliminated by [[F.C. Barcelona|Barcelona]] in the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/8010840.stm |work=BBC News | title=Chelsea 1–1 Barcelona (agg 1–1) | date=6 May 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> On 10 May, Alex scored a header in Chelsea's 4–1 [[Premier League]] win over Arsenal in the from a [[Didier Drogba]] free-kick.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8023065.stm |work=BBC News | title=Arsenal 1–4 Chelsea | date=10 May 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> The goal was his second against the Gunners in his career.

====2009–10====

Alex played his first pre-season match against [[AC Milan]] in the [[World Football Challenge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerway.com/players/alex-rodrigo-dias-da-costa/2380/ |title=Brazil – Alex Rodrigo Dias da Costa – Profile |publisher=Soccerway |accessdate=18 May 2010| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100606002607/http://www.soccerway.com/players/alex-rodrigo-dias-da-costa/2380/| archivedate= 6 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

On 13 October 2009, Alex signed a new four-year contract with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], keeping him at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] until the summer of 2013.<ref>{{cite news | title = Alex Signs New Chelsea Contract |work=BBC Sport | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/8305678.stm | date=13 October 2009 | accessdate=1 January 2010}}</ref>

Alex missed the start of the season, having sustained a groin injury on 15 August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goal.com/en/news/1715/match-preview/2009/08/22/1454606/premier-league-preview-fulham-chelsea |title=Premier League Preview: Fulham – Chelsea |publisher=Goal.com |date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref> He started his first game of the season in a League Cup match against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 28 October 2009, playing the full 90 minutes. He made his first [[Premier League]] start of the season against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 16 December 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goal.com/en/news/9/england/2009/12/16/1691864/chelsea-2-1-portsmouth-frank-lampard-late-penalty-denies |title=Chelsea 2–1 Portsmouth: Frank Lampard Late Penalty Denies Pompey |publisher=Goal.com |date=16 December 2009 |accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref>

On 13 March 2010, he scored his first goal of the season at Stamford Bridge giving Chelsea the lead in a 4–1 league win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8559629.stm |work=BBC News | title=Chelsea 4–1 West Ham | date=13 March 2010 | accessdate=23 April 2010| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100322194054/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8559629.stm| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

====2010–11====
[[File:Newcastle vs Chesea 28 Nov 2010 - 4.jpg|thumb|180px|Alex and [[Didier Drogba]] marking [[Newcastle United]]'s [[Andy Carroll]] and [[Shola Ameobi]].]]

In light of Ricardo Carvalho's departure to [[Real Madrid]], Alex started the 2010-11 season as first choice centre back for Chelsea, alongside [[John Terry]]. On 3 October 2010, he scored a 25 yard freekick in a 2–0 victory over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]. On 5 October, he was ruled out for up to three weeks after picking up a thigh injury in the final stages of Sunday's 2–0 win over Arsenal, and subsequently withdrew from the Brazil squad for the friendly matches against [[Iran]], and [[Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9044194.stm |title=
Chelsea 2–0 Arsenal |author=Phil McNulty |date=3 October 2010 |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=3 October 2010| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20101004013408/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9044194.stm| archivedate= 4 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Alex made his return for Chelsea where he made his return on 30 October 2010 and played 90 minutes against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in a 2-1 win. On 1 December 2010, Alex suffered a knee injury and was out of action about 3 months. While rehabilitation on his injury, Manager [[Carlo Ancelotti]] would consider signing a new defender if Alex fails to recover from knee surgery before the end of January but Alex failed to do so and Chelsea went on to sign [[David Luiz]] from Benfica.<ref>{{cite news|title=Carlo eyes January buy|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6617821/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=27 December 2010|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> By mid March 2011, Alex made his return to training with the first-team squad.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex set for Chelsea return|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6815022/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>

After he recovered from the injury, Alex made his return on 9 April 2011 in a match against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in a 1-0 win, where he came on for [[Paulo Ferreira]] in the 75th minute. On 8 May 2011, it took a goal-costing mistake from David Luiz against [[Manchester United]] in the season-deciding match for Alex to break back into the starting line-up, getting substituted on at half time that match, and then starting and playing the full 90 minutes the following match against [[Newcastle United]] at Stamford Bridge on 15 May 2011, where he scored a headed goal in the 82nd minute in a 2–2 draw. In the last league game of the season against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], Alex started the match alongside [[John Terry]] but was substituted on 70 minutes for Ferreira in their 1–0 defeat at [[Goodison Park]]. At the end of the campaign, Alex made 20 appearances and scored 2 goals in all competitions. Alex was criticized for allegedly stating in an interview that he was a boyhood Liverpool supporter.

====2011–12====
In the summer transfer window, Alex was the subject of a bid from [[Arsenal F.C.-Chelsea F.C. rivalry|local rivals]] [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Arsenal eyeing Alex|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7137378/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=29 August 2011|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> On 20 August 2011, in a home game against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], a defensive mistake from Alex allowed striker [[Shane Long]] through to score four minutes into the game. In the end, however, Chelsea won 2–1. On 21 September 2011, in a League Cup tie against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], Alex received a straight red card in the 49th minute after a foul on [[Kerim Frei]], which also resulted a penalty. [[Pajtim Kasami]], however, missed Fulham's penalty after his kick was saved by back-up goalkeeper [[Ross Turnbull]]. In the end, Chelsea later won 4-3 on penalties to progress to the next round.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 0 Fulham 0 (AET, 4-3 on pens): 10-man Blues through after ending penalty hoodoo|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2040202/Chelsea-0-Fulham-0-AET-4-3-pens--10-man-Blues-ending-penalty-hoodoo.html#ixzz1ugJkuxAp|publisher=Daily Mail|date=22 September 2011|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> In November 2011, Alex made his last Chelsea appearance in a League Cup in a quarter-final against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], which Chelsea lost 2-0.  He started the match but  committed a handball in the penalty area, which  Turnbull again saved from [[Andy Carroll]].

On 3 December 2011, Alex submitted a transfer request, which was accepted.<ref>{{cite news|title=NEWSFLASH: ANELKA AND ALEX CAN GO|url= http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2536197|publisher=Chelsea's official website|date=3 December 2011|accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> He had been the subject of a bid from [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the first transfer activity under their new manager [[Mark Hughes]]. The move, however, broke down after both parties reportedly failed to agree personal terms; QPR could not match his wage demands and Alex stated he did not want to stay in England.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex wishes to join PSG|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7456612/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Alex transfer from Chelsea to QPR falls through|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/alex-transfer-from-chelsea-to-qpr-falls-through-6293881.html|publisher=The Independent|date=24 January 2012|accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>

===Paris Saint-Germain===
[[File:Alex Rodrigo Dias da Costa (PSG).JPG|thumb|Alex warming up with Paris Saint-Germain]]
On 27 January 2012, Alex joined [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] for £4.2 million<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex completes £4.2m move from Chelsea to Paris Saint-Germain|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/16756100.stm|publisher=BBC|date=27 January 2012|accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref> to reunite with his former manager Carlo Ancelotti. On his move, he publicly stated that the reason for it was that [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] manager [[André Villas-Boas]] had not given him enough playing time at the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex completes move to PSG as defender ends Stamford Bridge misery|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2092692/Alex-completes-PSG-Chelsea.html|work=Daily Mail |date=27 January 2012|accessdate=27 January 2012}}</ref> He was given the number 13 shirt, free since the departure of [[Sammy Traoré]].

On 12 February 2012, Alex made his debut for PSG in a 0–0 draw against [[OGC Nice|Nice]], where he made his first start before coming off for [[Christophe Jallet]] at half-time. The following week, on 19 February 2012, Alex scored a 30-yard goal from a lay-off free kick, his first goal for PSG, against Montpellier on a free-kick combination with compatriot [[Nenê (footballer born 1981)|Nenê]], which the result was 2–2. On 8 April 2012, Alex scored the winning goal in the 61st minute in a 2–1 win over [[Olympique de Marseille]]. On 6 November 2012, in a Champions League match against [[Dinamo Zagreb]], Alex scored the first goal of the match, a  half-volley that evaded the reach of Dinamo goalkeeper [[Ivan Kelava]] after 16 minutes.

On 3 August 2013, Alex scored the game-winning goal with the last kick of the game in PSG's 2–1 defeat of [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] in the [[2013 Trophée des Champions|Trophée des Champions]] at the [[Stade d'Angondjé]] in [[Libreville]], [[Gabon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1513330/paris-saint-germain-beat-bordeaux-trophee-des-champions?cc=5901 |title=Blanc wins first trophy with PSG |publisher=ESPNFC |date=4 August 2013 |accessdate=4 August 2013 }}</ref>

===A.C Milan===
On 5 June 2014, Alex signed for [[A.C. Milan]] on free transfer when his contract with PSG expired.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex joins AC Milan from Paris Saint-Germain ahead of David Luiz's arrival in French capital|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2649853/Alex-joins-AC-Milan-Paris-Saint-Germain-ahead-David-Luizs-arrival-French-capital.html|accessdate=31 August 2014|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=5 June 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut on 31 August in their first match of the new [[Serie A]] season, a 3&ndash;1 home win over [[SS Lazio|Lazio]] in which he deflected [[Antonio Candreva]]'s shot into his own net.<ref>{{cite news|title=AC Milan 3-1 Lazio: Inzaghi era starts with a bang|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/milan-vs-lazio/1836107?ICID=HP_FM_6|accessdate=31 August 2014|work=[[Goal.com]]|date=31 August 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
Alex made his debut for [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] on 17 July 2003 against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in [[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. Although he played under [[Brazil Olympic football team|Brazil U-23 team]] at the tournament, the tournament was a full international tournament, hence the international cap gained was fully recognized by [[FIFA]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Futebol – The Foreign Legion| work=ofutebol.com | url=http://alexbellos.com/fl_country.asp?id=137| accessdate=20 August 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070927091950/http://alexbellos.com/fl_country.asp?id=137 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 27 September 2007}}</ref>

He was overlooked for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] squad. However, after the World Cup, he earned regular call-ups with the new head coach, [[Dunga]]. He was a member of the Brazil squad that won the [[2007 Copa América]] with a 3–0 victory over arch-rivals [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in the final. He was dropped from the Brazilian squad for the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup]] due to injuries.

On 11 May, he was called up to the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] squad as one of the seven back-up players.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbf.com.br/php/noticias.php?e=29&n=11190|title=Comissão técnica da Seleção Brasileira divulga a lista complementar enviada à FIFA|date=11 May 2010|accessdate=12 May 2010|work=CBF.com.br|language=Portuguese| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100515030023/http://www.cbf.com.br/php/noticias.php?e=29&n=11190| archivedate= 15 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

'''Graham Alexander''' (born 10 October 1971) is a former professional [[Association football|footballer]]. He is the manager of [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]].

For most of his career, [[Coventry]]-born Alexander played as a specialist at [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]], but was also deployed in [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfield]],<ref name=autogenerated2>
[http://www.burnleyfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~1102381,00.html Alexander The Seventh! | Burnley | News | Latest Headlines | Latest Headlines<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> as he did early on in his career with [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe]]. He is the fourth oldest player to score in [[Premier League]] history.<ref>[http://www.statbunker.com/football/ktg/index.php?PL=ktgalltime&Code=EPL&statType=oldest_gs]</ref> He was also a [[penalty kick]] specialist. On 16 April 2011, in Burnley's win over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in a Championship match, Alexander became only the second outfield player in English football history to have made 1,000 professional appearances, after [[Tony Ford (footballer born 1959)|Tony Ford]].<ref name="1000th game">{{cite web|title=Burnley 2-1 Swansea  |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13022994.stm  |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2011 }}</ref> He is fifth on the [[list of footballers in England and Scotland by number of league appearances]]. He won the 2013/14 League 1 Playoffs as manager of Fleetwood Town.

==Club career==
Alexander began his career in the late 1980s as a [[youth team|youth player]] with [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]]. He made his first-team debut on 27 April 1991, coming on as a substitute for [[Mark Hine]], and signed his first professional contract the same year. In [[1991-92 in English football|1991–92]], he established himself as a member of Scunthorpe's first team, usually playing at right back.

===Luton Town===
Alexander made over 200 appearances at Scunthorpe before moving to [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] for a transfer fee of £100,000.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/2151067.stm | work=BBC News | title=Alexander eyes Iron tie | date=2002-07-25 | accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref><ref>[http://www.soccerbase.com/players_details.sd?playerid=87 www.soccerbase.com – The Internet Soccer Database<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He went on to make a similar number of appearances with Luton in his four years with the club.

===Preston North End===
In 1999 two clubs were vying for his signature; [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]]. Both clubs made offers for the player but Alexander opted for a move to Preston.<ref>[http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/loadnews.asp?cid=TMNW&id=350838 Graham Alexander is finally a Dingle – Burnley FC – Clarets MAD<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He became a first team regular at [[Deepdale]], eventually club captain and an established set-piece taker, particularly in [[penalty kick|penalties]].<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.burnleyfootballclub.premiumtv.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10413~8811,00.html Graham Alexander | Burnley | Team | Profiles<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Alexander stayed remarkably fit during his career, hardly ever suffering a major injury. However, during the [[2000-01 in English football|2000–01]] season, Alexander missed several weeks of the season after breaking his [[ribs|rib]] in an away match against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/1090991.stm | work=BBC News | title=Alexander injury blow for Preston | date=2000-12-28 | accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref> During his eight years at Preston, Alexander made exactly 400 appearances for the club, with his 400th and final match coming against [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester]] on 25 August 2007.<ref>[http://www.pnefc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10362~1098579,00.html 400 Up For Grezza | Preston North End | News | Latest | Latest<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was also in the PFA's Championship Team of the Season for [[2004-05 in English football|2004–05]]<ref name=autogenerated3 /> 

During the summer of 2007 a number of clubs were linked with Alexander including [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] who had a £50,000 bid turned down by Preston, who said;
<blockquote>
"He is club captain and a vital member of this squad and certainly not a player we will allow to leave."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/5221206.stm | work=BBC News | title=Preston reject bid for Alexander | date=2006-07-27 | accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref>
</blockquote>

===Burnley===
On 29 August 2007, he made a surprise move to local rivals [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] almost nine years after they had originally tried to sign him. The reasons cited for his departure were that Preston would not extend his contract by another year,<ref>[http://www.pnefc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10362~1103387,00.html Grezza's Emotional Farewell | Preston North End | News | Latest | Latest<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> so when offered a two-year contract by Burnley the player accepted and made a £200,000 move to [[Turf Moor]].<ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/preston/6970677.stm | work=BBC News | title=Burnley recruit PNE's Alexander | date=2007-08-31 | accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref> Preston [[Chairman]] [[Derek Shaw (businessman)|Derek Shaw]] did not want to lose the player and said;

<blockquote>
"We don't particularly want to sell Graham but he has the comfort of a two-year contract at Burnley whereas he only has one year here at Deepdale. We quite possibly would have renewed Graham's contract, he's a fit man." <ref name=autogenerated5 /><ref>http://www.lep.co.uk/WebPartsTpls/sport?articleid=3161836</ref>
</blockquote>

The £200,000 transfer money was made up of £100,000 payable in 2007 and the final £100,000 payable in the summer of 2008.<ref name=autogenerated2 />

In Burnley's promotion season in 2008–09 Alexander at the age of 37 played in all of Burnleys 61 League and Cup games that season ending with the 1–0 Play-Off final victory over Sheffield United at Wembley which took Burnley back to the Top Flight of English Football for the first time in 33 years.

On 29 June 2009, Alexander signed a new one-year contract at Burnley,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/8123860.stm|title=Alexander pens new Burnley deal |date=2009-06-29|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref> and on 15 August he became the oldest player to make a Premier League debut. On 19 September, Alexander scored his first Premier League goal, a penalty, in a 3–1 win at home to [[Sunderland AFC|Sunderland]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 3–1 Sunderland |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8255397.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=19 September 2009 |accessdate=19 September 2009 }}</ref> On 31 October 2009, Alexander scored both goals in a 2–0 home win against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley 2–0 Hull |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8333572.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=31 October 2009 |accessdate=31 October 2009 |first=Oliver |last=Brett}}</ref> A week later he then scored the first for Burnley, from the spot, at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in a thrilling 3–3 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man City 3–3 Burnley |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8342972.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=7 November 2009 |accessdate=7 November 2009 }}</ref> On 16 December, he scored his 100th league goal. He scored an equaliser against Arsenal, sending ''Gunners'' 'keeper [[Manuel Almunia]] the wrong way. On 10 April 2010, Alexander again scored twice against Hull City – both penalties – in a 4–1 win to take his tally for the season to eight, seven of which have been penalties. Alexander takes penalties in an unusual way, opting to use the outside of his foot rather than the inside. On 6 May 2010 he was named Burnley's Player of the year for the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley Player of the Year Awards  |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2044757,00.html |work=www.burnleyfootballclub.com |date=6 May 2010 |accessdate=7 May 2010 }}</ref> He is among the oldest players ever to score in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1249463/Goal-den-oldies-Kevin-Phillips-latest-Premier-League-veteran-hit-net.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Clare | last=Martin | title=Goal-den oldies: Kevin Phillips becomes the latest Premier League veteran to hit the net | date=9 February 2010}}</ref>

On 5 August 2010 Burnley's First Team Manager, [[Brian Laws]], officially named the 38-year-old as club captain for the 2010–11 season.<ref name="burnleyfootballclub.com">http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2111901,00.html</ref> On Alexander's appointment, Laws said "Graham is the consummate professional who has been instrumental in the success that this club has seen in the past few seasons, so it was an easy choice" <ref name="burnleyfootballclub.com"/>

In April 2011, Alexander made his 1,000th senior appearance for club and country in a 2–1 win against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] as an 87th minute substitute.<ref name="1000th game"/> Only [[Tony Ford (footballer born 1959)|Tony Ford]] has matched this feat as an outfield player.<ref name="1000th game"/> At the end of the season, Alexander looked likely to leave [[Turf Moor]], as he was linked with managerial jobs with [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] and [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]], but Burnley boss [[Eddie Howe]] stated that he was still part of his plans for the following season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley captain Graham Alexander to stay at Turf Moor |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9522169.stm |work=BBC Sport |date=24 June 2011 |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref> On 4 July 2011, Alexander was released by Burnley.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alexander Leaves Turf Moor|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2386010,00.html|publisher=Burnley Football Club|accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref>

===Return to Preston North End===
Alexander returned to [[Preston North End]] on 3 August 2011, as he signed a one-year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14392301.stm|title=Graham Alexander re-joins Preston North End|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=3 August 2011|accessdate=4 August 2011}}</ref> He was given the number 22 and made his debut against [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]].

Alexander scored his first goal for Preston in 4 years with a trademark penalty in a 2–1 home win against Tranmere on 24 September 2011.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14958277
|title=Preston   2 - 1   Tranmere
|publisher=BBC
|date=24 September 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> This was after his first penalty back in a Preston shirt was saved by Exeter's [[Artur Krysiak]],<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14514783
|title=Preston   1 - 0   Exeter
|publisher=BBC
|date=20 August 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> and before his third was saved by [[Lee Butcher]] of Leyton Orient.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15045281
|title=Leyton Orient   2 - 1   Preston
|publisher=BBC
|date=1 October 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> His next penalty came in a penalty shootout against Rochdale in the [[Football League Trophy]], which was slotted into the top corner after he was brought on as a substitute for [[Conor McLaughlin]] especially to take a penalty in the shootout.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15534949
|title=Rochdale   1 - 1   Preston
|publisher=BBC
|date=8 November 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> However, he missed his next penalty, again in the JPT, and again in a penalty shootout, this time against Chesterfield. He was the third Preston player to take a penalty in this shootout, and he blazed it over the bar, much to the disbelief of the fans. Preston's next penalty-taker, [[Paul Coutts]], had his penalty saved, and then when the next penalty was scored by Chesterfield's [[Alexandre Mendy]], Preston got knocked out of the tournament.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15933261
|title=Preston   1 - 1   Chesterfield
|publisher=BBC
|date=6 December 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> Alexander started the next league game against Stevenage but was replaced through injury by [[Steven Smith (footballer)|Steven Smith]] after just 3 minutes,<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16015514
|title=Preston   0 - 0   Stevenage
|publisher=BBC
|date=10 December 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> after which Alexander did not feature for the Lilywhites for a long time, and there was speculation that he had played his last game for Preston, and in his career.

After the sacking of Phil Brown a few games down the line, he became joint-caretaker manager, alongside David Unsworth. His first match in joint-charge was an away match against MK Dons, which they won 1–0. Just before what was to be an ordinary match against Wycombe Wanderers, it was announced that Graham Westley would replace them at the helm of Preston, and that Wycombe was to be the last match in charge for the pairing of Alexander and Unsworth. They won the match 3–2, and left a good base for Westley to build on.

Playing his final game on 28 April 2012 against [[Charlton Athletic F.C|Charlton Athletic]], Alexander came on as a substitute for [[Max Ehmer]] in the 84th minute. This was supposed to be a cameo appearance to allow the Preston supporters to show their appreciation of his service to the club. However, with Preston losing 1–2 in stoppage time, they were awarded a free-kick 25 yards from Charlton's goal. Alexander stepped up to curl the ball around the wall and inside the near post, scoring with the very last kick of his career.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17796001
|title=Preston   2 - 2   Charlton
|publisher=BBC
|date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref>

On 20 June 2012, Alexander was appointed Head of Youth Development.  Chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] said "He's got over 1,000 games under his belt, he's a hero here and what better person to head our youth development." <ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18525245
|title=Preston appoint Graham Alexander as head of youth development
|publisher=BBC
|date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref>

In July 2013 Alexander was voted Preston North End's greatest ever right back by the fans.

==International career==
Although Alexander was born in [[England]], he was eligible to play for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] through his Scottish father.<ref name ="father"/> Before his first international call, Alexander said, "To be honest, since I started playing football, I've had two ambitions: to play in the Premier League, and to play for Scotland. I've been brought up supporting Scotland as far back as I can remember."<ref name ="father">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/1908913.stm |title=Alexander hoping for Scotland call |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=3 April 2002 |accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> This ambition was fulfilled when he made his Scotland debut on 17 April 2002 in a 2–1 friendly defeat to [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] at [[Pittodrie Stadium]].<ref name=autogenerated4/> Alexander was part of the Scotland squad who won the annual Japanese [[Kirin Cup]] tournament in 2006, beating [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] 5–1 before drawing 0–0 with [[Japan national football team|Japan]].<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kirin.html Kirin Cup]</ref> He gained his 25th Scotland [[cap (sport)|cap]] in a famous 1–0 victory against [[France national football team|France]].<ref name="Scotland 1-0 France">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/5397614.stm |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Sport |title=Scotland 1–0 France |date=7 October 2006 |first=Colin|last=Moffat}}</ref> He gained a total of 40 caps for Scotland. Alexander was shown only one yellow card while playing for Scotland, against [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] in May 2003.

'''Jens Niclas Alexandersson''' ({{IPA-sv|ˈnɪklɑs ɑlɛkˈsɑndɛʂɔn}} (born on 29 December 1971 in [[Halmstad]], [[Sweden]]) is a retired [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Association football|football]] [[midfielder]]. He played as a right winger and right full back. Apart from his versatility, he is known for his dribbling and stamina.

==Club career==
After starting his career with local club Vessigebro BK he moved to [[Halmstads BK]] in 1988. He played for the team until 1995, when he joined [[IFK Göteborg]], with whom he won the Swedish Championships and played in the [[UEFA Champions League]]. After one year in [[Gothenburg]], he moved on to England, where he was signed for £750,000 by [[Ron Atkinson]] for [[Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref name="sheffieldwednesday.rivals.net">http://sheffieldwednesday.rivals.net/default.asp?sid=894&p=2&stid=7961461</ref> He played for three seasons in Sheffield, where he became a fan's favorite and won the Player of The Season award the year the team was relegated.<ref name="sheffieldwednesday.rivals.net"/> After relegation he was signed by [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] for £2.5m where he played for from 2000–2003, until he moved back to [[Gothenburg]], where he played from 2004–2008. After the retirement last season he has been working on [[IFK Göteborg]] project Änglagårdskolan. Is a school where you can combine school and football in the spirit of [[IFK Göteborg]]. 27 September 2009, newspapers told that Niclas is going for a comeback and will be start training again on 29 September 2009.<ref>http://www.sr.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2835&artikel=3129628</ref> On 2 October 2009 it was revealed that Alexandersson has sign a contract for the rest of the season.<ref>http://www.fotbollskanalen.se/1.1247026/2009/10/02/ifk_har_skrivit_kontrakt_med_alexandersson_han_spelar_pa_mandag</ref> After the season, he retired for good.

==International career==
He made his debut for the national team in 1993, and has since participated in 100 international games, scoring seven goals. His participation in the national team includes the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] and one [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Championship]] ([[2000 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 2000]]). He was also a member of the Swedish squad that competed at the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in Barcelona. One of his goals came in Sweden's 1–1 draw against England, which he shot powerfully from outside the box and passed through [[David Seaman]] during the group stages of the 2002 World Cup.

The day after Sweden's exit from [[Euro 2008]] he decided that he would retire from the national team alongside [[Marcus Allbäck]], however he also said that if it was needed, due to injuries, he would play for the national team again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svttext/web/pages/303.html|title=The first blue and yellow to retire|date=19 June 2008|accessdate=19 June 2008|publisher=SVT.se}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Alexandersson was born in [[Halmstad]] on 29 December 1971 to father [[Lennart Alexandersson]], a former Halmstads BK player. He grew up in [[Falkenberg]], where he started playing football in the local club [[Vessigebro BK]]. In 1978, his brother [[Daniel Alexandersson]], who is also a professional football player, was born. In 1988, he moved to Halmstad to play for Halmstads BK. While living in Halmstad, he attended [[Sannarpsgymnasiet]], the same school Swedish footballer [[Fredrik Ljungberg]] attended.

Alexandersson married his wife Frida. The couple had first child Tilda in 1999 and son named Noah in 2001.<ref>http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotbollsbladet/article78995.ab</ref> While playing football, Alexandersson's family has lived in numerous places including [[Sheffield, England|Sheffield]], Liverpool, and London before returning to [[Gothenborg]].
