'''Jérémie Aliadière''' (born 30 March 1983) is a [[France|French]] [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]] for [[Umm Salal SC|Umm Salal]].

As a graduate of the elite [[Clairefontaine]] academy, he signed for Arsenal aged 16. After making his Premier League debut in the [[2001–02 in English football|2001–02]] season, he ultimately had limited opportunities, partly due to injury. For the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season he was loaned to three clubs, [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in the [[Scottish Premier League]], [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in the Premier League, and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the [[Football League Championship]], before returning to Arsenal for another season, featuring in the [[2007 Football League Cup Final]] loss to Chelsea. At the beginning of the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08]] season he was sold to Premier League club Middlesbrough for £2.5 million, where he spent the next three seasons, two in the Premier League and the last in the Championship, before electing not to extend his contract and leaving the club in June 2010.

== Club career ==

=== Arsenal ===
Aliadière signed for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at the age of 16 before the beginning of the [[1999–2000 in English football|1999–2000]] season. 
He made his Premiership debut for Arsenal against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in the [[2001–02 FA Premier League|2001–02 season]], replacing [[Thierry Henry]] in a 4–1 victory. That game was his only league appearance that season, meaning he wasn't eligible for a medal as Arsenal won the [[2001-02 FA Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Games played by Jeremie Aliadiere in 2001/2002|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=28839&season_id=131|publisher=Soccerbase|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club the following season, in a 5–2 victory over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on 27 August 2002.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2216506.stm | title=Slick Arsenal crush Baggies | publisher=BBC Sport | date=27 August 2002 |accessdate=31 August 2009}}</ref>

In the [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04]] season, Aliadière was mainly played in the [[2003–04 Football League Cup|2003–04 League Cup]] rather than the league, scoring Arsenal's first League Cup goal of the season against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]]. The match finished 1–1 after extra time, with Arsenal winning 9–8 on penalties.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3204793.stm | title=Arsenal 1–1 Rotherham | publisher=BBC Sport | date=28 October 2003 |accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> He also scored twice against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the following round of the League Cup,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3246940.stm | title=Arsenal youngsters thump Wolves | publisher=BBC Sport | date=2 December 2003 |accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> his second winning goal for the month for December. In total he scored four goals in the cup run, having also scored against West Brom in the quarter finals, with Arsenal finally being eliminated by [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3314305.stm | title=Arsenal outgun Baggies | publisher=BBC Sport | date=16 December 2003 |accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> He was voted best young talent in the 2003–04 League Cup.<ref>[http://www.carlingcup.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/0,,11995~611622,00.html  Rising Stars]. Retrieved 1 December 2007 {{Dead link|date=September 2010}}</ref> As the season went on, he made further inroads into the Arsenal first team, playing 10 Premier League matches, seven as a substitute, to gain a Premier League winners' medal, as well as making his [[FA Cup]] debut in a 1–0 defeat against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the semi finals. He also came on as a late substitute in Arsenal's 5-1 victory over [[Inter Milan]] in the [[San Siro]]. Seconds after coming on he set up the 5th goal for [[Robert Pires]].<ref>{{cite web 
|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2003/nov/26/match.championsleague
|title=Arsenal rise from the ashes
|publisher=Guardian
|date=26 November 2003 |accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref>

Aliadière missed much of the following [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]] season through injury, and was kept out of action until February. On his return, he made six substitute appearances for the first team. Although he failed to score in these matches, he scored eight goals in five games for Arsenal's reserves. Despite his limited opportunities, he was offered and signed a new Arsenal contract, running until the summer of 2009, announced at the same time as a loan move to Celtic.<ref>{{cite news|title=New deal for Aliadiere|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11670/2339962/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=25 June 2005|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

=== Loan to Celtic ===
In the summer of 2005, Aliadière was sent on loan to Scottish club [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], for the entire [[2005–06 in Scottish football|2005–06]] season, in order to play regular first team football. Despite his limited appearances, Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger had stated he had a future at Arsenal, despite being kept out of the side at the time by the form of [[Thierry Henry]] and [[Dennis Bergkamp]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Aliadiere signs on at Celtic Park|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/celtic/4625607.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 July 2005|accessdate=25 November 2007}}</ref> In the end, his time at Celtic was forgettable; he made just two substitute appearances for the club, one in each leg of their loss to [[FC Petržalka 1898|Artmedia Bratislava]] in the [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. He accused Celtic manager [[Gordon Strachan]] of not giving him a chance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11685/2346045/|title=Aliadiere slams Strachan|publisher=Sky Sports|date=25 August 2005|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

=== Loan to West Ham United ===
On 24 August 2005, Aliadière decided to move back to London after a lack of first team opportunities, where [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] took over his year-long loan deal, having been promoted back to the Premier League after two seasons in the lower leagues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aliadiere leaves Celtic, joins Hammers on loan|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=340400&cc=5739|publisher=Soccernet.epsn.go.com|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref>  Once again affected by injury, he only made eight appearances for West Ham, seven as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jeremy Aliadiere|url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=819&united=Jeremie_Aliadiere|publisher=westhamstats.info|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref>

=== Loan to Wolverhampton Wanderers ===
On 31 January 2006, West Ham terminated the loan, and Aliadière moved to the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] to join the [[Football League Championship]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on loan for the remainder of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season. He scored two league goals for Wolves, in games against Hull<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4727024.stm | title=Hull 2–3 Wolves | publisher=BBC Sport | date=25 February 2006 | accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> and Watford.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4890832.stm | title=Wolves 1–1 Watford | publisher=BBC Sport | date=14 April 2006 | accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> At the end of the season he returned to Arsenal.

=== Return to Arsenal ===
Having returned to Arsenal, during the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season Aliadière was again mainly used in the [[2006–07 Football League Cup]] campaign, scoring both goals in their 2–0 win over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on 24 October 2006.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6072672.stm | title=West Brom 0–2 Arsenal | publisher=BBC Sport | date=24 October 2006 | accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> His first Premier League goal of the season came on 16 December 2006, a 2–2 draw against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], with Aliadière playing for 70 minutes before being replaced by [[Robin Van Persie]]. Continuing appearances in Arsenal's League Cup campaign saw him score in the quarter-final against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a 6–3 victory, and in the second leg of the semi-final against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], with Arsenal advancing with a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6236687.stm | title=Liverpool 3–6 Arsenal | publisher=BBC Sport | date=9 January 2007 | accessdate=2 November 2009 | first=Sam | last=Lyon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6305313.stm | title=Arsenal 3–1 Tottenham (agg 5–3) | publisher=BBC Sport | date=31 January 2007 | accessdate=2 November 2009 | first=Sam | last=Lyon}}</ref> Arsenal ultimately lost [[2007 Football League Cup Final|the final]] 2–1 to Chelsea, with Aliadière featuring for 80 minutes.

With four appearances in Premier League matches during the season; as of 9 January 2007 he had played 37 times for Arsenal, 25 as a substitute, scoring nine goals, all but one coming in the League Cup, four against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. In the January 2007 transfer window, Aliadière was linked with a move to the Premier League club [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in North East England, after Wenger said he would be allowed to leave the club. The move failed to happen however, after [[Robin van Persie]] broke his foot, and he was told to stay at Arsenal for the time being. He made his final Arsenal appearance on the final day of the 2006–07 season against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in a 0–0 draw at [[Fratton Park]].

=== Middlesbrough ===
[[File:Jérémie Aliadière 18-10-2008 1.jpg|thumb|Aliadière playing for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in 2008]]
Middlesbrough signed Aliadière on 19 June 2007, for an initial fee of £2&nbsp;million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aliadiere completes Boro switch |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/m/middlesbrough/6736685.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 June 2007 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref> He scored his first goal in a Premier League match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]] in October 2007, with a header to draw level at 1–1, before Middlesbrough went on to lose the game 4–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd 4–1 Middlesbrough |first=Ian |last=Hughes |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7054065.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2007 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref> This was his first Premier League goal, since scoring his first ever for Arsenal on 27 August 2002. He scored for Middlesbrough against old club Arsenal on 15 March in a 1–1 draw,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7284973.stm | title=Arsenal 1–1 Middlesbrough | publisher=BBC Sport | date=15 March 2008 | accessdate=2 November 2009 | first=Saj | last=Chowdhury}}</ref> before rounding off the season, scoring in the final day 8–1 victory over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 11 May 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Middlesbrough 8–1 Man City |first=Chris |last=Bevan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7381794.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2008 |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref>

Aliadière got a red card and three match ban for slapping [[Javier Mascherano]]  in a 23 February 2008 Premier League match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], after Mascherano had raised his hands against him, in full view of the referee. It was the cause of controversy after Middlesbrough's consequent appeal was deemed as "frivolous" by [[the Football Association]] (FA) and extended by one more game, with the club's chairman and chief executive, and Tottenham manager [[Harry Redknapp]], deeming this unfair and criticising the FA, contrasting it with a recent appeal by Chelsea's [[Michael Essien]].<ref name="Lamb Slaughters FA">{{cite news | title = Lamb Slaughters FA | url = http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11680_3200633,00.html | publisher = Sky Sports | date = 27 February 2008 | accessdate = 2008-02-27}}</ref><ref name="Gibson rages at FA over appeal">{{cite news | title = Gibson rages at FA over appeal | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/middlesbrough/7263735.stm | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 28 February 2008 | accessdate = 2008-02-28}}</ref><ref name="Harry Slams Appeals Process">{{cite news | title = Harry Slams Appeals Process | url = http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11680_3210265,00.html | publisher = Sky Sports | date = 28 February 2008 | accessdate = 2008-02-28}}</ref>

Before the start of the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09]] season, Aliadière switched to wearing the number 10 previously worn by midfielder [[Fábio Rochemback]], when his number 11 was given to 3.2 million summer signing [[Marvin Emnes]]. He scored his first goal of the season in Middlesbrough's 5–1 home victory against [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] on 26 August 2008. His first Premier League goal of the season came in a 1–0 win against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at the [[JJB Stadium]] on 4 October 2008, scoring in the 89th minute of the match. After a run of not scoring in his next ten matches, he again scored against his old club Arsenal, with a headed equaliser in a home 1–1 draw on 13 December 2008.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7763484.stm | title=Middlesbrough 1–1 Arsenal | publisher=BBC Sport | date=13 December 2008 | accessdate=2 November 2009 | first=Phil | last=McNulty}}</ref> At the end of the season, Middlesbrough finished equal bottom of the Premier League with West Brom, on 32 points, and as a result were relegated to the [[Football League Championship]].

On 12 September 2009, he came off the bench against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] to score two goals after 30 minutes of being on the pitch, and scored another goal in the same week against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]. His next goal came on 26 December against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]], in his first start under new manager [[Gordon Strachan]] due to injury. Having failed to reach the play-offs, and after three injury hit seasons at Middlesbrough, he left the club on 30 June 2010 at the end of his contract having decided not to take up the option of extending his contract. In total he had made 86 appearances, scoring 12 goals, for the club.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/middlesbrough/8664874.stm | title=Jeremie Aliadiere set for Middlesbrough exit – Strachan | publisher=BBC Sport | date=6 May 2010 | accessdate=31 August 2010}}</ref> 2010–11 pre-season found Aliadière training with West Ham with a view to a permanent move to the London club. The deal fell through when he damaged his knee ligaments playing in a reserve game against Crystal Palace. Subsequently his old club Middlesbrough offered the player full use of their rehabilitation and training facilities in order to overcome the injury and regain full fitness.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Jeremie-Aliadiere-salutes-former-club-Middlesbrough-for-helping-him-overcome-his-cruciate-knee-ligament-injury-he-suffered-at-West-Ham-article571837.html | title=Aliadiere salutes Middlesbrough after injury nightmare | publisher=Mirror Football | date=4 September 2010 | accessdate=5 September 2010 }}</ref>

In January 2011, Aliadiere also revealed he was linked with a move to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] but the move collapsed over contract issues; he described the experience as hitting 'rock-bottom'.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nightmare for Aliadiere|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6914372/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=5 May 2011|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> [[Al Ain FC|Al Ain]], a club based in the [[United Arab Emirates]], announced on 13 February 2011 that they had signed Aliadiere,<ref>{{cite news|title=The French striker Jérémie Aliadière joins Al Ain Club|url=http://www.alainfc.net/en/index.php?p=shownews&nid=2240|publisher=alainfc.net|date=13 February 2011|accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref> but he subsequently denounced their claim, stating that he had rejected a move and Al Ain had "been very unprofessional in their conduct".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_6754114,00.html | work=Sky Sports | title=Aliadiere rejects Al Ain move}}</ref>

=== Post-Middlesbrough ===
In March 2011, Aliadière returned to former club, Arsenal's [[London Colney]] training ground in a bid to return to fitness.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1363877/Jeremie-Aliadiere-training-Arsenal.html| title=Wenger welcomes Aliadiere back to Arsenal training as striker seeks to rebuild his career | work=Daily Mail | date=8 March 2011| accessdate=8 March 2011 | location=London | first=Sami | last=Mokbel}}</ref> Aliadiere, along with the newly re-signed [[Jens Lehmann]], both played the full 90 minutes in a reserve game against Wigan on 29 March 2011, losing the game 2–1.

=== Lorient ===
On 5 July 2011, Aliadière signed a deal with [[Ligue 1]] club [[FC Lorient]] on a free transfer, to revive his career and an options of three years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-Arsenal striker joins Lorient|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/transfer-news/Ex-Arsenal-striker-Jeremie-Aliadiere-joins-Lorient-article759248.html|work=Daily Mirror|date=5 July 2011|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> It was revealed [[Arsène Wenger]] helped Aliadiere seal his move to Lorient.<ref>{{cite news|title=WENGER HELPS SEAL ALIADIERE'S LORIENT MOVE|url=http://younggunsblog.co.uk/2011/07/wenger-helps-seal-aliadieres-lorient-move/|publisher=younggunsblog.co.uk|date=5 July 2011|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> He made his debut for Lorient, in a 2–0 win against [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]]. Aliadiere scored his first goal and score another, in a 3–0 win over [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Montpellier held 2–2 at Brest in French league|url=http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=1710146|publisher=taiwannews.com |date=18 September 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> On 18 October 2011, Aliadiere agreed to a new three-year deal with Lorient<ref>{{cite news |title=Aliadiere pens Lorient deal |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7249166/ |work=Sky Sports |date=18 October 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> and Aliadiere officially signed it on 1 November 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aliadiere delighted with deal|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7289615|work=Sky Sports|date=3 November 2011|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref>

In Lorient's 2–2 draw with [[Paris Saint-Germain|PSG]] to start the [[2012-13 Ligue 1]] season, Aliadiere scored Lorient's second, putting them up 2–0 at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=342954&cc=5901 |title=Paris Saint-Germain 2 – 2 Lorient |publisher=ESPNFC |date=11 August 2012 }}</ref> With his side down 4–1 at home to [[AC Ajaccio|Ajaccio]] on 28 October 2012, Aliadiere scored a second-half brace to help Lorient earn a point, as [[Gilles Sunu]] scored Lorient's fourth goal in the dying seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=342859&cc=5901 |title=Lorient 4–4 AC Ajaccio |publisher=ESPNFC |date=28 October 2012 }}</ref> On 9 December, Aliadière opened the scoring against title contenders [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]], striking from the penalty spot and also provided the assist for [[Kevin Monnet-Paquet]]'s strike, as Lorient won comfortably 3–0 at the [[Stade Velodrome]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/342805/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |title=Marseille 0–3 Lorient |publisher=ESPNFC |date=9 December 2012 }}</ref>

On 12 December, Aliadière received the ball from a poor clearance by Sochaux goalkeeper [[Simon Pouplin]] and found [[Alain Traoré]], who fizzed a long-range effort in off the left-hand post, giving Lorient a 1–0 lead; Lorient went on to win 2–0 and moved up to fourth in the Ligue 1 table.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/342795/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |title=Lorient 2–0 Sochaux |publisher=ESPNFC |date=12 December 2012}}</ref> Lorient continued their ascent up the Ligue 1 table with a 2–0 defeat of [[AS Saint-Étienne]] on 16 December, Aliadière opening the scoring in the 20th minute after defeating two defenders and finishing past the keeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/342785/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |title=St Etienne 0–2 Lorient |publisher=ESPNFC |date=16 December 2012 }}</ref> In January transfer window, Aliadière was linked a return move to England by joining Middlebrough's rival [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], due to personal reason. But the move was rejected by the club<ref>{{cite news|title=Lorient won't sell Jeremie Aliadiere after reports of Newcastle bid for striker|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/8391305/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=13 January 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> Eventually, he remained at the club throughout the transfer window and said that transfer speculation didn't affect his form and hints to play for the national team.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lorient striker Jeremie Aliadiere unconcerned with France talk|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/8529274/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 February 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

In Lorient's Brittany derby with [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]] on 2 February 2013, Aliadière scored the team's second goal in a game that finished 2–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/342735/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null |title=Lorient 2-2 Stade Rennes |publisher=ESPNFC |date=2 February 2013 }}</ref> Ahead of the match, Aliadière told the Ligue 1.com when asked about comparing the derbies and said: "You can't really compare them to be honest. The derbies I played in the UK were Arsenal versus Spurs or even Middlesbrough against Sunderland or Newcastle. The derbies here are not as fanatical as those in England. It's obviously a big game and a game that the fans want to win but it won't be the end of the world for them if they don't. They are not as passionate as the people in the UK so it's not as big."<ref>{{cite news|title=ALIADIÈRE BACK ON SONG|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/exclusive-aliadiere-back-on-song.htm|publisher=Ligue 1.com|date=1 February 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

Aliadière converted a penalty to open the scoring in a 2–1 defeat of [[Evian Thonon Gaillard F.C.|Evian Thonon]] on 16 February, keeping Lorient within reach of securing European football.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/342711/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null |title=Lorient 2-1 Evian Thonon Gaillard |publisher=ESPNFC |date=16 February 2013 }}</ref> Aliadière expressed his pleasure at playing for manager [[Christian Gourcuff]], stating that "his vision of football ... means very good organization defensively."<ref>{{cite news|title=EXCLUSIVE: ALIADIÈRE: 'ENJOYING MY FOOTBALL AGAIN'|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/exclusive-aliadiere-enjoying-my-football-again.htm|publisher=Ligue 1.com|date=7 February 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

=== Umm Salal ===
On 25 July 2014, it was announced that Aliadière had completed a transfer to Qatari side [[Umm Salal SC|Umm Salal]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Luxmana |last=Perampalam |title=Officiel, Lorient: Aliadière file au Qatar |url=http://www.footmercato.net/breves/officiel-lorient-aliadiere-file-au-qatar_134980 |work=Footmercato |date=25 July 2014 |accessdate=5 August 2014 |language=French}}</ref>

== International career ==
Aliadière has made seven appearances and scored one goal for the [[France national under-21 football team]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Aliadiere gets France Under-21 call-up|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11670/2242870/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=12 August 2002|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Aliadière is of [[Swiss]] and [[Algeria]]n descent and has a tattoo with the [[flag of Algeria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fclweb.fr/actualite/article/question-reponse-avec-jeremie-aliadiere|title=Question / Réponse avec Jérémie Aliadière.|publisher=FCLWeb.fr|date=2 January 2012|accessdate=18 August 2012|language=French}}</ref> Aliadière says [[Arsène Wenger]] is like a father to him, during his six year spell at Arsenal and still remains in contact with him now.<ref>{{cite news|title=ALIADIÈRE: 'MY BEST SEASON'|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/aliadiere-my-best-season.htm|publisher=Ligue|date=19 March 2013|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>

'''Hasney Aljofree''' (born 11 July 1978) is a former English [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].

He began his career with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], during which time he earned one cap for the [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] side. He joined [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in 1996 and made his first-team debut the following year. Aljofree moved on to [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] in 2000 and spent a productive two years with the club, scoring his first four goals in league competition. He linked up with [[Paul Sturrock]] for a second time at [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], where he enjoyed the most successful period of his career to date. Having gained his first league winners medal in 2004, Aljofree played an important role in re-establishing the club in the second tier of [[Football in England|English football]]. He spent time on loan with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] and [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] before being signed by [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]]; linking up with Sturrock for a fourth time.

Aljofree [[Captain (association football)|captained]] the side on numerous occasions, but was also hampered by injury problems, one of which kept him sidelined for 10 months. He was released from his contract in 2010 and then signed for Oldham Athletic on a short-term contract.

==Early career==
Aljofree started his career as a youth player with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], a move to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in July 1996. He made 22 first-team appearances for Bolton, scoring three goals, before being transferred in 2000 to [[Scottish Premier League]] side [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dundee_utd/810130.stm|title=Duo arrive at Tannadice|date=28 June 2000|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> who were managed at the time by [[Paul Sturrock]]. Aljofree scored his first goal in his fourth match for the club, netting in a 2–1 defeat to [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]], and he scored again in December, again in a defeat. Established as a first-team regular, Aljofree scored five times in the [[2001–02 in Scottish football|2001–02 season]], finishing on the winning side every time. After starting one match at the beginning of the following season, Aljofree was released from [[Tannadice Park|Tannadice]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dundeeunitedfc.co.uk/index.asp?tm=3&nID=1101&cd=2002&cd1=8|title=Hasney departs Tannadice|date=30 August 2002|publisher=Dundee United FC|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> subsequently moving to by English [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] side [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]], now managed by Sturrock.

==Plymouth Argyle==
During the [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05 season]], he moved on loan to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], again managed by Sturrock, and many thought that the manager would sign Aljofree again permanently.{{fact|date=January 2015}} After just two appearances for Wednesday, he picked up an injury and returned to Argyle. Following the injury, he continued to make regular starts for Plymouth Argyle and captained the side during a pre-season friendly against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] in 2006. He appeared to have picked up a serious injury after 31 minutes of an away game against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 16 September 2006 and left the field on a stretcher with a neck brace. It was soon announced that he had been taken to hospital, and announced that he had suffered no injury at all.

In January 2007, Aljofree caused controversy with a goal celebration after scoring in a [[2006–07 FA Cup]] match at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]]. After celebrating in front of the opposing fans, bottles were thrown at the player, prompting a police investigation. Aljofree made a written apology to Peterborough fans, which was displayed on the club's official website,<ref>{{cite news |title=Police probe Aljofree celebration |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/6245537.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 January 2007 |accessdate=29 October 2008 }}</ref> with then-Plymouth manager [[Ian Holloway]] saying, "To celebrate like that was a disgrace and I would have thrown a bottle at him myself."<ref>{{cite news |title=Peterborough 1–1 Plymouth |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/6213935.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 January 2007 |accessdate=29 October 2008 }}</ref>

==Swindon Town==
Aljofree had his fourth spell with manager [[Paul Sturrock]] by signing for Swindon Town in 2007,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/6228150.stm|title=Swindon bag Plymouth's Aljofree|date=21 June 2007|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> although Sturrock left for his former club, Plymouth Argyle, in November 2007, after naming Aljofree as Swindon's captain for the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/6922768.stm|title=Aljofree handed Swindon captaincy |date=30 July 2007|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> Under the management of [[Maurice Malpas]] he retained the captaincy.

As Malpas' Swindon team struggled at the wrong end of the table, Aljofree performances followed suit as he received criticism from the fans ofa lack of leadership and under-par performances. Aljofree hit back publicly by telling the Swindon Advertiser that the felt the players were "scared to play at the [[County Ground, Swindon|County Ground]]",<ref>[http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/2454497.we_are_scared_to_play_here/ 'We are scared to play here']</ref> a statement that received widespread ridicule from the Swindon faithful, as they expected results to turn around.

A month later, Aljofree captained the Swindon team to a 1–0 defeat at [[Conference National|Conference]] side [[Histon F.C.|Histon]] in the [[FA Cup]],<ref>[http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/3831130.FULL_TIME__Histon_1_Town_0/?action=complain&cid=7333021 FULL TIME: Histon 1 Town 0]</ref> with an ankle injury keeping him out of the next two games, by which time Maurice Malpas had been given the sack. Aljofree is yet to play under current manager [[Danny Wilson (footballer, born 1960)|Danny Wilson]] as a knee injury forced him off in a relegation battle with [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil]], a week prior to Wilson's arrival on Boxing Day. The knee injury was expected to keep him out of the festive period only, however, in early January, Aljofree underwent surgery on the injury, extending his layoff for another 5 weeks. To add insult to injury, during his five-week recovery period it was announced he would have to have another operation, keeping him out for the remainder of the season.

On 20 October 2009, Aljofree made a return to football, playing 45 minutes for Swindon Reserves in a match against his old side [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth]], after 10 months out of action. However, with stiff competition for defensive roles at the club, Aljofree has accepted that he may need to head out [[Loan (association football)|on loan]] to regain full recovery.<ref>[http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/4693344.Hasney_returns_from__touch_and_go__injury/ Hasney returns from 'touch and go' injury]</ref>

On 1 February 2010, Aljofree's tenure with Swindon Town came to an end as it was announced that the player had left the club after both the player and club agreed to terminate his contract.<ref>[http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10341~1932282,00.html Aljofree Allowed To Seek Pastures New]</ref>

==Return to Oldham==
On 3 February 2010, Aljofree signed a pay-as-you-play contract with [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] until the end of the 2009–10 season.<ref>[http://www.oldham-chronicle.co.uk/news-features/10/oldham-athletic-news/36230/latics-sign-free-agent-aljofree Latics sign free agent Aljofree]</ref> He was released after the 3–0 defeat to Yeovil, his only start in an Oldham shirt.<ref>[http://www.oldhamathletic.co.uk/page/NewsUpdate/0,,10337~2043706,00.html]</ref>

He returned to Oldham for a third time in November 2010 as a coach for the under-14 side, having been forced to retire from the playing side of the game after a 14-year career.<ref>[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11730_6496810,00.html Aljofree returns to Oldham]</ref>

'''Derek Thomas Allan''' (born 24 December 1974) is a Scottish former [[Association football|football]] [[Defender (association football)|defender]].

He is currently the coach of [[Greenock Morton F.C.|Greenock Morton's]] U17 side.

==Playing career==
Allan or "Swan neck" was born in [[Irvine, North Ayrshire|Irvine]], [[Scotland]] and started his professional career at [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]], where he made only five appearances. After just one year at the club he was sold to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] of the [[FA Premier League|English Premiership]] for a fee of £75,000 in March 1993.

Southampton's manager [[Ian Branfoot]] saw Allan as "one for the future" but a series of injuries restricted him to just one premiership appearance when he came on as a late substitute for [[Matthew Bound]] in a 1–0 defeat at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 1 May 1993.<ref name ="ITN">{{cite book | author=Duncan Holley & Gary Chalk | title=In That Number - A post-war chronicle of Southampton FC  | publisher=Hagiology Publishing | year=2003|pages=227 & 472|isbn=0-9534474-3-X}}</ref>

In March 2014 [[Jimmy Case]] took him on loan to [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]], before making the move permanent. In the three years he spent at [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]] he made 67 league appearances, scoring twice. Allan joined non-league side [[Kingstonian F.C.|Kingstonian]] and was player of the season in the [[1999-00 in English football|1999–00 season]]. Allan had a successful spell at Kingsmeadow, being part of the winning 2000 FA Trophy squad beating Kettering Town 3-2 in a dramatic Wembley Final. 68 appearances in 2 seasons <ref name ="ITN"/>

In July 2001 he was signed by [[Scotland|Scottish]] side [[Queen of the South F.C.|Queen of the South]]. His stay was again hampered by injuries<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.qosfc.com/profile034.htm| title=Queen of the South Squad Details 2003/2004 | publisher=www.qosfc.com| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070305180440/http://www.qosfc.com/profile034.htm |archivedate=5 March 2007}}</ref> and he was limited to just 47 league appearances. Allan spent the last season of his career at [[Dumbarton F.C.|Dumbarton]], before early retirement at the age of just 30.

Derek is now the Elite Youth Coach at Greenock Morton Under 17s and a fully UEFA Qualified 'A' licence Youth Coach.

'''Marcus Christian Allbäck''' ({{IPA-sv|ˈmarkɵs ˈal.ˈbɛk}}; born 5 July 1973 in [[Gothenburg]]), is a retired [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[association football|football]]er and coach, who currently is assistant coach for the [[Sweden national football team]]. He is a well-travelled [[Forward (association football)|striker]] known for his sharp finishing ability

==Club career==
Allbäck started his professional career with [[Örgryte IS]]. He then proceeded to have two modest stints abroad, with [[Lyngby Boldklub]] and [[A.S. Bari]] of [[Serie A]], before rejoining his first club.

In 2000 he joined [[SC Heerenveen]] of the [[Eredivisie]], before moving to [[Aston Villa]] for £2 million in 2002. He was not a regular for the [[Premier League]] club, due to [[Darius Vassell]] and [[Juan Pablo Ángel]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/2303690/ | title = Italians eye Villa marksman | publisher = Sky Sports | accessdate = 29 April 2014 | first = Nadia | last = Carminati }}</ref> At the end of his contract, he joined [[Hansa Rostock]] in summer 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=220176.html | title = Hansa snap up Allbäck | publisher = UEFA.com | date = 28 August 2004 | accessdate = 29 April 2014}}</ref>

In the summer of 2005, aged 32, Allbäck signed with [[F.C. Copenhagen]]. On 1 November 2006, he scored their first goal ever in the [[UEFA Champions League]] – a winner against two-times competition winners [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/nov/02/match.sport1 | title = Allback goal leaves United stuck in muddy misery | publisher = The Guardian | date = 2 November 2006 | accessdate = 29 April 2014 | first = Daniel | last = Taylor}}</ref> In that match, he was also awarded the fans' Man of the Match award. 20 days later he also scored against [[S.L. Benfica]] at [[Estádio da Luz]] – a match lost 3–1. Allbäck scored again in the last group stage match against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] at Parken in a 3–1 win. After the final home game of the [[Danish Superliga 2006–07]] season, he was presented with the fans' Player of the Year award, as the side emerged back-to-back champions, and the striker netted 11 league goals.

In August 2007, Allbäck scored a late away equaliser against [[Beitar Jerusalem]] in the second leg of the second round Champions League qualifier in [[extra time]], to keep Copenhagen's group stage dreams alive, although the side would eventually bow out to Benfica in the next round.

On 1 July 2008, Allbäck returned to Sweden and Örgryte, his third spell at the club.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fotbollskanalen.se/fotbollskanalen/landslag/629097.html | title = Allbäck: Öis är klubben i mitt hjärta  | publisher = Fotbollskanalen.se | language = Swedish | accessdate = 21 February 2010}}</ref>

On 14 December 2009, after [[Örgryte IS]] was relegated from [[Allsvenskan]], Allbäck announced his retirement from football.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fotbolldirekt.com/allb%C3%A4ck-l%C3%A4gger-karri%C3%A4ren-p%C3%A5?page=1211 | title =  Allbäck: "Lägger karriären på is" | publisher = fotbolldirekt.se | language = Swedish | accessdate = 14 January 2012}}</ref>

After Sweden's victory against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]], it was official that Allbäck would participate in Örgryte's next home game against Motala, He came on in the 69th minute but could not affect the game in any way.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://fotboll.ois.se/9213/Nyhet.aspx | title = Från kostym till kortärma | publisher = fotboll.ois.se | language = Swedish | accessdate = 14 January 2012 | date = 14 October 2011}}</ref>

==International career==
Allbäck played for [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] at [[UEFA Euro 2000|Euro 2000]], [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]], [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2008|Euro 2008]], totalling 74 [[cap (sport)|caps]] with 30 goals. He made his debut for the national side on 27 November 1999 in a friendly against [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]].

On 20 June 2006 during the 2006 World Cup, Allbäck helped Sweden earn a 2–2 draw against [[England national football team|England]] by netting their first goal. This goal by Allbäck was the 2,000th goal scored in the history of the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. On 6 September, he scored twice to help propel Sweden past visitors [[Liechtenstein national football team|Liechtenstein]] 3–1 in the second of their [[2008 UEFA European Football Championship qualifying|2008 European Championship qualifying]] matches.

On 6 June 2007, during [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying|Euro 2008 qualifiers]], Allbäck scored a highly [[Surrealism|surreal]] goal against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] when an opponent, [[Ívar Ingimarsson]], gave him the ball incorrectly thinking a [[Direct free kick|free kick]] had been awarded.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://youtube.com/watch?v=WoVmuq9FNKY | title = Marcus Allback, Sweden vs. Iceland 5:0, 06–06–07 | work = Youtube | accessdate = 21 February 2010}}</ref>

After Sweden's group stage exit from Euro 2008 (in which he played as a second-half substitute against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] in [[Innsbruck]]), Allbäck announced that he would retire from the national team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svttext/web/pages/303.html|title=Here is the first blueyellow to retire|date= 19 June 2008 |accessdate= 19 June 2008|publisher=SVT.se}} {{Dead link|date=February 2010}}</ref>

==Coaching career==
[[File:Marcus Allbäck and Erik Hamrén.jpg|thumb|left|Allbäck and Swedish coach [[Erik Hamrén]].]]

On 7 November 2009 was named as the new assistant coach of the [[Sweden national football team]].

'''Bradley James Allen''' (born 13 September 1971) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who is currently an academy [[Coach (sport)#Association football|coach]] at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].

As a player, Allen played as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] from 1988 to 2004, making [[Premier League]] appearances for both [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. He also made [[The Football League|Football League]] appearances for [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]], [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]], [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] and [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]]. He represented [[England national football team|England]] at [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level, earning eight caps and scoring two goals.

==Club career==

===Queens Park Rangers===
Born in [[Harold Wood]], London, Allen began his career with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], where he signed professionally in 1988 during the tenure of [[Jim Smith (footballer)|Jim Smith]], although Smith was replaced by [[Trevor Francis]] mid-way through Allen's first professional season.<ref name="WWCU"/> Over the coming years, he went from strength to strength and began to see regular runs in the first-team. During the inaugural [[Premier League]] season in [[1992–93 FA Premier League|1992–93 season]], Allen played six times and scored twice, once in a 1–1 draw with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in January 1993 and the winner during a 2–1 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at [[Loftus Road]] in May 1993.<ref name="SB9293">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 1992/1993 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=122 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> On 20 November 1993, he scored a [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|hat-trick]] in a 3–0 win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Houston |first=Bob |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-everton-lose-dignity-1505673.html |title=Everton lose dignity |date=21 November 1993 |accessdate=18 July 2009 |work=The Independent |location=London}}</ref>

Allen was eventually placed on the transfer list during the ill-fated [[1995–96 FA Premier League|1995–96 season]] in which Rangers were relegated. In total, Allen scored 27 goals in 81 league games for QPR.<ref name="NB">{{cite web |title=BRADLEY ALLEN |url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player1/bradleyallen.html |publisher=Post War English & Scottish Football League A – Z Player's Database |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>

===Charlton Athletic===
[[Football League First Division|First Division]] [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] paid £400,000 for Allen's services in March 1996.<ref name="WWCU"/> He scored six goals in 21 appearances in the league and [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] in his first full season with the club<ref name="SB9697">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 1996/1997 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=126 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> but chances became harder to come by for Allen, as he made only 14 first-team appearances and could net only two goals during the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98 season]] as Charlton were promoted to the Premier League.<ref name="SB9798">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 1997/1998 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=127 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He then made only one appearance for the club in the [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99 season]],<ref name="SB9899">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 1998/1999 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=128 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> and then joined [[Football League Second Division|Division Two]] side [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] in February 1999.<ref name="WWCU"/> This spelt the end of his time with Charlton, having scored nine goals in 40 league appearances.<ref name="NB"/>

====Colchester United loan====
Recruited by Colchester manager [[Mick Wadsworth]],<ref name="WWCU"/> Allen made his debut for the U's in a 1–1 home draw with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 27 February 1999, before being replaced by [[Steve Forbes (footballer)|Steve Forbes]] after 68 minutes.<ref name="CU debut">{{cite web |title=Colchester United – Match details – Colchester Utd 1–1 Reading |url=http://coludata.co.uk/matchdetails.asp?mid=2889 |publisher=Coludata.co.uk |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He scored one goal while on loan with the club, a 40th minute equaliser during a 2–2 draw with [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on 9 March.<ref name="CU goal">{{cite web |title=Colchester United – Match details – Colchester Utd 2–2 Oldham Athletic |url=http://coludata.co.uk/matchdetails.asp?mid=2891 |publisher=Coludata.co.uk |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> Allen made four appearances in total during his short stay at [[Layer Road]].<ref name="NB"/>

===Grimsby Town===
Allen was placed on the transfer list at Charlton and transferred to [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] in the summer of 1999, who at the time plied their trade in the First Division under [[Alan Buckley]].<ref name="WWCU"/> He scored nine goals in 36 games in all competitions in the [[1999–2000 in English football|1999–2000 season]]<ref name="SB9900">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 1999/2000 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=129 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> but found himself limited to just 25 appearances in the [[2000–01 in English football|2000–01 season]], being limited by injuries and only managing to score six goals.<ref name="SB0102">{{cite web |title=Bradley Allen – Football Stats – Season 2000/2001 – Soccer Base |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=104&season_id=130 |publisher=Soccerbase |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> The [[2001–02 in English football|2001–02 season]] saw a return of 5 goals in 31 games, but his injury record and Grimsby's financial plight saw Allen released at the end of the season.<ref name="SB0102"/> He ended his Grimsby stay with 15 goals in 80 league games.<ref name="NB"/>

===Peterborough United===
Allen joined [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on trial in the summer of 2002, where he featured in a friendly against [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]].<ref name="PU trial">{{cite web |title=Allen eyes Posh deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/peterborough_united/2166803.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> However, he initially delayed joining the club and also refused offers from [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]], [[Football Conference|Conference]] promotion hopefuls [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] and Cyprus-based club [[APOEL F.C.|APOEL Nicosia]].<ref name="PU trial2">{{cite web |title=Doncaster 'hunt Allen' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/doncaster/2180572.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He then had an unsuccessful trial spell with [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] before signing for Peterborough on 29 August 2002.<ref name="PU signing">{{cite web |title=Posh sign duo |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/peterborough_united/2223703.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> Allen scored three goals in 11 games for the Posh<ref name="NB"/> but Peterborough chairman [[Barry Fry]] confirmed that his short-term contract would not be renewed when it expired in December 2002. Having been linked with a move to [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]].<ref name="PU CU">{{cite web |title=Allen set for Carlisle move |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/2489297.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>

===Bristol Rovers===
[[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] signed Allen in November 2002 from Peterborough following the expiry of his short-term contract.<ref name="BR signing">{{cite web |title=Pirates capture Street |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_rovers/2524367.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He made eight appearances in the league for the club and scored one goal against [[Cambridge United]],<ref>{{cite web 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/2575617.stm
|title=Cambridge 3-1 Bristol R
|publisher=[[BBC]]
|date=21 December 2002 |accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> as he was released at the end of the [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03 season]].<ref name="BR exit">{{cite web |title=Howie leads Rovers exodus |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/3007533.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He also scored once in the [[FA Cup]] against [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].<ref>{{cite web 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/2530769.stm
|title=Bristol Rovers 1-1 Rochdale
|publisher=[[BBC]]
|date=7 December 2002 |accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref>

===Hornchurch===
Ambitious [[Isthmian League]] club [[Hornchurch F.C.|Hornchurch]] signed Allen in September 2003 following trials with a number of clubs.<ref name="Horn signing">{{cite web |title=ANOTHER 'BIG-NAME' JOINS HORNCHURCH |url=http://www.nonleaguedaily.com/news/index.php?newsmode=FULL&nid=12549 |publisher=NonLeagueDaily.com |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> He was one of a number of former professional players with [[The Football League|Football League]] experience in a squad that knocked League side [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] out of the [[FA Cup]] in 2003.<ref name="Horn cup">{{cite web |title=Hornchurch hope for Cup shock |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/3288621.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> However, with the club facing financial turmoil, Hornchurch began releasing players during the [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04 season]], with Allen one of the squad members released.<ref name="Redb exit">{{cite web |title=ONE IN – ONE OUT AT REDBRIDGE |url=http://www.nonleaguedaily.com/news/index.php?newsmode=FULL&nid=19177 |publisher=NonLeagueDaily.com |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>

===Redbridge===
Following his release from Hornchurch, Allen quickly joined [[Conference South]] side [[Redbridge F.C.|Ford United]], who would later change name to become Redbridge. Having scored on his debut, his stint did not last long, and was subsequently released in July 2004, with club manager Craig Edwards stating that the club would prefer "to go with younger players" for the coming season and that there were financial implications. Allen then joined [[Billericay Town F.C.|Billericay Town]] on trial, scoring in a pre-season friendly against [[Grays Athletic F.C.|Grays Athletic]].<ref name="Redb exit"/>

==International career==
Allen represented [[England national football team|England]] at youth level and earned eight caps at [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level, where he scored twice.<ref name="WWCU"/>

==Coaching career==
After retiring from the game in 2004, Allen became a [[physical education|PE teacher]] and became an academy coach at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], where he is currently running the under-15 side.<ref name="WWCU"/><ref name="Academy">{{cite web |title=About the Academy – Academy – tottenhamhotspur.com |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/academy/about-the-academy/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur FC |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref> In addition to his coaching, Allen has worked in the media, providing co-commentary for [[Sky Sports]] [[Football First]] programme and also for radio coverage.<ref name="Media">{{cite web |title=WHERE 'R' THEY NOW? BRADLEY ALLEN |url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/news/article/271212-where-r-they-now-bradley-allen-562453.aspx |publisher=Queens Park Rangers FC |accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref>

==BBC London==
Bradley is a regular co-commentator on [[BBC London 94.9]] usually alongside Phil Parry.

==Personal life==
Allen comes from a famous footballing family. He is the son of former Chelsea, Tottenham and QPR player and [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Les Allen]]. His brother is former England international [[Clive Allen]] and his nephew is former [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] player [[Oliver Allen (footballer)|Oliver Allen]]. His uncle, [[Dennis Allen (footballer)|Dennis Allen]] played over 300 league games for [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], and his cousin [[Martin Allen]] has managed a number of Football League clubs, alongside representing QPR and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He is also related to [[Charlie Allen (footballer)|Charlie Allen]], Martin's son, who has played for [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] and [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]]. [[Paul Allen (footballer)|Paul Allen]] is also a cousin to Bradley, who made appearances for West Ham, Tottenham and [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] amongst others.<ref name="WWCU"/>

'''Christopher Anthony''' "'''Chris'''" '''Allen''' (born 18 November 1972 in [[Oxford]]) is an [[English people|English]] former [[Association football|football]] [[midfielder]], who now works at [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] as a youth team coach.

A former [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] international, he started his career at Oxford United in 1991, playing 181 games in five years, helping to send the club on their way back to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in [[1995–96 Football League|1995–96]] before he signed with [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] for a £400,000 fee. He played 26 [[Premier League]] games for Forest, though played little part in the club's [[1997–98 Nottingham Forest F.C. season|1997–98]] First Division promotion campaign. Instead he was loaned out to [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] and [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] promotion winners [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], before he was allowed to sign with [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in March 1999. His career diminished in brief spells with [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], before he featured for non-league sides [[Dover Athletic F.C.|Dover Athletic]], [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] and [[North Leigh F.C.|North Leigh]]. He retired from playing in 2010, having helped North Leigh to win promotion from the [[Hellenic Football League]] in 2007–08.

==Playing career==
Allen started his career with [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], and made his debut under [[Brian Horton]] in the [[1991–92 Football League|1991–92]] [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] campaign; he played fourteen games, helping the "U's" to avoid relegation.<ref name="sporting">{{cite web|title=Chris Allen|url=http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football-heroes/displayhero_club.asp?HeroID=37992|work=sporting-heroes.net|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref> He made 31 appearances in [[1992–93 Football League|1992–93]], as Oxford finished mid-table in the newly re-branded [[Football League First Division|First Division]].<ref name="sporting"/> New manager [[Denis Smith (footballer)|Denis Smith]] played Allen in 45 games in [[1993–94 Football League|1993–94]], though neither player or manager could prevent Oxford suffering relegation into the third tier.<ref name="sporting"/> He played 36 games in [[1994–95 Football League|1994–95]], as United missed out on the play-offs by six points.<ref name="sporting"/> He played 24 games in the club's promotion winning [[1995–96 Football League|1995–96]] campaign.<ref name="sporting"/> Allen scored a total of 17 goals in 181 appearances in all competitions. Whilst at Oxford, he was capped twice for England at [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u21-intres86.html]</ref>

He joined [[Frank Clark (footballer)|Frank Clark]]'s [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan in February 1996, and made his [[Premier League]] debut on 2 March, in a 3–1 win over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] at [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]]. He scored his first top-flight goal a fortnight later, in a 1–1 draw with [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] at the [[Riverside Stadium]], though would only make one further appearance in [[1995–96 Nottingham Forest F.C. season|1995–96]]. Allen moved to the [[City Ground]] permanently in the summer for a £400,000 fee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Big Matt to the rescue...but United still millions in debt|url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/archive/1998/09/15/Oxfordshire+Archive/6638541.Big_Matt_to_the_rescue___but_United_still_millions_in_debt/|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=Oxford Mail|date=15 September 1998}}</ref><ref name=fl>[http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player3/chrisallen.html Football League career stats at Neil Brown]</ref> He then played 23 Premiership games in [[1996–97 Nottingham Forest F.C. season|1996–97]], and also scored against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in the [[FA Cup]]; Forest were relegated at the end of the season. He appeared in just one league game under new manager [[Dave Bassett]] in Forest's [[1997–98 Nottingham Forest F.C. season|1997–98]] promotion campaign, though he appeared in both legs of the 10–1 demolition of [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]], finding himself on the scoresheet for the 8–0 triumph at [[Belle Vue (football)|Belle Vue]].

Allen joined [[Lennie Lawrence]]'s [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] on loan in November 1997, and played seventeen games, scoring once against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] at [[Kenilworth Road]]. He did not feature for Forest once his three month loan spell at Luton ended. Allen did not feature under either Bassett or [[Ron Atkinson]] in [[1998–99 Nottingham Forest F.C. season|1998–99]], and was instead loaned out to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in October. He appeared five times for [[Frank Burrows]]'s [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] [[1998–99 Cardiff City F.C. season|promotion winning]] side. In March he was transferred to Brian Horton's [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]], playing five games, scoring once against [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]]; the "Valiants" [[1998–99 Port Vale F.C. season|avoided relegation]] on goals scored.

Allen signed with [[Andy Kilner]]'s Stockport County in October 1999, and played sixteen games in [[1999–2000 Football League|1999–2000]]. He then signed with [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], but did not make a senior appearance. He spent summer 2001 on trial at [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]], but was not offered a contract.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cambridge keep six trialists|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cambridge_utd/1438966.stm|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=14 July 2001}}</ref> He signed with [[Dover Athletic F.C.|Dover Athletic]] in October 2001, after manager [[Gary Bellamy]] said that he "destroyed the opposition" in the three games he played on trial.<ref>{{cite news|title=Allen joins Dover|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dover_athletic/1594106.stm|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=11 October 2001}}</ref> He played 17 [[Football Conference|Conference]] games in [[2001–02 Football Conference|2001–02]], as the "Whites" finished bottom of the table and were relegated into the [[Southern Football League|Southern League]].

He signed for [[North Leigh F.C.|North Leigh]] in 2006<ref>{{cite web|title=FOOTBALL: North Leigh sign Allen|url=http://archive.oxfordmail.net/2006/8/11/101743.html|publisher=Oxford Mail|accessdate=14 August 2010|date=11 August 2006}}</ref> and played with them until 2010. The "Yellows" were promoted out of the [[Hellenic Football League]] into the Southern League Division One South & West in 2007–08.

==Coaching career==
Allen returned to [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in June 2010, when he was appointed as youth team coach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chris Allen returns to Oxford United as coach|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oxford_utd/8805723.stm|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=9 July 2010}}</ref><ref name=oufc>{{cite news|title = Chrissy comes home|url = http://www.oufc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10342~2088207,00.html|publisher = Oxford United F.C.|accessdate = 29 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = Allen is back at Oxford United|url = http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/oxfordunited/8265424.Allen_is_back_at_Oxford_United/|publisher = Oxford Mail (Newsquest Media Group)|accessdate =29 January 2012}}</ref> He has been credited as playing a key role in the development of a number of youth team players who have made the step up into the Oxford United first team, including [[Max Crocombe]], [[Callum O'Dowda]], [[Josh Ashby]], [[Sam Long]] and [[James Roberts (footballer, born 1996)|James Roberts]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Duberry|first1=Michael|title=Only Matter of Time Before Callum O'Dowda is in the Barclays Premier League|url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/11830989.MICHAEL_DUBERRY_COLUMN__Only_a_matter_of_time_before_Callum_O_Dowda_is_in_the_Barclays_Premier_League/|website=Oxford Mail Online|accessdate=07/03/2015}}</ref>

'''Clive Darren Allen''' (born 20 May 1961) is a retired [[England national football team|English]] [[Association football|footballer]], a prolific scorer for a number of clubs.

Allen is the son of ex-[[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] forward [[Les Allen]], who was a member of the team which won the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] title and [[FA Cup]] "double" in 1961. He is the brother of former footballer [[Bradley Allen]] and cousin of football manager [[Martin Allen (footballer)|Martin Allen]] and ex [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur]] midfielder [[Paul Allen (footballer)|Paul Allen]].

==Club career==

===Queens Park Rangers===
He started his career at [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the late 1970s, and scored 32 league goals in 49 appearances, before moving to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Clive Allen|url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/cliveallen.html|work=Post War English & Scottish Football League A&nbsp;— Z Player's Database|publisher=Neil Brown|accessdate=28 October 2012}}</ref>

===Arsenal===
Allen signed for Arsenal in the summer of 1980 for a fee of £1.25m, but he did not play a single competitive match (although he did play three matches in Arsenal's [[1980-81 in English football|1980-81]] pre-season friendly campaign). He shortly moved on to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in a swap deal with [[Kenny Sansom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/opinion/blogs/mirror-football-blog/Sol-Campbell-Clive-Allen-Joey-Beauchamp-and-the-Top-10-shortest-transfers-of-all-time-article128239.html|title=Sol Campbell, Clive Allen, Joey Beauchamp and the Top 10 shortest transfers of all-time|last=David Gerges|work=Mirror Football|publisher=Trinity Mirror|accessdate=28 October 2012}}</ref>

===Crystal Palace===
Allen was Palace's top scorer for the [[1980-81 in English football|1980-81 season]] with nine goals in the league and 11 in all competitions, when Palace finished bottom of the First Division.<ref>[http://www.holmesdale.net/page.php?id=82&story=4387 Holmesdale.net]</ref>

===Return to Queens Park Rangers===
QPR, still in the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]], were now managed by [[Terry Venables]] (who had signed Allen for palace) and Allen's first season back at the club ([[1981-82 in English football|1981-82]]) revived his fortunes as he scored 13 Second Division goals, though not enough to win promotion. QPR also had their most successful [[FA Cup]] run, reaching the [[FA Cup Final 1982|FA Cup Final]] for the first time with Allen scoring the vital goals in 1-0 victories in both the 6th Round (vs [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]) and Semi final (vs [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]).

Over the next two seasons, Allen scored 27 League goals as QPR first won the Second Division Championship in 1982-83 and then consolidated their new status helping them to finish fifth in the First Division in 1983-84, but would be playing [[UEFA Cup]] football for Tottenham rather than QPR the following season as a £700,000 fee took him to [[White Hart Lane]].

===Tottenham Hotspur===
Allen scored twice on his debut and eight goals from 15 appearances in his first season, where Spurs finished third after being top of the league at Christmas.

In [[1986-87 in English football|1986–87]] he scored 33 League goals, and 49 goals in all competitions.<ref name=tott/>

His goal tally that season broke the Spurs club record held by [[Jimmy Greaves]], and remains unbroken. No player associated with any top division club has managed to match or exceed Allen's total of goals in all competitions since then, either. However, his top-flight league goals tally was surpassed by [[Andrew Cole|Andy Cole]] of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in [[1993-94 in English football|1993-94]] and [[1994-95 in English football|a year later]] by [[Alan Shearer]] at [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].

He also picked up the titles of [[PFA Players' Player of the Year|PFA Player of the Year]] and [[Football Writers' Association|Football Writers' Association Footballer of the Year]].

===Bordeaux===
He moved from Spurs to join [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] in March 1988.<ref name=tott>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/sites/spurs/History%20of%20the%20Club/great-players/clive-allen.page|title=Great players: Clive Allen|work=History of the club|publisher=Tottenham Hotspur|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>

===Later career===
He spent just one season in France before returning to England in August 1989 when he joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], who had just been promoted to the First Division. He scored 10 league goals as City survived their first season back in the top flight, but scored just four goals in 20 league games in [[1990-91 in English football|1990-91]]. He managed three appearances and scored twice in the league for City the following season, and was transferred to Chelsea in December 1991.

He scored seven goals in 16 league games over the next three months with Chelsea before he joined West Ham United in March 1992, scoring once in four league games and unable to stop them from being relegated.

He scored 14 goals in the [[1992-93 in English football|1992-93]] Division One campaign as West Ham were promoted as runners-up, but played just seven league games (scoring twice) in the [[1993-94 in English football|1993-94]] in the new Premier League.

In January 1994, when Allen was out of favour at West Ham United, Tottenham manager [[Ossie Ardiles]] (who had been his Tottenham team mate the previous decade) expressed interest in bringing Allen back to [[White Hart Lane]] as he looked to spend up to £500,000 on buying a striker to cover for the injured [[Teddy Sheringham]], but the transfer never happened.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-ardiles-looking-to-angell-or-allen-1406880.html Football: Ardiles looking to Angell or Allen]</ref>
Allen opted to drop down a division and join [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] for a fee of £75,000.<ref>[http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=5&united=Clive_Allen Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Clive Allen]</ref> In 1995 Allen ended his career with 3 games for [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]].

==International career==
In the summer of 1984, Allen was given his first [[England national football team|England]] cap in a friendly against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], coming on as a [[substitute (soccer)|substitute]]. England won 2-0 but when Allen started against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] England lost 2–0. He received his third cap in a goalless draw against [[Chile national football team|Chile]]. On 29 April 1987, Allen got his fourth England cap in a goalless draw versus [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]]. He won his fifth and final England cap in another goalless draw, against [[Israel national football team|Israel]] on 17 February 1988.<ref>[http://www.englandfc.com/Profiles/php/PlayerProfileByName.php?id=10 englandfc.com profile]</ref>

==Managerial career==
Allen was the Tottenham Hotspur reserve team coach under [[Martin Jol]] at White Hart Lane, as well as being a pundit for a variety of media organisations. He was coach of Spurs Reserves when they won the [[FA Premier Reserve League]] Southern Division in [[2005-06 in English football|2005-06]].

After Jol's dismissal in October 2007, Allen took up the position of Interim Manager of the senior squad. He took charge of the team for one match, a 1-2 defeat by [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in the [[Premier League]], before handing the reins over to [[Juande Ramos]].

==Personal life==
His son [[Oliver Allen (footballer)|Oliver]] was also a footballer.

'''Graham Allen''' born 8 April 1977 in [[Bolton]] is a former professional footballer who plays as a central defender for [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.|Bradford Park Avenue]].

Graham started his career at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] making his debut against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on the 26 December 1996, He played 6 times for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] before signing for [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] in 1998 after a successful loan spell.

He played 200 league games for [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] scoring 10 goals before signing for [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] in 2004 playing 31 league games and scoring 2 goals before signing for [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]] in 2006. Injuries forced him to retire from professional football after only one year at the [[Deva Stadium]], having made just three league appearances for the Blues.

After spending time on trial with [[Droylsden F.C.|Droylsden]], Allen joined [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.|Bradford Park Avenue]] in August 2007.
