'''Joseph Michael "Joe" Allen''' (born 14 March 1990) is a [[Welsh people|Welsh]] professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and the [[Wales national football team|Wales national team]] as a [[midfielder]].

==Club career==

===Swansea City===
[[File:Joe Allen vs Arsenal.jpg|thumb|left|232px|Joe Allen in 2011.]]
[[File:Joe Allen.jpg|thumb|left|202px|Joe Allen playing for Swansea against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2010.]]
[[File:Joe Allen - 2.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Joe Allen playing for Swansea against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2010.]]

Born in [[Carmarthen]],<ref name="Hugman2010-11 19"/> Allen started his career playing in local team Tenby.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shaw|first=Chris|title='I always tried to watch Zidane'|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/i-always-tried-to-watch-zidane|publisher=Liverpool F.C|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=24 January 2013}}</ref>  Allen was part of the [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] youth set-up from the age of nine. As a first-year scholar in the youth team in the 2006–07 season, he featured as an unused first-team [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 3–0 away win over then [[Premier League|FA Premier League]] side [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in the third round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/6213977.stm |title=Sheff Utd 0–3 Swansea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 January 2007 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Two weeks later, when Allen was just 16, Swansea [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Kenny Jackett]] gave Allen his debut in the [[FAW Premier Cup]] away tie to local [[Welsh Premier League]] side [[Port Talbot Town F.C.|Port Talbot Town]]. Allen played the first half of the match, as Swansea lost 2–1 after extra time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_of_wales/6264237.stm |title=Port Talbot 2–1 Swansea (aet) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 January 2007 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Allen made his league debut for Swansea as a substitute in a 6–3 defeat to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on the final day of the [[Football League One|League One]] season, as Swansea missed out on a play-off position under new manager and former team captain [[Roberto Martínez]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/6603011.stm |title=Swansea 3–6 Blackpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2007 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref>

The following pre-season Allen played in numerous games for the club. As the 2007–08 season got underway, he started in the first round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] game in a 2–0 home win over [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]]. Allen was named [[man of the match]] for his performance, which included assisting in the first goal by providing a left-footed chipped cross to [[Paul Anderson (footballer)|Paul Anderson]]. In August 2007 Martínez awarded Allen his first professional contract, which kept him at Swansea until 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swansea_city/6949127.stm |title=Swans reward Allen with new deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2007 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Allen started in the next round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] at home to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], and again received the man of the match award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/football-news/2009/01/29/swansea-city-s-teenage-star-joe-allen-tipped-for-top-by-ferrie-bodde-91466-22805559/ |title=Swansea City's teenage star Joe Allen tipped for top by Ferrie Bodde |newspaper=Western Mail |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref>

The following season, Swansea's first in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]], Allen struggled to get into the first team due to competition from midfielders [[Darren Pratley]], [[Ferrie Bodde]], [[Owain Tudur Jones]], [[Jordi Gómez]] and [[Leon Britton]]. In October 2008 Allen joined [[Conference National]] club [[Wrexham F.C.|Wrexham]] on a one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]] deal,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wrexham/7657000.stm |title=Swan Allen joins Wrexham on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> and scored a goal from 25&nbsp;yards on his debut for the North Wales side in a 3–1 win over [[York City F.C.|York City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/7646274.stm |title=Wrexham 3–1 York |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Allen made a handful of appearances for the club, but his loan spell was cut short when he damaged ankle ligaments, which kept him out for a month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrexhamafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10311~1429114,00.html |title=Joe likely to be out for several weeks |publisher=Wrexham F.C |date=22 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Allen returned from the injury in December going back into Swansea squad at home to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]]; regular midfielder Ferrie Bodde had been ruled out for the remainder of the season as a result of injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swansea_city/7854024.stm |title=Allen is premier quality – Bodde |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> With Swansea 2–0 down playing terribly, manager Roberto Martinez was prompted to bring Allen on from the bench.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7763339.stm |title=Swansea 2–2 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> Swansea went on to earn a late 2–2 draw and, despite only playing 25 minutes, Allen once more received the man-of-the-match award.

In April 2009, Allen came on as a substitute to score his first goal for Swansea in a [[South Wales derby]] away at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7972863.stm |title=Cardiff 2–2 Swansea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> At the end of the season, he signed a new three-year contract until 2012. After frequently being injured in the 2009–10 season, Allen returned to regular first-team football at the start of the 2010–2011 season. A string of impressive performances prompted manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] to play Allen in the South Wales derby in November 2010, with Allen receiving the man-of-the-match award in the 1–0 win.

A few days prior to the beginning of the [[2011–12 Premier League]], Allen signed a new four-year contract with Swansea until 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14436086.stm |title=Joe Allen spurred by new Swansea City contract |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 August 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref>

===Liverpool===

On 10 August 2012 after passing a medical at [[Melwood]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/allen-completes-liverpool-move | title=Allen completes Liverpool move | publisher=Liverpool F.C | date=10 August 2012 | accessdate=10 August 2012}}</ref> Allen signed a long-term contract with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a deal worth £15 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anfield-online.co.uk/lfc-news/2012/joe-allen-signs-for-liverpool-fc/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+lfcreds+(Anfield+Online+-+Liverpool+FC+Website) |title=Joe Allen signs for Liverpool FC – LFC News – Liverpool FC |publisher=Anfield Online |date=2012-08-10 |accessdate=2013-01-18}}</ref> He made his Premier League debut on 18 August 2012, starting in a 3-0 loss against [[West Bromwich Albion]] at [[The Hawthorns]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/345827?cc=5739 |title=Baggies condemn Reds to nightmare start|date=18 August 2012|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=23 August 2012 }}</ref> He started Liverpool's next game of the league campaign against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], where he was voted [[Man of the Match]] on the club's official website by fans and journalists.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/joe-gets-your-vote |title=Joe gets your vote |publisher=Liverpool F.C|date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> He went on to win the Liverpool Player of the Month award for August 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Joe Allen named Liverpool 'Player of the Month'|url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/sport/9937199.Joe_Allen_named_Liverpool__Player_of_the_Month_/|newspaper=Western Telegraph|location=Haverfordwest|accessdate=18 January 2013|date=19 September 2012}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Liverpool on 27 January 2013, in a 3-2 defeat to [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21106938 "Oldham 3-2 Liverpool"] BBC Sport. 27 January 2013. Retrieved 29 January 2013.</ref> He scored his first European goal on 21 February 2013, in a 3-1 win over [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit St. Petersburg]] in the [[UEFA Europa League]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21455139] BBC Sport. 21 February 2013. Retrieved 4 March 2013.</ref> On 20 March 2013, it was announced that Allen would be ruled out for the remainder of the 2012–13 season, with him requiring surgery on his left shoulder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21865753 |title=Liverpool midfielder Joe Allen ruled out for remainder of season |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2013|accessdate=20 March 2013}}</ref> 

On 5 May 2014 Allen scored his first and only goal for Liverpool in the [[2013&ndash;14 Premier League]] season with a header from a corner to give Liverpool the lead in a 3-3 draw against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27184083</ref>

Throughout the 2014-15 season Allen was criticised by fans for his performance in the matches where he played and he also got injured in between. Allen was praised when he played the full 90 minutes in the win against Manchester City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool 2–1 Manchester City |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31572160|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 March 2015|date=1 March 2015}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:Joe Allen Wales.jpg|thumb|upright|Allen with the [[Welsh national football team|Wales national team]] in 2011]]
Soon after receiving his first professional contract for Swansea City, in August 2007 Allen was called up for the [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales under-21 team]], in a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] away to [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]]. Allen came on as a substitute to score the winner in a 4–3 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_of_wales/6955612.stm |title=Sweden U21 3–4 Wales U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2007 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref>

In May 2009 Allen made his debut for the [[Wales national football team|senior Wales team]], as a substitute during a friendly against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8046478.stm |title=Wales 1–0 Estonia |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> In November 2009 Allen was called up for another international friendly, against [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]], at the newly opened [[Cardiff City Stadium]]. Allen made his first start for Wales in a 2–0 [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying Group G]] match against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] at the [[Liberty Stadium]] in Swansea on October 2011. Four days later Allen started again for Wales in a 1–0 victory against [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]], played in [[Sofia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cardiff boos didn't affect me at all, says patriotic Allen|url=http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/news/Cardiff-boos-didn-t-affect-says-patriotic-Allen/article-1516294-detail/article.html|newspaper=South Wales Evening Post|date=16 November 2009}}</ref> He was awarded the prize for the Wales' Player of the Year for 2012 in October of that year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Allen nets Welsh crown |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/allen-nets-welsh-crown|publisher=Liverpool F.C |date=9 October 2012}}</ref> Allen captained Wales for the first time in the absence of [[Ashley Williams (footballer)|Ashley Williams]] through injury on 4 June 2014 versus the Netherlands.

==2012 Summer Olympics==
Allen chose to be included in [[Team GB]]'s [[2012 Summer Olympics]] football squad.<ref>{{cite news|title=Five Welshmen named in Team GB football squad for London 2012 Olympics|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sports/sports-news-round-up/2012/07/02/by-jon-doel-91466-31304619/|publisher=Wales online|date=2 July 2011}}</ref> Captained by [[Ryan Giggs]], Allen was one of five Welsh players. A mistake in the official Team GB programme for their first game described Allen as English.<ref>{{cite news|title=London 2012: Wales' Joe Allen listed as English by Team GB|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/18997930|accessdate=26 July 2012|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 July 2012}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Allen was raised in the [[Pembrokeshire]] town of [[Narberth, Pembrokeshire|Narberth]], and is a former student of [[Ysgol y Preseli]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Positive Premiership start for former Preseli lad Joe|url=http://www.fishguard-today.co.uk/Sport.cfm?id=600&headline=Positive%20Premiership%20start%20for%20former%20Preseli%20lad%20Joe|publisher=Fishguard Today|date=6 January 2012}}</ref>  He is a fluent [[Welsh language|Welsh speaker]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Last two games like cup finals|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cymru/chwaraeon/fidio/jallen_sheff.shtml|publisher=BBC Wales|date=22 April 2010}}</ref>

'''Malcolm Allen''' (born 21 March 1967 in [[Deiniolen]], [[Gwynedd]]) is a [[Wales|Welsh]] former professional [[Association football|footballer]] who played for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Stevenage Borough F.C.|Stevenage Borough]]. Allen played 14 times for [[Wales national football team|Wales]] between 1986 and 1993. 

After retiring from the professional game he moved into coaching and television punditry. He is a Welsh speaker.<ref name="Jones">Jones, pp 23</ref>

==Career==
Allen began his career with Watford, signing apprentice terms in July 1983, before becoming professional in March 1985.<ref name="Jones"/> He scored Watford's only goal in 1985 [[FA Youth Cup]] final.<ref name="Jones"/> He played and scored for the Hornets in their [[FA Cup]] semi-final defeat against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 1987, and in 19 cup appearances for Watford scored eight goals.<ref name="Jones"/> He was loaned to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in September 1987 by new Watford manager [[Dave Bassett]], and joined Norwich for a fee of £175,000 in August 1988.<ref name="Jones"/> Whilst with Norwich he scored four in their club record FA Cup victory, 8–0 against [[Sutton United F.C.|Sutton United]] in the fourth round. This was one of the most successful seasons in Norwich's history, as they finished fourth in the league and were semi-finalists in the FA Cup.

In 1989, an incident between Allen and [[David O'Leary]] sparked a mass brawl at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]'s [[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury]] stadium.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/funny_old_game/2395547.stm Happened on this Day – 4 November], BBC Sport</ref> O'Leary picked up Allen by the scruff of his neck and carried him some yards. Police officers needed to intervene,<ref>[http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/comment/article88890.ece Graham Kelly: Points deduction is best weapon but it must be used with the utmost care], The Independent</ref> and Arsenal were fined £20,000.<ref>[http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2002390000-2003502037,00.html We are so sorry], The Sun</ref><ref>[http://www.redcafe.net/archive/index.php/t-79252.html Goons' role of shame update], RedCafe.net</ref>

Allen joined [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in March 1990 for £400,000, spending three years there before moving to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for £300,000 in August 1993. He retired due to injury, aged 28, in December 1995.<ref name="Jones"/>

===International career===
Allen represented [[Wales national football team|Wales]] at youth, B and full international level.<ref name="Jones"/> He received his first full cap aged 18, after only playing a small number of senior club games,<ref name="Jones"/> taking to the field on 25 February 1986 in a 2–1 friendly win over [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] in [[Dhahran]]. He was capped a total of 14 times by Wales at senior level, his last appearance coming on 17 November 1993 in the disappointing 2–1 defeat to [[Romania national football team|Romania]] at [[Cardiff Arms Park]], which ended their hopes of qualifying for the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]].<ref>[http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football/wales/malcolm-allen-8455/welsh-caps-1986-93_a10933/]</ref>

==Arrests==
In August 2006, Allen was in court charged with assault.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/north_west/5263402.stm Ex-footballer admits kicking girl]</ref> In April 2008, charged from his [[Watford]] home, he was given a [[suspended sentence]] and a ban for drink-driving after admitting drinking ten pints of beer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7339342.stm|title=Ten-pint former footballer banned|publisher=BBC News|date=9 April 2008|accessdate=8 April 2008}}</ref>

==Media work==
He is a regular pundit on ''Sgorio'', a [[Welsh language]] football review programme on [[S4C]] alongside [[Dai Davies (footballer born 1948)|Dai Davies]]. Malcolm also regularly co-commentates on live [[Sgorio]] games as well as on [[BBC]] [[Radio Cymru]]'s Camp Lawn programme.

===Autobiography===
In the autumn of 2009 Y Lolfa published his autobiography in his native Welsh language.

'''Martin James Allen''' (born 14 August 1965) is an English former [[Association football|football]] player and current head coach of [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]]. He played more than 100 games for each [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] before finishing his playing career with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] and [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]]. Five years later, he took his first job in management, at non-league [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]]. He has since managed [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]], [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]], [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] and [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]]. He rejoined [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] as manager on 16 April 2012 on a short term, three-match contract succeeding [[Lawrie Sanchez]]. In July 2012 he became manager of [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] and in the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13]] season led the team to the [[Football League Two]] title, earning Allen his first promotion as a manager and Gillingham's first divisional title in 49 years. He was sacked as Gillingham manager in October 2013. He played as a [[midfielder]].

==Playing career==
Often referred to by his nickname of "Mad Dog", Allen began his career with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], signing professional in 1983 and spending six years at [[Loftus Road]] playing in the [[1986 Football League Cup Final|1986 League Cup Final]] defeat against [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], before a £670,000 move to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. Signed by manager [[Lou Macari]], Allen made his debut on 26 August 1989 in a 3–2 home win against [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]]. He scored the second goal, the other West Ham goals coming from [[David Kelly (footballer)|David Kelly]] and [[Kevin Keen]].<ref name=whudebut>{{cite web|title=West Ham United v Plymouth Argyle, 26 August 1989|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/west-ham-united-v-plymouth-argyle-26-august-1989-123690/|publisher=www.11v11.com|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> Under manager [[Billy Bonds]] Allen was part of the team which won promotion to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in 1991 and to the [[Premier League]] in 1993.<ref name=whustats>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics|url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=6&united=Martin_Allen|publisher=www.westhamstats.info|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> Allen was frequently [[Yellow card (sports)|booked]] during his West Ham career and had a reputation for poor discipline.<ref name=red1>{{cite book|last=Powles|first=John|title=Seeing Red for The Claret and Blue|year=2012|publisher=SoccerData|location=Hockley, Essex|isbn=978-1-905891-54-2|pages=58}}</ref> He was  [[Red card (sports)|sent off]] in a match on 17 January 1990 for a two-footed lunge on [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]'s [[Mark Patterson (footballer born 1968)|Mark Patterson]].<ref name=red>{{cite book|last=Powles|first=John|title=Seeing Red for The Claret and Blue|year=2012|publisher=SoccerData|location=Hockley, Essex|isbn=978-1-905891-54-2|pages=49}}</ref> During a game on 30 November 1991 against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], managed by Allen's manager at Queens Park Rangers, [[Trevor Francis]], Allen was booked after only 20 seconds of being on the pitch for a jump tackle on [[Carlton Palmer]] which saw Palmer carried off with a suspected broken leg. Although not sent-off, West Ham manager Bonds fined Allen a week's wages.<ref name=red2>{{cite book|last=Powles|first=John|title=Seeing Red for The Claret and Blue|year=2012|publisher=SoccerData|location=Hockley, Essex|isbn=978-1-905891-54-2|pages=52}}</ref> During his time at Queens Park Rangers Allen had been refused permission, by manager Francis, to attend the birth of his first child as Allen would miss an important match. Allen attended the birth and was disciplined by the club.<ref name=qprtf>{{cite news|title=Top 10 player and manager feuds, starring David Beckham, Roy Keane, Harry Redknapp and more|url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/top-10-player-and-manager-feuds-789312|accessdate=20 September 2012|newspaper=www.mirror.co.uk}}</ref> Under Bonds and [[Harry Redknapp]] Allen formed a successful partnership with [[Peter Butler (footballer born 1966)|Peter Butler]] with Allen contributing 34 goals from midfield in 234 appearances. However by 1995 team discipline was poor at West Ham and with Allen playing alongside [[Julian Dicks]], [[John Moncur]] and [[Don Hutchison]] bookings were commonplace.<ref name="red1"/> Allen was again dismissed in a match against Queens Park Rangers on 3 May 1995 after fouling [[Rufus Brevett]].<ref name=red3>{{cite book|last=Powles|first=John|title=Seeing Red for The Claret and Blue|year=2012|publisher=SoccerData|location=Hockley, Essex|isbn=978-1-905891-54-2|pages=59}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Game played on 03 May 1995|url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3957&united=03_May_1995|publisher=www.westhamstats.info|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> He would play only five more games before being allowed to leave.<ref name=whustats/>

Allen stayed with the Hammers until September 1995 when he made a £500,000 switch to [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] after a successful loan spell at [[Fratton Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/sherwood-to-placate-blackburn-protesters-1600747.html |title=Sherwood to placate Blackburn protesters - Sport |publisher=The Independent |date=12 September 1995 |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> After three frustrating years with Pompey, which took in a brief loan stint at [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]], he retired and began a coaching career.

==Management career==

===Reading===
Allen began his management career as an assistant manager at hometown club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], where he joined [[Alan Pardew]] when the Royals were in the relegation zone. The team produced championship form in their closing 20 fixtures, winning 12 and drawing 4 to secure a top 10 finish. Two years later they won promotion to Division One.

===Barnet===
Allen's first full manager role was at Conference side [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]], from March 2003 to March 2004. He succeeded from [[Peter Shreeves]], to whom he was assistant manager from March 2002. Allen built a team from scratch in pre-season of the [[2003-04 in English football|2003–04]] campaign. The team shot straight to the top end of the table, however Allen left for [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] with a few weeks of the season remaining in a move that disappointed many Barnet fans. Under the guidance of new manager [[Paul Fairclough]], the Bees made the play-offs but were beaten in the semi-finals by [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]].

===Brentford===
[[File:Martin Allen, football manager, February 2005.jpg|thumb|right|Allen exiting the [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] team bus at [[Victoria Park (Hartlepool)|Victoria Park]] in 2005.]]
Allen took over the from [[Wally Downes]] at [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] side [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in March 2004.<ref>http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/news/472385.print/</ref> He had a good run at the club, saving them from relegation to the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] in what remained of the [[2003-04 in English football|2003–04]] season. In the [[2004-05 in English football|2004–05]] and [[2005-06 in English football|2005–06]] seasons he took Brentford to the play-offs with fourth and third place finishes respectively, but they were eliminated by [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] and [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] respectively in the semi-finals on both occasions. Allen won press attention during the 2004–05 season for the success of his self-described "two bob team",<ref>http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-124598058.html</ref> which was composed of ageing pros ([[John Salako]], [[Andy Myers]], [[Scott Fitzgerald (footballer born 1969)|Scott Fitzgerald]] and [[Jamie Lawrence]]), [[Free transfer (football)|free transfers]] ([[Deon Burton]], [[Chris Hargreaves]], [[Stewart Talbot]] and [[Isaiah Rankin]]) and young guns who would go on to play in the [[FA Premier League|Premier League]] ([[Jay Tabb]], [[Stephen Hunt (footballer born 1981)|Stephen Hunt]], [[Sam Sodje]] and [[Michael Turner (footballer)|Michael Turner]]). Allen took Brentford to the fifth round of the [[FA Cup]] in two consecutive years, going out to Premier League sides [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the 2004–05 season (losing 3–1 in a replay, after a 2–2 draw at [[St Mary's Stadium|St Mary's]]) and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] 3–1 in the 2005–06 season. He also was in charge of one of the major [[Upset|giant killings]] in the fourth round in the 2005–06 season, beating Premier League side [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 2–1.

At Brentford, he proved to be a very popular manager with the fans and an object of curiosity to opponents and media alike due to his unconventional managerial methods, which paid off due to the relative success Brentford had under him on a limited budget. He participated in a 25&nbsp;mile sponsored bike ride on November 2005 to raise funds for Brentford.<ref name="Sponsor Martin Allen">{{cite news
| title      = Manager Allen completes bike ride
| url        = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brentford/4480964.stm
| publisher  = BBC Sport
| date       = 2005-11-29
| accessdate = 2007-05-25}}</ref> To inspire the team, Allen swam in the [[River Tees|Tees]] before a 1-0 FA Cup fourth round replay victory over [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] in February 2005 and jumped naked into the [[Solent River|Solent]] before Brentford's 2-2 draw at Southampton in the following round.<ref>http://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/feb/27/newsstory.sport8</ref> In May 2006, Allen announced his resignation as manager of Brentford, citing lack of Board commitment to investing in the team to take it to the next level.<ref name="Allen resigns from Bees">{{cite news
| title      = Allen resigns from Bees
| url        = http://home.skysports.com/list.asp?hlid=391110&CPID=11&clid=94&lid=5&title=Allen+resigns+from+Bees
| publisher  = Sky Sports
| date       = 2006-05-30
| accessdate = 2007-05-25}}</ref> In July 2006 he completed his [[UEFA Pro Licence]] in coaching.<ref name="class2006">{{cite news
|title       = The Class of 2006
|url         = http://www.thefa.com/GetIntoFootball/FALearning/NewsAndFeatures/2006/Pro_Licence
|date        = 3 July 2006
|first       = 
|last        = 
|newspaper   = The Football Association
|accessdate  = 26 April 2012
}}</ref> With the club struggling in League One in late 2010, there was speculation that Allen would replace [[Andy Scott (English footballer)|Andy Scott]] as manager, but the reports were quashed by Brentford chief executive Andrew Mills.<ref>http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/other-sport/brentford-play-down-rumours-martin-5992207</ref>

===Milton Keynes Dons===
Allen then dropped down a level to manage League Two team [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] for the [[2006-07 in English football|2006–07]] season, a club with heavy financial backing and ambitions from owner [[Pete Winkelman]], albeit one that had been in severe decline for the past few years and had dropped from the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] to League Two in three seasons. Allen managed to arrest the club's decline and took his team to the play-offs, but lost in the semi-finals to [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]].

===Leicester City===
In May 2007, Allen became the new manager at [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]],<ref name="Allen named new Leicester manager">{{cite news| title = Allen named new Leicester manager| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leicester_city/6665547.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2007-05-25| accessdate = 2007-05-25}}</ref> after Leicester and Milton Keynes Dons had negotiated a compensation package.

In August 2007, striker [[Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink]] agreed contract terms with Leicester and chairman [[Milan Mandarić]] invited him to undergo a medical at Leicester.<ref name="Jimmy in dark over Foxes">{{cite news|title = Jimmy in dark over Foxes|url = http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_2661318,00.html|publisher = Sky Sports|date = 2007-08-14|accessdate = 2010-02-01}}</ref> But when Hasselbaink arrived in Leicester on 13 August, Allen told him that the medical was no longer going take place.<ref name="Hasselbaink baffled by Foxes snub">{{cite news| title = Hasselbaink baffled by Foxes snub| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leicester_city/6946891.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2007-08-14| accessdate = 2007-09-30}}</ref> Six days later, Mandarić confirmed an interest in striker [[Derek Riordan]], who was lacking first team football at [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]. However, Allen refused to make an offer for Riordan, which further aggravated Mandarić.<ref name="Riordan's Leicester hopes fade">{{cite news| title = Riordan's Leicester hopes fade| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/celtic/6942124.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2007-08-20| accessdate = 2007-09-30}}</ref> Relations with chairman Milan Mandarić quickly deteriorated and his contract was terminated by mutual consent on 29 August 2007 after just four games in charge.<ref name="Allen ends brief Leicester reign">{{cite news| title = Allen ends brief Leicester reign| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/leicester_city/6969388.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2007-08-29| accessdate = 2007-08-29}}</ref>

After leaving Leicester, Allen declared his interest in managing [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]],<ref>{{cite news| title = Allen to apply for Swindon post| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/7120718.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2007-11-30| accessdate = 2007-11-30}}</ref> which eventually went to [[Maurice Malpas]].

===Cheltenham Town===
Allen was appointed as manager of [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] on 15 September 2008, on a three year contract.<ref name="Martin Allen confirmed as Robins boss">{{cite news| title = Martin Allen confirmed as Robins boss| url = http://www.cheltenhamtownfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10434~1392810,00.html| publisher = Cheltenham Town F.C.| date = 2008-09-15| accessdate = 2008-09-15}}</ref> His father, [[Dennis Allen (footballer)|Dennis]], had been manager at [[Whaddon Road]] between 1974 and 1979.<ref name="Like father, like son">{{cite news
| title      = Like father, like son
| url        = http://www.cheltenhamtownfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10434~1392827,00.html
| publisher  = Cheltenham Town F.C.
| date       = 2008-09-15
| accessdate = 2008-09-15}}</ref> With financial difficulties hitting the club and an increasingly troubled dressing room atmosphere, the entire Cheltenham squad were put up for sale. Allen allowed key players to leave mid-season either on loan or for reduced prices, contributing to a run of results which left Cheltenham near the foot of the League Two table. On 20 October 2009 and amidst poor results on the pitch, Allen was suspended by Cheltenham Town and placed on [[gardening leave]] pending an internal investigation into allegations that he racially abused a nightclub [[Bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]].<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/oct/20/martin-allen-cheltenham-league-two Cheltenham suspend manager Martin Allen over alleged racism at nightclub] www.guardian.co.uk</ref> In November [[Gloucestershire]] police announced that no action would be taken against Allen concerning the alleged nightclub incident. He remained on leave whilst Cheltenham Town considered his future at the club.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/nov/09/martin-allen-cheltenham Martin Allen in the clear over 'racism' allegations after police drop case] www.guardian.co.uk</ref> On 11 December it was announced he had left the club.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/dec/11/martin-allen-leaves-cheltenham Martin Allen leaves Cheltenham despite being cleared of racial abuse]</ref> In January 2010 he was appointed part-time [[Scout (sport)|scout]] for [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>[http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/sport/news/Allen-scouts-job-club-Queens-Park-Rangers/article-1678389-detail/article.html Allen scouts out a job with former club Queens Park Rangers] www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk</ref>

===Return to Barnet===
On 23 March 2011, Allen returned to his first managerial club, Barnet, until the end of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{cite news|author='+ dateCreated +' |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6831097,00.html |title=Allen back as Bees boss &#124; Football News |publisher=Sky Sports |date= 2011-03-23|accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> He was working on an eight game contract but left after only three games, in which Barnet were unbeaten,<ref name="Notts County"/> to take charge of [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].

===Notts County===

Allen took charge of Notts County on 11 April 2011 signing a one-year rolling contract.<ref name="Notts County">{{cite news| title = Notts County appoint Martin Allen as manager| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13036140.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 2011-04-11| accessdate = 2011-04-11}}</ref> Notts County won eight points out of the seven games Allen was in charge of at the end of the 2010–11 season, enough for them to avoid relegation. Allen was named League One Manager of the Month in September 2011 after leading the team to four wins and a draw in the league.

Allen was sacked by Notts County on 18 February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Notts County sack manager Martin Allen|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17087244|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref>

===Third spell at Barnet===

Allen was appointed caretaker manager of Barnet on 16 April 2012 for the last three games of the 2011–12 season, replacing [[Lawrie Sanchez]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Lawrie Sanchez leaves Barnet with Martin Allen returning to manage the side until the end of the season|url=http://www.times-series.co.uk/sport/9651446.Sanchez_leaves_Barnet_as_Allen_returns/|accessdate=16 April 2012|newspaper=Hendon & Finchley, Barnet & Potters Bar, Edgeware & Mill Hill Times|date=16 April 2012}}</ref> Barnet managed two wins under Allen's managership, finished 22nd and avoided relegation from [[Football League Two|League Two]] with a 2–1 win on 5 May 2012 on the last day of the season, against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Burton Albion 1-2 Barnet|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878414|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> Following the end of the season, Allen's contract ended.<ref>{{cite web|title=Allen wants Barnet job|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/08052012/63/allen-wants-barnet-job.html|publisher=Eurosport|accessdate=14 May 2012}}</ref>

===Gillingham===
On 5 July 2012, Allen was appointed manager of [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] signing a two-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Martin Allen appointed new Gillingham manager|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18687696|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 July 2012}}</ref>
His first match as Gillingham manager came on 14 August 2012, a 2-1 away win against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref name=1stgills>{{cite web|title=Bristol City 1-2 Gillingham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19159754|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 August 2012}}</ref> While at Gillingham, Allen oversaw the [[Kent]] side's best ever start to a league season.<ref name="When Saturday Comes">{{cite web|title=Martin Allen has Gillingham hoping for glory|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1153-october-2012/9079-martin-allen-has-gillingham-hoping-for-glory|publisher=WSC.co.uk|accessdate=20 October 2012}}</ref> He also broke the club record for most away wins in a football league season with a 1-0 win over [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]], the eleventh of the season on 23 February 2013. On 6 April 2013 Gillingham secured promotion to [[Football League One|League One]], Allen's first ever promotion in his career as a manager.<ref>[http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/news/article/martin-post-chesterfield-away-feb-23-674221.aspx Martin: "It'S An Historic Day"<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They secured the [[2012–13 Football League Two|League Two]] title with a 2-2 draw against [[AFC Wimbledon]] at [[Priestfield Stadium|Priestfield]] on 20 April.<ref>http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/fixtures-results/match-report/index.aspx?MatchId=3520268&tcmuri=185405&pageView=full#anchored</ref>
On 20 May 2013, Allen was crowned [[League Managers Association Awards|League 2 Manager of the Year]] by the [[League Managers Association|LMA]] for his achievements with the club.<ref>[http://www.gillinghamfootballclub.com/news/article/martin-wins-lma-award-829644.aspx Martin Named Manager Of The Year<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Allen was sacked by Gillingham in October 2013 after sixteen months in charge. Gillingham had won just two games from eleven played on their return to League One.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24514317 | title=Martin Allen: Gillingham manager sacked after 16 months | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=14 October 2013}}</ref>

===Fourth spell at Barnet===
Allen was appointed head coach of Barnet on 19 March 2014 until the end of the 2014&ndash;15 season, marking his fourth spell at the club.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.barnetfc.com/news/article/martin-allen-returns-as-head-coach-1431355.aspx#Jr4lr8xJum9xrLX5.99 | title=Martin Allen Returns As Head-Coach | publisher=BARNET FC | accessdate=19 March 2014}}</ref>

==Honours==

;[[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]]

;[[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]]
*[[Football League Two]] (1): [[2012-13 Football League Two|2012–13]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24514317|title=Martin Allen: Gillingham manager sacked after 16 months|quote=Gillingham have sacked manager Martin Allen after 16 months in charge.  Allen, 48, led the Gills to the League Two title last season but they had won just two of 11 league games this term.|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 October 2013|accessdate=9 August 2014}}</ref>

==Family==
His cousins, [[Paul Allen (footballer)|Paul Allen]], [[Bradley Allen]] and [[Clive Allen]], were also footballers, as was his uncle [[Les Allen]]. His father, [[Dennis Allen (footballer)|Dennis]], played for [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] and [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. His son [[Charlie Allen (footballer)|Charlie Allen]] played under his management at several clubs and now plays for [[Margate F.C.|Margate]].  His nephews [[Harry Grant (footballer)|Harry]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kentsportsnews.com/allen-brings-in-nephew-on-loan-28-03-2013/ | title=Allen brings in nephew on loan | publisher=www.kentsportsnews.com | accessdate=21 March 2014}}</ref> Freddie and Alfie{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} are also young footballers. Freddie is the captain of [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]]'s youth team.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2546299/MAD-DOG-ON-MONDAY-Martin-Allen-weekly-column-David-Moyes-Stan-Collymore-Patrick-Bamford.html | title=MAD DOG ON MONDAY: I've found the best signing of the January window... and it's NOT Mata (plus, why Collymore was right to make Twitter stand and Moyes will get time) | publisher=Mail Online | date=27 January 2014 | accessdate=21 March 2014 | author=Allen, Martin}}</ref>

==Business career==
Having run his own soccer schools programme across 13 towns while still playing professionally. Allen, a [[UEFA Pro Licence]] holder and a graduate of the [[League Managers Association|LMA's]] Certificate in Applied Management at [[Warwick University]], created the company Pro FC which finds young people with the potential to become footballers. He is also non-exec director of the football charity, [[Coaching for Hope]].<ref name="Business">{{cite news| title = Who are we?  - Martin Allen| url = http://www.profc.net/about-pro-fc/who-are-we| publisher = www.profc.net| date = | accessdate = 2011-05-12}}</ref>

==Journalism==
In December 2013 Allen began writing for the [[Daily Mail]]. His column, "''Mad Dog on Monday",'' is published online via the Daily Mail's website, [[Mail Online]] Sport.<ref name="Mad Dog on Monday">{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2524287/Robin-van-Persie-needs-leave-Manchester-United-Arsenal-drop-Jack-Wilshere--Martin-Allen.html | title=MAD DOG ON MONDAY: Moyes needs to get rid of RVP... Arsenal must drop Wilshere to win the title... and why Clarke knew the writing was on the wall at West Brom | publisher=Daily Mail | date=16 December 2013 | accessdate=19 December 2013 | author=Allen, Martin}}</ref>

'''Paul Kevin Allen''' (born 28 August 1962) is an English former [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[midfielder]] in [[the Football League]] for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]], [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/paulallen.html |title=Paul Allen |work=UK A–Z Transfers |publisher=Neil Brown |accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref> He won three [[cap (sport)|caps]] for [[England national under-21 football team|England at under-21 level]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u21-intres76.html |title=England – U-21 International Results 1976–1985 – Details |first=Barrie |last=Courtney |publisher=RSSSF |date=10 January 2004 |accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref>

==Career==
At 17 years and 256 days old, Allen's appearance for West Ham United against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[1980 FA Cup Final]] made him the youngest player to appear in an FA Cup final at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], though [[James F.M. Prinsep|James Prinsep]] played at a younger age at [[Kennington Oval]] in 1879. Both records have since been broken.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/curtis-weston-history-man-or-just-a-footballing-footnote-1220953.html |title=Curtis Weston: History man or just a footballing footnote? |first=Glenn |last=Moore |newspaper=The Independent |date=2 January 2009 |accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref> His debut for West Ham had come on 29 September 1979 when 32 days after his 17th birthday he had appeared for the club in their 2–1 home win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the Second Division. He collected a Second Division title medal for the Hammers in [[1980–81 in English football|1980–81]] and helped re-establish them as a First Division side. He made 152 league appearances for the Hammers, scoring six goals, before a £400,000 fee took him to their London rivals Tottenham Hotspur on 19 June 1985.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Allen|url=http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football/west-ham-united-fc/paul-allen-9499/1979-80-1984-85_a12576/|work=Sporting Heroes|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>

Allen went on to play in two FA Cup finals for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], on the losing side in [[1987 FA Cup Final|1987]] but victorious in [[1991 FA Cup Final|1991]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.givemefootball.com/premier-league/paul-allen-still-remembered-for-the-cup-final-goal |title=PAUL ALLEN: Still remembered for the cup final goal he didn't score! |first=Dave |last=Smith |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |date=10 December 2002 |accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref> In eight years with Tottenham, he played 292 league games and scored 23 goals. He was voted player of the year for the [[1992-93 in English football|1992–93 season]], his final full season at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>[http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football-heroes/displayhero_club.asp?HeroID=38000]</ref>

He remained at [[White Hart Lane]] until 16 September 1993, when a £550,000 deal took him to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]. He played 33 [[FA Premier League]] games in [[1993–94 in English football|1993–94]], scoring once, but played just 10 league games without scoring in [[1994–95 in English football|1994–95]] and was loaned out for 17 games to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], scoring once in a 4–2 defeat away at [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] in [[1994–95 in English football|March 1995]]. He then signed for [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on a free transfer and helped them win the Division Two title (and promotion to Division One) in [[1995–96 in English football|1995–96]].

After retiring from playing football at the end of the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98]], which he spent in Division one with Millwall, he worked for the [[Professional Footballers' Association]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article438151.ece |title=Caught in Time: West Ham win the FA Cup, 1980 |first=Greg |last=Struthers |newspaper=The Sunday Times |date=27 March 2005 |accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref>

'''Rory Allen''' (born 17 October 1977) is an English ex-professional [[association football|football]] player.

==Club career==
===Early career===
A striker, Allen made his professional football debut for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 4 September 1996 as a [[substitute (football)|substitute]] in a 1–0 defeat at [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] (aged 18). 
He went on to score four times in 28 games for Spurs including starting a memorable{{whom|date=July 2012}} 3rd round [[FA Cup]] tie in 1997 against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] alongside [[Neale Fenn]] up front{{where|date=July 2012}}. Two of his four goals came in the league, against Newcastle<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/keegan-strikes-balance-1362407.html
|title=Keegan strikes balance 
|publisher=[[The Independent]] 
|date=7 September 1996 |accessdate=7 November 2009
| location=London
| first=Stan
| last=Hey}}</ref> and Manchester United,<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/beckhams-drive-cuts-at-the-heart-of-spurs-faithful-1282925.html
|title=Beckham's drive cuts at the heart of Spurs' faithful 
|publisher=[[The Independent]] 
|date=12 January 1997 |accessdate=7 November 2009
| location=London
| first=Mike
| last=Rowbottom}}</ref> also scoring a brace against Preston North End in the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/allen-provides-key-for-spurs-1365148.html
|title=Allen provides key for Spurs
|publisher=[[The Independent]] 
|date=25 September 1996 |accessdate=7 November 2009
| location=London
| first=Greg
| last=Wood}}</ref> Allen was sent on loan to [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] in 1997, scoring 7 goals in 9 appearances in what was then [[Football League Second Division|Division Two]] (the third tier of English football).

===Portsmouth===
[[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] paid Spurs a club record £1,000,000 for him in July 1999, as he became Pompey's first million-pound signing,<ref>[http://archive.andoveradvertiser.co.uk/1999/7/15/90597.html Pompey swoop for Spurs striker], Andover Advertiser, 15 July 1999.</ref> citing manager [[Alan Ball, Jr.|Alan Ball]] as a key factor in his decision to make the move.<ref name=dm230899>{{cite web|first=Alan|last=Bromsgrove|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-109792465.html|title=Ball's joy as Allen underlines his worth|work=Daily Mail|date=23 August 1999|accessdate=8 December 2013}}{{Subscription required|via=Highbeam Research}}</ref> He suffered an injury in pre-season training.<ref name=dm230899/> He scored his first goal for Portsmouth on 15 August 1999 in a match against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3A+RORY'S+GLORY.-a060240737|title=Football: RORY'S GLORY|work=Sunday Mirror|date=15 August 1999|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> The following week, he made it two goals in a week, scoring in a 2–0 victory at home to [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3A+Rory+hits+warpath%3B+Portsmouth+2+Stockport+0.-a060145832|title=Football: Rory hits warpath; Portsmouth 2 Stockport 0|work=The People|date=22 August 1999|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> He injured his ankle in September 1999, lasting only 24 minutes of a league match against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/10-man+Ipswich+dig+deep+for+reward%3B+Portsmouth+1+Ipswich+Town+1.-a060200574|title=10-man Ipswich dig deep for reward; Portsmouth 1 Ipswich Town 1|work=Sunday Mercury|date=12 September 1999|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> He wouldn't play again until making an appearance as a substitute in March 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Giveaway+Forest+felled+by+Claridge+late+show%3B+Portsmouth+2+Nottm...-a060899684|title=Giveaway Forest felled by Claridge late show; Portsmouth 2 Nottm Forest 1|work=Sunday Mercury|date=12 March 2000|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> Allen scored his third Portsmouth goal against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|QPR]] in May 2000, equalising in the 53rd minute but with Portsmouth finally losing the match 3–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Pompey+sunk+by+super-sub+Gallen%3B+REST+OF+DIVISION+ONE.-a061931336|title=Pompey sunk by super-sub Gallen; REST OF DIVISION ONE|work=The Birmingham Post|date=8 May 2000|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref>

He struggled for match fitness,<ref>{{cite web|first=John|last=Curtis|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5197137.html|title=Football: Promotion Nilsson's Premier Goal|work=The Independent|date=17 October 2001|accessdate=8 December 2013}}{{Subscription required|via=Highbeam Research}}</ref> and missed the whole of the 2000–01 and 2001–02 seasons due to knee problems.<ref name=alaves>{{cite web|first=Jenny|last=Lea|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3A+RORY+GLORY+ENDS+AGONY%3B+Portsmouth+1+Alaves+1.-a090108017|title=Football: RORY GLORY ENDS AGONY; Portsmouth 1 Alaves 1|work=The People|date=4 August 2002|accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> He scored in a pre-season friendly match against Spanish side [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]] in August 2002,<ref name=alaves/> but made no further competitive appearances. He left the club in November 2002, handing in a letter of resignation with eight months of his contract remaining.<ref>{{cite web|first=Mary|last=Hannigan|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-24649005.html|title=After all, it's only a game|work=The Irish Times|date=18 November 2002|accessdate=8 December 2013}}{{Subscription required|via=Highbeam Research}}</ref> Having already undergone eight operations to his ankles and knees over the course of his career, this signalled his retirement from football aged just 25.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/theknowledge/story/0,,2012031,00.html | title=The Knowledge| accessdate = 14 February 2007 | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=James | last=Dart | date=14 February 2007}}</ref>

==Personal life==
In 2000, Allen was arrested and fined alongside Portsmouth goalkeeper [[Aaron Flahavan]] after admitting being abusive towards police officers following a drinking session.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5058777.html|title=Football: Uefa Cup Place for Worthington Victors|work=The Independent|date=23 February 2000|accessdate=8 December 2013}}{{Subscription required|via=Highbeam Research}}</ref>

'''Joseph Ball''' "'''Joe'''" '''Allon''' (born 12 November 1966) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]]. A [[Forward (association football)|striker]], he scored 112 goals in 300 league games in a 14-year career in [[the Football League]].

Starting his career with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 1984, he failed to break into the first team and moved on to [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] three years later. After a season with the "Swans" he signed with [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]]. After scoring 50 league goals for the club he transferred to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 1991. After a season with Chelsea, including a loan spell with [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]], he joined [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]]. In 1994 he moved back to Port Vale permanently, before moving back to Hartlepool United via [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] in 1995. He retired in 1998. He won three promotions with three different clubs, and was voted onto the Fourth Division [[PFA Team of the Year]] in [[1990–91 Football League|1990–91]].

==Playing career==
A forward, Allon started his professional career with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 1984, at a time when [[Jack Charlton]] was manager at [[St James' Park]]. At the end of [[1984–85 Newcastle United F.C. season|1984–85]] he starred in the [[FA Youth Cup]] final victory over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], in which [[Paul Gascoigne]] scored a wonder goal. Allon scored twice in nine [[Football League First Division|First Division]] games in [[1985–86 Newcastle United F.C. season|1985–86]] and [[1986–87 Newcastle United F.C. season|1986–87]], before manager [[Willie McFaul]] moved him on to [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in August 1987. [[Terry Yorath]]'s "Swans" won promotion out of the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] in [[1987–88 Football League|1987–88]] after beating [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] 5–4 on aggregate in the [[1988 Football League Fourth Division play-off Final|play-off final]]. During the season Allon also scored against rivals [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in the [[South Wales derby]], in a 2–2 draw at [[Vetch Field]] on New Year's Day. He scored twelve times in 40 league and cup appearances in a partnership with [[Colin Pascoe]], before he returned to the North-East to join [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] in November 1988, as one of [[Bobby Moncur]]'s first signings as manager.

The "Pools" struggled near the foot of [[the Football League]] in [[1988–89 Football League|1988–89]], and Allon scored just five goals in 26 starts.<ref name="inthemadcrowd">{{cite web|title=Profile|url=http://www.inthemadcrowd.co.uk/cgi-bin/itmc_view_person.asp?oid=11|work=inthemadcrowd.co.uk|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> The team again struggled in [[1989–90 Football League|1989–90]], though Allon managed 17 goals in 45 league starts to become the club's joint top-scorer with strike partner [[Paul Baker]].<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/> After new boss [[Cyril Knowles]] installed a defence to match the Allon-Baker partnership, the club won promotion in [[1990–91 Football League|1990–91]]; United finished third, but were only one point behind champions [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]].<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/> Allon hit 35 goals in 55 games in the campaign, and was named Hennessey Cognac North East Player of the Year and North East Football Writers Player of the Year, and was also voted onto the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/>

His form that season earned him a move to top-flight side [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in August 1991, with manager [[Ian Porterfield]] paying a fee reported to be £250,000. However he failed to make an impact at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], and in February of the [[1991–92 Port Vale F.C. season|1991–92]] season he joined [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] on loan, but made just six goalless appearances for [[John Rudge]]'s "Valiants", who struggled in vain to avoid relegation out of the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]].<ref name="kent">{{cite book|last=Kent|first=Jeff|title=Port Vale Personalities|publisher=Witan Books|page=7|year=1996|isbn=0-9529152-0-0}}</ref> He only stayed for a few months of [[1992–93 Chelsea F.C. season|1992–93]], the inaugural season of the [[Premier League]]. It was rumoured that his friendship with [[Vinnie Jones]] led him astray and helped to bring about his poor form.<ref name="Joe Allon">{{cite web|last=Parkinson|first=Ed|title=Joe Allon|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/content/view/2934/29/|work=wsc.co.uk|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> In all he started just four games (with a further 14 substitute appearances) and scored three goals for the "Blues". He was sold to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in November 1992 for a club-record incoming fee of £275,000.<ref name="bees05">{{cite book |last= |first= |year=2005 |title=Brentford Football Club Official Matchday Magazine versus Hull City 07/05/05 |url= |location= |page=46|isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> The "Bees" were relegated out of the First Division at the end of the [[1992–93 Football League|1992–93]] season under [[Phil Holder]]. He scored a total of 28 goals in 56 league and cup appearances at [[Griffin Park]].

Allon moved to back Port Vale – this time permanently – in March 1994.<ref name="kent"/> He scored twice in what remained of the [[1993–94 Port Vale F.C. season|1993–94]] campaign, helping the club to win promotion out of the Second Division.<ref name="kent"/> He bagged seven goals at [[Vale Park]] in [[1994–95 Port Vale F.C. season|1994–95]], before he was sold to [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] side [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] for £42,500 in July 1995.<ref name="kent"/> After just five games and three months at [[Sincil Bank]] he was on the move again, during which manager [[Sam Ellis (footballer)|Sam Ellis]] was replaced by [[John Beck (footballer)|John Beck]], and returned to [[Victoria Park, Hartlepool|Victoria Park]] when Hartlepool manager [[Keith Houchen]] splashed out £40,000. He scored nine goals in 24 games in [[1995–96 Football League|1995–96]] to become joint top-scorer, but a persistent knee injury restricted his first team appearances.<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/> He scored 11 goals in 34 games in [[1996–97 Football League|1996–97]] to again become the club's top-scorer, as Hartlepool finished just four points above the bottom of the Football League under the stewardship of [[Mick Tait]].<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/> His goal spree towards the end of the season helped the club to avoid a drop into the [[Football Conference|Conference]].<ref name="Joe Allon"/> He only made it onto the pitch five times in [[1997–98 Football League|1997–98]], but still found the net twice, before he retired due to injury.<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/> His total of 79 goals for Hartlepool puts him in seventh place in their overall list of top scorers.<ref name="inthemadcrowd"/>

==Post-retirement==
Between 2006 and 2008 Allon worked under ex-[[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] teammate [[Dennis Wise]] on the coaching staff at [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]]. He has also appeared as a summariser and expert on local radio and remains a popular figure with Hartlepool United fans.

'''Bernard Allou''' (born 19 June 1975 in [[Cocody]]) is an [[Côte d'Ivoire|Ivorian]]-born French [[Football (soccer)|football]] player. He most notably played for [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]], [[Nagoya Grampus Eight]] and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. 

In 1997 he had a trial at [[Newcastle United]] but it didn't lead to a contract.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-on-the-move-1239179.html
|title=On The Move
|publisher=[[The Independent]]
|date=14 September 1997 |accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref> In March 1999 Allou signed for Nottingham Forest and went on to make 2 appearances in the remainder of that season, as Forest were relegated from the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=16545&season_id=128
|title=Games played by Bernard Allou in 1998/1999
|publisher=Soccerbase.com
|accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref> The following season he scored two goals for Forest; one against [[Mansfield Town]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]]<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/1999/aug/12/newsstory.sport7
|title=Results, 11 August 1999
|publisher=[[The Guardian]]
|date=11 August 1999 |accessdate=6 November 2009}}</ref> and one against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the league.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/news/article/165/7939750/nottingham-forest-1-wolves-1
|title=Nottingham Forest 1 Wolves 1
|publisher=Sporting Life
|date=19 September 1999 |accessdate=5 November 2009}}</ref>

'''Daniel Lee "Danny" Allsopp''' (born 10 August 1978) is a former Australian [[Association football|football (soccer)]] player who played as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]]. He last played for [[Croydon City Arrows]]. He is a full international for the [[Australia national football team]], and is well known for being [[Melbourne Victory FC|Melbourne Victory]]'s second highest, and the [[A-League]]'s seventh highest all-time goalscorer, behind [[Archie Thompson]], [[Shane Smeltz]], [[Besart Berisha]], [[Sergio van Dijk]], [[Mark Bridge]] and [[Carlos Hernández (footballer)|Carlos Hernandez]].

==Club career==
Allsopp started his professional football career with Croydon City F.C. in the [[Victorian Premier League]] competition, having been selected from the [[Victorian Institute of Sport]] in 1999

Allsopp then moved to England to trial for [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], and after scoring in City's first friendly match against [[Newquay F.C.|Newquay]] as well as some reserve team matches, he was signed for the club for the 1998–99 season. Allsopp's four goals in 25 games saw Manchester City promoted to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]], but he struggled to find a regular place in the team as the team in the 1999–2000 season, and was loaned out to [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].

He was loaned to [[Wrexham F.C.|Wrexham]] in early 2000, and scored four goals in just three league matches by end of the 1999–2000 season. The following season he went on loan to [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]], where he failed to score a goal in his four league appearances. Allsopp returned on loan to Notts County, and scored four goals in three matches before being bought for [[Pound sterling|£]]300,000 by the club. In a three-season career, he scored 50 goals in 111 appearances (in all matches) before signing with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for 2003–04. The move provided more success for Allsopp, as he scored 15 goals in his first season and seven in 2004–05 as a regular in the line-up.

Allsopp negotiated an early release from Hull, and decided to return to Australia to play for new club [[Melbourne Victory]] under [[Ernie Merrick]], who had coached Allsopp during his time at the VIS.<ref>{{cite web| date=8 March 2005| title=Victory sign Hull's Allsopp| url=http://wwiii.sbs.com.au/a-league/index.php3?page=tn&tid=146&id=55286| accessdate=7 May 2006}}</ref> Despite making 20 starts in the [[A-League 2005-06|2005–06 season]], Allsopp was not nearly as prolific as at his previous clubs, and only managed three goals for the year. The season featured Allsopp's 250th match in all league competitions.<ref>{{cite web| date=21 September 2005| title=Danny's 250 milestone| url=http://www.melbournevictory.com.au/default.aspx?s=newsdisplay&id=1630| accessdate=7 May 2006}}</ref>

The 2006–07 season saw a remarkable turnaround in Allsopp's scoring record at Melbourne. He finished the season as the league Golden Boot winner as highest scorer in the home and away fixtures. His tally of 11 made him the first A-League player to score a double figure tally and was one goal more than second place, teammate [[Archie Thompson]]. His 35 shots on target was also the equal highest with [[Newcastle Jets]] [[midfielder]] [[Nick Carle]].

During the 2009–10 A-League season it was confirmed that Allsopp had signed with [[Qatar]]i side, [[Al-Rayyan Sports Club]], for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web| date=8 September 2009| title=
Allsopp joins Qatar's Al-Rayyan| url=http://melbournevictory.com.au/default.aspx?s=newsdisplay&id=29176| accessdate=8 September 2009}}</ref> He had less than a year left on his contract with Victory.

On 22 September 2009, Allsopp made his debut for Al-Rayyan against Al-Kharatiyat, providing an assist for [[Amara Diane]]'s goal.

Allsopp joined [[Major League Soccer]] club [[D.C. United]] on 18 January 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/soccerinsider/2010/01/dc_united_signs_australian_str.html | work=The Washington Post | title=D.C. United Signs Australian Striker}}</ref> Allsopp and D.C. United mutually agreed to terminate his contract after just one season with the club.<ref>http://www.dcunited.com/press-release/2010/11/dc-united-and-danny-allsopp-part-ways</ref> On 24 December 2010 Allsopp rejoined with his team mates at the [[Melbourne Victory]], in a contract that will keep him there until the end of the 2012–13 season.<ref>{{cite web|title=
Allsopp back for more |work=Melbourne Victory |url=http://www.a-league.com.au/default.aspx?s=newsdisplay&id=37744 |accessdate=24 December 2010}}</ref>

On 18 October 2012 he announced his retirement from professional football.<ref>http://www.footballaustralia.com.au/news-display/Danny-Allsopp-announces-retirement/50647</ref>

In 2013, Allsopp will return to play for his boyhood club, [[Croydon City Arrows]].

==International career==
In 1995 he made his name in the [[1995 FIFA U-17 World Championship|under-17 World Championship]], where he was tied top scorer with five goals, including one in [[Australia national association football team|Australia]]'s 3–1 loss to eventual runners-up [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]]. His performance opened the door for his entrance into the Australian [[National Soccer League]], signing with [[South Melbourne FC|South Melbourne]]. He stayed with the club until 1997, having scored two goals in his 20 appearances.

Allsopp represented Australia again, this time at under-20 level in the [[1997 FIFA World Youth Championship]] in [[Malaysia]], with Australia making it through to the second round before being knocked out by [[Japan national football team|Japan]].<ref>{{cite web| title=World Youth Cup (U-20) 1997 (Malaysia, June&nbsp;16-July 5)| url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesw/wyc97.html| work=[[RSSSF]]| accessdate=7 May 2006| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mq05ouqw | archivedate = 16 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> On his return he was signed for [[Carlton S.C.|Carlton SC]], but was loaned out to VPL club [[Port Melbourne Sharks]].

Meanwhile, Allsopp had become a regular member of Australia's under-23 national team (the "Olyroos") in 1999,<ref>{{cite web| title=Olyroos 1999 Matches| url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Olympics/1999.html| accessdate=7 May 2006}}</ref> and played three matches for one goal in 2000,<ref>{{cite web| title=Olyroos 2000 Matches| url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Olympics/2000.html| accessdate=7 May 2006}}</ref> but was not selected in the squad for the [[2000 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Squad for 2000 Olympic Games| url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Olympics/squads/Sep2000.html| accessdate=7 May 2006}}</ref>

Allsopp finally earned his first call-up to the [[Australia national football (soccer) team|Australia]] senior squad for a friendly match against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] on June 2007 and came on as a 78th minute substitute in the 2–1 defeat by the South Americans. On 23 May he got his second  international appearance for Australia when he came on as a substitute for [[James Troisi]] in a friendly against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Qantas Socceroos squad named for Uruguay|work=Football Federation Australia|url=http://www.footballaustralia.com.au/default.aspx?s=insideffa_newsfeatures_newsitem&id=10659|accessdate=22 May 2007}}</ref>

National coach [[Pim Verbeek]] described Allsopp's performance against [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] in February 2009 as "absolutely hopeless",<ref name=bag>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/02/24/2500041.htm Verbeek unleashes on 'hopeless' Socceroos pair]</ref> although he later added that "in the last games (for Melbourne) I have seen they were very good, so maybe it was because of Indonesia or the trip".<ref name="bag"/>

==Personal life==
Allsopp was born in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and is married with two sons.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}

'''Marco António Bernardo Parcana Almeida''' (born 4 April 1977) is a Portuguese retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]].

He started his career with [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting]], going on to amass [[Primeira Liga]] totals of 90 games and five goals over the course of six seasons, also representing in the competition [[S.C. Campomaiorense|Campomaiorense]] and [[F.C. Alverca|Alverca]]. He also competed professionally in England, Spain and Cyprus.

==Football career==
Almeida was born in [[Barreiro Municipality|Barreiro]], [[Setúbal District|Setúbal]], and played youth football with [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]]. He started his senior career with [[Casa Pia A.C.]] on loan, moving to [[Sporting Clube Lourinhanense]] in 1996 as the latter acted as [[Farm team|feeder club]] to the [[Primeira Liga]] giants. For the [[1998–99 Primeira Liga|1998–99 season]], still in the top level, he was again loaned, now to [[S.C. Campomaiorense]].

In July 1999 Almeida was signed by [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]'s manager [[Dave Jones (football manager)|Dave Jones]] on a year's loan, with a view to a permanent move.<ref>[http://www.theguardian.com/football/1999/jul/20/newsstory.sport3 'Detonator' breaks bank at Coventry]</ref> After impressing in pre-season [[Exhibition game|friendlies]]<ref>[http://www.andoveradvertiser.co.uk/sport/5633979.Solid_start_is_a_must_for_Dean/ Solid start is a must for Dean]</ref> he made his first-team debut as a 71st-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Claus Lundekvam]] in a [[Premier League]] match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at [[The Dell (Southampton)|the Dell]], on 19 September 1999: within eight minutes, he was alongside fellow substitute [[Thierry Henry]] just outside the Southampton area, when the latter received a pass from [[Tony Adams (footballer)|Tony Adams]]. He stumbled while trying to clear the ball, allowing Henry to wrap his foot around the ball and send a rocket of a shot into the far corner of the Southampton net, in what was the Frenchman's first goal in English football.<ref>[http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/henry-from-also-ran-to-thoroughbred Henry, from also-ran to thoroughbred]</ref>

Although Almeida made a few appearances for the Saints' [[Reserve team|reserves]], including scoring in a 2–2 draw with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 22 September 1999, he was never again called into the main squad and, in December, the loan was cancelled.<ref>[http://www.andoveradvertiser.co.uk/sport/5631768.Football__Saints_let_Almeida_go_back_home/ Football: Saints let Almeida go back home]</ref> In the same country, he would also have unsuccessful trials with [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in September 2000<ref>{{cite book|author=Duncan Holley & Gary Chalk|title=In That Number – A post-war chronicle of Southampton FC |publisher=Hagiology Publishing|year=2003|page=473|isbn=0-9534474-3-X}}</ref> and [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (managed by former Southampton boss Jones) in 2007; subsequently he returned to Sporting, being released in the following summer after which he re-joined Campomaiorense, now as a [[free agent]].

Almeida's most steady period came at [[F.C. Alverca]], which he helped promote from the [[Segunda Liga]] in [[2002–03 Segunda Liga|his second year]] by netting a career-best five times in 32 games. After three seasons he moved abroad again, going almost unnoticed at [[Ciudad de Murcia]] – Spanish [[Segunda División]] – and he subsequently returned to his country, playing one campaign apiece with second-tier sides [[F.C. Maia]] and [[Portimonense S.C.|Portimonense SC]].

In the following years Almeida, already in his 30s, alternated between his country's lower levels and [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] football.
