'''Manuel Almunia Rivero''' (born 19 May 1977) is a Spanish retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]].

He competed mainly in the Spanish lower leagues in his early years, only appearing in 26 [[La Liga]] games over the course of two seasons with [[Recreativo de Huelva|Recreativo]] and [[Albacete Balompié|Albacete]], after starting out at [[CA Osasuna|Osasuna]].

Most of his professional career was spent with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], for which he signed in 2004, going on to play 175 official matches and [[2005 FA Cup Final|winning the 2005 FA Cup]]. He also had a short loan spell at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. 

In 2012, after his contract expired, Almunia joined [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] and played there for two years, following which he retired.

==Club career==
===Early career===
Born in [[Pamplona]], [[Navarre]], Almunia started his senior career with [[CA Osasuna]]'s [[CA Osasuna B|reserves]] in 1995, going on to spend four seasons with the team in [[Segunda División B]]. Subsequently, he stayed in the same level, where he represented [[FC Cartagena|FC Cartagonova]] and [[CE Sabadell FC]].

In the 2001 summer Almunia first reached [[La Liga]], after signing with [[Celta de Vigo]]. He never represented the club officially however, being loaned to [[SD Eibar]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2001/07/30/pagina-23/447036/pdf.html|title=La cesión de Boban empieza a tomar cuerpo|trans_title=Boban loan starting to gain shape|publisher=[[El Mundo Deportivo (newspaper)|El Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=30 July 2001|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> (where he won the [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]] in [[Segunda División]] for the [[2001–02 Segunda División|2001–02 campaign]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2002/05/27/pagina-24/491500/pdf.html|title=Liga a la baja|trans_title=Low league|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=27 May 2002|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref>), [[Recreativo de Huelva]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2002/07/07/pagina-11/498183/pdf.html|title=Guerrero, muy cerca del Recreativo de Huelva|trans_title=Guerrero, very close to Recreativo de Huelva|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=7 July 2002|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> and [[Albacete Balompié]], the last two in the top flight.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2003/07/23/pagina-32/549056/pdf.html|title=El Albacete se interesa por Jordi Cruyff y Almunia llega cedido|trans_title=Albacete asks about Jordi Cruyff and Almunia arrives on loan|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=23 July 2003|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref>

Playing understudy to [[José Antonio Luque Ramírez|José Antonio Luque]] and César at ''Recre'', Almunia's debut in the [[Spanish football league system|main category of Spanish football]] came on 17 November 2002, following a [[Ejection (sports)|red card]] to the latter in a 0–3 away loss against [[Deportivo Alavés]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2002/11/18/pagina-14/509385/pdf.html|title=Baño de autoconfianza|trans_title=Bathing in self-confidence|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=18 November 2002|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> It was one of only two league appearances during [[2002–03 La Liga|the season]], as the [[Andalusia]]ns suffered relegation after ranking 18th.

At [[Albacete Balompié]], Almunia started as backup to [[Carlos Roa]]. However, after the [[Argentina|Argentine]] came down with illness he became first-choice,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2003/12/22/pagina-4/1505219/pdf.html|title=Lacruz y Prieto, con problemas gástricos|trans_title=Lacruz and Prieto, with gastric problems|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=22 December 2003|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> going on to help his team easily escape relegation through a [[2003–04 La Liga|14th-place finish]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2004/05/24/pagina-21/756422/pdf.html|title=El Valencia va de fiesta en fiesta|trans_title=Valencia cannot stop partying|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=24 May 2004|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> his first league appearance was on 9 November 2003, in a 0–1 home defeat to [[Málaga CF]] as Roa was suspended.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/2003/11/10/pagina-25/565278/pdf.html|title=Mal partido en el Carlos Belmonte|trans_title=Poor match at the Carlos Belmonte|publisher=El Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=10 November 2003|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref>

===Arsenal===
Almunia joined [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 14 July 2004 for an undisclosed sum, to provide back up to [[Jens Lehmann]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/3877979.stm|title=Almunia joins Arsenal|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=14 July 2004|accessdate=29 May 2007}}</ref> He made his debut for his new team on 27 October in a 2–1 win at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] for [[2004–05 Football League Cup|the season]]'s [[Football League Cup|League Cup]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3947065.stm|title=Man City 1–2 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 October 2004|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref> and his maiden [[Premier League]] appearance came on 4 December against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4047547.stm|title=Arsenal 3–0 Birmingham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 December 2004|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref> the highlight of [[2004–05 FA Premier League|his first year]] came in [[2004–05 FA Cup|the fifth round]] of the [[FA Cup]], a replay at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]: with the game finishing 0–0 after [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]] and heading to [[Penalty shoot-out|penalties]], he saved [[Alan Quinn]] and [[Jon Harley]]'s attempts to book his team a place in the quarter-finals,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4300405.stm|title=Sheff Utd 0–0 Arsenal (aet)|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 March 2005|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref> and was an unused [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in [[2005 FA Cup Final|the final win]] over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].

In the [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06 campaign]] Almunia continued as second-choice to Lehmann, but found himself thrust into the spotlight when he replaced [[Robert Pirès]] in the 20th minute of [[2006 UEFA Champions League Final|the final]] of the [[UEFA Champions League]] against [[FC Barcelona]], as the German was sent off. He performed well for the most part, only conceding both goals in the 1–2 loss late in the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4773353.stm|title=Barcelona 2–1 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=17 May 2006}}</ref>

[[2006–07 FA Premier League|2006–07]] brought Almunia 14 appearances for the Gunners all competitions comprised. This included [[2007 League Cup Final|the League Cup final]], lost to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6371613.stm|title=Live – Carling Cup final|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=24 February 2008}}</ref> He and Lehmann were by all accounts rivals off the pitch as well. In an interview with German television in October 2007, speaking about manager [[Arsène Wenger]]'s decision to drop him in favour of the Spaniard, Lehmann said: “It’s possible that some day I’ll feel like talking about the whole issue. But at the moment I’m just swallowing it all as part of the humiliation. But I think – and this is aimed at my dear manager – one shouldn’t humiliate players for too long. I won’t just fade away quietly. Almunia has not yet showed he can win matches for us. I’ve experienced this before and know what the others are expecting from the goalkeeper.” Five months later, Almunia responded: “I treat people the way I would like to be treated myself. To have someone here who hates me is just amazing. Every morning I wake up I know it is going to be the same. But I don’t care any more. I come into training and work with [[Łukasz Fabiański]] and [[Vito Mannone]]. They are better than him anyway.”<ref>''The Arsenal Companion'' (2nd ed) – Paul Donnelley (Pitch Publishing 2011)</ref>

Almunia finally won the battle for first-choice duties in the [[2007–08 Premier League|2007–08 season]]. Highlights included saving a [[Penalty kick|penalty]] from [[Robbie Keane]] to help Arsenal beat [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7145733.stm|title=Arsenal 2–1 Tottenham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 December 2007|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> He was given the number one shirt after Lehmann left for [[VfB Stuttgart]] at the beginning of the [[2008–09 Premier League|2008–09 campaign]], and he saved another important penalty on 21 March 2009, this time from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]'s [[Obafemi Martins]] in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7937084.stm|title=Newcastle 1–3 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> In June 2008 he signed a new four-year contract with the English club,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3379955,00.html|title=Almunia agrees Arsenal deal|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=3 June 2008|accessdate=1 August 2008}}</ref> but his subsequent performances were highly inconsistent, with brilliant displays in [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League|the Champions League semi-final first leg]] against Manchester United<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8010847.stm|title=Man Utd 1–0 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=29 April 2009}}</ref> and the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League|2010 Champions League quarter-finals]] against Barcelona,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/0910/post/first-team/champions-league-arsenal-2-2-barcelona|title=Arsenal 2–2 Barcelona|publisher=Arsenal F.C|date=31 March 2010|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> and very poor ones which resulted in rumours arising that he would be sold.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2010/07/09/2017471/arsenal-set-to-move-for-udinese-goalkeeper-samir-handanovic|title=Arsenal set to move for Udinese goalkeeper Samir Handanovic|publisher=[[Goal.com]]|date=9 July 2010|accessdate=10 July 2010}}</ref>

[[File:Manuel Almunia.JPG|thumb|Almunia warming up for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 2006]]
Despite the speculation, Almunia started [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11]] as first-choice. However, on 25 September against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], he conceded a penalty (which he saved), let a tame shot slip through the near post and was caught out of position in the opposition's third goal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9024632.stm|title=Arsenal 2–3 West Brom|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 September 2010|accessdate=26 September 2010}}</ref> He lost his place through injury and, upon his return, found himself third-choice behind the Polish duo of Fabiański and [[Wojciech Szczęsny]].

Almunia made a return to the team on 30 January 2011 against [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in [[2010–11 FA Cup|the FA Cup]], and went on to play both games in the next round against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. On 8 March 2011 he came on as a 19th-minute substitute for the injured Szczęsny against Barcelona in the [[UEFA Champions League]] last-16 stage, and made a series of saves as Arsenal lost 1–3 at the [[Camp Nou]] to exit the tournament, [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League|3–4 on aggregate]]; he was voted [[Man of the Match]] by fans on the club's official website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1011/motm/first-team/barcelona-v-arsenal-choose-your-motm|title=Man of the Match against Barcelona – Almunia|publisher=Arsenal F.C|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> 

With Szczęsny (dislocated finger), Fabianski (shoulder) and Mannone all out with injury, Almunia again became Arsenal's first-choice. On 19 March, during a 2–2 draw at West Bromwich, he was caught out of position along with [[Sébastien Squillaci]], gifting the home team their second goal; already with Lehmann back in the club as an emergency signing, Almunia injured his knee during warm-up of the fixture against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]; he did not appear in any more matches for the rest of the season.

On 30 September 2011, Almunia signed an initial one-month emergency loan deal with [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] after [[Robert Green]] was ruled out for six weeks with a knee cartilage injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,,11685_7213697,00.html|title=Hammers land Almunia on loan|publisher=Sky Sports|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=30 September 2011}}</ref> He made his debut for the Hammers on 1 October in a 2–2 away draw against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2044076/Crystal-Palace-2-West-Ham-2-Sub-Carew-rescue-Hammers.html?ito=feeds-newsxml|title=Crystal Palace 2 West Ham 2: Sub Carew to the rescue for Hammers|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|first=Alex|last=Montgomery|location=London|date=1 October 2011|accessdate=}}</ref> but, at the end of October and with Green's return to fitness, he returned to Arsenal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11670/7283471/Almunia-returns-to-Arsenal|title=Almunia returns to Arsenal|publisher=Sky Sports|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref>

On 22 May 2012, Arsenal announced that Almunia and six other players would be released from their contracts as of 30 June.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/1076621/manuel-almunia-shown-the-arsenal-door?cc=5739#|title=Almunia released|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=22 May 2012|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>

===Watford===
In July 2012, aged 35, Almunia signed a one-year contract with second division's [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], replacing [[Scott Loach]] who had moved to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10400~2865682,00.html|title=Official: Hornets delighted with a magnificent seven signings|publisher=Watford F.C|date=30 July 2012|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> He played his first game on 11 August in a [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup tie]] at home to [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], and kept a [[Shutout|clean sheet]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19124003|title=Watford 1–0 Wycombe|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 August 2012|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> 

Having appeared in all thirty four of Watford's league games, Almunia injured his hamstring against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 23 February 2013. He proceeded to miss the next six contests as young understudy [[Jonathan Bond]] deputized in his absence, returning in a 0–0 home draw against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 6 April 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/130406-almunia-post-cardiff-757429.aspx?pageView=full#anchored|title=Reaction: "Happy with clean sheet"|publisher=Watford F.C|date=7 April 2013|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref>

On 12 May 2013, in [[2012–13 Football League Championship|the play-off semi-final second leg]] at home to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], Almunia made a double save from [[Anthony Knockaert]]'s penalty in injury time, with Watford leading 2–1 but still trailing on aggregate. The Yellow Army counter-attacked from the resulting saves and [[Troy Deeney]] scored another goal to put his team in [[2013 Football League play-offs|the decisive match]] against Crystal Palace, where a [[Kevin Phillips (footballer)|Kevin Phillips]] penalty in extra time meant the 0–1 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417772|title=Watford 3–1 Leicester|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 May 2013|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref>

On 5 July 2013 Watford announced that Almunia had signed a new twelve-month deal, to keep him at the club for [[2013–14 Football League Championship|one further season]]. Manager [[Gianfranco Zola]] commented: "His experience and influence are so important for us and the impact he had at Watford last season was magnificent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11686/8811025/Watford-goalkeeper-Manuel-Almunia-signs-new-one-year-contract|title=Watford goalkeeper Manuel Almunia signs new one-year contract|publisher=Sky Sports|date=6 July 2013|accessdate=8 July 2013}}</ref> He left in June of the following year, as his link expired.

Almunia retired on 28 August 2014 on medical advice, after a rare heart condition was picked up during a medical with [[Serie A]] side [[Cagliari Calcio]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28966630|title=Manuel Almunia: Ex-Arsenal keeper retires with heart problem|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 August 2014|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
Almunia did not represent [[Spain national football team|Spain]] at any level. He stated on more than one occasion his desire to play for [[England national football team|England]], only provided that he did not receive a call-up from his nation of birth first.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3052410,00.html|title=Almunia eyes international call|publisher=Sky Sports|date=16 January 2008|accessdate=17 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2009/05/01/futbol/futbol_internacional/premier_league/1241191339.html|title=Wenger pide a Capello que cite a Almunia|trans_title=Wenger asks Capello to call Almunia|publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=1 May 2009|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref>

'''Benjamin Robert "Ben" Alnwick''' (born 1 January 1987) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].

Alnwick started his career at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in 2004, having progressed through the club's youth ranks, but never fully established himself in the first team. He left for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in January 2007, having made 19 league appearances, but never made more than a single league appearance for Tottenham. Instead, he spent several loan spells away from the club, at [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]], [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]], [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] and [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. He switched permanently to Barnsley in July 2012, and made 12 appearances, but was deemed surplus to requirements in September 2013, and his contract was terminated by mutual consent.

Alnwick has represented [[England national football team|England]] at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels, but has yet to represent the full international side.

==Club career==

===Sunderland===
Alnwick was born in the small [[Northumberland]] town of [[Prudhoe]]. He spent his boyhood years playing for the Prudhoe youth side. He started his professional career at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and came to prominence at the climax of their [[2004-05 in English football|2004–05]] [[Football League Championship]]-winning season, replacing the injured [[Thomas Myhre]] for Sunderland's last three games. His performances against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], the games that won [[Sunderland A.F.C|Sunderland]] promotion to the [[Premier League]] and Championship win respectively, were impressive. In November 2005, he spent a stint as the number one goalkeeper at Sunderland, replacing [[Kelvin Davis]]. Despite impressing, particularly in Sunderland's 3–2 defeat to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] where he made a penalty save from [[Robbie Keane]], Alnwick was dropped in favour of [[Kelvin Davis]]. After the departure of Davis to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], Alnwick was given the number 1 shirt for the [[2006-07 in English football|2006–07 season]].

After a disappointing start to the season 2006–07 season, Alnwick was relegated to the substitutes bench in favour of [[Darren Ward (goalkeeper)|Darren Ward]] by new boss [[Roy Keane]].

===Tottenham Hotspur===
Just two days after the January 2007 transfer window had opened, Alnwick joined Tottenham Hotspur for a fee of £900,000 in a deal that could rise to £1.3&nbsp;million and saw [[Márton Fülöp]] going the other way for £500,000.

====Loan moves====
In September 2007 he was loaned to [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] on a three-month loan deal.<ref name="Luton sign Tottenham goalkeeper">{{cite news
| title = Luton sign Tottenham goalkeeper
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/7016763.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 27 September 2007| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msIpMp80 |archivedate = 18 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> He was recalled from Luton in October, due to an injury to [[Paul Robinson (goalkeeper)|Paul Robinson]].<ref name="Spurs recall Alnwick from Luton">{{cite news
| title = Spurs recall Alnwick from Luton
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/t/tottenham_hotspur/7063539.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 26 October 2007| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msIpQUJc |archivedate = 18 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> However, on 7 January 2008, Alnwick joined [[Leicester City]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref name="Alnwick arrives">{{cite news
| title = Alnwick arrives
| url = http://www.lcfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~1208181,00.html
| publisher = Leicester City F.C.
| date = 7 January 2008}}</ref>
[[File:Penalty Alnwick.jpg|thumb|left|Alnwick fails to save a [[penalty kick]] in an [[M69 derby]] at the [[Ricoh Arena]]]]
Alnwick made his league debut in an [[M69 Derby]] on 12 January, keeping a [[clean sheet]] as Leicester won 2–0 at the [[Walkers Stadium]].<ref name="Leicester 2-0 Coventry">{{cite news
| title = Leicester 2–0 Coventry
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/7172833.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 12 January 2008| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msIouNfQ |archivedate = 18 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> He kept four [[clean sheet]]s in eight league games, conceding six goals before suffering a thigh injury as Leicester were relegated from the Championship.

On 16 October 2008, Alnwick joined League One side [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] on an initial one-month loan deal<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/carlisle_united/7673596.stm |title=Cumbrians seal Alnwick loan move |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=16 October 2008| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msIpZK4V | archivedate = 18 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> and was recalled by Tottenham after the one month loan ended to become another serious option for the first team goal-keeper position.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/t/tottenham_hotspur/7740460.stm |title=Spurs recall goalkeeper Alnwick |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=20 November 2008 |accessdate=20 November 2008 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5msIpcdMZ | archivedate = 18 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref>

====Return to Tottenham Hotspur====
Alnwick made his debut for Tottenham in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] semi-final second leg against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], which ended in a 3–2 loss, although Tottenham won 6–4 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7824257.stm |title=Burnley 3–2 Tottenham (agg 4–6) |author=Ian Hughes|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 January 2009|accessdate=22 January 2009 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqfk279r | archivedate = 17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref>

====Loan to Norwich City====
In July 2009, he signed on loan at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] for three months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/page/NewsDetails/0,,10355~1731618,00.html |title=Alnwick joins on loan |publisher=Norwich City F.C|date=24 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009 }}</ref> Alnwick made his debut in the 4–0 win over [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] and kept a clean sheet. He returned to Tottenham on 5 September after picking up a hip injury that was expected to keep him out for six weeks.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/page/NewsDetails/0,,10355~1787396,00.html |title=Lambert gears up for Walsall clash |publisher=Norwich City F.C|date=5 September 2009|accessdate=5 September 2009 }}</ref>

====Return to Tottenham====
His first [[Premier League]] game for Tottenham was at [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on the final day of the 2009-10 season, 9 May; he conceded four goals as Burnley won 4–2.

====More loan moves====
On 14 October 2010 Alnwick joined [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] on loan for 28 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20101015/premier-league-keeper-joins-on-loan_2247585_2185755 |title=News &#124; News &#124; News &#124; Premier League Keeper Joins On Loan |publisher=Leeds United |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/articles/leeds-loan-for-alnwick-151010.html |title=Latest News - News |publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> Alnwick was named on the bench against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] and [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20101016/boro-live_2247585_2185882 |title=News &#124; News &#124; News &#124; Becchio Seals Battling Win At Boro |publisher=Leeds United |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>

Alnwick moved to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on 4 March 2011 and stayed until 9 April 2011 after their goalkeeper [[Neil Sullivan]] became injured. He was an unused sub in games against Leeds United and [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]. Later in the year, he made eight appearances on loan for [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]].

===Barnsley===
On 4 July 2012, Alnwick moved to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on a two-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |title=Reds land Goalkeeper Alnwick |url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/news/article/reds-land-goalkeeper-alnwick-213724.aspx? |work=Barnsley F.C. |date=4 July 2012 |accessdate=4 July 2012}}</ref> Alnwick made his Barnsley début on 11 August 2012 in a League Cup tie away at Rochdale. With Barnsley leading 2-1 at 90 mins Alnwick conceded a penalty and was sent off. The penalty was subsequently scored moving the game into extra game. however Barnsley went on to win regardless.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19123950 |title=BBC Sport - Rochdale 3-4 Barnsley |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2012-08-11 |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> On 28 August 2012, he returned to action in the following league cup tie in a 3-1 away defeat to Swansea. Alnwick played his first Championship match of the season in a 1-0 victory over Bristol City on 1 September 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=37870 |title=Ben Alnwick &#124; Football Stats &#124; Barnsley &#124; Age 25 |publisher=Soccer Base |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> However, after the signings of [[Mike Pollitt]] and [[Christian Dibble]], Alnwick's contract was terminated by mutual consent on 2 September 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12040/8903563/transfer-deadline-day-barnsley-release-goalkeeper-ben-alnwick |title=Transfer deadline day: Barnsley release goalkeeper Ben Alnwick |publisher=BSkyB |work=Sky Sports |date=2 September 2013 |accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref>

===Charlton Athletic===
On 4 September 2013, Alnwick signed a one-year contract for [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/20130902-alnwick-commits-to-addicks-deal-1031807.aspx |title=Alnwick commits to Addicks deal |publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C. |date=4 September 2013 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> He made his debut in a game against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] after [[Ben Hamer]] was injured during the warm up. He managed to keep a clean sheet in a game that Charlton won 2-0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25093204 |title=Charlton Athletic 2-0 Doncaster Rovers |publisher=BBC |date=26 November 2013 |accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref>

===Leyton Orient===
On 31 January 2014, Alnwick joined [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. However, a week later, it was announced that Alnwick was suffering from unspecified medical problems, and was unable to train or play.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/sport-football/orient/personal_reasons_rule_out_orient_goalkeeper_ben_alnwick_1_3290472 |title=Personal reasons rule out Orient goalkeeper Ben Alnwick |publisher=Ilford Reporter |date=7 February 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2014 |first=Robin |last=Cottle}}</ref> On 24 March 2014, Alnwick left Leyton Orient by mutual consent after having his contract cancelled.<ref>{{Cite web |title=NEWS: Alnwick Leaves Club |url=http://www.leytonorient.com/news/article/alnwick-leaves-240314-1441089.aspx |work=Leyton Orient FC |date=24 March 2014}}</ref>

===Peterborough United===
On 25 July 2014, Alnwick signed a three-year deal at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28487510|title=Ben Alnwick: Peterborough United sign ex-Tottenham Hotspur keeper|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref>

==International career==
Alnwick received his first call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 squad]] ahead of the 15 August 2006 match against [[Moldova]].  Still awaiting his debut, Alnwick was named in [[Stuart Pearce]]'s first squad as England under-21 coach, alongside another uncapped goalkeeper, [[Joe Hart]]. He was not chosen to start the match, on 6 February 2007, against [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain]].

Alnwick was named in the first England U21 squad to play at the new Wembley against [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy U21s]] on 24 March 2007, but he remained an unused sub. He was also named in England's squad for the [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|U21 European Championships]] in the [[Netherlands]]. He debuted a year after his first call-up, in a friendly against [[Romania national under-21 football team|Romania]] at [[Ashton Gate Stadium|Ashton Gate]]. He came on for the second half as a substitute for [[Joe Hart]], and kept a [[clean sheet]].

==Personal life==
His younger brother [[Jak Alnwick|Jak]], who is also a goalkeeper, was at the Prudhoe local youth clubs and the Sunderland youth academy but joined North East rivals [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] as a first year scholar in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10278~1397343,00.html|title=Academy Boys Face Stoke Test|author=|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|date= 19 September 2008}}</ref> Jak won Newcastle's "Wor Jackie" award (named after legend Jackie Milburn) for best under-18 player in 2011.<ref name="2011awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20110308/nobby-scoops-top-gong_2281670_2310739 |title=Newcastle United &#124; News &#124; Latest News &#124; Latest News &#124; Nobby Scoops Top Gong |publisher=Nufc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>

Alnwick has been in an on-off relationship with his childhood sweetheart since 2007.<ref name="Factfile">{{cite web|url=http://archive.mehstg.com/fact_alnwick.htm |title=ben alnwick - fact file |publisher=Archive.mehstg.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>

'''Jak Alnwick''' (born 17 June 1993) is an English [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. He has also represented England at [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[england national under-18 football team|under-18]] levels.

==Club career==
===Newcastle United===

Alnwick joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] from [[Tyne–Wear derby|local rivals]] [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in 2008. He won the Wor [[Jackie Milburn|Jackie]] Award for the club's best youth player in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Dan|title=Jak Of All Trades|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20110308/jak-of-all-trades_2281670_2311095|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|accessdate=6 December 2014|date=8 March 2011}}</ref>

====Gateshead (loan)====

Alnwick was loaned to [[Conference Premier]] club [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] in September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gateshead sign Newcastle United goalkeeper Jak Alnwick|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/14838585|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 December 2014|date=8 September 2011}}</ref> He made a total of six league and three [[FA Cup]] appearances during his loan spell.

====Return to Newcastle United====

Alnwick signed a new two-year contract in July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marshall|first1=Anthony|title=New Deals For Young Stars|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20130704/new-deals-for-young-stars_2281670_3228091|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|accessdate=6 December 2014|date=4 July 2013}}</ref> He made his first appearance for Newcastle United as a half-time substitute for the injured [[Rob Elliot]] in a 2–1 [[Premier League]] home win over [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 6 December 2014 and made five saves. Prior to the win, Chelsea were unbeaten in all competitions from the start of the season.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Newcastle United 2–1 Chelsea|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/30257076|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 December 2014|date=6 December 2014}}</ref> A week later, in his first start, Newcastle lost 4–1 away to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnston|first1=Neil|title=Arsenal 4-1 Newcastle|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30357669|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=13 December 2014}}</ref> Alnwick made his first [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] appearance in the quarter-finals at [[Tottenham Hotspur]], and spilled a corner while under no pressure, which allowed [[Nabil Bentaleb]] to open the scoring in a 0&ndash;4 defeat.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jurejko|first1=Jonathan|title=Tottenham 4-0 Newcastle|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30407770|accessdate=26 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=17 December 2014}}</ref> In his first start at [[St James' Park]], Alnwick conceded in injury time from Sunderland's [[Adam Johnson (footballer)|Adam Johnson]] as Newcastle lost the [[Tyne-Wear derby]] on 21 December.<ref>{{cite news|title=Newcastle 0-1 Sunderland|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30467745|accessdate=26 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=21 December 2014}}</ref> He was dropped from the team altogether on 11 January 2015 when [[Tim Krul]] returned from injury for Newcastle's trip to Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reddy|first1=Luke|title=Chelsea 2-0 Newcastle|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30663822|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2015}}</ref>

====Bradford City (loan)====

Alnwick joined [[Football League One|League One]] club [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] on loan until the end of the 2014–15 season on 13 March 2015.<ref name=bradford>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31872777|title=Newcastle United keeper Jak Alnwick joins Bradford City on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 March 2015|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> The following day, he started away to [[Notts County]] in a 1&ndash;1 draw,<ref>{{cite news|title=Notts County 1-1 Bradford|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31776247|accessdate=27 March 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=14 March 2015}}</ref> but was cup-tied for their defeat by [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in an FA Cup sixth round replay on 16 March.<ref name=bradford/> In Bradford's next league game, a 2&ndash;2 home draw against [[Fleetwood Town]] five days after that, Alnwick was dropped to the bench as regular goalkeeper [[Ben Williams (footballer, born 1982)|Ben Williams]] returned.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bradford 2-2 Fleetwood|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31882615|accessdate=27 March 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=21 March 2015}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Alnwick was born in [[Hexham]] and is the younger brother of former [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] and [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] goalkeeper [[Ben Alnwick]].<ref name=nufcprofile/><ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news |first=Luke |last=Edwards |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/newcastle-united/11277386/Newcastle-v-Chelsea-Jak-Alnwick-faces-uncertain-future-despite-goalkeeping-heroics.html |title=Newcastle v Chelsea: Jak Alnwick faces uncertain future despite goalkeeping heroics |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=6 December 2014 }}</ref>

'''John Aloisi''' (born 5 February 1976) is a retired Australian [[association football|football (soccer)]] player and the former manager of A-League club [[Melbourne Heart FC|Melbourne Heart]]. In a professional career that spanned 20 seasons, with league totals of 459 games and 127 goals, he was the first Australian ever to play and score in [[La Liga]], the [[Premier League]] and [[Serie A]]. 

He returned to his country in 2007, with four seasons in the [[A-League]]. Aloisi was an integral member of the [[Australia national association football team|Australia national team]] for more than one decade, and represented the nation at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]], being an essential figure in [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (OFC)|the qualifying stages]].<ref name="WORLD CUP">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/4435400.stm Australia reach World Cup finals]; [[BBC Sport]], 16 November 2005</ref> He also appeared for the Socceroos in two [[FIFA Confederations Cup|Confederations Cups]]. Aloisi was described as a goal poacher who was able to "hold the ball up well and create opportunities for his teammates."<ref>{{cite web|title=Player Profiles|url=http://archive.is/kFN3V|publisher=Yahoo!7 Sport|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref> 

==Club career==
===Early years and England===
Born in [[Adelaide]], Aloisi arrived in Europe aged only 16, signing with [[Standard Liège]] from [[Adelaide City]]. He did not appear in any official games for the club, and also played sparingly for his next team, fellow [[Belgian Pro League|top division]] outfit [[Royal Antwerp FC]].

In November 1995, Aloisi moved countries and signed for Italian side [[US Cremonese]]. On the 25th, only two minutes after being on the pitch, he scored in a 2–1 home win against [[Calcio Padova]], becoming the youngest foreign player to ever score in a [[Serie A]] match.<ref>[http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1995/novembre/27/Dall_Australia_con_furore_John_co_0_9511275772.shtml Dall' Australia con furore: John Aloisi regala i primi 3 punti alla Cremonese (From Australia with furor: John Aloisi gives Cremonese first three points)]; [[Corriere della Sera]], 27 November 1995 {{it icon}}</ref> Ultimately, the [[Lombardy]] team suffered two consecutive relegations, and he left the club.

Aloisi arrived in [[Football in England|English football]] early in the 1997–98 season, signing for [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in the [[Football League First Division|Division One]], under the chairmanship of Australia national football team manager [[Terry Venables]]. He scored 12 goals in his first season in England as Pompey narrowly avoided relegation, bettering that total to 13 in the following campaign.

On 18 December 1998, Aloisi moved to the [[Premier League]] with [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]], who paid [[Pound sign|£]]650,000 for his services. He made his Sky Blues debut in a 1–1 home draw against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], appearing as a late [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]]; also coming from the bench, he netted in the next match, 1–1 against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].

Aloisi's next notable performance came almost 12 months later, in a historic 4–1 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at [[Villa Park]]. He scored twice in Coventry's first ever away victory in the league against their [[English Midlands|Midlands]] rivals. Starting in the next game, against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], he was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] for punching [[Danny Mills]], receiving a considerable ban; both Portsmouth and Coventry combined, he finished the season with 18 goals.

Aloisi never really got a proper run at Coventry during his spell, as the team was constantly threatened with relegation, which befell at the end of the [[2000–01 FA Premier League|2000–01 season]] after a 34-year top flight stay, with the player scoring just three times (he did net a [[hat-trick]] against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] for [[2000–01 Football League Cup|the season]]'s [[Football League Cup]] – 4–1 home win, 7–2 on aggregate<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/worthington_cup/943427.stm Coventry 4–1 Preston]; BBC Sport, 27 September 2000</ref>). In June, he was allowed to leave [[Highfield Road]], and came close to signing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]],<ref>[http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football-heroes/displayhero_club.asp?HeroID=38010 Coventry City biography]; at FootballHeroes</ref> but nothing came of it.

===Spain===
In 2001, Aloisi moved to Spain, joining [[Pamplona]]'s [[CA Osasuna]]. He scored nine goals in 30 games in [[2001–02 La Liga|his first season]] in [[La Liga]], being regularly used during his four-year spell in [[Navarre]]. On 11 April 2004, he played the full 90 minutes in a 3–0 away win against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=148966&cc=5739 Real Madrid 0–3 Osasuna]; [[ESPNsoccernet]], 11 April 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2004/apr/16/smalltalk.sportinterviews Small talk: John Aloisi]; [[The Guardian]], 16 April 2004</ref> and, on 11 June of the following year, he netted in the [[Copa del Rey]] [[2004–05 Copa del Rey|final]], equalising in an eventual 1–2 [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]] loss against [[Real Betis]].

After a move to [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] collapsed,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/p/portsmouth/4114874.stm Aloisi fails Panathinaikos test]; BBC Sport, 5 July 2005</ref> Aloisi signed for another Spanish outfit, [[Deportivo Alavés]], on a [[Free transfer (football)|free transfer]]. Even though he scored a career-best (in Spain) ten goals in [[2005–06 La Liga|2005–06]], the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] suffered top flight relegation.

===Return to Australia===
On 20 October 2007, it was announced that Aloisi had signed with the [[Central Coast Mariners FC]] for the remainder of the season.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=483269&root=global&cc=3436&lpos=spotlight&lid=tab2pos1 Aloisi's A-League adventure]; ESPNsoccernet, 19 November 2007</ref> The team was able to not include his wages in the [[salary cap]] due to a loop hole relating to injured players.<ref>[http://au.fourfourtwo.com/news/63393,aloisi-nows-the-right-time.aspx Aloisi: Now's the right time]; Australian FourFourTwo, 20 October 2007</ref> He made his debut in the [[A-League]] on the 28th against [[Sydney FC]], in a 2–3 defeat.<ref>[http://www.a-league.com.au/default.aspx?s=hal_newsdisplay&id=19933  Brosque double sinks Mariners]; A-League official website, 28 October 2007</ref>

On 3 March 2008, after failing to re-sign with the Mariners, Aloisi penned a two-year deal with [[Sydney FC]], for an undisclosed fee reported to be $1.4 million a season,<ref>[http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,23306722-5000940,00.html Sydney unveil new signings]; [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]], 3 March 2008</ref> making him the highest-paid player based in Australia in any of the four football codes. He made his debut as a second-half substitute against [[Perth Glory FC]] at the [[Sydney Football Stadium]], and scored his first goal for Sydney in a 2–0 upset win over archrivals [[Melbourne Victory FC]].

On 18 February 2009, 33-year old Aloisi was linked with a loan move to [[Shanghai Shenhua F.C.]] in China. He soon decided against the deal, opting instead to spend the entire pre-season with Sydney FC, under the club's new coach [[Vítězslav Lavička]].<ref>[http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,25105036-23210,00.html Aloisi wary of Chinese burn-out]; Fox Sports, 25 February 2009</ref> He scored twice in a friendly with the [[Newcastle United Jets FC]],<ref>[http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/a-league/aloisi-double-sinks-jets-204112 Aloisi double sinks Jets]; The World Game, 12 July 2009</ref> and eventually started repaying the faith the team had in him by scoring a double in a 3–2 win against [[North Queensland Fury FC]] in [[Townsville, Queensland|Townsville]], in the first game of [[2009–10 A-League|the season]]; he finished the campaign – winning both the minor and the major championships – as the first Sydney player ever to reach double digits in a single season.

On 29 March 2010, [[Melbourne Heart FC]] signed Aloisi on a free transfer.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/sport/soccer/heart-signs-john-aloisi-20100329-r6b5.html Heart signs John Aloisi]; The Age, 29 March 2010</ref> He impressed at the new club and scored eight goals, including three against rivals Melbourne Victory, both the first goal ever in a [[Melbourne derby]], and a brace which equalised the game at 2–2 after the Heart had been 2–0 down. On 12 February 2011, he played the final game of his career against former team Sydney FC, in the last round of the [[2010–11 A-League|A-League season]], scoring and being replaced by in the 83rd minute by [[Kristian Sarkies]], to a standing ovation from the home crowd.<ref>[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/soccer/john-aloisi-on-target-in-melbourne-heart-farewell/story-e6frfg8x-1226005077979 John Aloisi on target in Melbourne Heart farewell]; [[Herald Sun]], 12 February 2011</ref>

==International career==
[[Image:Aloisi penalty - The Moment.JPG|thumb|right|270px|Aloisi taking the penalty that secured the victory over Uruguay and Australia's place in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]].]]
Aloisi made his debut for the [[Australia national association football team|Australian national team]] in 1997. Also [[1997 FIFA Confederations Cup|in that year]], he was selected to the [[FIFA Confederations Cup]], scoring in a 3–1 group stage win against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] for the eventual runners-up.

After representing Australia at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] as one of the three overage players, scoring three goals in an eventual [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|quarterfinal exit]],<ref>{{FIFA player|154050}}</ref> Aloisi finished second in the scoring charts at the [[2005 FIFA Confederations Cup|2005 Confederations Cup]], netting braces against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] as the Socceroos did not manage one single point in three games.
 
On 16 November 2005, Aloisi scored the decisive [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty]] against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL – OFC play-off)|playoffs]], after a 1–1 aggregate tie. That goal meant Australia qualified to the [[FIFA World Cup]] for the first time since 1974.<ref name="WORLD CUP"/> He was selected in the squad for the final stages in Germany and, on 12 June, came off the bench to score the third goal in a 3–1 group stage victory against [[Japan national football team|Japan]], thus becoming only the second Australian in history to score a goal at the World Cup finals, after teammate [[Tim Cahill]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4852706.stm Australia 3–1 Japan]; BBC Sport, 12 June 2006</ref>

On 21 July 2007, Aloisi scored in the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]]'s quarterfinal match against Japan (1–1), in an eventual penalty shootout exit in Australia's first ever participation in [[AFC Asian Cup|that tournament]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/6910021.stm Japan and Iraq reach semi-finals]; BBC Sport, 21 July 2007</ref> It would be the last of his 27 international goals, second-best behind [[Damian Mori]] at the time of his retirement.

After his return to the A-League, Aloisi ceased to be recalled by the national team. In early 2008, his penalty kick against Uruguay which took the Socceroos to the 2006 World Cup was voted by the Sport Australia Hall of Fame as one of three greatest moments in [[Sport in Australia|Australian sporting]] history.<ref>[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/aloisis-shot-of-confidence/story-e6frf9if-1111115456686 John Aloisi's shot of confidence]; Herald Sun, 2 February 2008</ref>

==Coaching career==
After retiring, Aloisi started his coaching career, being appointed youth manager at Melbourne Heart.<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sport/john-aloisi-and-josip-skoko-look-to-coaching-after-ending-careers-as-senior-players/story-fn63e0vj-1226005406060 John Aloisi and Josip Skoko look to coaching after ending careers as senior players]; [[The Australian]], 14 February 2011</ref> On 8 May 2012, it was announced that he had accepted a three-year contract to be the manager of [[Melbourne Heart FC|Melbourne Heart]].<ref>http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/news/1104757/Heart-plumps-for-Aloisi</ref> On 5 October 2012, he got his first win as manager as [[Melbourne Heart FC|Melbourne Heart]] beat [[Melbourne derby|rivals]] [[Melbourne Victory FC|Melbourne Victory]] 2–1. Aloisi struggled in his first season as head coach, with Melbourne Heart coming ninth in the 2012–13 season and winning only one away game all season. The 2013-14 season did not start any better with the Heart managing 0 wins, 4 draws and 6 losses from 10 starts.  On 28 December 2013, Aloisi was sacked as the manager of Melbourne Heart following the club's seventeenth competitive match without a win.

On 9 February 2015, Aloisi joined [[Melbourne Victory FC]] as the development coach of its National Youth League and National Premier League sides.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.melbournevictory.com.au/article/melbourne-victory-appoints-john-aloisi-to-new-role/1kj46sx2irl4v1h0sfp13vmf1p |title= Melbourne Victory appoints John Aloisi to new role |publisher= [[Melbourne Victory FC]] |date= 9 February 2015 |accessdate= 9 February 2015}}
</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.fourfourtwo.com/au/news/aloisi-joins-melbourne-victory-youth-coach |title= Aloisi joins Melbourne Victory as youth coach |work= [[FourFourTwo]] |date= 9 February 2015 |accessdate= 9 February 2015}}
</ref>

==Personal==
Aloisi's older brother [[Ross Aloisi|Ross]], was also a professional footballer. Aloisi appeared on the cover of the Australian version of [[Pro Evolution Soccer 6]].

| years4 = 2013– | clubs4 = [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] | caps4 = 22 | goals4 = 0
| years5 = 2014  | clubs5 = → [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] (loan) | caps5 = 16 | goals5 = 0<!--LEAGUE APPS & GOALS ONLY -->

'''Marcos Alonso Mendoza''' (born 28 December 1990) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for Italian club [[ACF Fiorentina]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left back]] or [[midfielder]].

He started his career with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], going on to represent [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in England, where he amassed [[Premier League]] totals of nine games and one goal over the course of two seasons, spending three in total with the club.

==Football career==
===Real Madrid===
Born in [[Madrid]], Alonso joined [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]'s youth academy still an infant, going on to represent every youth side in the following years. In 2008 he reached [[Real Madrid Castilla]] which competed in [[Segunda División B]], and first appeared for the [[reserve team]] on 22 February 2009, playing the entire game in a 0–1 home loss against [[AD Alcorcón]].<ref>[http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/es/1202762847844/noticia/Cronica/0-1:_Castigo_excesivo.htm 0–1: Castigo excesivo (0–1: Excessive punishment)]; Real Madrid's official website, 22 February 2010 {{es icon}}</ref>

On 11 December 2009 Alonso was first summoned by the main squad – coached by [[Manuel Pellegrini]] – for a [[La Liga]] match at [[Valencia CF]]; eventually, he did not make the final list of 18, and his debut arrived on 4 April of the following year as he came on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Gonzalo Higuaín]] in the 90th minute of a 2–0 win at [[Racing de Santander]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/275589?cc=5739|title=Ronaldo and Higuain on target|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=4 April 2010|accessdate=22 September 2011}}</ref>

===Bolton Wanderers===
Alonso joined [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] of the [[Premier League]] for an undisclosed fee, on 27 July 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/8859038.stm|title=Bolton sign Real Madrid defender Marco Alonso|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=27 July 2010|accessdate=27 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=810408&sec=transfers&cc=5739&campaign=rss&source=soccernet|title=Bolton complete deal for Marcos Alonso from Real|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=27 July 2010|accessdate=27 July 2010}}</ref> He made his competitive debut for the club in a [[Football League Cup]] [[2010–11 Football League Cup|1–0 away win]] against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 24 August;<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8936599.stm Southampton 0–1 Bolton]; BBC Sport, 24 August 2010</ref> his first league appearance arrived on 1 January 2011, starting for suspended [[Paul Robinson (footballer born December 1978)|Paul Robinson]] in a 1–2 away loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9327929.stm Liverpool 2–1 Bolton]; BBC Sport, 1 January 2011</ref> 

Alonso scored his first goal for Bolton on 31 March 2012, netting the second in an eventual 3–2 success at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17497418|title=Wolves 2–3 Bolton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 March 2012|accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref> At the end of the [[2012–13 Football League Championship|2012–13 season]] he was voted [[The Bolton News]]' player of the year, winning 37% of the vote: Marc Iles wrote, "''...this has been a break-out season for the former Real Madrid starlet. Alonso has grown in stature and become a consistent performer at full-back – chipping in with some important goals too.''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/wanderers/wanderersnews/10383450.VOTE_NOW_for_your_Bolton_Wanderers_player_of_the_season/|title=Vote now for your Bolton Wanderers player of the season|publisher=[[The Bolton News]]|author=Marc Iles|date=29 April 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> In the matchday programme of the match between Bolton Wanderers and Wigan Athletic, Bolton and former Liverpool midfielder Jay Spearing included Alonso in his best ever XI he had played with.

===Fiorentina===
In May 2013, Alonso signed for Italian side [[ACF Fiorentina]] on a three-year deal, despite being offered a new contract by Bolton manager [[Dougie Freedman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22735124|title=Marcos Alonso: Fiorentina sign Bolton's out-of -contract-full-back|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 May 2013|accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> On 30 December, after the player had made nine official appearances, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] boss [[Gus Poyet]] announced that he would join on 1 January 2014, on loan until the end of [[2013–14 Premier League|the campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25552668|title=Sunderland: Fiorentina's Marcos Alonso joins on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 December 2013|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref>

Alonso played his first game with the ''Black Cats'' on 7 January 2014, featuring the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 home win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] for [[2013–14 Football League Cup|the League Cup semifinals' first leg]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25556245|title=Sunderland 2–1 Man Utd|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 January 2014|accessdate=8 January 2014}}</ref> and being given the ''[[Man of the match]]'' award by [[Sky Sports]]. He appeared in [[2014 Football League Cup Final|the final of the competition]] on 2 March, not being able to prevent a 1–3 loss against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]];<ref name="LC">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26311649|title=Man City 3–1 Sunderland|publisher=BBC Sport|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|date=2 March 2014|accessdate=14 June 2014}}</ref> overall he contributed with 20 appearances all competitions comprised, helping his team [[2013–14 Premier League|retain its top flight status]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcos-alonso.com/sunderland-stay-in-premier-league/|title=Sunderland stay in Premier League|publisher=Official website|date=8 May 2014|accessdate=14 June 2014}}</ref>

==Personal==
Alonso's [[Grandparent|grandfather]], [[Marcos Alonso Imaz]], played eight years with Real Madrid's first team. His father, [[Marcos Alonso Peña]], played several seasons in Spain's top flight, most notably for [[Atlético Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona]], and both represented [[Spain national football team|Spain]] at senior level.<ref>[http://segundab.futboldecantabria.com/noticia/marcos-alonso-mi-sueno-es-dar-el-salto-al-primer-equipo-del-real-madrid-398.html Marcos Alonso: "Mi sueño es dar el salto al primer equipo del Real Madrid" (Marcos Alonso: "I dream of playing for Real Madrid's first team")]; Fútbol de Cantabria, 8 September 2009 {{es icon}}</ref>

On 2 May 2011, Alonso was arrested following his involvement in a [[Traffic collision|car accident]] in Madrid. He was the driver of a car that collided with a wall, killing one of the passengers, a 20-year-old woman.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/05/02/futbol/equipos/real_madrid/1304342009.html|title=Detenido el jugador del Bolton Marcos Alonso tras un accidente en el que ha muerto una joven|trans_title=Bolton's Marcos Alonso arrested after accident in which young woman dies|publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=2 May 2011|accessdate=2 May 2011}}</ref> He is alleged to have been over the legal alcohol limit for driving.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/may/03/bolton-marcos-alonso-car-accident|title=Bolton's Marcos Alonso in court over fatal car accident in Madrid|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=2 May 2011|accessdate=2 May 2011}}</ref>

{{Spanish name|Alonso|Olano}}
'''Mikel Alonso Olano''' (born 16 May 1980) is a Spanish [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Real Unión]] as a [[midfielder]].

==Football career==
===Real Sociedad===
A product of [[Real Sociedad]]'s youth ranks, as younger brother [[Xabi Alonso|Xabi]], Alonso was born in [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]], [[Gipuzkoa]], and made his debut in [[La Liga]] on 22 April 2001 against [[Real Valladolid]]. However, the presence of his sibling and [[Mikel Aranburu]] in central midfield meant that he was restricted to a supporting role, and he was then sent on loan to [[Segunda División]]'s [[CD Numancia]] for [[2003–04 Segunda División|2003–04]] but, while he was dedicated to the [[Soria]] team's bid for promotion, he remained keen to establish himself at Real Sociedad, returning at the end of the season;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noticias.info/archivo/2004/200401/20040116/20040116_17275.shtm|title=Mikel Alonso: "A la Real y a mí nos interesa que juegue cada Domingo"|trans_title=Mikel Alonso: "Real and myself are interested in me playing every Sunday"|publisher=Noticias|language=Spanish|date=16 January 2004|accessdate=13 December 2008}}</ref> under the management of [[José Mari Bakero]], the player's importance to the team was demonstrated in the [[2005–06 La Liga|2005–06 campaign]], when he was the club's most used footballer playing in 37 games.

After brother Xabi had already settled in England with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] (having arrived during the summer of 2004), Alonso also decided to move to the [[Premier League]]. He joined [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], another team in [[North West England|north-west England]], on a loan deal on 10 July 2007 with the option of a permanent deal at the end of [[2007–08 Premier League|the season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/6290040.stm|title=Alonso joins Bolton from Sociedad|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=10 July 2007|accessdate=10 July 2007}}</ref> However, after manager [[Sammy Lee (footballer)|Sammy Lee]] was dismissed he fell out of favour and, under new coach [[Gary Megson]], he only made two first-team appearances; subsequently, the Trotters opted to not extend his contract.

Alonso went back to Spain for [[2008–09 Segunda División|2008–09]] but, upon his return to the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], discovered he was not a part of coach [[Juan Manuel Lillo]]'s plans and was sent on trial to [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos FC]]. This proved unsuccessful, however, and Real Sociedad exercised their right to buy the remainder of his contract, releasing him as a [[free agent]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundodeportivo.es/web/gen/20080903/noticia_53530989163.html|title=El club presentará mañana el ERE con Alonso y Stevanovic|trans_title=The club will release Alonso and Stefanovic tomorrow under ERE legislation|publisher=[[El Mundo Deportivo (newspaper)|El Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=3 September 2008|accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref>

===Tenerife===
Following his release from Real Sociedad, [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] boss [[Roberto Martínez]] offered countryman Alonso a chance to regain fitness.<ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/football-news/2008/12/11/alonso-enjoying-his-swansea-city-stint-91466-22451036/ Alonso enjoying his Swansea City stint]; The Western Mail, 11 December 2008</ref> After his brother highly recommended both coach and the player to arrange the deal, he accepted the offer and joined the squad in training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/swansea-city-fc/2008/12/14/alonso-my-brother-xabi-told-me-to-link-up-with-swans-91466-22470921/|title=Alonso: My brother Xabi told me to link up with Swans|publisher=Wales on Sunday|date=14 December 2008|accessdate=15 December 2008}}</ref>

However, Alonso would not remain in [[Wales]] and, in late January 2009, moved to second level outfit [[CD Tenerife]], after being contacted regarding a [[2008–09 Segunda División|season]]-long contract.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2009/01/28/futbol/equipos/tenerife/1233166726.html El Tenerife confirma el fichaje de Mikel Alonso (Tenerife confirms Mikel Alonso's signing)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 28 January 2009 {{es icon}}</ref> He accepted the offer and stated that he had "heard good things" about Tenerife. However, he remained a fan of his former club Real Sociedad, stating that, although the team were rivals to Tenerife, he hoped they gained promotion;<ref>[http://www.as.com/futbol/articulo/mikel-alonso-tenia-varias-opciones/dasftb/20090129dasdasftb_29/Tes Mikel Alonso: "Tenía varias opciones y Tenerife me pareció la más atractiva" (Mikel Alonso: "I had several options and Tenerife seemed the right choice")]; [[Diario AS]], 29 January 2009 {{es icon}}</ref> he contributed with 11 matches as the [[Canary Islands]] side returned to the top flight after a seven-year absence.

In the [[2009–10 La Liga|2009–10 campaign]] Alonso began as a starter, scoring with a rare header in the second matchday, a 1–0 home win against [[Athletic Bilbao]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=275693&cc=5739|title=Athletic Bilbao lose 100% record|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=23 September 2009|accessdate=11 May 2011}}</ref> However, he appeared less regularly in the final stretch, as Tenerife were eventually relegated back.

===Charlton===
In late June 2011, following [[2010–11 Segunda División|another Tenerife relegation]], 31-year-old Alonso returned to England, joining [[Football League One]] team [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10267~2379946,00.html|title=Mikel makes three|publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C|date=21 June 2011|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> He made his official debut on 5 October in the [[Football League Trophy]] tie at [[The Valley (London)|The Valley]] against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], conceding a [[Penalty kick|penalty]] in an eventual 0–3 home loss.

Alonso was released at the end of [[2011–12 Football League One|the season]], without making any appearances in any of the three major competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10267~2767632,00.html|title=Euell and Doherty head released list|publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C|date=10 May 2012|accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>

===Real Unión===
On 14 July 2014, after nearly two years without a club, Alonso signed for [[Real Unión]] in [[Segunda División B]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realunionclub.com/hnot014.aspx?244,Primer+equipo,%27Silas%27+y+Alonso+se+suman+a+la+plantilla|title='Silas' y Alonso se suman a la plantilla|trans_title='Silas' and Alonso added to roster|publisher=Real Unión|language=Spanish|date=14 July 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
The first son of [[Miguel Ángel Alonso|Periko Alonso]], who played with Real Sociedad and [[FC Barcelona]], Alonso grew up surrounded by football: he and his younger brother, [[Xabi Alonso|Xabi]] – who also appeared for Real Sociedad before representing with individual and team success [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] – would go training with their father when he was playing for [[CE Sabadell FC]]; all three were midfielders.

Influenced by his father, Alonso followed his example and became a professional footballer at the [[San Sebastián]] side.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/dads-and-lads-periko-and-xabi-alonso|title=Dads and lads: Periko and Xabi Alonso|publisher=Liverpool F.C|last=Balague|first=Guillem|date=18 May 2008|accessdate=12 October 2014}}</ref>
