'''Xabier "Xabi" Alonso Olano''' ({{IPA-eu|ˈʃaβi aˈlons̺o oˈlano|lang}}, {{IPA-es|ˈ(t)ʃaβj aˈlonso oˈlano|lang}}; born 25 November 1981) is a Spanish [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for German club [[FC Bayern Munich]] as a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]].

Alonso began his career at [[Real Sociedad]], the main team of his home province [[Gipuzkoa]]. After a brief loan period at [[SD Eibar]], he returned to Sociedad where then-manager [[John Toshack]] appointed Alonso as his [[Captain (association football)|team captain]]. Alonso succeeded in the role, taking Real Sociedad to second place in the [[2002–03 La Liga|2002–03 season]]. He moved to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in August 2004 for [[Pound sterling|£]]10.5 million. He won the [[UEFA Champions League]] in his first season at the club, scoring the equalising goal in the [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|Final]] against [[A.C. Milan]]. The following season, he won the [[FA Cup]] and the [[FA Community Shield]]. He moved to [[Real Madrid]] for the start of the [[2009–10 La Liga|2009–10 season]] in a deal worth around £30 million. After five seasons at the club, winning honours including a league title in 2012 and the Champions League in 2014, he was signed by Bayern Munich on a two-year contract.

He made his international debut for [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in April 2003 in a 4–0 victory against [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]]. While playing for Spain, Alonso has won [[UEFA Euro 2008|Euro 2008]],  [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]] and the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]], and he has also represented his country at [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]] and the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]]. On 23 June 2012, Alonso won his 100th cap for Spain in the quarter-final of Euro 2012 against [[France national football team|France]]: he celebrated the occasion by scoring both of Spain's goals to send them into the semi-finals. Following Spain's failure to progress out of the group stages at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]], Alonso retired from international football on 27 August 2014. His 114 caps make him the fifth most capped player in the nation's history.

==Early years==
Alonso was born into a family known for its footballing prowess. His father, [[Miguel Ángel Alonso|Periko Alonso]], won [[La Liga]] twice in successive seasons with [[Real Sociedad]] and a third time after he moved to [[FC Barcelona]]. He also featured in the national team, winning 21 caps over the course of his career.<ref name=GB1/> Xabi Alonso was born in the small town of [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]], [[Gipuzkoa]], [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]]. Alonso lived in [[Barcelona]] for the first six years of his life and moved to [[San Sebastián|San Sebastián (Donostia)]] thereafter. It was here that his passion for football began as he whiled away his childhood playing at ''Playa de la Concha'' (Shell Beach).<ref name=GB1>{{cite web |last=Ballague |first=Guillem |title=Clever Xabi sets the pass mark |publisher=''[[The Observer]]'' |date=22 May 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/may/22/sport.comment |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> On the Basque sands, Alonso befriended a fellow resident of Calle Matia, [[Mikel Arteta]], and the two would battle each other in exhibitions of technical ability.<ref name=FieldBB>{{cite web |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Arteta seeks revenge in battle of Basques |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=25 March 2006 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2006/mar/25/newsstory.sport15 |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> He was immersed in football and his father would often bring him and his older brother, [[Mikel Alonso|Mikel]], to [[CE Sabadell FC|CE Sabadell]]'s training ground to practice together. Alonso was influenced by his father's playing, taking more pleasure in passing the ball well than shooting at goal.<ref name=GB0>{{cite web |last=Balague |first=Guillem |title=Dads and Lads: Periko and Xabi Alonso |publisher=Liverpool|date=18 May 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/drilldown/N159927080518-0840.htm |accessdate=15 August 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080701220709/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/drilldown/N159927080518-0840.htm |archivedate = 1 July 2008}}</ref> At an early age, he decided to play as a [[defensive midfielder]], a role which helped him learn how to distribute the ball well. This talent would later prove to be an integral part of his club and international career.<ref name=GB1/>

At the age of 15, Alonso went to the Irish town of [[Kells, County Meath]], on a school exchange programme to learn English.<ref>{{cite news |title=Royal help for Alonso |url=http://www.eleven-a-side.com/offthefield/irish_soccer_detail.asp?newsid=17468 |work=eleven-a-side.com |publisher=Lynn Group |date=25 May 2005 |accessdate=17 May 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2014}}</ref><ref name="gaaboard">{{cite web |url=http://gaaboard.com/board/index.php?topic=6122.15|title=Reprint of aforementioned article on messageboard|publisher=GAA Board|date=3 January 2008|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Alonso learned a few tricks in Kells, Co Meath. |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/FOOTBALL%3A+Alonso+learned+a+few+tricks+in+Kells,+Co+Meath.-a0138605756 |work=''Daily Mirror'' |first=Michael |last=Scully |publisher=The Free Library |date=25 May 2005 |accessdate=29 July 2014 }}</ref> There, he helped the local Kells junior football team to win an All Ireland Junior club title in Keating Park, Chairsiveen.{{fact|date=March 2015}}

Alonso and Arteta were ambitious and dreamed of playing alongside each other for Real Sociedad when they were older. Though they attended different schools, the two young players joined forces at the local youth side [[Antiguoko]], playing games at the weekend. Their performances attracted the attention of scouts from top Spanish sides and the young ''[[Donostia]]rras'' separated ways, ending nine years of friendly rivalry, as Alonso went to [[Real Sociedad]] and Arteta moved to [[Catalonia|Catalan]] giants Barcelona.<ref name=HunterSS>{{cite news |last=Hunter |first=Andy |title=Mikel Arteta: 'It's a long way from San Sebastian...' |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=19 November 2005 |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/mikel-arteta-its-a-long-way-from-san-sebastian-515944.html |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso's move to Real Sociedad, however, was not a companionless one as he was joined by his older brother [[Mikel Alonso|Mikel]], who had also become an adept player.<ref name=GB1/>

Alonso progressed through the youth ranks and the [[reserve team]] at Real Sociedad and impressed enough to earn a first team debut at the age of 18.<ref name=GB0/> He made his first senior appearance against [[CD Logroñés]] in December 1999 in a [[Copa del Rey]] match.<ref name=LFCProfile>{{cite web |title=Xabi Alonso Profile |publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/team/squad/alonso/ |accessdate=11 August 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080804215916/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/team/squad/alonso/ |archivedate = 4 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso failed to make another appearance in the season but the following year brought more opportunities. At the beginning of the [[2000–01 La Liga|2000–01 season]], [[Javier Clemente]] sent Alonso to [[Segunda División]] team [[SD Eibar]] to gain experience. Alonso's father particularly felt the move to the smaller club improved him as a player.<ref name=GB0/> A quick turnover of managers, however, including a two-month period with Periko Alonso in charge, left Real Sociedad in a dire situation. By January 2001, Real Sociedad were bottom of the league and the new manager, [[John Toshack]], turned to the prodigious Alonso in the hope of reversing the team's fortunes. In a surprise move, the Welsh manager made 20-year-old Alonso the team [[Captain (association football)|captain]], a position traditionally held by more senior players.<ref name=GB1/> By the end of the season, Sociedad had climbed out of the [[Relegation#Structure|relegation zone]] and finished in 14th place.<ref>{{cite web |last=Andrados |first=Juan Pedro |title=Primera División 2000/01 |publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] |date=10 November 2001 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/span01.html |accessdate=12 August 2008| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mr6Wak4s | archivedate = 17 January 2010| deadurl=no}}</ref> Toshack lauded Alonso, noting that the impression he had on the team was exceptional, especially for a player from the youth team.<ref name=GB1/>

==Club career==
===Real Sociedad===
Under the tutelage of [[John Toshack]], Alonso's captaincy marked a resurgence of form for [[Real Sociedad]]. Toshack recognised Alonso's potential and invested much time in his young captain, creating a training method designed to improve his touch and control specifically for him.<ref>{{cite web |last=Abbandonato |first=Paul |title=It's the Real deal for Toshack |publisher=Wales Online (''[[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]]'') |date=3 July 2008 |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/football-in-wales/2008/07/03/it-s-the-real-deal-for-toshack-91466-21218919/  |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> The team cemented their mid-table position in the [[2001–02 La Liga|2001–02]], finishing in 13th place. Alonso appeared consistently in [[La Liga]] with 30 appearances over the course of the season and also scored his first league goal, finishing with a season total of three. Real Sociedad's management changed again in the summer of 2002, with the arrival of [[Raynald Denoueix]] but Alonso kept his place in the first team on the strength of his past performance.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lowe |first=Sid |title=Sociedad enjoy ride of their lives |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=4 November 2002 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2002/nov/04/europeanfootball.sport |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref>

The [[2002–03 La Liga|2002–03 season]] was the club's best league performance since the [[1981–82 La Liga|1981–82 season]], in which they won the league. The Basque team finished second, two points behind [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Real seal Spanish title |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/3007132.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=22 June 2003 |accessdate=23 June 2012 }}</ref> setting a club record for their highest ever points total, and qualifying for the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time.<ref>{{cite news |title=Champions League Soccer : Juventus and Real Sociedad show mettle |first=Rob |last=Hughes |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/02/sports/02iht-soccer_ed3_.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |date=2 October 2003 |accessdate=23 June 2012 }}</ref> Alonso received much praise for his role in the team's success, and was given the Best Spanish Player award by Spanish sports magazine ''[[Don Balón]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Diaz |first=Emilio Pla |title=Spain&nbsp;– Footballer of the Year |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date=28 January 2004 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/spanpoy.html |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> In addition, Alonso significantly contributed to the team's goal tally, scoring 12 goals in all competitions.<ref name=Sinnott>{{cite news |last=Sinnott |first=John |title=Alonso the pass master |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/3552474.stm |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> His performances earned Alonso national repute and [[Iñaki Sáez]], the coach of the Spanish national team, called him up for ''[[La Selección]]''. Alonso made his international debut in April 2003 in a 4–0 [[Exhibition game|friendly]] win over [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]].<ref name=FDB>{{cite web |title=Xabi Alonso Profile |publisher=Football Database |url=http://footballdatabase.com/index.php?page=player&Id=550&pn=Xabier_Alonso_Olona |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20101215152525/http://footballdatabase.com/index.php?page=player&Id=550&pn=Xabier_Alonso_Olona |archivedate=15 December 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> Sáez raved over Alonso, saying, "He has a fantastic range of accurate passing [and] sees football with an extraordinary clarity."<ref name=GB1/>

The [[2003–04 La Liga|2003–04 season]] comprised mixed results for Alonso and his [[San Sebastián]] club. Alonso revelled in the opportunity to perform in Europe, appearing in all the team's games, and Real Sociedad qualified for the [[Single-elimination tournament|knockout phase]] of the Champions League. The team struggled under the pressure of the extra matches, however, and were promptly knocked out of the tournament by [[Olympique Lyonnais]] and finished 15th in La Liga.<ref name=Sinnott/> The combination of Alonso's outstanding performances and the team's poor league finish made a move away from [[Estadio Anoeta]] inevitable. Despite interest from La Liga champions Real Madrid, Alonso remained committed to Real Sociedad.<ref name=GB1/> Madrid failed to meet the [[Pound sterling|£]]13 million price tag that [[José Luis Astiazarán]], the Real Sociedad President, had placed on Alonso and the deal reached a stalemate.<ref name=Sinnott/> Alonso had other concerns and focused on international duty with Spain at the [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]] tournament.<ref name=FDB/> Despite the fact that Alonso's appearance at the tournament was brief, he caught the attention of retired footballer [[Jan Mølby]], who was impressed with his precise passing abilities.<ref name=GB1/>

The summer [[transfer window]] at Real Sociedad saw the arrival of Alonso's childhood friend [[Mikel Arteta]].<ref name=Drop>{{cite news |title=Real Sociedad drop Alonso |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/3552128.stm |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> Arteta was ecstatic at the prospect of partnering Alonso in midfield but his excitement was short lived.<ref name=FieldBB/> Alonso was not picked for Real Sociedad's pre-season friendlies, signalling that an offer by [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] was being treated seriously.<ref name=Drop/> The Basque side announced on 20 August 2004 that they had made a deal worth £10.7 million with Liverpool and Alonso had agreed terms with the [[Merseyside]] team.<ref name=LFCProfile/><ref name=AnfieldMove>{{cite news |title=Alonso makes Anfield move |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/3569648.stm |accessdate=12 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso did not lament the fact that a move to Real Madrid had not materialised. Instead, he concentrated on integrating with the new Spanish contingent at Liverpool under the guidance of former [[Valencia CF]] manager [[Rafael Benítez]].<ref name=GB1/>

===Liverpool===
====2004–05: Champions League victory====
Alonso arrived at Liverpool along with [[Luis García Sanz|Luis García]] from [[FC Barcelona]], marking the beginning of a new era at [[Anfield]]. Liverpool's new coach, [[Rafael Benítez]], sought to revolutionise the club and completely overhauled the squad, impressing his own management style and tactics upon the team.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ortego |first=Enrique |title=La 'Rafalution' entra en la historia del Liverpool (''The 'Rafalution' becomes part of Liverpool history'') |publisher=''[[Diario AS]]'' |date=3 November 2008 |url=http://www.as.com/futbol/articulo/futbol-rafalution-entra-historia-liverpool/dasftb/20081103dasdaiftb_31/Tes |accessdate=18 November 2008}}</ref> The technical Spaniards were Benítez's first signings and he remarked that their emphasis of skill over strength offered the team something different.<ref name=AnfieldMove/><ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool grab Garcia |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/3582406.stm |accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso made his [[Premier League]] debut for the [[Merseyside]]rs against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] at the [[Reebok Stadium]] on 29 August 2004.<ref name=LFCProfile/> Liverpool lost the fixture 1–0 but Alonso was already receiving praise for his passing skills from the press.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bolton 1–0 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3586112.stm |accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref> A [[2003-04 FA Premier League|Premier League]] tie against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] displayed more of Alonso's talents. Liverpool were losing 2–0 at [[half-time]] and Benítez brought on Alonso as a [[substitute (football)|substitute]] after the break. He revived a deflated Liverpool and the game finished 4–2 to the Merseyside team.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cox |first=Gerry |title=Alonso inspires a change of fortune |publisher=''[[The Observer]]'' |date=17 October 2004|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2004/oct/17/match.sport11 |accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref> Furthermore, Alonso scored his first [[Goal (sport)|goal]] for the team from a [[Direct free kick|free kick]] to bring Liverpool ahead of the opposition.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 2–4 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 October 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/3724106.stm  |accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref>

[[File:Xabi Alonso.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Alonso playing against [[The New Saints F.C.|The New Saints]] in the Champions League in July 2005.]]

Alonso continued to provide important goals for the club, scoring his first goal at Anfield against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 2–1 Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 November 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4028103.stm |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso was elated at the achievement and felt he was settling in well in England.<ref>{{cite video |people=Xabi Alonso |date=3 December 2004 |title=Alonso happy to be at Anfield |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/sol/newsid_4060000/newsid_4062700/4062717.stm?bw=bb&mp=wm&news=1&bbcws=1# |format=Windows Media Player/Real Video |medium=Video |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=15 August 2008 |time=0.05mins/2.00mins |quote=I think I'm settling quickly no? You know you come to a different country with a different culture but you have to accept all this"/"It was exciting to score at Anfield. I was looking for it and I felt great when I did, in a big game as well }}</ref> The Arsenal game marked the return of [[Steven Gerrard]] from injury but Alonso's midfield partnership with the [[Captain (association football)|team captain]] came to a halt when Alonso suffered his first setback at Liverpool. Alonso's ankle was broken following a tackle from [[Frank Lampard]] in Liverpool's 1–0 defeat against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on New Year's Day 2005 and the Spaniard was ruled out of action for three months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 0–1 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4114653.stm |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Alonso sidelined for three months |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 January 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/4139747.stm |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref>

He made his return to the first team in the second leg of the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] quarter final against [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]. Alonso was not at full fitness but, as Steven Gerrard was injured, he played for the full 90 minutes and Liverpool held the score at 0–0 in Italy, defeating the eventual Italian Champions on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news |title=Juventus 0–0 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 April 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4431795.stm |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref> Kevin McCarra of ''[[The Guardian]]'' paid testament to Alonso's skill and dedication to the game, saying: "This marvellously accomplished footballer testified in the [[Stadio delle Alpi]] that technique can overcome a serious physical disadvantage".<ref>{{cite web |last=McCarra |first=Kevin |title=Liverpool set up Chelsea clash |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=14 April 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/apr/14/match.sport1 |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref> In the next round against Chelsea, Alonso received a [[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow card]] in a tense and scrappy 0–0 draw at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], making him suspended for the following fixture.<ref>{{cite web |last=McCarra |first=Kevin |title=Red resistance tips the balance |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=28 April 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/apr/28/match.sport1 |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso was distraught that he would miss the game and vehemently contested the referee's decision to no avail.<ref name=Sublime>{{cite news |last=Shaw |first=Phil |title=Alonso adds touch of the sublime to Anfield armada |work=[[The Independent]] |publisher=Independent Print Limited |date=25 May 2005 |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/alonso-adds-touch-of-the-sublime-to-anfield-armada-6145471.html |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Alonso tells of Reds heartbreak |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/4493135.stm |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Gerrard returned from injury for the second leg, however, and the captain steered his team to a 1–0 win with the help of a Luis García goal, qualifying for the final against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Winter |first=Henry |title=Glorious Liverpool a big noise again |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date=4 May 2005 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2359108/Glorious-Liverpool-a-big-noise-again.html |accessdate=15 August 2008}}</ref>

Liverpool's fifth place finish in the Premiership left much to be desired but debut season glory still awaited Alonso in the form of the [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|Champions League final]]. The team fell three goals behind Milan but completed a dramatic second-half comeback.<ref>{{cite news |last=Keogh |first=Frank |title=Why it was the greatest cup final |publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 May 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4582357.stm |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Liverpool, trailing 3–2, were awarded a penalty and it was decided that Alonso would take the spot kick. While [[Dida (goalkeeper)|Dida]], Milan's acclaimed [[Brazil]]ian goalkeeper, managed to save the penalty Alonso fired the rebound into the roof of the net, bringing the score to 3–3.<ref>{{cite web |last=McCarra |first=Kevin |title=Grit, spirit and the ultimate glory |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=26 May 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/may/26/match.acmilan |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> [[Extra time]] passed without a goal from either team and Liverpool won 3–2 in the penalty shootout.<ref>{{cite news |title=AC Milan 3–3 Liverpool (aet) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 May 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4573159.stm |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso was praised for his pivotal influence on the team's comeback and manager Benítez reinforced his importance to the team.<ref>{{cite web |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Gerrard inspires Liverpool by sheer willpower |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=26 May 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/may/26/newsstory.championsleague |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Benítez's brave change of tack leaves Milan in reverse gear |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=26 May 2005 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/may/26/championsleague2 |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Benítez demands trophy defence for Reds |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=26 May 2005|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2005/may/26/newsstory.championsleague200405 |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso was ecstatic with the win, commenting: "This is the best moment in my professional career".<ref>{{cite news |title=Benítez stunned by epic comeback |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4582585.stm |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref>

====2005–06: FA Cup winner====
[[File:CK that Aronso kicks.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Alonso taking a corner kick for Liverpool in March 2006.]]
Alonso was ever-present in the first team in the [[2005–06 Premier League|2005–06 season]], largely avoiding injuries that had marred his first season at the club. The summer [[transfer window]] brought [[Peter Crouch]] to Liverpool and the striker's height sparked accusations that the team would change to [[long ball]] tactics. Crouch denied this, highlighting that Alonso's passing ability, alongside Gerrard, would define Liverpool's style of play.<ref>{{cite news |title=Crouch defends Liverpool tactics |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 September 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/4261110.stm |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso faced more competition for his place in the form of new arrival [[Mohamed Sissoko]]. However, Steven Gerrard's injuries and Rafael Benítez's favouring of a [[4-5-1|4–5–1]] [[Formation (association football)|formation]] ensured Alonso's place in the team. Alonso appeared in all of Liverpool's games in the [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] but the dominance shown in the previous season had gone as the team lost to [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in the [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League#Knockout stage|knockout stage]].

On 7 January 2006, in an [[FA Cup]] third-round tie against [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]], Alonso assisted Liverpool to a 5–3 comeback victory after being down 3–1 early in the second half.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bradbury |first=Jamie |title=Reds edge classic |publisher=[[The Football Association|The FA]] |date=7 January 2006 |url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/TheFACup/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2006/01/FACup3rdRd_LutonLiverpool.htm |accessdate=12 November 2008 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20081123024907/http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/TheFACup/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2006/01/FACup3rdRd_LutonLiverpool.htm |archivedate=23 November 2008}}</ref> Alonso scored two impressive goals from distance: one from 45 yards, and the other 65 yards from goal; behind the [[Association football pitch|half-way line]].<ref name=LFCProfile/><ref>{{cite web |last=McCarra |first=Kevin |title=Echoes of another epic as Liverpool forced to treat Luton like Milan |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=9 January 2006 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2006/jan/09/match.lutontown |accessdate=12 November 2008}}</ref> Consequently, Alonso's goals marked a stroke of luck for a Liverpool fan who won £25,000 from a £200 bet on Alonso scoring from within his own half.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fan makes £25,000 on dream goal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/berkshire/4598198.stm|accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref> Alonso suffered an ankle injury in a 3–1 victory over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], putting his participation in the [[2006 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] in doubt.<ref>{{cite web |title=Portsmouth 1–3 Liverpool |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=8 May 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4957462.stm |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> However, he recovered sufficiently to start the game against [[West Ham United]] and Gerrard scored Liverpool's third goal from Alonso's free kick, pulling the team ahead of the opposition. Alonso, still affected by the injury, could not manage the whole 90 minutes and was substituted in the second half. Liverpool won on penalties without his help but Alonso still earned his first FA Cup winners' medal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool 3–3 West Ham (aet) |publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 May 2006 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4756045.stm| accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref>

====2006–2009====
[[File:Kuyt Alonso Liverpool.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Alonso and [[Dirk Kuyt]] playing for  Liverpool in April 2007.]]
On 20 September 2006 Alonso scored what the [[BBC]] described as "an outrageous strike" from his own half in a 2–0 Premiership win against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle]].<ref name=70Y>{{cite news|last=Hughes|first=Ian|title=Liverpool 2–0 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 September 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/5351794.stm |accessdate=14 August 2008}}</ref> Andy Hunter of ''[[The Independent]]'' described it as "one of the most audacious goals in Anfield's rich 115-year history".<ref>{{cite news |last=Hunter |first=Andy |title=Liverpool 2 Newcastle United 0: Alonso hits 70-yard wonder goal to thrill Reds |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=21 September 2006 |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/liverpool-2-newcastle-united-0-alonso-hits-70yard-wonder-goal-to-thrill-reds-416922.html |accessdate=11 November 2008}}</ref> Alonso rebutted claims that his 70-yard goal was all down to luck and stated that he took long range shots as part of his training routine.<ref>{{cite web |last=Winrow |first=Ian |title=Alonso denies his long shots are a gamble |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date=22 September 2006 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2346331/Alonso-denies-his-long-shots-are-a-gamble.html |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Despite the similarity of the goals struck from inside his own half, Alonso was in no doubt which was his best. He said, "I think this was better. The Luton goal bounced a few times, this one went quite straight. The Luton one was left-footed&nbsp;– it was different&nbsp;– but I am quite happy to score the goal."<ref>{{cite web |title=Newcastle goal my best |publisher=''[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]'' |date=22 September 2006 |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/2006/09/22/d60922041537.htm |accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> It was his first goal for Liverpool since the goal against Luton, making distinct history as the only outfield player in modern professional football history to score two consecutive goals from inside his own half of the pitch.<ref name=70Y/>

On 8 June 2007, Alonso signed a five-year contract, stating, "I knew there was interest from other clubs but it was always my idea to stay here. I have been here for three seasons now and have such special feelings for the club and the supporters. I understand what Liverpool means to so many people. It is such a special club and I just didn't want to leave."<ref>{{cite web |title=Alonso commits to five more years at Liverpool |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2007/jun/08/newsstory.sport |date=8 June 2007 |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> The 2007–08 season started well for the Spaniard: Gerrard's absence led to Alonso playing in a more advanced position and he scored twice in a 6–0 rout against Premier League newcomers [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Jackson |first=Jamie |title=Benítez has Liverpool dreaming of a new tilt at the title |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=2 September 2007 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2007/sep/02/match.derbycounty |accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Liverpool 6 Derby County 0: Torres and Alonso lead Rams to the slaughter |first=Ronald |last=Atkin |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=2 September 2007 |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/liverpool-6-derby-county-0-torres-and-alonso-lead-rams-to-the-slaughter-401179.html |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> However, the bright beginning was short-lived as a minor injury sustained in a game against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] became aggravated in training.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bad breaks put Xabi Alonso and Daniel Agger out for six weeks |publisher=''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]'' |date=20 September 2007 |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2007/09/20/bad-breaks-put-xabi-alonso-and-daniel-agger-out-for-six-weeks-64375-19818267/ |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120806214302/http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/sport/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2007/09/20/bad-breaks-put-xabi-alonso-and-daniel-agger-out-for-six-weeks-64375-19818267/ |archivedate=6 August 2008 |accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref> The metatarsal injury forced him out of training for six weeks but his return to the first team was rushed and his injury recurred in his first game back. Alonso's determination and passion proved to be his downfall and he later reflected: "I had been feeling a bit tired around that time because it was only my first game back and the match was very fast. But as a player you don't want to come off, particularly when the team is winning and I stayed on."<ref>{{cite web |title=Xabi Alonso speaks of his Liverpool injury hell |publisher=''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]'' |date=19 December 2007 |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2007/12/19/xabi-alonso-speaks-of-his-liverpool-injury-hell-64375-20268762/ |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120806214318/http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/sport/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2007/12/19/xabi-alonso-speaks-of-his-liverpool-injury-hell-64375-20268762/ |archivedate=6 August 2008 |accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref>

Alonso returned from injury at December 2007, but over the following months he increasingly faced competition for a place in midfield from [[Javier Mascherano]] and [[Lucas Leiva]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Barrett |first=Tony |title=Steven Gerrard out of cup clash as Xabi Alonso returns |publisher=''[[Liverpool Echo]]'' |date=18 December 2007 |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2007/12/18/steven-gerrard-out-of-cup-clash-as-xabi-alonso-returns-100252-20264834/ |accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Winter |first=Henry |title=Torres ensures Liverpool place in Fab Four |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''  |date=12 March 2008 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/henrywinter/2294248/Torres-ensures-Liverpool-place-in-Fab-Four.html |accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref> His role in Liverpool's five-man midfield role was assured, however, as [[Rafael Benítez]] regarded him as "a top class player", stating that Alonso had the ability to change games and break down the opposition's defence.<ref>{{cite web |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Liverpool may fall short in title tilt |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=14 August 2008 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/philmcnulty/2008/08/liverpool_could_fall_short_aga.html |accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rafa Benítez: "Xabi Alonso es un jugador de clase superior" (''Xabi Alonso is a top class player'') |publisher=''[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]'' |date=27 October 2007 |url=http://www.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/internacional/es/desarrollo/1051158.html |accessdate=13 November 2008|language=Spanish}}</ref> Alonso made his 100th league appearance for Liverpool on 12 January 2008 against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hassall |first=Paul |title=Xabi's sweeper dream |publisher=Liverpool |date=12 January 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/archivedirs/news/2008/jan/14/N158402080114-1217.htm |accessdate=15 December 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080430152622/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/archivedirs/news/2008/jan/14/N158402080114-1217.htm |archivedate = 30 April 2008}}</ref>

The 2008 summer transfer window suggested a move away from Merseyside, as Liverpool pursued England international [[Gareth Barry]] to replace Alonso.<ref>{{cite web |title=Liverpool still want Gareth Barry |publisher=''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]'' |date=29 July 2008 |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2008/07/29/liverpool-fc-still-want-gareth-barry-64375-21426760/ |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120806214339/http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/sport/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2008/07/29/liverpool-fc-still-want-gareth-barry-64375-21426760/ |archivedate=6 August 2008 |accessdate=6 October 2008}}</ref> By the start of the 2008–09 season, neither Alonso or Barry had moved club but the drawn-out transfer saga had left the Spaniard feeling unsettled at Liverpool and unsure of his position in the team.<ref>{{cite web |last=Barrett |first=Chris |title=Juventus end pursuit of Alonso |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=16 July 2008 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/jul/16/liverpool.premierleague |accessdate=6 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Alonso admits summer sorrow |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=4 October 2008 |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_4243844,00.html |accessdate=6 October 2008}}</ref> However, the club's fans did much to restore his spirits, supporting him on and off the pitch, and Alonso responded to this, saying:

:"[The fans] couldn't have done more to show me how they felt... If I went out for lunch or a coffee, there was always someone who would come over and say, 'We'd love you to stay'. I'm just glad that, in the end, nothing came of it [the transfer] because it wasn't something I ever asked for."<ref name=Adoptedson>{{cite web |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |title=The adopted son they couldn't drive away |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=4 October 2009 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/oct/04/premierleague.liverpool |accessdate=6 October 2008}}</ref>

Despite the events of the summer, Alonso made a confident start to the season and both his peers and the press praised his strength of character, citing his influence as a factor in the team's strong opening to the season.<ref name=Adoptedson/><ref>{{cite web |title=Gerrard tribute to Xabi Alonso |publisher=Liverpool |date=15 September 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/media-watch/gerrard-tribute-to-xabi-alonso |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> Alonso's importance to the team was further underlined when he scored the only goal, through a deflection, in a 1–0 victory against Chelsea, making Liverpool the first away team to win at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in over four years.<ref>{{cite web |title=Alonso Fires Reds Clear at the Top |publisher=Liverpool |date=26 October 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/season/2008-2009/oct//681/finalwhistle.htm |accessdate=4 November 2008 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20081030084318/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/match/season/2008-2009/oct/681/finalwhistle.htm |archivedate=30 October 2008}}</ref> Statistical analysis reflected Alonso's good form: on 11 December figures from Opta revealed that he was the first Premier League player to complete 1000 successful passes in the season.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rice |first=Jimmy |title=Xabi's 1,000 passes |publisher=Liverpool |date=11 December 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/xabi-s-1-000-passes |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> His last goal for Liverpool came in their 3–1 win at [[Hull City]] on 25 April, striking after his free kick deflected off the Hull wall.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Hull 1–3 Liverpool|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8000571.stm|accessdate=29 August 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=25 April 2009}}</ref>

===Real Madrid===
====2009–10 season====
[[File:Xabi Alonso 48609.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Alonso playing for Real Madrid in February 2012]]
Alonso completed his £30 million move to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] on 5 August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/8184444.stm |title=Alonso completes £30m Real move |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 August 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref> It has been suggested that he never wanted to leave the Anfield side, with his contract existing until at least 2012, and that his departure was due to differences with Benítez.<ref>{{cite web |last=Pearce |first=James|title=Liverpool's Xabi Alonso hands in transfer request|publisher=''[[Liverpool Echo]]''| url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-fc/liverpool-fc-news/2009/07/30/liverpool-fc-s-xabi-alonso-hands-in-transfer-request-100252-24275822/|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Eaton|first=Paul|title=Liverpool agree Alonso Deal|publisher=''Liverpool | url= http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/liverpool-agree-alonso-deal|accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/8184444.stm |title=Alonso completes £30m Real move |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=5 August 2009 |accessdate=5 August 2009 }}</ref> Former teammate Steven Gerrard said he was "devastated" by Alonso's decision, and cited his departure as one of the reasons behind Liverpool's poor run of form at the start of the following season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gerrard 'devastated' by Alonso exit|publisher=''[[Soccernet]]''| url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=693666&sec=england&cc=5901|accessdate=4 March 2009}}</ref>

Alonso was given the number 22 jersey in Madrid and played in a holding midfield position. He scored his first goal for his new team on 21 February 2010, a penalty against [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] in a 6–2 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/gamecast/275756/gamecast.html|title=Real Madrid 6&nbsp;– 2 Villarreal|date=21 February 2010|work=ESPN|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref> Unless he was injured or suspended, [[Manuel Pellegrini]] started Alonso in every match of the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] and in [[La Liga]] in his first season at Real Madrid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/players/stats?id=13842&cc=3888  |title=Xabi Alonso statistics |work=ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref> In La Liga he helped the club finish with a club record 96 points, three points behind winners [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/tables?league=esp.1&season=2009&seasonType=1&cc=3888 |title=Spanish Primera División Table 2009-2010 |work=ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref> It was the third time in Alonso's career that he helped his team set a new club record in terms of points gathered, while finishing in second position (he achieved the same feat with Real Sociedad in 2002–03 and with Liverpool in 2008–09). During his first season at Real Madrid Alonso scored three goals and was considered one of the club's "most consistent" players.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=787862&sec=europe&root=europe&cc=3888 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100522034339/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=787862&sec=europe&root=europe&cc=3888 |archivedate=22 May 2010 |title= At the end of the day... |author=Ball, Phil |date=17 May 2010 |work= ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref> Readers of [[Marca (newspaper)|''Marca'']] made him part of their ''La tiga'' team of the season, as their choice [[defensive midfielder]]; the only other Real Madrid player featured was [[Cristiano Ronaldo]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marca.com/2010/05/18/futbol/1adivision/1274200043.html?a=ddf97ad21ca867da264b51a1a804ee17&t=1274206042 |title=Seis azulgranas, en el once ideal de la Liga |publisher=Marca |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref> Alonso received the same accolade from [[ESPN Soccernet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=786445&sec=soccernetawards&root=soccernetawards&cc=3888 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100520065116/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=786445&sec=soccernetawards&root=soccernetawards&cc=3888 |archivedate=20 May 2010 |title=La Liga Team of the Season |author=Alvarez, Eduardo |work=ESPN Soccernet |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref> He was also a nominee in the [[LFP Awards]], awards given out by the [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional]], the Spanish Football league. Alonso was nominated in the Best Midfielder category, alongside [[Xavi]] and [[Javi Martínez]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lfp.es/Default.aspx?tabid=73&Controltype=dn&IDNoticia=5585 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120603162721/http://www.lfp.es/Default.aspx?tabid=73&Controltype=dn&IDNoticia=5585 |archivedate=3 June 2012 |title=Finalistas Premios LPF |work=LFP |accessdate=15 July 2010}}</ref> Several members of the Spanish press, as well as a number of Real Madrid supporters, gave Alonso a new nickname during the season: ''La Barba Roja'' (The Red Beard).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/deportes/Capitan/brazalete/elpepidep/20100223elpepidep_7/Tes |title=Capitán sin brazalete |author=Torres, Diego |publisher=El Pais |date=23 February 2010 |accessdate=19 May 2010 }}</ref>

====2010–11 season====
His second season at Real Madrid started with the arrival of a new manager, [[José Mourinho]]. He was given the number 14 jersey, after the departure of the vice-captain [[Guti (footballer)|Guti]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Ollie |last=Irish |url=http://www.whoateallthepies.tv/kits/37525/cristiano-ronaldo-takes-rauls-no-7-shirt-at-real-madrid-benzema-moves-to-no-9-xabi-alonso-takes-no-14.html |title=Cristiano Ronaldo Takes Raul's No.7 Shirt at Real Madrid, Benzema Moves To No.9, Xabi Alonso Takes No.14 |publisher=Whoateallthepies.tv |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> He did not score any goals that whole season but was very vital. While he believed{{cn|date=February 2015}} that [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] would win the league, in fact they only managed to win the [[Copa del Rey]] that season.

====2011–12 season====
Xabi Alonso started his third season at Real Madrid by scoring the second goal in a 2–2 draw against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] in the [[2011 Supercopa de España]] at the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium]]. On 21 September 2011, he played his 100th official game for Real Madrid in the 0–0 draw against [[Racing de Santander|Racing Santander]]. Alonso continued to be an undisputed force in the starting eleven and ultimately claimed the first league title of his career.

====2013–14 season====
[[File:Xabi Alonso (Real Valladolid-Real Madrid).jpg|thumb|right|Alonso with Real Madrid in 2014.]]
On 8 January 2014, Alonso signed a contract extension with Real Madrid, which would have kept him at the club until 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2536096/Xabi-Alonso-signs-two-year-contract-extension-Real-Madrid.html|title=Alonso signs two-year contract extension at Real Madrid despite Premier League interest|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=11 January 2014|work=Daily Mail}}</ref>

On 29 April 2014, Real Madrid defeated [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] 4–0 in the second leg of their UEFA Champions League semi-final to qualify for the [[2014 UEFA Champions League Final]] on a 5–0 aggregate win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2616415/Xabi-Alonso-suspended-Champions-League-final-wants-rules-changed.html|title=Xabi Alonso is suspended for Champions League final... and wants 'unfair' rules changed|date=29 April 2014|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref> Alonso received a yellow card after a sliding tackle on [[Bastian Schweinsteiger]] in the first half. As he already had two before the match, this ruled him out of [[2014 UEFA Champions League Final|the final]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27193338|title=Bayern Munich 0 Real Madrid 4|date=29 April 2014|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref> He claimed his second Champions League winners medal as Real defeated [[Atletico Madrid]] 4–1 in extra time.

===Bayern Munich===
[[File:CSKA-Bavaria (1).jpg|thumb|left|161px|Xabi Alonso playing for Bayern against [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] in 2014.]]
On 29 August 2014, Alonso moved to Bayern Munich on a two-year deal for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fcbayern.de/en/news/news/2014/xabi-alonso-signs-for-bayern-290814.php | title = Xabi Alonso completes Bayern switch | date = 29 August 2014 | accessdate = 29 August 2014 | work = fcbayern.de | publisher = FC Bayern Munich}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/en/news/2014/08/official-announcement-xabi-alonso|title=Official announcement: Xabi Alonso|date=29 August 2014|work=realmadrid.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Xabi Alonso: Bayern Munich sign Real Madrid player|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28964916|accessdate=29 August 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2014}}</ref> He made his debut the following day, starting in a 1–1 draw at [[Schalke 04]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Coleman|first1=Tom|title=Schalke 1-1 Bayern Munich: Howedes seals controversial point for hosts|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/schalke-04-vs-bayern-m%C3%BCnchen/1713403/report?ICID=MP_MS_5|accessdate=31 August 2014|work=Goal.com|date=30 August 2014}}</ref> On 27 September 2014, in the match against [[1. FC Köln]], Alonso broke the record for most passes completed in a Bundesliga game with a total of 196.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reilly|first1=Garry|title=5 Incredible Stats That Show How Important Xabi Alonso Is For Bayern Munich|url=http://balls.ie/football/5-incredible-stats-show-important-xabi-alonso-bayern-munich/|website=Balls.ie| date = 1 October 2014 | accessdate = 2 October 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 18 October 2014, a free kick in a 6–0 win over [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bayern Mun 6-0 SV Werder Bremen|url= http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29657702 |accessdate=19 October 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=18 October 2014}}</ref>

On 17 February 2015, in his 100th Champions League appearance, Alonso was sent–off for a second bookable offense, in a 0–0 draw against [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reddy|first1=Luke|title=Shakhtar Donetsk v Bayern Munich|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/31508728|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 February 2015}}</ref> Alonso was suspended for the return leg of the fixture<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lovell|first1=Mark|title=Bayern Munich awakening from winter-break hibernation|url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/bayern-munich/132/blog/post/2313384/bayern-munich-awakening-from-winter-break-hibernation|accessdate=23 February 2015|publisher=ESPN FC|date=23 February 2015}}</ref> which Bayern won 7–0.<ref>{{cite news|title=FC Bayern düst ins Viertelfinale|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/champions-league-fc-bayern-duest-ins-viertelfinale-1.2389807|accessdate=12 March 2015|publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung|date=11 March 2015|language=German}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:Xabi Alonso Euro 2012 vs France 02.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Alonso playing against [[France national football team|France]] at [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]].]]

===Euro 2004===
Alonso was a substitute in Spain's 1–0 victory against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] and played a full 90 minutes against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]. Spain were knocked out in the group stage.<ref name=FDB/>

===2006 World Cup===
Alonso was named in the Spanish squad for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] and he scored Spain's first goal of the tournament, his first international goal, against Ukraine on 14 June 2006.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bulman |first=Erica |title=David Villa scores twice as Spain reigns over Ukraine 4–0 |publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' |date=14 June 2006 |url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/worldcup/2006-06-14-spain-ukraine_x.htm |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref> Despite a successful [[2006 FIFA World Cup Group H|group phase]], where Spain won all their games, Alonso did not achieve international glory as the team were beaten by the eventual finalists [[France national football team|France]] in the first [[2006 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|knockout stage]] of the tournament.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spain 1–3 France |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 July 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991524.stm |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref>

===Euro 2008===
[[Liverpool F.C. season 2007–08|Liverpool's 2007–08 season]] finished trophyless but the opportunity to win honours awaited Alonso in the form of the [[Euro 2008]] tournament. Alonso featured mainly as a substitute but, with key players resting, he captained [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in the final group game against [[Greece national football team|Greece]], earning the [[man of the match]] award.<ref>{{cite web |last=Baskett |first=Simon |title=Second string Spain too good for Greece |publisher=Reuters |date=18 June 2008 |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSL1867995520080618?sp=true |accessdate=15 December 2008}}</ref> Despite a strong performance, he could not attain a starting position in the team, highlighting Spain's strength in depth.<ref>{{cite web |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |title=Second-string Alonso displays class of Spanish squad |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=19 June 2008 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/jun/19/euro2008.euro2008groupd1 |accessdate=15 December 2008}}</ref> Spain went on to win the tournament and he featured in four of Spain's six matches.<ref name=SpainStats>{{cite web |title=Xabi Alonso Player Profile Euro 2008 |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/euro2008/player-profiles/0,23132,12024_90026,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100402194102/http://www.skysports.com/football/euro2008/player-profiles/0,23132,12024_90026,00.html |archivedate=2 April 2010 |accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref> Speaking to [[Guillem Balague]], he said that Spain's victory was deserved and the players' teamwork had been crucial to the team's undefeated run in the tournament. The Basque was ecstatic at the achievement, declaring "Right now, we're all just living the moment. It's incredible and we're all walking around in a dream. It's fantastic".<ref>{{cite web |last=Balague |first=Guillem |title=Exclusive Interview: Xabi Alonso |publisher=[[Guillem Balague]] |date=30 June 2008 |url=http://www.guillembalague.com/interview_desp.php?id=14&titulo=Exclusive%20Interview:%20Xabi%20Alonso |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120223101615/http://www.guillembalague.com/interview_desp.php?id=14&titulo=Exclusive%20Interview:%20Xabi%20Alonso |archivedate=23 February 2012 |accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref> Alonso's international success continued as he scored twice in a 3–0 win in a friendly against Denmark in August.<ref>{{cite web |last=McLaughlin |first=Kim |title=UPDATE 1-Soccer-Alonso double helps Spain ease past Denmark |publisher=Reuters |date=20 August 2008 |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldFootballNews/idUKLK00223720080820?rpc=401&=undefined&sp=true |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref>

===2009 Confederations Cup===
After Spain were surprisingly eliminated from the Confederations Cup by a defeat to the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]], Alonso and Spain faced [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] in the third-place match. After 90 minutes the game was tied at 2–2, so extra time was added. Then in extra time Alonso scored an free-kick in to the bottom corner which helped Spain obtain the third place in the tournament.

===2010 World Cup===
Xabi Alonso started every game for [[Spain national football team|Spain]] during the 2010 tournament, playing alongside [[Sergio Busquets]] and [[Xavi]] in midfield and helping his side to lift their first ever World Cup trophy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=207528/index.html |title= FIFA player Statistics: XABI ALONSO |publisher=[[FIFA]]}}</ref> In the 28th minute of the final against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] he received a [[Kung fu]]-style kick to the chest from Dutch midfielder [[Nigel de Jong]], the foul was controversial since it appeared to be a foul worthy of a straight red but was only ruled out to be a yellow card given by Howard Webb. This left Alonso in pain and in fear of a broken rib.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailyexpress.co.uk/posts/view/186572/Xabi-Alonso-in-broken-rib-fear-/ |title=Xabi Alonso in broken rib fear |publisher=the Daily and Sunday Express |author=Joyce, Paul |accessdate=15 July 2010}}</ref> Despite this pain, he continued playing on for another hour.
[[File:Xabi Alonso goal celebration Euro 2012 vs France.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Alonso celebrates scoring against [[France national football team|France]] at [[UEFA Euro 2012]].]]

===Euro 2012===
[[File:Alonso Basque.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Xabi Alonso playing for the Basque Country.]]
On 23 June 2012, Xabi Alonso played his 100th match for Spain<ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/euro-2012/top-stories/Xabi-Alonso-fires-Spain-to-Euro-2012-semifinals/articleshow/14365126.cms |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120625042250/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/euro-2012/top-stories/Xabi-Alonso-fires-Spain-to-Euro-2012-semifinals/articleshow/14365126.cms |archivedate=25 June 2012 | title= Xabi Alonso fires Spain to Euro 2012 semifinals| date=24 June 2012}}</ref> in the quarterfinals against [[France national football team|France]] in which he scored both goals in a 2–0 victory for Spain. The first goal came after he magnificantely headed a cross from the left flank delivered by [[Jordi Alba]], while the second one came from a penalty kick given after [[Pedro Rodríguez Ledesma|Pedro Rodríguez]] was fouled by [[Anthony Réveillère]] in the dying seconds of the match. Alonso's penalty in the semi-final shoot-out against Portugal was saved by [[Rui Patricio]] in which Spain went on to win 4–2 after a 0–0 draw in game itself. Alonso and [[Spain]] went on to beat [[Gianluigi Buffon]] and [[Italy]] 4–0 in the finals. This was Alonso's 3rd major win with [[Spain]].

===2014 World Cup===
[[Spain]] were again amongst the favourites for cup victory in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] but had a very disappointing campaign ending in the first round. Alonso scored a penalty in the 27th minute of their first match against The [[Netherlands]]. However he was substituted in the 62nd minute with Spain losing 2–1. The match ended with a resounding 5–1 win for the Netherlands. Spain then suffered another defeat, this time 2–0 to [[Chile]]. In that match Alonso received a yellow card in the first half and was substituted at half time with the score already at 2–0. Spain were then eliminated from the tournament but did win their final match 3–0 against Australia and finished third in the group. Alonso played for 83 minutes against [[Australia]].

Alonso retired from international football on 27 August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Xabi Alonso: Real Madrid midfielder retires from Spain duty|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28959560|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 August 2014|date=27 August 2014}}</ref>

===Basque Country===
Alonso made his debut for the [[Basque Country regional football team]] in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 29 December 2001<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eff-fvf.org/pub/verFichaPartido.asp?idioma=ca&idPartido=141 |title=Euskadi-Ghana |work=Euskadiko Futbol Federakundea | date = 29 December 2001 | accessdate = 30 August 2014}}</ref> and receives regular call ups since, while&nbsp;– due to his busy club schedule&nbsp;– not always being able to appear. Most recently, Alonso appeared for Euskal Selekzioa on 29 December 2012, in a 6–1 victory over [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eff-fvf.org/pub/noticiaAmpliada.asp?idioma=ca&idnoticia=1488&gruponoticia=11 |title=La Euskal Selekzioa arrolla a Bolivia |work=Euskadiko Futbol Federakundea | date = 20 December 2012 | accessdate = 30 August 2014}}</ref>

==Style of play==
A complete, consistent, hardworking and versatile midfielder, Alonso is regarded as one of the best midfielders of his generation, and is effective both creatively and defensively.<ref name="bundesliga.com_1">{{cite web | url = http://www.bundesliga.com/en/liga/news/2014/0000303084.php | title = Xabi Alonso: FC Bayern's indisputable Ballmagnet | publisher = bundesliga.com | date = 28 September 2014 | accessdate = 3 December 2014}}</ref> Gifted with good technique, as well as excellent vision and varied passing range, he excels in the deep-lying [[Playmaker|playmaking]] role, where he can best utilise his accurate [[Long ball (Football)|long passing]] ability to create goal scoring chances for team-mates;<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.espnfc.com/blog/espn-fc-united-blog/68/post/2103551/xabi-alonso-provides-the-tempo-that-makes-bayerns-jazz-flow | title = Xabi Alonso provides the tempo that makes Bayern's jazz flow | publisher = ESPN FC | date = 22 October 2014 | accessdate = 3 December 2014 | first = Raphael | last = Honigstein}}</ref> he also possesses a powerful and accurate shot from distance, and he is an effective [[Direct free kick|set-piece]] and [[penalty kick]] taker.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.calciomercato.it/news/153706/Campioni-ai-Raggi-X-Xabi-Alonso-e-larte-del-passaggio.html | title = Campioni ai Raggi X: Xabi Alonso e l'arte del passaggio | language = it | publisher = calciomercato.it | date = 16 April 2012 | accessdate = 3 December 2014 | first = Stefano | last = D'Alessio}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.tuttomercatoweb.com/editoriale/pirlo-e-xabi-alonso-vietato-fare-confusione-inter-milan-e-la-potenziale-nuova-mappa-dei-direttori-sabatini-in-testa-lodi-uno-da-toro-leonardi-da-appla-502420 | title = Pirlo e Xabi Alonso: vietato fare confusione. Inter-Milan e la potenziale nuova mappa dei direttori, Sabatini in testa. Lodi, uno da Toro. Leonardi da applausi. La tessera del tifoso: qualcuno paghi | language = it | publisher = tuttomercatoweb.com | date = 17 November 2013 | accessdate = 3 December 2014 | first =  Alfredo | last = Pedullà}}</ref><ref name="bundesliga.com_1" /> Due to his height, positioning, and physical characteristics, Xabi Alonso is also effective in the air, often contributing with headed goals from set pieces when advancing into more offensive positions.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gazzetta.it/Europei/2012/23-06-2012/spagna-ci-pensa-xabi-alonso-francia-spenta-ed-eliminata-911621155933.shtml | title = Spagna, ci pensa Xabi Alonso Francia spenta ed eliminata | language = it | publisher = La Gazzetta dello Sport | date = 23 June 2012 | accessdate = 3 December 2014}}</ref> In addition to his creative attributes, he is also capable of excelling as a defensive midfielder due to his strength and powerful physique, combined with his tenacity, tactical intelligence, aggressive tackling, and his ability to read the game.<ref name="bundesliga.com_1" /><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ilpost.it/2014/10/21/roma-bayern-monaco/ | title = Roma-Bayern Monaco, stasera | language = it | publisher = ilpost.it | date = 21 October 2014 | accessdate = 3 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ilfoglio.it/articoli/v/103382/rubriche/la-spagna-gioca-da-sola-contro-la-francia-e-si-merita-la-semifinale.htm | title = La Spagna gioca da sola contro la Francia e si merita la semifinale | language = it | publisher = Il Foglio | date = 24 June 2012 | accessdate = 3 December 2014}}</ref> He has at times been criticised, however, for occasionally committing rash challenges, and for his tendency to lose his composure and pick up unnecessary cards for particularly hard fouls.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2045834-xabi-alonso-suspended-for-champions-league-final-after-yellow-card | title = Xabi Alonso Slams UEFA Rule After Earning Suspension for Champions League Final | publisher = bleacherreport.com | date = 29 April 2014 | accessdate = 3 December 2014 | first = Tim | last = Keeney}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Alonso was regarded as a quiet and friendly person by his former teammates at Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rice |first=Jimmy |title=Reina hails 'One of world's best' |publisher=Liverpool |date=3 December 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/reina-hails-one-of-world-s-best |accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> He is married to Nagore Aramburu and the couple have three children: Jontxu, Ane and Emma. Alonso stayed in [[Merseyside]] to be at her side while she gave birth, later saying: "It was a little frustrating to miss the match against [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Inter]] but I have to be with my family at times like these."<ref>{{cite web |title=Xabi Alonso: "Fue un poco frustrante no jugar, pero tenía que estar con mi familia" | trans_title = Xabi Alonso: "It was a little frustrating to miss the match, but I had to be with my family" |publisher= [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |date=13 March 2008 |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2008/03/13/futbol/1205432606.html |accessdate=4 November 2008|language=Spanish}}</ref> His decision to place his family ahead of a [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] tie caused much friction with manager [[Rafa Benítez]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Wallace |first=Sam |title=Alonso left at home after Benítez tires of baby talk |publisher= [[The Independent]] |date=11 March 2008 |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/alonso-left-at-home-after-benitez-tires-of-baby-talk-794019.html |accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=That's yer tot, Alonso |work=[[The Sun (newspaper)|The Sun]] |date=11 March 2008 |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article900748.ece |accessdate=4 November 2008 | first = Phil | last = Thomas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Martín |first=Luis |title= La paternidad de Xabi Alonso provoca un lío en Anfield | trans_title = Xabi Alonso's fatherhood whips up a storm at Anfield |publisher= [[El Pais (Madrid)|El Pais]] |date=12 March 2008 |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/deportes/paternidad/Xabi/Alonso/provoca/lio/Anfield/elpepidep/20080312elpepidep_1/Tes |accessdate=4 November 2008|language=Spanish}}</ref> On 30 March 2010 they had their second child; a girl named Ane Alonso Aranburu.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kickette.com/pitter-patter-xabi-and-nagore-welcome-baby-ane/ |title = Pitter Patter: Xabi And Nagore Alonso Welcome Baby Ane |publisher= Kickette | date = 31 March 2010 | accessdate = 30 August 2014}}</ref> Their third child and second daughter, Emma Alonso Aranburu, was born on 2 December 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanitatis.com/noticias/2013-12-02/xabi-alonso-y-nagore-aramburu-ya-tienen-la-familia-numerosa-con-el-nacimiento-de-emma_61637/ |title=Xabi Alonso y Nagore Aramburu ya tienen la familia numerosa con el nacimiento de Emma |publisher= Vanitatis | language = es | date = 2 December 2013 | accessdate = 30 August 2014 | first = Raoul | last = Higuera}}</ref>

Alonso and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] player [[Mikel Arteta]] were neighbours on the same street while growing up in [[San Sebastián]] and also lived near each other in [[Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Ducker |first=James |title=Arteta puts friendship on hold as Everton eye Europe |publisher= [[The Times]] |date=25 March 2006 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/everton/article695785.ece |accessdate=14 August 2008 | location=London}}</ref> Alonso convinced Arteta to transfer to Everton after he told him how happy he was living in Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web |last=Prentice |first=David |title=Mikel Arteta and Xabi Alonso's special bond put on hold in Everton-Liverpool derby |publisher= [[Liverpool Echo]] |date=26 September 2008 |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/everton-fc/everton-fc-news/2008/09/26/mikel-arteta-and-xabi-alonso-s-special-bond-put-on-hold-in-everton-liverpool-derby-100252-21906863/ |accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref> Alonso also helped persuade former [[Real Sociedad]] team mate [[Juan Ugarte]] to make a move to Wales by joining [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]] in 2004.<ref name=Big1>{{cite web |last=Rice |first=Jimmy |title=Xabi Alonso: The Big Interview |publisher=Liverpool |date=18 January 2007 |url= http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/features/this_season/FN11090070118-1117.htm |accessdate=15 August 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070918230815/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/features/this_season/FN11090070118-1117.htm |archivedate = 18 September 2007}}</ref>

His brother, [[Mikel Alonso]] plays for Spanish team  [[Real Unión]]. He previously spent a season on loan at [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in the [[2007–08 Premier League|2007–08 season]] with an option for a permanent deal.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bolton clinch Alonso |publisher= [[Manchester Evening News]] |date=16 July 2007 |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/bolton_wanderers/s/1011/1011420_bolton_clinch_alonso.html |accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Alonso joins Bolton from Sociedad |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=10 July 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/6290040.stm |accessdate=4 November 2008}}</ref> However, the team opted not to extend the loan deal and he returned to Spain to train with Xabi Alonso's former club, Real Sociedad.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lorenzo |first=J. L. |title=El club presentará mañana el ERE con Alonso y Stevanovic | trans_title = The club will release Alonso and Stefanovic tomorrow under ERE legislation |publisher= [[Mundo Deportivo]] |date=3 September 2008 |url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/web/gen/20080903/noticia_53530989163.html |accessdate=1 December 2011|language=Spanish}}</ref> Alonso also has another brother involved in football, Jon, who works as a [[referee (association football)|referee]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.laopinion.es/secciones/noticia.jsp?pRef=2009012900_11_196509__Deportes-Tenerife-elige-Mikel-Alonso | title =  El Tenerife elige a Mikel Alonso | language = es | publisher = La Opinion de Tenerife | date = 28 January 2009 | accessdate = 30 August 2014 | first = Manoj | last = Daswani}}</ref>

Alonso is a [[Meath GAA|Meath]] [[Gaelic football]] supporter.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Gaelic+Football%3A+Meath+Kop+big+fan+in+Alonso%3B+GAELIC+WORLD.-a0173616681|title=Meath Kop big fan in Alonso|publisher= Sunday Mirror |date=20 January 2008|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref> His interest in the Irish sport stems from the age of 15 when he went to the Irish town of [[Kells, County Meath]] and stayed with a family to learn English, where he played it in his spare time.<ref name="gaaboard" />

Even while playing at Real Madrid, Alonso has declared himself a [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] supporter and returns to watch games at Anfield when his schedule allows. He was quoted in ''[[The Times|The Times Online]]'' in 2011 as saying: "I am still a Liverpool fan and will be forever, absolutely" and that he will raise his Liverpool-born son as a Red supporter.<ref>{{cite web |title=Alonso: My son's a Red  |publisher=Liverpool |date=4 April 2011 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/alonso-my-son-s-a-red |accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref>

In October 2014, Alonso had a [[Twitter]] following of 8.23 million, making him the tenth most followed sportsperson and eighth most followed footballer on the website.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nagle|first1=Ben|title=Wayne Rooney is the first Premier League footballer to reach 10 million Twitter followers as Manchester United captain becomes site's fifth most popular athlete|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2782242/10-million-followers-Wayne-Rooney-Manchester-United-England-captain-Premier-League-footballer-reach-Twitter-milestone.html|accessdate=19 November 2014|work=Daily Mail|date=6 October 2014}}</ref>

==Politics==
In 2009, Xabi Alonso criticised then [[prime minister]] [[Gordon Brown]]'s [[Chancellorship of Gordon Brown|economic policy]], in particular the devalued [[pound sterling]] and the 50p tax rate, warning that it has weakened [[English football]] and could drive top players away from the UK.<ref name="tax">{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/5578084/Xabi-Alonso-warns-that-tax-will-drive-top-players-away.html|title=Xabi Alonso warns that tax will drive top players away|publisher=Telegraph|date=20 June 2009|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
