'''Josmer Volmy "Jozy" Altidore''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|l|t|i|d|ɔər}} (born November 6, 1989)<ref name="confedcup">{{Cite journal |title=Altidore gets his message across this time |url=http://msn.foxsports.com/soccer/story/9726684/Altidore-gets-his-message-across-this-time |publisher=[[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox Sports]] |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=June 24, 2009 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> is an American professional [[Association football|soccer]] player who plays for [[Toronto FC]] and for the  [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]].

Altidore made his professional debut in 2006 at the age of 16 with the [[New York Red Bulls]]. In the middle of his third season with New York, in 2008, he made a transfer to [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] for a fee of $10&nbsp;million. During his time with Villarreal, he left on three loan stints – with Spanish [[Segunda División]] club [[Xerez CD|Xerez]] in February–May 2009, English [[Premier League]] club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for the entire [[2009–10 Hull City A.F.C. season|2009–10 season]], and Turkish club [[Bursaspor]] where he went on a six-month loan. In the summer of 2011, he made a switch to [[AZ (football club)|AZ]] in the Netherlands. On March 3, 2013, Altidore surpassed [[Clint Dempsey]] for most goals by an American in a European club season with his 24th goal of the 2012–13 campaign. During the 2013 Summer transfer window, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] signed Altidore. He spent one-and-a-half seasons there, with a comparatively poor goalscoring record, then returned to MLS with Toronto.

Altidore has represented the United States on various levels of international competition, featuring for the [[United States U-17 men's national soccer team|United States U-17 team]] at the [[2005 FIFA U-17 World Championship]], [[United States U-20 men's national soccer team|U-20 team]] at the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]], the [[United States U-23 men's national soccer team|U-23 team]] at the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]], and the senior national team at the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup]], and the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]] and [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]] [[FIFA World Cup]]s.

==Early life==
The youngest of four children of a [[Haitian American|Haitian-American]] family, Altidore was born in [[Livingston, New Jersey]] and raised in [[Boca Raton, Florida]]. He enjoyed playing soccer from the time he was a boy.<ref>Dampf, Andrew. [http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2009-06-24-1584081152_x.htm "Altidore gets his message across this time"], ''[[USA Today]]'', June 24, 2009. Accessed February 24, 2011. "Born in Livingston, New Jersey, to Haitian parents, U.S. Soccer is hoping Altidore develops into the consistent scorer the team has lacked for years. So far he's on schedule."</ref> Altidore played for various [[South Florida]] youth teams such as Boca Raton Juniors Soccer Club, Schulz Academy and Sunrise S.C while also spending time training with the under-17 national team at the [[IMG Academy]] in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]].

==Club career==

===New York Red Bulls===
[[File:Jozy Altidore RedBullNY.jpg|thumb|Altidore in a press conference with the Red Bulls in March 2008]]
Altidore was taken seventeenth overall in the [[2006 MLS SuperDraft]], with the [[New York Red Bulls|MetroStars]] (now the New York Red Bulls) trading up to receive the selection. Altidore spent the majority of the [[Major League Soccer 2006 season|2006 season]] away from the team while working towards his high school diploma in Florida.

Altidore made his professional debut on August 23, 2006, as a substitute in a 3–1 [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|U.S. Open Cup]] loss to [[D.C. United]]. He scored his first professional goal at the age of sixteen with an 83rd minute, 28-yard shot to beat the [[Columbus Crew]] 1–0 on September 16, 2006. Exactly one week later, on September 23, 2006, in a 4–3 loss to D.C. United, Altidore scored again. Scoring three times in seven appearances, including a crucial goal against [[Chicago Fire S.C.|Chicago Fire]] on September 30, 2006, Altidore became a fan favorite. He scored the Red Bulls' only goal of their 2–1 aggregate loss to D.C. United in the Eastern Conference Semifinals Series when he headed in a cross in the second leg. With that goal, he became the youngest player to score in the [[Major League Soccer]] playoffs at 16 years, 337 days (breaking [[DaMarcus Beasley]]'s record by almost three years). Altidore was also youngest to start in a Major League Soccer playoff match on October 21 against D.C. United (16 years, 349 days). He also scored two goals in a 5–4 win over [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] on August 18, 2007.

===Villarreal===
On June 4, 2008, [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] of [[La Liga]] agreed in principle with Major League Soccer and the New York Red Bulls to sign Altidore for roughly $10&nbsp;million or €7.4&nbsp;million.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/sports/soccer/05altidore.html?ref=sports | work=The New York Times | title=Spanish Soccer Team Strikes Deal for Altidore | first1=Jack | last1=Bell | first2=Joshua | last2=Robinson | date=June 5, 2008 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.soccerbyives.net/soccer_by_ives/2008/06/altidore-sold-t.html Soccer By Ives – Altidore Sold to Villarreal for $10&nbsp;million<!--Bot generated title -->]</ref> This transfer fee surpasses [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]'s fee for [[Clint Dempsey]], which was $4&nbsp;million or roughly £2&nbsp;million, and is now the largest fee paid for any MLS player. Altidore finalized his personal contract and was unveiled by the club on June 11, 2008.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=U.S. striker Jozy Altidore excited by Villarreal move |url=http://msn.foxsports.com/soccer/story/8235232/U.S.-striker-Jozy-Altidore-excited-by-Villarreal-move |publisher=''[[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox Sports]]'' |date=June 12, 2008 |accessdate=June 13, 2008 |format=  – <sup>[http://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3AU.S.+striker+Jozy+Altidore+excited+by+Villarreal+move&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |postscript=<!--None-->}} {{Dead link|date=May 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.soccerbyives.net/soccer_by_ives/2008/06/altidore-agrees.html Soccer By Ives: Altidore agrees to terms with Villarreal, to be introduced on Wednesday<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On September 14, 2008, Altidore made his La Liga debut, coming on as a second-half substitute against [[Deportivo La Coruña]]. On November 1, 2008, he became the first American international to score in La Liga when he came on in the 90th minute and scored against [[Athletic Bilbao]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/11/02/altidore-scores-his-first-goal-for-villarreal/ | work=The New York Times | title=Altidore Scores His First Goal for Villarreal | first=Jack | last=Bell | date=November 2, 2008 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}}</ref> On November 30, 2008, Altidore started his first game in [[La Liga]] against [[Recreativo Huelva]]. After spending a year and a half on loan, Altidore returned to Villarreal. He favored staying with Villarreal instead of another loan to try to prove to the club he was worth the investment they made two years ago.

===Xerez===
On January 30, 2009, Villarreal agreed to loan Altidore to [[Xerez CD|Xerez]], leader of the [[Segunda División]] at the time of the transfer, until the end of the [[2008–09 Segunda División|2008–09 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Altidore headed to Xerez on loan |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=614312&sec=americansabroad&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPNsoccernet]] |date=January 31, 2009 |accessdate=April 21, 2009}}</ref> It was expected that the move would allow Altidore to get more playing time, and also allow him to continue the process of assimilating into the Spanish culture.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ives |last=Galarcep |title=Altidore completes loan move to Xerez |url=http://www.soccerbyives.net/soccer_by_ives/2009/01/altidore-loan-deal-to-xerez-is-done.html |work=SoccerByIves.net |date=January 31, 2009 |accessdate=April 21, 2009}}</ref>

On April 16, 2009, Altidore underwent minor surgery on an injured toenail that required more than a month of recovery, resulting in him never making an appearance for Xerez.<ref>{{cite news |first=Arch |last=Bell |title=Altidore undergoes knife, out month |url=http://www.yanks-abroad.com/get.php?mode=content&id=4583 |work=Yanks-Abroad.com |date=April 16, 2009 |accessdate=April 21, 2009}}</ref>

===Hull City===
On August 5, 2009, Altidore announced on his [[Twitter]] page that he would be loaned to English [[Premier League]] club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{Cite news |first=Kristian R. |last=Dyer |title=Altidore to join Hull City on loan |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=665334&sec=americansabroad&cc=5901 |work=ESPNsoccernet |date=August 5, 2009 |accessdate=August 6, 2009}}</ref> He joined Hull City the next day on a season-long loan with the option for Hull City to purchase his rights at the end of the [[2009–10 Premier League|2009–10 season]] for a fee believed to be £6.5&nbsp;million ($11&nbsp;million).

On August 10, 2009, Hull City announced that they were successful in obtaining a [[Work permit (United Kingdom)|work permit]] for Altidore.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Altidore Granted Work Permit |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1749853,00.html |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=June 7, 2013|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120329135352/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1749853,00.html|archivedate=March 29, 2012}}</ref> Altidore made his debut for Hull on August 22, 2009, coming on as a second-half substitute against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton]]. He provided the assist for [[Kamel Ghilas]] to score the only goal in a 1–0 home victory at the [[KC Stadium]].<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Hull 1–0 Bolton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8209351.stm |publisher=BBC |date=August 22, 2009 |accessdate=August 22, 2009 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On August 25, 2009, Altidore scored his first goal for Hull in a 3–1 win over [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] in the [[2009–10 Football League Cup|second round]] of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Altidore sinks Shrimpers |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=281566&cc=5901 |publisher=ESPN |date=August 25, 2009 |accessdate=August 25, 2009 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> Altidore was popular with supporters but struggled to make a lasting impact with the Tigers as his finishing was often found wanting, however he did manage to score his first and only [[Premier League]] goal in the 2–1 home win over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on February 6.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Hull 2–1 Man City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8498610.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=February 6, 2010 |accessdate=February 6, 2010 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> On April 24, in an important game for Hull City's Premier League survival, he was dismissed for violent conduct after a spat with Sunderland's [[Alan Hutton]] who was also sent off. Hull City lost 1–0 and were all but relegated from the top flight.<ref name="Hull 0 - 1 Sunderland">{{cite news
 | title = Hull 0 – 1 Sunderland
 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8637469.stm
 | publisher = [[BBC]]
 | work = [[BBC Sport]]
 | date = April 24, 2010
 | accessdate = April 27, 2010
 | last = Sheringham
 | first = Sam }}</ref>

===Bursaspor===
On January 31, 2011, Altidore was loaned out to Turkish champions [[Bursaspor]] on a six-month loan.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Jozy Altidore heading to Bursaspor |url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/6078103/jozy-altidore-being-loaned-bursaspor-6-months |work=ESPNsoccernet |date=January 31, 2011 |accessdate=February 2, 2011}}</ref> On Friday April 8, Altidore scored his first goal for his new club in a 3–2 home loss to [[Antalyaspor]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/soccer-insider/post/video-jozy-altidore-goal-for-bursaspor/2011/04/08/AFXvdx3C_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Stats, scores and schedules | date=April 8, 2011}}</ref>

===AZ===

On July 15, 2011, Altidore agreed to terms with [[Eredivisie|Dutch]] side [[AZ (football club)|AZ]].<ref>Galarcep, Ives. http://www.soccerbyives.net/soccer_by_ives/2011/07/altidore-joining-az-alkmaar.html ''Soccerbyives.net''. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref>

====2011–12====
On August 7, Altidore made his debut for the club as a second-half substitute against [[PSV Eindhoven]].  Altidore scored in the 80th minute, helping his new side to a 3–1 opening day win.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=321917&cc=5901 Report: AZ v PSV Eindhoven – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN Soccernet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  Altidore was again used as a sub in the club's next Eredivisie game as AZ fell 2–0 to [[FC Twente]].<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/321911?cc=5901 Report: Twente Enschede v AZ – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN Soccernet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  Altidore made his first start in the league for AZ on August 21, when they played host to [[NEC Nijmegen]] at the [[AFAS Stadion]].  After a goalless first-half, Altidore opened the scoring in the 54th minute, pouncing on the rebound after NEC goalkeeper [[Jasper Cillessen]] saved his header.  Altidore scored again nineteen minutes later after some nice passing with [[Adam Maher]] and AZ ran out 4–0 winners.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/321899?cc=5901 Report: AZ v NEC Nijmegen – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN Soccernet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

On August 25, Altidore started in the second leg of the UEFA Europa League final qualifying match against [[Aalesunds FK]] from Norway. Before being substituted in the 63rd minute by [[Charlison Benschop]], Altidore scored twice.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match/_/id/327672?cc=5901 Match: AZ v Aalesund – UEFA Europa League – ESPN Soccernet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> His first goal in the 23rd minute gave AZ  a 2–0 lead and his second goal in the 59th minute brought the score to 4–0 in a game AZ eventually won by 6–0.<ref>[http://www.vi.nl/Nieuws-item/205851/AZ-in-eigen-huis-veel-te-sterk-voor-Aalesunds-FK.htm Voetbal International – AZ in eigen huis veel te sterk voor Aalesunds FK<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  Altidore added to his [[2011-12 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] account when he opened the scoring in the 21st minute of his side's first group match against [[Malmo FF]] on September 15.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/gamecast?id=332027&cc=5901 Gamecast: AZ v Malmo FF – UEFA Europa League – ESPN Soccernet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  After a long wait Altidore returned to the score sheet for AZ, netting in the 83rd minute of a 3–0 victory over [[ADO Den Haag]] on November 6 that also secured his side's 10th victory of the Eredivisie campaign.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=321816&cc=5901 Report: AZ v ADO Den Haag – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN FC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  On December 4, Altidore scored his side's only goal in a 5–1 loss to Heerenveen.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=321789&cc=5901 Report: Heerenveen v AZ – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN FC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  Altidore had to wait until February 8, 2012 to score his next league goal, grabbing a brace in a 6–0 win over ADO Den Haag.<ref>http://www.soccerway.com/news/2012/February/08/eredivisie-ado-den-haag-0-az-alkmaar-6/</ref>  The result put AZ level on points with PSV at the top of the table.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=321748&cc=5901 Report: ADO Den Haag v AZ – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN FC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Altidore headed in the winning goal against [[VVV Venlo]] on Sunday April 22 to keep AZ second in the table and their title hopes still alive.<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=321648&cc=5901 Report: AZ v VVV Venlo – Dutch Eredivisie – ESPN FC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Altidore led the team in scoring in his first campaign with 22 goals across all competitions.  He finished tied for seventh in the Eredivisie in goals scored.  Altidore credits his successful campaign to his new coach, manager Gertjan Verbeek.<ref name="Fox Soccer - Altidore finding peace in Holland">{{cite web|last=Galarcep|first=Ives|title=Altidore finding peace in Holland|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/foxsoccer/usa/story/jozy-altidore-united-states-az-alkmaar-starting-to-deliver-062112|publisher=Fox Soccer|accessdate=June 22, 2012}}</ref>

====2012–13====
In the opening game of the new [[2012–13 Eredivisie|Eredivisie]] campaign, Altidore scored a quick brace as AZ drew 2–2 with reigning champions [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] on August 12, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/3cfc29e7a611436eba2db85b332ea0de/SOC--Euro-Rdp|title=US striker Jozy Altidore scores twice for AZ against Ajax in 2–2 draw as season opens |publisher=The Republic |date=August 12, 2012}}</ref>  Altidore continued his impressive start to the league campaign, netting another brace in the club's 3–1 victory over [[SC Heracles]] on the second weekend of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/1137438/jozy-altidore-scores-two-more-goals-for-az-alkmaar?cc=5901|title=Jozy Altidore scores twice for AZ |publisher=ESPNFC |date=19 August 2012}}</ref>  Following the international break, Altidore scored the first [[Hat-trick#Association football|hat-trick]] of his club career on September 16, helping AZ to a 4–0 defeat of [[Roda JC Kerkrade|Roda JC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/gamecast/statistics/id/343519/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=AZ 4 – 0 Roda JC Kerkrade |publisher=ESPNFC |date=September 16, 2012}}</ref>

Altidore powered his team to just their fourth victory in 17 games, and their first since October 28, netting a brace in a 2–1 defeat of [[PEC Zwolle]] on December 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eredivisielive.nl/wedstrijd/1697277 |title=Wedstrijdverslag PEC Zwolle – AZ &#124; Seizoen 2012/2013 |publisher=Eredivisie Live |language=Dutch |date=December 15, 2012 }}</ref>  In the first game of 2013, Altidore hammered home 3 for the hat-trick against [[Vitesse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.yahoo.com/news/jozy-altidore-nets-hat-trick-221700641--sow.html |title=Jozy Altidore Nets Hat Trick |publisher=Yahoo |date=January 19, 2012 }}</ref>

On April 14, Altidore netted his third hat-trick of the season in a 6–0 victory over [[FC Utrecht]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/66/united-states/2013/04/14/3902735/altidore-nets-hat-trick-against-utrecht?source=breakingnews&ICID=HP_BN_9 |title=Altidore nets hat trick against Utrecht |publisher=Goal.com |date=April 14, 2013 }}</ref> On 9 May, he scored the winning goal against [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] in the [[2012–13 KNVB Cup|KNVB Cup]] final, helping AZ to lift the Dutch Cup for the first time in 31 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=2076563.html |title=Alkmaar edge PSV to lift cup |publisher=FIFA |date=May 9, 2013 |accessdate=May 21, 2013 }}</ref>  Subsequently Altidore became the first-ever American to be named in [[De Telegraaf]]'s "Team of the Season" after finishing with 23 goals in the Eredivisie and 8 in the KNVB Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/05/14/american-exports-jozy-altidore-becomes-first-american-named-dutch-team-seaso?utm_source=Outbrain&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=USMNT |title=American Exports: Jozy Altidore becomes first American named to Dutch Team of the Season |publisher=MLS |date=May 14, 2013 |accessdate=May 21, 2013 }}</ref>

===Sunderland===
[[File:Jozy Altifore Sunderland.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Altidore playing for Sunderland in 2013]]
On July 5, 2013, AZ agreed to sell Altidore's contract to English [[Premier League]] club [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jozyaltidore.com/news_media/breaking-news-altidore-heading-back-to-epl-gets-transfer-to-sunderland |title=ALTIDORE HEADING BACK TO EPL, GETS TRANSFER TO SUNDERLAND |publisher=Jeremy D. Pond |date =July 5, 2013 |accessdate=July 5, 2012 }}</ref> with whom he signed a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2013/july/di-canio-swoops-for-altidore |title=Di Canio gets his man |publisher=Sunderland A.F.C |date =July 9, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013 }}</ref> It was eventually reported that Sunderland paid AZ a $13&nbsp;million transfer fee.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com/2015/01/16/has-jozy-altidores-premier-league-legacy-damaged-reputation-of-us-players |title=Has Jozy Altidore’s Premier League legacy damaged reputation of US players? |publisher=[[NBC Sports]] |date=January 27, 2015 |accessdate=January 27, 2015}}</ref>  Altidore's first goal for Sunderland came on August 27, 2013, spurring a dramatic late comeback in the [[2013–14 Football League Cup|League Cup]], defeating [[MK Dons]] 4-2.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23764127
|title=Sunderland 4 - 2 MK Dons
|publisher=[[BBC]]
|date=August 27, 2013 |accessdate=August 27, 2013}}</ref> In Altidore's first [[Tyne-Wear derby]], he put in a man of the match performance in a 2–1 win. On December 4, 2013, Altidore scored his first league goal for Sunderland to give them a 1–0 lead against Chelsea, a game which eventually finished 3–4. After failing to find the net again for Sunderland, Altidore was dropped to the Sunderland Under 21s instead of playing against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on April 7, 2014.<ref>altidore-on-u21-duty-while-first-team-are-at-white-hart-lane-1-6547497</ref>

Altidore ended the 2013–14 season with two goals in 37 appearances, and by October 2014, he had made just six appearances and scored one goal. Altidore told reporters, "If it doesn’t turn around then in January I’ll be looking to start elsewhere" to stay in the United States national team picture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com/2014/10/08/jozy-on-the-move-altidore-open-to-club-switch-in-january-transfer-window/|title=Jozy On The Move? Altidore open to club switch in January transfer window|date=October 8, 2014|publisher=Pro Soccer Talk|first=Mike|last=Prindville}}</ref>

Altidore left Sunderland in January 2015 for [[Toronto FC]] of [[Major League Soccer]]. He finished his stay with three goals in 52 appearances in all competitions and one goal in 42 league games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/altidore-joins-toronto-fc-from-sunderland-in-swap-deal-with-defoe-011615|title=Altidore joins Toronto FC from Sunderland in swap deal with Defoe|date=January 16, 2015|work=Sky Sports}}</ref>

===Toronto FC===
In January 2015, Sunderland agreed to send Altidore and an undisclosed fee to [[Toronto FC]] of [[Major League Soccer]] in exchange for [[Jermain Defoe]]. Toronto used its allocation spot and signed Altidore to a [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Player contract]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/01/16/toronto-fc-acquire-us-international-jozy-altidore-allocation-jermain-defoe|title=Toronto FC acquire US international Jozy Altidore via Allocation, send Jermain Defoe to Sunderland|date=January 16, 2015|publisher=MLSsoccer.com}}</ref> The [[New York Red Bulls]], his former MLS team, were the league's preferred destination for Altidore, and tried to move up the allocation order through a trade with the [[Montreal Impact]], who held the first allocation spot. However, Toronto was unwilling to accept the cash settlement from New York that was also required for the move.<ref>{{cite news | title = Sources: Altidore will join Toronto FC; latest on TFC's pursuit of Giovinco | publisher = TSN |  url = http://www.tsn.ca/sources-altidore-will-join-toronto-fc-latest-on-tfc-s-pursuit-of-giovinco-1.182800   accessdate = 2015-01-19 | first = Gareth | last = Wheeler | date = January 14, 2015}}</ref> Altidore said his [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] teammate [[Michael Bradley (soccer)|Michael Bradley]], who himself joined Toronto the previous season after playing in Europe, recruited him, and Bradley was seen on camera talking to Altidore about the club in July 2014, during the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Toronto FC manage to land Jozy Altidore with an assist from US national teammate Michael Bradley | publisher = MLSsoccer.com | url = http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/01/18/toronto-fc-manage-land-jozy-altidore-assist-us-national-teammate-michael-bra# | accessdate = 2015-01-19 | first = Armen | last = Bedakian | date = January 18, 2015}}</ref> On his return to MLS, Altidore scored twice in his first game for Toronto, a 3&ndash;1 victory away to the [[Vancouver Whitecaps]] to start the [[2015 Major League Soccer season|2015 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/sports/tfc/2015/03/07/toronto-fc-defeats-vancouver-in-season-opener.html|title= Toronto FC defeats Vancouver in season opener Jozy Altidore scores twice and Robbie Findley adds one in 3-1 victory over Whitecaps.|last= Clipperton |first= Joshua |date=7 March 2015|publisher=Toronto Star|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:Jermaine Jones and Jozy Altidore vs Belgium.jpg|thumbnail|right|Altidore (right) and Jermaine Jones (left) playing for the USA national team in a friendly against Belgium]]

In the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] held in Canada, Altidore finished tied third in overall scoring with four goals. He scored three in the first round,  one vs. Poland in Montreal and two vs. Brazil in Ottawa, and added a fourth goal vs. Austria in the quarterfinals in Toronto.

On March 28, 2009, Altidore scored his first away goal in World Cup Qualifying in the 2–2 draw with [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]]. On April 1, 2009, Altidore scored three goals in a 3–0 victory over [[Trinidad and Tobago national football team|Trinidad and Tobago]], making Altidore the youngest American to score a [[hat-trick]] in an international game.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=U.S. 3–0 T&T: Altidore hits hat trick |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=262890&cc=5901 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=April 1, 2008 |accessdate=April 1, 2008 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>

On June 24, 2009, Altidore scored in the semi-final of the [[2009 FIFA Confederations Cup]] against [[Spain national football team|Spain]], turning club teammate Joan Capdevilla to get a clear shot on Iker Casillas' goal. The U.S. went on to defeat the Spanish team, 2–0.<ref name="confedcup"/>

Altidore suffered a hamstring injury at the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Altidore to miss remainder of Gold Cup with injury |url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2011-06-22-3320144671_x.htm |publisher=[[USA Today]] |date=June 22, 2011 |accessdate=June 23, 2011 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>

On June 2, 2013, Altidore ended an almost two year scoring drought by sinking the first goal in an international friendly against [[Germany]].  He subsequently scored in his next two international games against [[Jamaica]] and [[Panama]], marking the first time that he has scored in three consecutive international games. Altidore then went on to score in a fourth consecutive game against Honduras in a World Cup Qualification match on June 18. Scoring in four consecutive matches tied Altidore all-time for most consecutive games with a goal by any USMNT player, joining a select group of players that includes Landon Donovan, Eddie Johnson, Erik Wynalda, and William Lubbe.<ref>http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/06/19/jozy-altidores-history-making-strike-icing-cake-remarkable-season</ref>

On August 14, 2013, Altidore scored a hat-trick in the United States' 4-3 comeback win over [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]], notably scoring from a free kick just outside the box with a curling effort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=soccer&id=9568339 |title=Altidore's hat trick leads US to 4-3 win vs Bosnia |publisher=ESPN |date=August 14, 2013 |accessdate=August 14, 2013 }}</ref> Altidore's three goals and an assist stretched his consecutive game scoring streak to 5 games, the most in U.S. national team history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2013/08/jozy-altidore-usmnt-bosnia-usa-soccer-hat-trick-comeback/ |title=Jozy Altidore breaks U.S. record with amazing hat trick |publisher=USA Today |date=August 14, 2013 |accessdate=August 14, 2013 }}</ref> On June 7, 2014, Altidore broke his goal-scoring drought with two goals against [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]], the defending [[Africa Cup of Nations]] champions.

On June 16, 2014, in the United States' opening [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] match against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]], Altidore injured a hamstring and had to be carried from the field.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/17/usa-ghana-jozy-altidore-world-cup|title= Victory over Ghana, agony over Altidore: America wakes up to the World Cup|date=17 June 2014|work=Guardian |accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref>

==Personal==
In 2007, Altidore was a candidate for [[ESPN]]'s Next Award and is one of the stars featured in [[Adidas]]' "[[Adidas#"Impossible is Nothing"|Impossible is Nothing]]" advertisements. Altidore is featured on the cover of the North American version of ''[[FIFA 08]]'' by [[EA Sports]], alongside [[Ronaldinho]] and [[Guillermo Ochoa]].<ref>[http://ps3.ign.com/articles/811/811327p1.html IGN: Jozy Altidore Talks FIFA 08<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Following the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], Altidore joined the relief effort by asking people to donate to Yéle Haiti.<ref>[http://www.yanks-abroad.com/get.php?mode=content&id=5695 Yanks Abroad (14 January 2010) "Altidore Calling on Fans for Haiti"]</ref>  He appeared on [[CNN]] to discuss his family members still living in [[Haiti]] and to encourage people to give money.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/sports/2010/01/14/mckay.haiti.jozy.altidore.intv.cnn?iref=allsearch CNN (14 January 2010) "Jozy Altidore on Haiti"]</ref>

In honour of the 26 victims of the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]] a week earlier, Altidore wrote their names on the boots he wore in the game against [[FC Twente]] on December 21, 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1273689/jozy-altidore-pays-tribute-to-school-victims?cc=5739 |title=Jozy Altidore pays tribute to victims |agency=Associated Press |work=ESPN FC |date=December 22, 2012 |accessdate=May 23, 2014}}</ref>

'''Omatsone "Sone" Aluko''' (born 19 February 1989) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]. He can also play as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]].

Aluko began his career at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] but failed to make any league appearances. He joined Aberdeen on loan in the 2007–08 season and was loaned to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at the beginning of the 2008–09 season. After just one appearance for Blackpool, he signed for Aberdeen permanently in August 2008. He left Aberdeen in July 2011 at the end of his contract. Aluko signed for [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in November 2011 and scored 12 goals in 21 appearances during the 2011–12 season. He became a [[free agent]] after his contract expired.

Born in England, Aluko was [[cap (sports)|capped]] by England at all levels up to [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] before accepting an offer to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]].

==Club career==

===Birmingham City===
Aluko was born in London<ref name=AFC090526>{{cite web |url=http://www.afc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/clubNewsDetail/0,,10284~1667288,00.html |title=Dons Ace Receives |publisher=[[Aberdeen F.C.]] |date=26 May 2009 |accessdate=26 May 2009}}</ref> and brought up from a young age in [[Birmingham]]. He progressed through [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]'s youth system, which he joined at the age of eight.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blues.premiumtv.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10412~35471,00.html |title=Player profiles: Sone Aluko |publisher=[[Birmingham City F.C.]] |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> He was given a first-team squad number in the [[FA Premier League 2005-06|2005–06 season]], and was an unused [[substitute (football)|substitute]] in the [[Premier League]] match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at [[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury]] in October 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4277850.stm |title=Arsenal 1–0 Birmingham |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=2 October 2005 |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> He made his first-team debut for Birmingham on 28 August 2007 as a late substitute in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6963483.stm |title=Birmingham 2–1 Hereford |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=28 August 2007 |accessdate=13 September 2007}}</ref>

====Aberdeen (loan)====

In August 2007, Aluko joined [[Scottish Premier League]] club [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] on loan until January 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aberdeen/6969302.stm |title=Dons bring in two young strikers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 August 2007 |accessdate=31 August 2007}}</ref> He made his debut for Aberdeen as a late substitute in the [[UEFA Cup 2007-08|UEFA Cup]] group match against [[Panathinaikos FC|Panathinaikos]] on 25 October 2007. He scored his first goal for the club the following week, opening the scoring in a 2–0 victory over [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/7074113.stm |title=Aberdeen 2–0 Dundee United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=3 November 2007}}</ref> The loan deal was extended to keep Aluko at Aberdeen for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aberdeen/7188521.stm |title=Aberdeen extend Aluko loan deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 January 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2008 }}</ref> In February 2008, as part of a performance which earned him the man-of-the-match award, he scored Aberdeen's second goal in a 2–2 draw against [[FC Bayern Munich]] in the UEFA Cup Round of 32.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7236397.stm |title=Aberdeen 2–2 Bayern Munich |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2008 |first=Julian |last=Taylor}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:LTIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11EDAE9E83954450&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815 |title=Aberdeen want more of same from youngsters |last=Gilfeather |first=Frank |format=reprint hosted at NewsBank |work=[[The Times]] |date=16 February 2008 |accessdate=18 June 2008 |location=London}}</ref>

====Blackpool (loan)====
Aluko signed for [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on a month's emergency loan on 8 August 2008,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11688_3957706,00.html |title=Aluko joins Blackpool |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=9 August 2008 |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref> and made his debut the following day as a late substitute in the Seasiders' 1–0 home defeat to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7540942.stm |title=Blackpool 0–1 Bristol City |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=9 August 2008 |accessdate=1 September 2008}}</ref>

===Aberdeen===
[[File:Sone Aluko Hull City v. Aberdeen 1.png|thumb|left|200px|Aluko playing for [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] in 2009]]
On [[transfer window|transfer deadline day]], 1 September 2008, Aluko returned to Aberdeen on a permanent basis, signing a three-year contract for a fee of £50,000 with the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/clubNewsDetail/0,,10284~1381890,00.html |title=Aluko rejoins Dons |publisher=[[Aberdeen F.C.]] |date=1 September 2008 |accessdate=1 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blues.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1381978,00.html |title=Aluko joins the Dons |publisher=[[Birmingham City F.C.]] |date=1 September 2008 |accessdate=1 September 2008}}</ref> He made his return in a 2–1 home defeat to [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton]] on 13 September,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/7611539.stm |title=Aberdeen 1–2 Hamilton Accies |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=13 September 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> and scored his first goal since rejoining the club to clinch Aberdeen's first home win of the season, a single-goal victory over [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] on 1 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/7701221.stm |title=Aberdeen 1–0 Kilmarnock |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=1 November 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> Aluko went on to win the [[Scottish Premier League|SPL]] Young Player of the Month award for November 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aberdeen/7772986.stm|title=Aluko named young player of month |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 November 2008 |accessdate=17 December 2008}}</ref> In September 2009, the tabloid press reported that he had put his Aberdeen future in jeopardy by going to play in the [[2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup]], against the wishes of manager [[Mark McGhee]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/sport/spl/2641124/Alukos-gone-AWOL.html |title=Aluko gone AWOL |work=[[The Scottish Sun]] |date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=17 September 2008 |location=London |first=Ronnie |last=MacKay}}</ref> He left the club at the end of his contract in July 2011.

===Rangers===
Following his release from Aberdeen, Aluko had a trial with [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://m.stv.tv/sport/football/scottish-premier/aberdeen/266152-sone-aluko/|title=Sone Aluko offered trial with Italian giants Juventus |date=13 August 2011 |accessdate=13 August 2011 |publisher=STV}}</ref> He then went on trial at [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15721331.stm |title=Sone Aluko begins trial with Rangers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 November 2011 |accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> Rangers were impressed with Aluko and offered him a contract, but the move was held up while Aberdeen and Rangers negotiated compensation.<ref name = "signed"/> Aluko signed for Rangers until the end of the season on 24 November 2011 after a deal was agreed.<ref name = "signed">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15721331.stm|title=Rangers sign Aluko after agreeing compensation with Aberdeen |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2011 |accessdate=24 November 2011}}</ref>

Aluko was banned for two games for diving to win a penalty in the Rangers-[[Dunfermline F.C.|Dunfermline]] game of 3 December 2011. Rangers' manager, [[Ally McCoist]], stated "The three gentlemen on the panel have effectively called my player a cheat and a liar, neither of which he is".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16091669.stm|title=Rangers manager furious at Sone Aluko simulation ban|publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 December 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2012}}</ref> On 25 March 2012, Aluko scored the opening goal in Rangers' 3–2 victory over [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17419735 | title=Rangers stun nine-man Celtic in thriller | publisher=BBC Sport | date=25 March 2012 | accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref> He scored a hat-trick for Rangers in a 4–0 victory at [[St. Johnstone F.C.|St. Johnstone]] on the final day of the [[2011–12 Scottish Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/sport/spl/4392412/Yanks-in-the-race-for-Aluko.html|title=Yanks in the race for Aluko |first=Robert|last=Grieve|work=The Scottish Sun|publisher=News International|date=25 June 2012|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref>

In June 2012, with his contract set to expire but the club holding an option to extend it, Aluko lodged an objection against the contract being transferred from Rangers to a new company set up by Charles Green.<ref name = "newco">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18560798|title=Rangers: Sone Aluko & Rhys McCabe oppose newco transfer|publisher=BBC Sport |first=Alasdair|last=Lamont|date=23 June 2012|accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref> [[PFA Scotland]] had previously commented that players were entitled to become [[free agent]]s if they objected to the transfer.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18446597 | title=Rangers: Players free not to join 'newco' says law expert | publisher=BBC Sport | date=14 June 2012 | accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref>

Aluko has raised a constructive dismissal claim against Rangers.<ref>{{ Cite news | url=http://local.stv.tv/glasgow/205234-sixty-seven-players-take-legal-action-over-rangers-contract-transfer/| title=Sixty-seven players 'in legal action' over Rangers contract transfer | publisher=STV Sport| date=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{ Cite news | url=https://www.rangersshareoffer.com/Prospectus.pdf | title=Rangers International Football Club plc | publisher=Rangersshareoffer.com | date=8 December 2012}}</ref>

===Hull City===

====2012–13====
[[File:Sone Aluko 1.png|thumb|200px|Aluko playing for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in 2012]]
On 25 July 2012, it was confirmed Aluko signed a two-year deal with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/aluko-deal-completed-265401.aspx|title=Aluko Deal Completed|publisher=Hull City A.F.C |date=25 July 2012|accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref>
He made his debut in the home match against [[Brighton and Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton and Hove Albion]] on 18 August 2012.<ref name="Hull 1&nbsp;– 0 Brighton">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221481| title = Hull 1&nbsp;– 0 Brighton| date = 18 August 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 18 August 2012}}</ref> On 1 September 2012 he scored his first goal for the club against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] at the [[KC Stadium]].<ref name="Hull 3&nbsp;– 1 Bolton">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19378191| title = Hull 3&nbsp;– 1 Bolton| date = 1 September 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 1 September 2012}}</ref> After the international break, Aluko scored his second goal for Hull City in the following game against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] to make it 4–0 before half time.<ref name="Hull 4&nbsp;– 1 Millwall">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19528046| title = Hull 4&nbsp;– 1 Millwall| date = 15 September 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 15 September 2012}}</ref> On 2 October, Aluko made it 3 in the Hull City shirt by scoring a wonderful strike from 20 yards out into the top corner against Blackpool.<ref name="Hull 2&nbsp;– 3 Blackpool">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19709705| title = Hull 2&nbsp;– 3 Blackpool| date = 2 October 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 2 October 2012}}</ref> His next goal came at the end of October against Bristol City. Himself and Jay Simpson linked up to put Hull 1–0 ahead inside 8 minutes, to which the commentator compared the goal to Barcelona.<ref name="Bristol City 1&nbsp;– 2 Hull">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20014260| title = Bristol City 1&nbsp;– 2 Hull| date = 27 October 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 27 October 2012}}</ref> He bagged another in the next game, at home to Barnsley. Team mate Ahmed Elmohamady's cross was half-cleared and Aluko, unlike Barnsley's defenders, was alert to the ball and fired home from a tight angle.<ref name="Hull 1&nbsp;– 0 Barnsley">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20107284| title = Hull 1&nbsp;– 0 Barnsley| date = 3 November 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 3 November 2012}}</ref> He then made it 3 in 3 and 6 goals for the season against Wolverhampton Wanderers, putting in a free-kick from 25 yards into the bottom-left corner past Wolves' Goalkeeper, Carl Ikeme.<ref name="Hull 2&nbsp;– 1 Wolves">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20134322| title = Hull 2&nbsp;– 1 Wolves| date = 6 November 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 6 November 2012}}</ref> On 17 November, Aluko scored twice against former club Birmingham City to put Hull 0–2 up, they went on to win the game 2–3.<ref name="Birmingham 2&nbsp;– 3 Hull">{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20278453| title = Birmingham 2&nbsp;– 3 Hull| date = 17 November 2012| work = BBC Sport| publisher = BBC| accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref> This made it five goals in five games for Aluko and eight goals for the season. In November 2012, Aluko picked up an Achilles injury, initially ruling him out for a month, which Hull City incidentally won all four games he was missing, but later in January the injury flared up again. This meant Sone would require surgery, with fears he would be out for 6 months, but after successful surgery, he was expected to be back in 2 months time.

====2013–14====
Aluko's first goal of the season, a 76th-minute "stunning volley", was Hull's winner in a 3–2 victory away to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 21 September.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24089824 |title=Newcastle 2–3 Hull City |first=Ian |last=Woodcock |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 September 2013 |accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> In November Steve Bruce announced that Aluko denied a contract extension, this blow to Hull came shortly after Aluko tore his Achilles again which would see him out of action until February. He signed a new two-and-a-half-year contract with the club on 3 January 2014, on the contract extension Aluko told the club website "I'm happy to be extending my stay here and I was always hopeful it would get sorted".<ref>{{cite web|title=Sone Aluko: Hull City forward extends Tigers contract|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25592339|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 January 2014|accessdate=4 January 2014}}</ref> On 17 May 2014 he played as a substitute in the [[2014 FA Cup Final]] against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27354148|title=Arsenal 3-2 Hull|date=17 May 2014|accessdate=18 May 2014|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>

==International career==

===England Youth===
Aluko represented England at under-16, under-17 and under-18 level before making his debut for the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19 team]] on 11 September 2007 in a friendly against [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] under-19.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players?p=332422 |title=Sone Aluko |publisher=[[The Football Association]] (The FA) |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> He was involved in two of the goals in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:NEPB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11BAC4EA70124A28&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815 |title=That's the way to clinch it, Magpies |newspaper=[[Nottingham Evening Post]] |format=reprint hosted at [[NewsBank]] |date=12 September 2007 |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> He was selected in the 23-man provisional squad for the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~1329847,00.html |title=Duo Called Up By Young Lions |publisher=[[Birmingham City F.C]] |date=17 June 2008 |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> but did not make the final 18.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.uefa.com/MultimediaFiles/Download/Publications/uefa/UEFAMedia/75/74/64/757464_DOWNLOAD.pdf |format=PDF |page=30 |title=UEFA Under19 Championship Technical Report |publisher=[[UEFA]] |year=2008 |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref>

===Nigeria===

Aluko was named in the squad for the Nigeria under 20 natonal football team for the [[2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in Egypt. He played in games against Venezuela, Spain and Tahiti.<ref>{{cite web|title=Technical Report and Statistics|url=http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/afdeveloping/technicaldevp/01/14/20/86/u20report_v2.pdf|publisher=FIFA.com|accessdate=7 July 2014|page=144|date=2009}}</ref>

Aluko was called up to the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigerian national team]] for a [[exhibition game|friendly]] against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] on 29 May 2009,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.completesportsnigeria.com/details.php?category=news&id=8281 |title=Amodu Lists Four New Players For Exhibition Game |work=Complete Sports |location=Nigeria |date=25 May 2009 |accessdate=26 May 2009}}</ref> an offer which with the support of his family he chose to accept.<ref name=AFC090526/> He made his full international debut in the starting eleven, forcing the Irish goalkeeper to save his 40-yard lobbed free kick and playing the first 61 minutes of the game.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3126020,00.html |title=Keane strike seals draw |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=30 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_facts/0,19762,11065_3126020,00.html |title=Match facts |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=30 May 2009}}</ref>

In April 2010, he was named in the provisional Nigeria squad for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kickoff.com/news/14936/utaka-gets-nigeria-recall.php |title=Utaka gets Nigeria recall |publisher= Kickoff.com |date=22 April 2010 |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> but failed to make the final cut. He was finally called up by current Nigerian coach Stephen Keshi and therefore has a chance to add to his one cap against Republic of Ireland in May 2009 after he represented England at various age-group levels. He was brought into the squad to face Namibia and Malawi in the World Cup Qualifiers in the month of June 2012, but was an unused sub for both games.

Aluko was included in a pre-selection for the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations]] but had to renounce because of an injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nigerianwatch.com/news/954-achilles-injury-rules-sone-aluko-out-of-nations-cup|title=Achilles injury rules Sone Aluko out of Nations Cup|publisher= Nigerianwatch.com |date=12 November 2012 |accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref> Nigeria later won the tournament. 

He scored his first goals for Nigeria against South Africa in a 2–2 draw on 19 November 2014 in the qualifying round for the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations]].<ref name="2015 Nations Cup: Nigeria fail to qualify for finals">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30095082|title=2015 Nations Cup: Nigeria fail to qualify for finals|date=19 November 2014|accessdate=19 November 2014|publisher=BBC|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Aluko's older sister, [[Eniola Aluko|Eniola]], is also a footballer who has played for [[England women's national football team|England women's football team]] over 70 times at full international level; she has played in two [[FIFA Women's World Cup|World Cup]] quarter finals and reached the quarter finals of the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012 Olympics]] soccer tournament with [[Great Britain women's Olympic football team|Great Britain]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1426718.html |title=Female stars keeping it in the family |publisher=FIFA |date=29 April 2011 |accessdate=26 March 2012}}</ref> His father is a former [[Member of Parliament|MP]] in Nigeria,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/4547911.stm|title=Eniola will not fly|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 May 2005|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> while [[Bolaji Aluko]], a chemical engineering professor, is his uncle.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nigerianmuse.com/20080723040837zg/sections/sports/eniola-aluko-goal-poacher-and-brilliant-lawyer/|title=Eniola Aluko: Goal Poacher And Brilliant Lawyer|publisher=Nigerian Muse|date=23 July 2008|accessdate=22 September 2013|first=Tunde |last=Adekeye}}</ref>

'''Ricardo Gabriel "Ricky" Álvarez''' ({{IPA-es| riˈkarðo ɣaˈβɾjel ˈalβaɾes}}; born 12 April 1988) is an Argentine professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] for English club [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on loan from [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]].

==Club career==

===Early career===

As a child, Álvarez played [[papi fut]] for Caballito Juniors and Club Parque, and then had a brief stay in [[Boca Juniors]] youth divisions.<ref name=goal>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/es-us/news/2214/mercado/2011/04/15/2442618/talentos-de-exportaci%C3%B3n-ricky-%C3%A1lvarez-la-magia-polifuncional-que- |title=Talentos de Exportación: Ricky Álvarez, la magia polifuncional que necesita Europa |author=Martín Manrupe |publisher=Goal.com |language=Spanish |date=2011-04-15 |accessdate=2011-05-23 }}</ref>

===Club Atlético Vélez Sársfield===

Álvarez played his first professional game with [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield|Vélez Sársfield]] in 2008. Following his debut, he suffered a [[knee]] [[cruciate ligament]] injury that stalled his progression on the first team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infovelez.com.ar/nota3665.htm |title=En Vélez siempre se tiene que pelear todo |author=Rubén David Oliva |publisher=Diario Infovelez |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-07-10 }}</ref> He then was part of the [[2008–09 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|2009 Clausura]] winning squad, playing only 18 minutes in the 1–0 victory over [[Gimnasia y Esgrima de Jujuy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ricardo Álvarez 2009 Clausura stats |publisher=Fútbol Pasión |url=http://www.futbolpasion.com/jugador_presencias.cfm?id=ravz&Campeonato=cl09&Equipo=vel |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-07-11 }}</ref>

The midfielder's breakthrough with the team finally came during the [[2009–10 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|2010 Clausura]], in which Vélez, forced by the tight fixture of the [[2010 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores]], played mostly with substitutes. He scored his first goal in a 1–2 defeat to [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]] at the [[Estadio Monumental Antonio Vespucio Liberti|Estadio Monumental]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Buonanotte volvió al gol y fue el héroe del triunfo de River |newspaper=TyC Sports |date=2010-04-30 |url=http://www.tycsports.com/notas/55557-buonanotte-volvio-al-gol-y-fue-el-heroe-del-triunfo-river |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref> and received his first red card from referee Javier Collado in Vélez' 1–3 defeat to [[Racing Club de Avellaneda|Racing]], for complaining about a yellow card. He totalled 11 matches during the tournament (4 as a starter), and 1 goal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.argentinesoccer.com/player_apps.cfm?id=ravz&Championship=cl10&Team=vel |title=Closing '10 statistics |publisher=Argentine Soccer |accessdate=2011-05-23 }}</ref>

Álvarez then played 15 games (2 starts) during Vélez' runner-up [[2010–11 Argentine Primera División season#Torneo Apertura|2010 Apertura]] campaign.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.argentinesoccer.com/player_apps.cfm?id=ravz&Championship=ap10&Team=vel |title=Opening '10 statistics |publisher=Argentine Soccer |language=Spanish |accessdate=2011-05-23 }}</ref> He also scored his second professional goal in his team's 1–0 home victory over [[Club Atlético Lanús|Lanús]] for the 14th fixture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canchallena.com/1324714-aprovecho-su-oportunidad-velez-gano-y-se-trepo-a-la-punta |title=Aprovechó su oportunidad: Vélez ganó y se trepó a la punta |newspaper=Cancha Llena |language=Spanish |date=2010-11-14 |accessdate=2010-11-14 }}</ref>

During the first semester of 2011, Álvarez got significant fan and media praise for his [[2010–11 Argentine Primera División season#Torneo Clausura|league]] and [[2011 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores]]' games. He also showed versatility by playing all the positions of the midfield.<ref name=goal/> During that semester, he helped his team win the 2011 Clausura and reach the semi-finals of the Copa Libertadores.

===Internazionale===

On 5 July 2011, Álvarez joined Italian club [[Inter Milan|F.C. Internazionale Milano]] for a €12.8 million fee, for 90% of his transfer rights.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canchallena.com/1387046-ricky-a-inter |title=Ricky Alvarez, el nuevo argentino de Inter |newspaper=[[La Nación|Cancha Llena]] |language=Spanish |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2011-07-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.velezsarsfield.com.ar/futbol/notas/2011/07/05/215203.html |title=La Maravilla se muda a Italia |publisher=Club Atlético Vélez Sársfield |language=Spanish |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2011-07-06 }}</ref> He debuted officially for his club in the [[2011 Supercoppa Italiana]] defeat to [[A.C. Milan|Milan]]. Under the coaching of [[Claudio Ranieri]], Álvarez began to establish himself in the team as he show he can play as a trequartista. His first official goal for Inter came against [[Trabzonspor]] on November 22, 2011 after a neat one-two with international teammate [[Diego Milito]]. He scored again in his side's 4–1 victory over [[U.S. Lecce|Lecce]], a tap in from a well worked cross by [[Yuto Nagatomo]].

He scored his first goal for Inter in 2013 against [[Catania Calcio|Catania]] in a 3–2 comeback win. He scored two goals on 7 April against [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]], although Inter lost that match 3–4 in the [[San Siro]]. Ten days later in a [[2012–13 Coppa Italia|Coppa Italia]] match at the San Siro, he scored again against [[A.S. Roma|Roma]], but Inter lost the match 2-3. On 5 May Álvarez scored from a penalty kick against [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] at the [[Stadio San Paolo]] but his team lost 3–1. Álvarez scored his 10th goal for Inter three days later  against [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] and missed a penalty kick, as Inter lost 1–3.

===Sunderland===

Sunderland signed Alvarez on September deadline day 2014. Alvarez initially signed on loan with a view to a permanent switch if Sunderland avoided relegation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland sign Sebastian Coates & Ricardo Alvarez on deadline day|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29012722|accessdate=13 September 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 September 2014}}</ref> Alvarez made his [[Premier League]] debut on 13 September 2014, playing 65 minutes in a 2-2 draw against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C|Tottenham]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland 2-2 Tottenham |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29090585|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 September 2014}}</ref>  He scored his first goal on 3 February 2015 in a 3-1 win against [[Fulham F.C|Fulham]] in an [[FA Cup]] fourth-round replay.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 1-3 Sunderland |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30991113|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 February 2015}}</ref> 

==International career==
On 18 August 2011, Álvarez was called for the first time to the [[Argentina national football team]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afa.org.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14876:lista-de-convocados-para-los-amistosos-ante-venezuela-y-costa-rica&catid=164:seleccion-mayor&Itemid=66 |title=Lista de convocados para los amistosos ante Venezuela y Nigeria |publisher=[[Argentine Football Association|AFA]] |language=Spanish |date=2011-08-18 |accessdate=2011-08-20 }}</ref> 
He made his debut on 2 September 2011 against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] in [[Exhibition game|Friendly]] match. Four days later played Álvarez another [[Exhibition game|Friendly]] match against [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]]. He made another appearance in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|2014 World Cup qualification]] match against [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia.]]

On 2 June 2014, Álvarez was called up for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].

==Honours==

'''Afonso Alves Martins Júnior''' (born 30 January 1981), known as simply '''Afonso Alves''', is a [[Brazil]]ian [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)|striker]]. 
Alves enjoyed the most successful period of his career playing at [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] in the Dutch [[Eredivisie]], where his goal-to-game ratio was higher than a goal a game. This precipitated a club record move to [[Football in England|English]] club [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in January 2008. Alves has been [[cap (sport)|capped]] for [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] on eight occasions.

==Early life==
Alves was born on 30 January 1981, in [[Belo Horizonte]], Brazil's third biggest city. He was brought up by his mother, Dona Eliade, and has a brother, Alexsander, and sister, Alexandra. His father died when he was nine years old.<ref name="mail interview">{{cite news
|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1078625/EXCLUSIVE-Why-Alves-bringing-boy-Brazil.html
|title=Why Alves will not be bringing over his boy from Brazil
|date=17 October 2008
|accessdate=27 October 2008
|work=Daily Mail |location=UK |first=Colin
|last=Young| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081021085732/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1078625/EXCLUSIVE-Why-Alves-bringing-boy-Brazil.html| archivedate= 21 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

==Club career==

===Early career===
Alves started his career with Brazilian side [[Atlético Mineiro]]. In 2002 he left Atlético Mineiro for the Swedish club [[Örgryte IS|Örgryte]] from [[Göteborg]]. In 2004 he moved to [[Malmö FF]], where he won the [[Allsvenskan|Swedish League]] that year. He stayed for the 2005 season, scoring 14 in 24 games, becoming the club's top-scorer for the second year running when Malmö finished fifth. Alves was at Malmö for the start of the [[2006 Allsvenskan|2006 season]], and scored three goals in seven matches.

===Heerenveen===
[[File:Afonso Alves.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Afonso Alves with Heerenveen]]
In Summer 2006, he moved to the Dutch club [[SC Heerenveen]] of the [[Eredivisie]] for €4.5&nbsp;million, which remains their highest-ever transfer fee paid.

In his first season, he finished as top goalscorer of the [[Eredivisie 2006/2007|Eredivisie]] with 34 goals (in 31 games), which is a club record. Alves is the third Brazilian to become topscorer in the Dutch first division, joining former [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] strikers [[Romário]] and [[Ronaldo]], and the second Brazilian who scored over 30 goals in the same competition, with Ronaldo netting 30 in the 1994–95 season. Other than finishing first in the scorers table, he was runner-up in the race for the [[European Golden Boot]], a single point behind [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] forward [[Francesco Totti]].

On 7 October 2007, in only his second appearance of the season, Alves scored seven goals in his side's 9–0 victory over Eredivisie rivals [[Heracles Almelo]],<ref>{{cite web | title=Report: Heerenveen vs SC Heracles Almelo | publisher=soccernet.com | url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=229746&cc=5901&league=NED.1 | accessdate=31 August 2008 }}</ref> setting a new [[Eredivisie]] record for most goals scored in a single match. Heerenveen's manager (Gert-Jan Verbeek) had already made three substitutions yet chose to take Alves off the pitch in the 89th minute to pay tribute to his fantastic performance.

Despite his impressive track record, his departure was surrounded by some controversy after he did not show up at several training sessions, while still under contract at SC Heerenveen and some remarks he made, insinuating that teammates in the Brazilian national team laughed at him for playing for such a small club.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}

===Middlesbrough===
[[File:Afonso Alves 18-10-2008 1.jpg|thumb|Alves with Middlesbrough]]
In the January transfer window of the 2007-08 season  he moved to [[Premier League]] side [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 31 January 2008. Alves' transfer fee was said to have been €20 million, on a four and a half year contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boro smash transfer record for Alves|publisher=mfc.co.uk|url=http://www.mfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,1~1230553,00.html|accessdate=31 January 2008| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080203164730/http://www.mfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,1~1230553,00.html| archivedate= 3 February 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref>

He made his debut on 9 February, against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] as a second-half substitute for [[Lee Dong-Gook]]. His first Middlesbrough start came on 27 February in an [[FA Cup]] home tie against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], when he was substituted in the 73 minute. Middlesbrough eventually won the game 1–0.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7260417.stm
|title=Middlesbrough 1–0 Sheff Utd (aet)
|date=27 February 2008
|accessdate=27 February 2008
|publisher=BBC Sport 
|first=Phil
|last=McNulty}}</ref>

His first two goals for Middlesbrough came at the [[Riverside Stadium]] on 6 April against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7320230.stm
|title=Middlesbrough 2–2 Man Utd
|date=6 April 2008
|accessdate=11 May 2008
|publisher=BBC Sport 
|first=David
|last=Ornstein| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080411183608/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7320230.stm| archivedate= 11 April 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He finished his first season in England with a hat-trick in an 8–1 home victory against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7381794.stm
|title=Middlesbrough 8–1 Man City
|date=11 May 2008
|accessdate=11 May 2008
|publisher=BBC Sport 
|first=Chris
|last=Bevan| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080512230840/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7381794.stm| archivedate= 12 May 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

Alves' first goal of the 2008–09 season came on 30 August, where he scored a 25-yard free-kick which flew into the top corner of the [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] net.<ref>{{cite web|author=DokterRamses |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hGfVCryGBaw |title=Amazing Free Kick by Afonso Alves‏ |publisher=YouTube |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=7 June 2011| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20110621094156/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hGfVCryGBaw| archivedate= 21 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He then scored goals against Blackburn Rovers and a penalty against Manchester City, two against Barrow and one against local rivals [[Sunderland A.F.C|Sunderland]] with a goal from 18 yards out. However, Alves could not find the form which led to his record move, and with a haul of just four league goals the season turned out to be a disappointing one for both him and Middlesbrough, who were relegated to the Championship.

===Al-Sadd===
On 4 September 2009 Alves moved to Al-Sadd on a three-year deal for £7&nbsp;million.<ref>{{cite web|author=England |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/england/2009/09/05/1482661/afonso-alves-joins-al-sadd-from-middlesbrough |title=Afonso Alves Joins Al-Sadd From Middlesbrough |publisher=Goal.com |date=5 September 2009 |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref> He scored 2 goals in 12 league matches, and scored one goal in the [[Qatari Stars Cup]] after three games. Alves then accepted a loan bid from another [[Qatari League]] club, [[Al Rayyan SC]].

====Al-Rayyan (loan)====
On 31 January 2010, Alves was loaned to the Qatari seven-time league champion [[Al Rayyan SC]], coached by the Brazilian coach [[Paulo Autuori]]. Alves scored 18 goals on his loan spell, 9 of them in seven matches of the [[AFC Cup]], and seven goals in seven league matches. He officially moved to Al-Rayyan in May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al-ahliclub.com/english/viewarticle.php?articleid=2351 |title=Al-Ahli Sports Club :: Al Sadd loan Brazilian Alves to Al-Rayyan in the main transfer of winter |publisher=Al-ahliclub.com |accessdate=7 June 2011| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20110707102129/http://www.al-ahliclub.com/english/viewarticle.php?articleid=2351| archivedate= 7 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

===Al-Rayyan===
[[File:Afonso Alves 2011.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Alves in Al-Rayyan colours]]
Alves officially moved to [[Al Rayyan SC]] for a further two years after winning the [[2010 Emir of Qatar Cup]] with Al Rayyan on the 15th of May, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1211900.html |title=Al Rayyan clinch Emir Cup |publisher=FIFA.com |date=16 May 2010 |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>

Alves shortly emerged as a fan favorite, however he suffered a ligament injury in his left knee in December which kept him out of action for eight months. While recovering, he stated "Offers may’ve come to me during the transfer period, but I never bothered to listen to them and left them all to my agent. While recuperating from surgery, I remained in touch with coach Paulo (Autuori) and the club management, and kept them updated on my progress." He is expected to rejoin Al-Rayyan as their top striker and start the [[2011–12 Qatar Stars League|2011–12]] season in Al-Rayyan's starting eleven.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qfa.com.qa/fit-again-afonso-ready-to-lead-rayyans-challenge.aspx |title=Fit-again Afonso ready to lead Rayyan's challenge  |publisher=QFA.com.qa |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref>

===Al Gharafa===
On 11 September 2012, he signed a 1–year deal with [[Qatar Stars League|QSL]] giants [[Al-Gharafa Sports Club|Al Gharafa]] as their fourth professional player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsl.com.qa/Users/newsen/NewsDetails.aspx?pid=895|title=Al Gharafa sign up Afonso for one season|publisher=[[Qatar Stars League]]|date=11 September 2012|accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref>

==International career==
On 17 May 2007, Alves received his first call-up for the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian national team]] for friendlies against [[England national football team|England]] and [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]].<ref>{{cite news | title=The 'lazy' Brazilian who says he'll catch England napping |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=458867&in_page_id=1779 | accessdate=1 June 2007 | date=31 May 2007}}</ref> On 1 June, in the game against England, Alves was brought on to replace [[Kaká]] after 71 minutes of play and very nearly scored after a [[Wes Brown]] slip. He was also part of the Brazilian squad which won the [[Copa America 2007]] in Venezuela. Alves scored his first international goal on September 12, 2007 against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in a 3–1 win.

==Personal life==
Alves left Brazil as a 21-year-old in 2002 to move to [[Sweden]]. He has a son, Felipe Henrique, who is a footballer at [[Atletico Mineiro]]'s Tupinambas Academy, and lives with Alves' former girlfriend in Brazil.<ref name="mail interview"/>

'''Paulo Lourenço Martins Alves''' (born 10 December 1969) is a Portuguese retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Forward (association football)#Centre forward|centre forward]], and the current [[Coach (sport)|coach]] of [[S.C. Beira-Mar]].

He amassed [[Primeira Liga]] totals of 301 games and 78 goals over the course of 13 seasons, mainly with [[Gil Vicente F.C.|Gil Vicente]] (five years). He also represented in the competition [[C.S. Marítimo]], [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting]] (three apiece) [[U.D. Leiria|União de Leiria]] (two) and [[S.C. Braga|Braga]].

Alves started coaching in 2005 and went on to be in charge of several clubs, including Gil.

==Playing career==
Born in [[Vila Real, Portugal|Vila Real]], Alves moved from local club to [[F.C. Porto]]'s youth ranks at 17, but had no success there, moving to [[Gil Vicente F.C.]] as a member of which he helped [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal]] win the [[1989 FIFA World Youth Championship]] in [[Saudi Arabia]] – in the group stage opener against [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]], he scored a [[Last-minute goal|last minute]] header (his strongest asset) for the game's only goal.<ref>{{FIFA player|160202}}</ref> Later in his career he also managed 14 [[Portugal national football team|full]] [[Cap (sport)|caps]], scoring seven times, all during the [[UEFA Euro 1996]] [[UEFA Euro 1996 qualifying|qualifying stage]] and [[Exhibition game|friendlies]] within that period.

After spells with [[F.C. Tirsense]], [[C.S. Marítimo]] (twice) and [[S.C. Braga|Sporting de Braga]], Alves joined [[Primeira Liga|first division]] giants [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]], being relatively used during his three-year stay. He also played in England with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on [[Loan (association football)|loan]], but managed just four [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] appearances in his three-month stint; upon his return to [[Lisbon]], he notably scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 6–3 win at [[S.C. Campomaiorense]].

Alves then spent two seasons with [[U.D. Leiria|União de Leiria]], netting six times in 27 matches in [[2000–01 Primeira Liga|his last]] to help the club to its best ever top flight finish, a fifth position. His second stint at Gil Vicente saw him finish as the club's top scorer for the [[2001–02 Primeira Liga|2001–02 campaign]], with 11 goals in 27 games; he retired in June 2005, at the age of 35.

==Manager career==
After retiring Alves immediately took up coaching, precisely with the [[Barcelos, Portugal|Barcelos]] outfit. In 2008 he joined another team he played for, Leiria, also in the [[Liga de Honra|second level]].

Due to poor results in the [[2008–09 Liga de Honra|2008–09 season]] Alves was sacked by União de Leiria, but stayed in the category by moving to [[F.C. Vizela]]. In the following summer he rejoined former Sporting teammtate [[Oceano da Cruz|Oceano]]'s coaching staff at the [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portuguese U21 team]], while also being charged with the [[Portugal national under-20 football team|under-20s]]; after a handful of games he resigned and returned to Gil Vicente, [[2010–11 Liga de Honra|winning the 2011 division two championship with the subsequent promotion]].

After three years, which also brought a [[2011–12 Taça da Liga|runner-up place]] in the [[Taça da Liga|domestic league cup]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-carlsberg-cup-news/32876-taca-da-liga-final-live-text-updates|title=Benfica win Taça da Liga|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=14 April 2012|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref> Alves replaced former national teammate [[Abel Xavier]] at the helm of [[S.C. Olhanense]] early into [[2013–14 Primeira Liga|2013–14]], being sacked after less than three months in charge and with only one point won in six league games.
