'''Morgan Amalfitano''' (born 20 March 1985 in [[Nice]]) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] as a [[midfielder]]. Amalfitano has earned one cap for the [[France national football team|France national team]], representing his country in a friendly in February 2012.

His main position is as a wide midfielder but he can also operate as an attacking or central midfielder. His younger brother [[Romain Amalfitano|Romain]] also plays professional football.

== Club career ==

=== Early career ===
Amalfitano made his professional debut in a 1–1 draw against [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] on 6 August 2006 under coach [[Serge Romano]]. He went on to play 30 games that season, starting in 28 of them. However, [[CS Sedan Ardennes|Sedan]] finished 19th and they were relegated to [[Ligue 2]]. The next season, [[CS Sedan Ardennes|Sedan]] managed to finish fourth failing to regain promotion under coach [[Jose Pasqualetti]].

In the summer of 2008, Amalfitano moved to [[Ligue 1]] side [[FC Lorient]]. He scored his first goal for Lorient, and his first professional goal, on 15 November 2008, scoring his side's first goal as they came from 0–2 down to defeat Marseille 3–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.soccerway.com/matches/2008/11/15/france/ligue-1/olympique-de-marseille/football-cub-lorient-bretagne-sud/632000/ |title=Olympique Marseille vs. Lorietn 2–3 |work=Soccerway |date=15 November 2008 |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> On 23 December 2009, Amalfitano scored two goals as Lorient twice came from a goal behind to defeat [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] 3–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.soccerway.com/matches/2009/12/23/france/ligue-1/football-cub-lorient-bretagne-sud/valenciennes-anzin-football-club/779036/ |title=Lorient vs. Valenciennes 3–2 |date=23 December 2009 |work=Soccerway |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref>

On 28 March 2010, Amalfitano provided an assist and scored a goal as Lorient completed a 4–0 rout over [[AS Saint-Étienne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/gamecast/271390/gamecast.html |title=Lorient 4–0 St. Etienne |work=ESPNFC |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> On 5 May, Amalfitano had a hand in both goals as Lorient drew 2–2 with [[AS Monaco]], scoring his side's first equalizer before setting up Kevin Gameiro for a late equalizer that secured a point for the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/gamecast/271522/gamecast.html |title=Lorient 2–2 AS Monaco |work=ESPNFC |date=5 May 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> On 6 November 2010, Amalfitano provided assists for both of [[Kevin Gameiro]]'s goals as Lorient defeat Saint-Étienne by a score of 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/gamecast/294903/gamecast.html |title=St. Etienne 1–2 Lorient |work=ESPNFC |date=6 November 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref> In three seasons with the club, Amalfitano played 121 matches and scored 15 goals in all competitions.
[[File:Rod Fanni, Jeremy Morel, Loic Remy and Morgan Amalfitano - TdC 2011.JPG|thumb|left|Morgan Amalfitano (19) lining up with Marseille for the [[2011 Trophée des champions]].]]

=== Marseille ===
In July 2011, Amalfitano joined [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] on a free transfer, signing a contract until 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Morgan Amalfitano|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/player/4983/morgan-amalfitano|publisher=[[Sky Sports News]]}}</ref>  He made his debut for the club in the [[Trophee des Champions]] against [[Lille OSC|Lille]] in a 5–4 win on 27 July, coming on as a substitute and later hitting the woodwork with his first show for the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lille 4–5 Marseille: Andre Ayew scores hat-trick as stunning OM comeback seals Trophee des Champions|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/63742/losc-lille-m%C3%A9tropole-vs-olympique-de-marseille/report|newspaper=Goal.com|date=27 July 2011}}</ref>  His competitive debut for the club came on 6 August in the first round of the new [[2011-12 Ligue 1|Ligue 1 season]], he was substituted in the 66th minute for [[Mathieu Valbuena]] as Marseille had to settle for a 2–2 draw at home to [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]].<ref name=Sochaux>{{cite news|title=Marseille 2 -2 Sochaux|url=http://espnfc.com/gamecast?id=320396&cc=5739|newspaper=[[ESPN]]|date=6 August 2011}}</ref> He made his [[2011-12 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] debut in a 1–0 win against [[Olympiacos Piraeus|Olympiakos]] on 13 September 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Marseille make winning start at Olympiacos|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2012/matches/round=2000263/match=2007571/postmatch/report/index.html|newspaper=[[UEFA]]|date=13 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Olympiakos 0&nbsp;– 1 Marseille|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=331257&cc=5901|newspaper=ESPN|date=13 September 2011}}</ref>  He scored his first goal for the club on 27 November 2011 in a 3–0 home victory against [[Paris Saint-Germain]],<ref name=Goal.com>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/match/60887/marseille-vs-psg/report|title=Olympique de Marseille 3–0 Paris Saint-Germain: Remy, Amalfitano and Andre Ayew on target as OM hammers PSG|newspaper=Goal.com}}</ref> as well as providing the assist for [[Jordan Ayew]]'s goal that sealed the emphatic win.<ref>{{cite news|title=Marseille 3&nbsp;– 0 Paris Saint-Germain|url=http://espnfc.com/gamecast?id=320256&cc=5739|newspaper=ESPN|date=27 November 2011}}</ref>   On 6 December 2011 in the final match of the group stage of the Champions League, Amalfitano provided assists for [[Loic Remy]] and [[Andre Ayew]] as a late Valbuena strike earned Marseille a 3–2 victory over [[Borussia Dortmund]] and a place in the knockout phase.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dramatic comeback secures Marseille's passage|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2012/matches/round=2000263/match=2007652/postmatch/report/index.html|newspaper=UEFA|date=6 December 2011}}</ref>

Amalfitano played the full 120 minutes on 14 April 2012 as Marseille defeated [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] 1–0, thanks to a late [[Brandão (footballer born 1980)|Brandão]] strike, to gain the [[2012 Coupe de la Ligue Final|Coupe de la Ligue]] trophy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Olympique Lyonnais&nbsp;— Olympique de Marseille|url=http://www.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuille_match/75841|newspaper=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]]|date=14 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bairner|first=Robin|title=Olympique Lyonnais 0–1 Olympique de Marseille (aet): Brandao secures Coupe de la Ligue for record-breaking OM|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/76265/olympique-lyonnais-vs-olympique-de-marseille/report|newspaper=Goal.com|date=14 April 2012}}</ref> Amalfitano finished the season with 49 appearances for the club but the up and down campaign which ended with the club missing out on the [[2012-13 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] resulted in Amalfitano asking for a transfer request.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amalfitano keen to leave Marseille&nbsp;— report|url=http://www.goal.com/en-my/news/3988/rest-of-europe/2012/05/26/3128620/amalfitano-keen-to-leave-marseille-report|newspaper=Goal.com|date=26 May 2012}}</ref>

=== West Bromwich Albion ===
[[File:Morgan Amalfitano 2013.jpg|thumb|Amalfitano playing for West Brom against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in December 2013.]]
On 1 September 2013, it was confirmed that Amalfitano had signed for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a season-long loan deal with a view to a permanent transfer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23928177|title=Transfer deadline day: Morgan Amalfitano joins West Brom|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for West Brom against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 21 September 2013 in a 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|title=West Brom 3&nbsp;– 0 Sunderland|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24089796|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=21 September 2013}}</ref> He scored his second league goal the following weekend, taking the ball from midfield and then knocking it through [[Rio Ferdinand]]'s legs, Amalfitano then nonchalantly dinked the ball over [[David De Gea]], helping West Brom to a 2–1 victory over [[Manchester United]] at Old Trafford, their first win at Old Trafford in 34 years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2435181/Manchester-United-1-West-Brom-2-match-report.html |title=Manchester United 1 West Brom 2: Boos at Old Trafford as Moyes faces more misery |publisher=Daily Mail |date=28 September 2013 |accessdate=29 September 2013 |location=London}}</ref>

After a positive start to life at The Hawthorns, his form declined up until the run-in in which he scored an audacious lob from 35 yards in the thrilling 3–3 draw against fellow relegations rivals [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 29 March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26694512 |title=Mats Moller Daehli scored a 95th-minute equaliser in reply to Thievy Bifouma's injury-time goal as Cardiff twice came back to steal a potentially crucial point against West Brom. |work=BBC Sport |date=29 March 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> He followed that strike up the following week with the solitary goal in West Brom's away win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/287613/report |title=Premier League: West Bromwich Albion beat Norwich City 1–0 at Carrow Road |work=Sky Sports |date=5 April 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> Upon finishing his loan at West Brom he returned to Marseille in July 2014.

=== West Ham United ===
On 1 September 2014, Amalfitano signed for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on a one year deal for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29019423 |title=West Ham sign French midfielder Morgan Amalfitano |work=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> He made his West Ham debut two weeks later against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on 15 September, replacing [[Diafra Sakho]] in the second-half of the 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2756976/Hull-2-2-West-Ham-Mo-Diame-scores-debut-against-former-club-spoils-shared-KC-Stadium.html |title=Hull City 2–2 West Ham: Mo Diame scores on his debut against his former club as spoils are shared at the KC Stadium |work=Daily Mail |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref>

On 20 September 2014, Amalfitano made his home debut for the Hammers, coming on in the second half and scoring his first goal for West Ham, against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], to complete a 3–1 victory and secure the club's first home win of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/sep/20/west-ham-liverpool-premier-league-match-report |title=Morgan Amalfitano completes frantic West Ham victory against Liverpool |work=The Guardian |date=20 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> Amalfitano's second goal for the club came on 25 October at home to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] when he netted the opener in a 2–1 victory over the reigning champions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29670449 |title=West Ham United 2:1 Manchester City |work=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2014 |accessdate=25 October 2014 }}</ref>

Amalfitano replaced [[Kevin Nolan]] after 60 minutes of West Ham's FA Cup fifth round game at [[West Bromwich Albion]]; ten minutes later he was booked for a heavy challenge. He then put his hand in an opponents face resulting in the referee issuing the red card in an eventual 4 - 0 defeat. <ref>{{cite news|title=West Brom 4-0 West Ham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31423104|accessdate=14 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=14 February 2015}}</ref> In March 2015, Amalfitano signed a new, two-year contract with West Ham which would keep him at the club until the end of the 2016-17 season.<ref name="morganamalfitano2">{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2015/March/13-March/Amalfitano-pens-new-deal | title=Amalfitano pens new deal | publisher=www.whufc.com | accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref>

== International career ==

Amalfitano made his debut in a 2–1 victory for [[France national football team|France]] in a friendly against neighbors [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 29 February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/252226/report |title=French claim German scalp |work=Sky Sports |date=29 February 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2014 }}</ref> He replaced his then Marseille teammate [[Mathieu Valbuena]] after 67 minutes and provided the cross from which [[Florent Malouda]] scored their second goal of the game.<ref>{{cite news|last=White|first=Jim|title=Germany 1 France 2: match report|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9114746/Germany-1-France-2-match-report.html|date=29 February 2012|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref>

'''Jordi Amat Maas''' (born 21 March 1992) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for Welsh club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]].

==Club career==
===Espanyol===
Born in [[Canet de Mar]], [[Province of Barcelona|Barcelona]], [[Catalonia]], Amat joined [[RCD Espanyol]]'s youth system at the age of only seven. He began appearing as a senior with [[RCD Espanyol B|the B-team]], in [[Segunda División B]].<ref>[http://www.pericosonline.com/noticias/detall/7304/jordi-amat-aixo-es-increible Jordi Amat: `això és increïble´ (Jordi Amat: `this is amazing´)]; Pericos Online, 23 January 2010 {{ca icon}}</ref>

On 24 January 2010, two months shy of his 18th birthday, Amat played his first [[La Liga]] game with the club, coming on as a late [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 1–1 home draw against [[RCD Mallorca]].<ref>[http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/275635/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739 Espanyol frustrated by penalty]; [[ESPN Soccernet]], 24 January 2010</ref> He finished [[2010–11 La Liga|his first full season]] with 26 league appearances (28 overall), helping the ''Pericos'' to a final eighth position.

For [[2012–13 La Liga|2012–13]] Amat was loaned to fellow top-division side [[Rayo Vallecano]],<ref>[http://www.rayovallecano.es/noticia/jordi-amat-nueva-incorporacion-para-esta-temporada/1304/ Jordi Amat nueva incorporación para esta temporada (Jordi Amat new addition for this season)]; Rayo's official website, 17 July 2012 {{es icon}}</ref> being first-choice during the campaign. On 24 February 2013 he scored his first goal for the [[Madrid]] oustkirts club, netting from 50 meters in an eventual 1–2 home loss to [[Real Valladolid]] and also putting one in [[Own goal|his own net]] in the same match.<ref>[http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/268428/report Rayo suffer home defeat]; [[Sky Sports]], 24 January 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/virals/130225/video-defender-scores-just-inside-half-madrid-192403 Video: Defender scores from just inside half in Madrid]; Talk Sport, 25 February 2013</ref>

===Swansea City===
On 27 June 2013, [[Premier League]] side [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] announced the club had signed Amat for a transfer fee of [[Pound sterling|£]]2.5 million on a four-year deal. It was subject to international clearance and a medical.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swanseacity.net/news/article/amat-signs-883662.aspx|title=Swans Amat boost|publisher=Swansea City A.F.C|date=27 June 2013|accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref> He made his official debut for his new club on 1 August, playing the full 90 minutes in a 4–0 home victory over [[Malmö FF]] in the first leg of the [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round#Third qualifying round|third qualifying round]] of the [[UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2382711/Swansea-4-Malmo-0-New-boy-Wilfried-Bony-nets-twice-12m-striker-gives-Michael-Laudrup-big-leg-lead-Europa-League-qualifying.html|title=Swansea 4 Malmo 0: New boy Bony nets twice as £12m striker gives Laudrup big first leg lead in Europa League qualifying|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=1 August 2013|accessdate=7 August 2013}}</ref> On 11 March 2015 he signed a new one year contract extension keeeping him at the club until summer 2018.

'''Darren Paul Francis Ambrose''' (born 29 February 1984) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who currently plays for [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. Ambrose, an [[attacking midfielder]], started his career at [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], and played for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] prior to his move to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]. He spent time on loan at [[Greek Superleague]] club [[Apollon Smyrni F.C.|Apollon Smyrni]] before leaving Birmingham when his contract expired at the end of the 2013–14 season.

He also made ten appearances for the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] side, scoring twice.

==Club career==

===Ipswich Town===
Born in [[Harlow]], [[Essex]], Ambrose started his career at [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] and made his debut as an 18-year-old against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 21 April 2002, replacing [[Martijn Reuser]] during a 2–0 defeat at [[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/1938548.stm|title=Arsenal go top|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 April 2002|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> Ipswich lost their Premiership status the following month, though Ambrose started brightly in the next campaign, scoring on his full debut in a 2–0 victory against [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] at the Bescot stadium, and went on to score ten more goals in 37 appearances, combining superbly throughout the season with his close friend, striker [[Darren Bent]]. In March, however, with Ipswich having fallen into administration, Ambrose was sold to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for what was considered a bargain £1m.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/2882977.stm |title= Ambrose signs for Magpies |date=25 March 2003|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref> The sale was ordered by the administrators, and completed at Newcastle by former Ipswich manager [[Bobby Robson]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/darren_plans_to_dampen_town_s_cheer_1_175916 |title=Darren plans to dampen Town's cheer |publisher=Eastern Daily Press |date=24 December 2009 |accessdate=28 October 2013 |author=King, Elvin}}</ref>

===Newcastle United===
In total, he scored 6 goals in 56 appearances for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2341953,00.html |author=Blackmore, Ben |title=Ambrose wants to play |publisher=SkySports |date=July 2005 |accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref>

===Charlton Athletic===
He joined [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on 8 July 2005 for a fee estimated to be in the region of £1.5&nbsp;million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4663085.stm |title=Charlton sign Newcastle's Ambrose |date=8 July 2005|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref>

After failing to gain promotion back to the Premier League in 2007–08, Ambrose was sent to former club Ipswich Town on loan in the first half of the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09]] season due to financial reasons, (ironically under similar circumstances to that of when Ambrose first moved from Ipswich in 2003)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7721498.stm |title=Ambrose rejoins Ipswich on loan |date=11 November 2008|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref> with rumours that Ipswich were reportedly interested in making the deal permanent in January 2009 for an estimated fee of £250,000, although no deal eventually materialised.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=nonwire_soccer/08/12/31/manual_172308.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110605030408/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=nonwire_soccer/08/12/31/manual_172308.html |title=Ambrose Back With Addicks |date=31 December 2008 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |website=sportinglife.com |publisher=365 Media Group}}</ref>

===Crystal Palace===
With his contract at Charlton ending at the end of that season, Ambrose was free to leave the club, and decided to remain in South London, joining [[South London derby|local rivals]] [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]. He set a career-best record of 12 goals in 20 games by November, a run that saw him named as the division's Player of the Month for the November.<ref name = "POTM">{{Cite news |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/ambrose-named-player-of-the-month-20091205_2248204_1896064 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20091208133609/http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/ambrose-named-player-of-the-month-20091205_2248204_1896064 |title=Ambrose named Player of the Month |date=5 December 2009 |archivedate=8 December 2009 |publisher=The Football League}}</ref> Ambrose ended the season with a goal against [[Sheffield Wednesday]] that saved the club from relegation and subsequently from extinction as well. He finished the season with 20 goals in all competitions. With Crystal Palace in administration, it was looking certain that Ambrose was going to leave at the end of the season, and was set to join [[Queens Park Rangers]], but he signed a new three-year contract with Crystal Palace on 26 July 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10323~2102768,00.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100916082500/http://www.cpfc.co.uk/page/News/0,,10323~2102768,00.html |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C |title=Ambrose signs new Eagles deal |date=30 July 2010 |archivedate=16 September 2010}}</ref>

In the 2011–12 season, Ambrose was again more of a squad player, featuring more from the bench than his first season at Palace. On 30 November 2011, in his 99th game in all competitions for Crystal Palace, Ambrose scored a 35 yard long range shot at Old Trafford and then got an assist for [[Glenn Murray]]'s goal in the 2–1 win over Manchester United in the League Cup quarter final.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/70292/manchester-united-vs-crystal-palace/report |title=Manchester United 1–2 Crystal Palace (AET): Ambrose wonderstrike & Murray winner dump weakened hosts out of League Cup |author=Shahid, Omar |date=1 December 2011 |accessdate=28 October 2013 |publisher=goal.com}}</ref>

===Birmingham City===
On 13 July 2012, Ambrose signed a two-year contract with [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] for an undisclosed fee, reported by [[BBC Sport]] to be in the region of £250,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18826706 |title=Birmingham City sign Darren Ambrose from Crystal Palace |date=13 July 2012|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> He scored on his competitive debut on 14 August, in the 5–1 defeat of [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-5-barnet-1-190359 |title=Birmingham City 5 Barnet 1 |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |first=Colin |last=Tattum |date=15 August 2012 |accessdate=13 October 2013}}</ref> and kept his place for the opening match of the [[2012–13 Football League]] season, in a 1–1 draw at home to former club Charlton Athletic.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221628 |title=Birmingham 1–1 Charlton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> He labelled his contribution to a poor team display in a 5–0 home defeat to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] in September as "the worst performance of my career".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/birmingham-city-darren-ambrose-reveals-4910 |title=Birmingham City: Darren Ambrose reveals his and Blues' hurt |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |first=Colin |last=Tattum |date=29 September 2012 |accessdate=10 July 2013}}</ref> Following that game, Ambrose picked up a knee injury which kept him out for most of the season,{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} in which he made just six league appearances.<ref name=sb1213/>

====Apollon Smyrni (loan)====
After making only two appearances for Birmingham early in the 2013–14 season,<ref name=sb1314/> Ambrose joined [[Greek Superleague]] club [[Apollon Smyrni F.C.|Apollon Smyrni]] on 14 January 2014, on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/news/article/20140113-darren-ambrose-makes-greek-move-1291978.aspx |title=Darren Ambrose makes Greek move |first=Andy |last=Walker |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |date=14 January 2014 |accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> He made his debut two days later, in the starting eleven as his club progressed to the quarter-finals of the [[2013–14 Greek Football Cup|Greek Cup]] on aggregate after a 1–0 second-leg defeat to [[Niki Volou]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/news/article/20140116-loan-watch-darren-ambrose-1299257.aspx |title=Loan watch&nbsp;– Darren Ambrose |first=Andy |last=Walker |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |date=16 January 2014 |accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref> In his second league match, Ambrose scored a late equaliser to earn a draw away to [[Levadiakos]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_05/02/2014_537131 |title=Moyes watches Olympiakos produce little as it beat Panionios |first=George |last=Georgakopoulos |newspaper=Ekatherimini |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref> He finished the [[2013–14 Superleague Greece|Superleague season]] with six goals from eleven games, but his contribution was not enough to save the team from relegation.<ref name=Soccerway/>

On his return from loan, Birmingham confirmed he would be released when his contract expired at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/news/article/20140509-paul-robinson-and-olly-lee-extend-blues-stay-as-six-depart-1544099.aspx |title=Paul Robinson and Olly Lee extend Blues stay as six depart |first=Andy |last=Walker |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=10 May 2014 |accessdate=19 May 2014}}</ref>

===Ipswich Town (3rd spell)===
Ambrose re-signed for Ipswich Town on 11 September 2014. Ambrose had twice featured for Ipswich's U21 side before putting pen to paper on a new contract. Ambrose, who will wear the number 29 shirt, joins [[John Wark]], [[Tommy Miller]], [[Richard Wright (footballer)|Richard Wright]] and [[Daryl Murphy]] as one of a select few players to have had three or more spells with the Blues. Ambrose moved back to West Suffolk earlier in the summer, played for [[Colchester United]] against the Blues in pre-season before joining up with the Town squad to train three weeks before signing. <ref>http://www.twtd.co.uk/ipswich-town-news/25750/town-re-sign-ambrose</ref>

==International career==
Ambrose is a former [[England national under-21 football team|England U21 national]] after becoming a regular in England's youth teams, but has never played at senior international level. He is also eligible to play international football for the [[Republic of Ireland]] through a grandparent, although he is yet to receive a call-up.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.herald.ie/sport/soccer/ambrose-is-set-for-trap-door-27972560.html |title=Ambrose is set for Trap door |publisher=Herald.ie |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=13 October 2013 |author=Fitzmaurice, Aidan}}</ref>

'''Gabriele Ambrosetti''' (born 7 August 1973) is a former [[Football in Italy|Italian football]]er who played as a winger.

Born in [[Varese]], he played for several Italian sides, including [[Brescia Calcio|Brescia]] and [[Vicenza Calcio|Vicenza]]. He won the [[1996–97 Coppa Italia]] at Vicenza,<ref>{{cite web 
|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/speciali/coppa_italia/2005/albo/1997_1.html
|title=1996/97 Coppa Italia
|publisher=gazzetta.it
|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref> and in April 1998 played in a Cup Winners Cup semi-final against Chelsea, inspiring the English [[Premier League]] club to sign him for £3.5 million in August 1999. He arrived as, according to his manager, [[Gianluca Vialli]], the 'Italian [[Ryan Giggs]]', but struggled to live up to the tag and in four years made only a handful of appearances. He made his Chelsea debut as a substitute on 21 August in a 1–0 home win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], replacing compatriot [[Gianfranco Zola]] for the last three minutes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Games played by Gabriele Ambrosetti in 1999/2000|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=14102&season_id=129|publisher=[[Soccerbase]]|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref>  The only goal he scored for Chelsea was in a 5–0 win against [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]] in [[Istanbul]], on 20 October 1999 during the [[UEFA Champions League]] Group Stage.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/flo-inspires-chelsea-exhibition-742325.html
|title=Flo inspires Chelsea exhibition
|publisher=[[The Independent]] 
|date=21 October 1999 |accessdate=5 November 2009
| location=London
| first=Mark
| last=Bradley}}</ref>

==Honours==
'''Vicenza'''
*[[Coppa Italia]]: 1997

'''Marco Ambrosio''' (30 May 1973 in [[Brescia]]) is a former Italian [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. Ambrosio played for multiple teams in the Italian leagues from 1991 until his retirement in 2009 (most notably with [[Serie A]] sides [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]], [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] and [[A.C. ChievoVerona|Chievo]]), but also had brief spells in England with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and in Switzerland with [[Grasshopper Club Zürich|Grasshopper]]. He made two appearances for his country's [[Italy national under-21 football team|under-21 side]] during the 1993&ndash;94 season, but never made an appearance for the full national side.

==Football career==

===A Decade in Italy===
The early years of Ambrosio's career were relatively undistinguished, and saw him play for a succession of minor Italian clubs, such as [[A.C. Lumezzane|Lumezzane]] ([[Serie D]]), [[Atalanta B.C.]] (youth), [[Pisa Calcio|Pisa]] ([[Serie B]]), [[A.C. Prato]] ([[Serie C1]]) and [[Ravenna Calcio|Ravenna]] ([[Serie C1]]). Whilst playing for Pisa, he made two appearances for [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy's under-21 team]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.figc.it/nazionali/DettaglioConvocato?codiceConvocato=1209&squadra=1 |title=Marco Ambrosio |publisher=Federazione Italiana Giuoco Calcio |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref> He also had a stint with [[U.C. Sampdoria]] in [[Serie A]]. He made his Serie A debut on 2 November 1997, Sampdoria lost 0–3 at home to [[A.C. Milan]]. In total, he played 10 Serie A  games for the [[Genoa|Genoese]] team, as second goalkeeper behind [[Fabrizio Ferron]].

After Sampdoria were relegated to Serie B, Ambrosio was sold to Serie C1 team [[A.S. Lucchese-Libertas|Lucchese]] in the summer of 1999, where he spent two seasons. In summer 2001 he was signed by newly promoted Serie A team [[A.C. ChievoVerona|Chievo]], where he made another 10 Serie A appearances as second-choice goalkeeper behind [[Cristiano Lupatelli]].

===Chelsea===
In June 2003 he was signed for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a free [[Transfer (football)|transfer]] by Italian manager [[Claudio Ranieri]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/footballeurope/news/kind=2/newsid=72689.html|title=Ambrosio revels in Chelsea move|date=1 June 2003|accessdate=3 April 2008|publisher=UEFA.com}}</ref>

Ambrosio was signed to be goalkeeping understudy to [[Carlo Cudicini]] and fellow new-acquisition [[Jurgen Macho]], and so found his playing opportunities limited at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]. His cause was not helped by an unlucky debut in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] against [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], in which he made a series of errors.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3204843.stm
|title=Chelsea 4-2 Notts County
|publisher=BBC
|date=29 October 2003 |accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> His second appearance, against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], proved far more assured as he made a string of impressive saves to secure a crucial 2–0 win for his side.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3536375.stm
|title=Bolton 0-2 Chelsea
|publisher=BBC
|date=13 March 2004 |accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> That, together with injuries to all Chelsea's other goalkeepers, earned him a run in the side. His most significant contribution came in the Champions League quarter-final against Arsenal when his saves helped Chelsea to a 2–1 victory at Highbury.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/champions_league/3593083.stm
|title=Arsenal 1-2 Chelsea
|publisher=BBC
|date=6 April 2004 |accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>

However, he lost his place in the side to the fit-again Cudicini towards the end of the season and with the signing of another new goalkeeper [[Petr Čech]], he was allowed to leave the club on a free transfer in August 2004.

===Return to Italy===
He moved to [[Switzerland|Swiss]] side [[Grasshopper Club Zürich]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/footballeurope/news/kind=2/newsid=214823.html|title=Grasshoppers chance for Ambrosio|date=11 August 2004|accessdate=3 April 2008|publisher=UEFA.com}}</ref> shortly afterward and has since signed for Italian team [[Salernitana Calcio 1919|Salernitana]] of Serie B on 5 January 2005, replaced [[Alex Brunner]] who left for [[Cagliari Calcio]], compete with former starter [[Domenico Botticella]].

Ambrosio followed the team relegated to Serie C1 and compete with former teammate in Chievo, [[Gioacchino Cavaliere]]

On 21 July 2006, he was signed by [[Brescia Calcio|Brescia]].

In summer 2007, he joined [[A.C. Reggiana 1919|Reggiana]] of [[Serie C2]].

In 2009, Ambrosio retired from football.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluetinted.com/category/first-team/5125/#.UpTAeMRtHpI |title=The House That Ranieri Built Pt 1: This Ones For 'Keeps |publisher=Blue Tinted |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>

'''Samuel Oluwaseyi J. "Sammy" Ameobi''' (born 1 May 1992) is a [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] as a [[winger (sports)|winger]]. He is the younger brother of fellow players [[Shola Ameobi|Shola]] and [[Tomi Ameobi]].

Born in England, Ameobi was capped by England at [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level before switching his allegiance to [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] in August 2014.

==Club career==

===Newcastle United===

====Early career====
Born in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], Tyne and Wear,<ref name="NUFCProfile" /> Ameobi joined the [[Newcastle United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Newcastle United Academy]] in July 2008 after finishing school<ref name="NUFCProfileold">{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/ReservePlayerProfile/0,,10278~2117098,00.html|title=Sam Ameobi|accessdate=15 May 2011|publisher=Newcastle United F.C}}</ref> and made his reserve team debut on 29 September 2008 against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].<ref name="NUFCProfileold" /> He made his first-team debut on 15 May 2011 as a second-half substitute against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in a 2–2 draw, alongside his brother [[Shola Ameobi|Shola]], coming on for [[Peter Løvenkrands]] just before Chelsea made the game 2–1. This prompted Newcastle fans to change a chant from "There's only one Ameobi" to "There's only two Ameobis". They became the first pair of brothers to play for Newcastle in a league match since [[George Robledo|George]] and [[Ted Robledo]] in 1952.<ref name="Shola and Sammy Ameobi tell of NUFC pride">{{cite news|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/newcastle-united/nufc-news/2011/05/16/shola-and-sammy-ameobi-tell-of-nufc-pride-72703-28701307/|title=Shola and Sammy Ameobi tell of NUFC pride|date=16 May 2011|accessdate=17 June 2011|first=Lee|last=Ryder|newspaper=Evening Chronicle}}</ref><ref name="guardian">{{cite news|title=Newcastle United's Shola and Sammy Ameobi revel in shared ambition|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/may/20/shola-sammy-ameobi-newcastle-united?INTCMP=SRCH|newspaper=The Guardian|date=20 May 2011}}</ref>

Ameobi scored his first senior goal on 15 July 2011, in a pre-season friendly against [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]]. Prior to the goal, supporters chanted, "If Sammy scores we're on the pitch" and thus the goal was followed by a pitch invasion which caused the game to be delayed for 10 minutes.<ref name="Darlington 0 Newcastle 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20110715/darlington-0-newcastle-2_2281670_2393957|title=Darlington 0 Newcastle 2|date=15 July 2011|accessdate=15 July 2011|first=Anthony|last=Marshall|publisher=Newcastle United F.C}}</ref> He scored his first competitive goal on 25 August 2011, scoring the winner in extra time against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] in the second round of the [[Football League Cup]].<ref name="Scunthorpe 1-2 Newcastle">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14569521.stm|title=Scunthorpe 1–2 Newcastle|date=25 August 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>

On 17 November 2011, Ameobi signed a new three-and-a-half-year contract extension with Newcastle United, keeping him at the club until 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sammy Signs Up!|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20111117/sammy-signs-up_2281670_2518504?WT.mc_id=sammy-hpto|publisher=Newcastle United F.C|date=17 November 2011}}</ref> On 19 November 2011, he started his first-ever Premier League match, away to Manchester City.

====Middlesbrough (loan)====
Ameobi joined [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 25 February 2013 on loan until the end of the 2012–13 season. On 2 March, Ameobi scored on his debut for the club in a 2–1 victory over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21556886 "Middlesbrough 2–1 Cardiff"] BBC Sport. 2 March 2013. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref>

====Return to Newcastle United====
Ameobi scored his first senior league goal for Newcastle on 26 October 2014, within seven seconds of the second half against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]]. <ref name="Tottenham 1-2 Newcastle">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29679402|title=Tottenham 1–2 Newcastle|date=26 October 2014|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>

==International career==
Ameobi joined the Nigeria U-20 squad training in Turkey ahead of the [[2011 African Youth Championship]].<ref name="Newcastle’s Sam Ameobi Joins Nigeria U-20's">{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/89/africa/2011/03/08/2385452/newcastles-sam-ameobi-joins-nigeria-u-20s|title=Newcastle's Sam Ameobi Joins Nigeria U-20's|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=17 June 2011|first=Lolade|last=Adewuyi|publisher=Goal.com}}</ref> He appeared in two friendly games for the Nigeria U20s against Saudi Arabia and Egypt.<ref name="Stuart Pearce keeps tabs on Sammy Ameobi">{{cite news|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/newcastle-united/nufc-news/2011/09/24/stuart-pearce-keeping-tabs-on-sammy-ameobi-72703-29478601/|title=Stuart Pearce keeping tabs on Sammy Ameobi|date=24 September 2011|accessdate=13 November 2011|first=Lee|last=Ryder|newspaper=Evening Chronicle}}</ref> However, in November 2011, he was called up to the England U-21 squad for matches against Iceland and Belgium by Stuart Pearce. He met up with his team mates for the first day of training on 7 November. On 10 November Ameobi made his England Under-21 debut against Iceland in a 5–0 win to maintain England's perfect start to their Euro 2013 Under-21 Qualifying group. On 14 November Ameobi made his first start against Belgium Under-21s. England were winning 1–0 when Ameobi was subbed off after 67 minutes, the game eventually ended 2–1 to Belgium.

On 6 August 2014, Ameobi confirmed that he has chosen to follow elder brother [[Shola Ameobi|Shola]] in declaring for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Okeleji|first1=Oluwashina|title=Sammy Ameobi: Newcastle United striker opts to play for Nigeria|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28674516|accessdate=6 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Ameobi has two older brothers who are also footballers: [[Shola Ameobi|Shola]], his former teammate at Newcastle, and [[Tomi Ameobi|Tomi]], who plays for [[FC Edmonton]] in [[Canada]].<ref name="NUFCProfileold" /> He attended [[Heaton Manor School]] in Newcastle and [[Grindon Hall Christian School]] in Sunderland, and finished school with 11 GCSEs prior to joining the Newcastle academy on a scholarship.<ref name="guardian" />

'''Foluwashola "Shola" Ameobi''' (born 12 October 1981) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for English club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria national team]].

He spent 14 years at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], where he received a winner's medal in 2010 when Newcastle lifted the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] trophy. He holds the record for the most appearances as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the [[Premier League]].<ref>http://www.futaa.com/football/article/ameobi-makes-another-epl-history</ref> On leaving Newcastle in 2014, he briefly represented [[Gaziantep BB]] in Turkey before joining Crystal Palace.

Born in Nigeria but raised in England, Ameobi was capped by the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]] before making his [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] debut in 2012 and representing them at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. He is the older brother of fellow footballers [[Tomi Ameobi|Tomi]] and [[Sammy Ameobi|Sammy]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Newcastle United F.C.]]|url= http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/ReservePlayerProfile/0,,10278~2117098,00.html|title=Sam Ameobi Profle|accessdate=31 October 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140227184653/http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/ReservePlayerProfile/0,,10278~2117098,00.html|archivedate=27 February 2014}}</ref>

==Early life==
Born in [[Zaria]], Nigeria to a family from Ijumu Local Government Area in modern day [[Kogi]] State, Ameobi moved to [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England when he was five. His initial promise was spotted whilst attending the Walker Central Boys Club, before he was invited to attend Newcastle United's Academy.<ref name=NUFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/PlayerProfile/0,,10278~7870,00.html|title=Shola Ameobi Profle|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|accessdate=31 October 2010|archivedate=26 December 2013|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20131226012847/http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/PlayerProfile/0,,10278~7870,00.html}}</ref>

==Club career==

===Newcastle United===
====Early career====
Ameobi signed a pre-contract with Newcastle on 1 July 1997.<ref name=NUFC/> He progressed through the youth setup, making his debut in the reserves in 1998 on 11 October against Sunderland. He made his first team debut two years later, 9 September 2000, in a home game against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref name=NUFC/> He went on to make 22 appearances for Newcastle that season,<ref name=NUFC/> in lieu of the injured [[Alan Shearer]] and [[Carl Cort]].<ref name=NUFC/>

The 2002–03 Champions League saw some of Ameobi's finest performances including an equalising goal against [[FC Barcelona]] in a 3–1 defeat at the [[Nou Camp]]<ref>{{cite news|date=11 Dec 2002
|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/dec/11/minutebyminute.sport1|title=Barcelona 3 – 1 Newcastle|publisher=[[theguardian.com]]|accessdate=18 October 2010|location=London|first=Anjana
|last=Gadgil|archivedate=21 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140521120806/http://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/dec/11/minutebyminute.sport1}}</ref> as well as scoring two goals against [[Bayer Leverkusen]] in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 February 2003|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/champions_league/2770553.stm|title=Newcastle stun Bayer|publisher=[[BBC]]|work=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=21 July 2011|archivedate=20 September 2008|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080920061943/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/champions_league/2770553.stm}}</ref>

His erratic form has earned him some criticism in the past, and although never having been claimed as a prolific goalscorer, many of his games were [[substitute (association football)|as a substitute]].{{citation needed|date=October 2010}} Due to injuries in the latter stages of the [[FA Premier League 2005–06|2005–06 season]], Ameobi gained a regular starting place, and scored six goals in Newcastle's last 12 Premier League games.{{cn|date=October 2010}}

In the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup 2006|2006 UEFA Intertoto Cup]], Ameobi scored twice in Newcastle's away tie at [[Lillestrøm SK]] (3–0),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/5203392.stm|title=L'strom 0–3 Newcastle (agg 1–4)|publisher=BBC Sport
|date=22 July 2006|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20080920061943/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/5203392.stm|archivedate=21 July 2014}}</ref> taking him to second place in the club's table of leading goalscorers in European competition with twelve goals, behind only Shearer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nufc.com/2011-12html/europe-stats.html|title=The Toon in Europe 1968–2009 the story so far...|publisher=NUFC.com|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20110702203711/http://nufc.com/2011-12html/europe-stats.html|archivedate=2 July 2011}}</ref>

====Injury, loan, and transfer attempts====
During the 2006–07 season, Ameobi needed a [[hip]] operation, a problem which had been plaguing him for two seasons. Newcastle's shortage of match-fit first team strikers during the previous season had forced him to postpone this surgery.<ref>{{cite news|date=25 October 2006|url= http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2393270,00.html|author=Alex Dunn|title=Shola set for hip op|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112092822/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2393270,00.html|archivedate=12 January 2009}}</ref> The problem eventually forced [[Glenn Roeder]] to send Ameobi for surgery two months before the transfer window, making the 0–0 draw away game to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] his last game and ruling him out for the rest of the season.{{cn|date=October 2010}} He had made 13 appearances (three as a substitute) and scored five goals.{{cn|date=October 2010}}

Ameobi and the Newcastle medical team reported his hip operation in the United States was a success and that the club doctors and medical staff would work on his rehabilitation.{{cn|date=October 2010}} It was originally thought that he would not be fit to play until the start of the [[FA Premier League 2007–08|2007–08 season]], but his rehabilitation progressed quickly and he returned with three games remaining in the season, clocking approximately 30 minutes of match action against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]<ref>{{cite news|date=1 May 2007|url= http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2454991,00.html|author=James Pearson|title=Ameobi thrilled to return|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008|archivedate=12 January 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112091809/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_2454991,00.html}}</ref> and making a further two appearances.

However, after failing to impress Newcastle manager [[Sam Allardyce]],<ref>{{cite news|date=21 January 2008|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_3067108,00.html|title=Ameobi grabs Keegan lifeline|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008}}</ref> or [[Kevin Keegan]]<ref>{{cite news|date=15 February 2008|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3148652,00.html
|title=Keegan issues Ameobi warning|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008|archivedate=12 January 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112160045/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3148652,00.html}}</ref> on 27 March 2008, Ameobi agreed a [[loan (association football)|loan]] deal with [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] until the end of the season, to help their promotion campaign. It is understood that a loan fee of around £500K was agreed and that a possible permanent transfer was also discussed subject to Stoke winning promotion.<ref>{{cite news
|date=27 March 2008|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3355333,00.html|title= Potters pounce for Ameobi|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008|archivedate=12 January 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112181959/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3355333,00.html}}</ref> Ameobi made his debut for Stoke against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on 29 March, the game ended 1–1. After playing for six games and not managing to score despite Stoke's gaining of promotion, Ameobi returned to Newcastle, and Stoke decided not to sign him permanently.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_3537502,00.html|author=Chris Burton|title=Potters deny Ameobi deal|publisher=Sky Sports|date=8 May 2008|accessdate=20 October 2008|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112160421/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_3537502,00.html|archivedate=12 January 2009}}</ref>

On 14 August, [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] manager [[Jim Magilton]] confirmed that the club were in talks with Ameobi and that the club were keen to get the deal finalised as long as Ameobi was willing to play in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]]. However, on 17 August, Ameobi failed a medical, showing hamstring problems, and the deal collapsed.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 August 2008|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_4012544,00.html|title=Injury halts Ameobi move|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 October 2008|archivedate=12 January 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112092650/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_4012544,00.html}}</ref>

====Return to fitness====
[[Image:Shola Ameobi warming up.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Ameobi warming up on the sidelines against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in 2010.]]
Due to long term injuries to [[Mark Viduka]] and [[Alan Smith (footballer born 1980)|Alan Smith]],{{cn|date=October 2010}} as well as shorter term injuries to [[Michael Owen]] and [[Obafemi Martins]],{{cn|date=October 2010}} Ameobi was able to start the 2008–09 season in the first team squad. He managed to score his first goal in two years for Newcastle in a 2–2 home draw with Manchester City on 20 October.<ref>{{cite news|date=20 October 2008|publisher=Sky Sports|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3023060,00.html|title= City deny ten-man Toon|accessdate=20 October 2008|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112000853/http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3023060,00.html|archivedate=12 January 2009}}</ref> After the match, interim manager [[Joe Kinnear]] praised Ameobi and backed him to kick-start his career.<ref>{{cite news|date=21 October 2008|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_4364468,00.html|title=Kinnear wants Ameobi reaction|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=21 October 2008|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090112100430/http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11678_4364468,00.html|archivedate=12 January 2009}}</ref> He followed this up with a goal in his next game away to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in a 2–1 defeat on 25 October.<ref>{{cite news|date=25 October 2008|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7674086.stm|title= Sunderland 2–1 Newcastle |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 October 2008|first=Owen|last= Phillips|archivedate=13 January 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090113051125/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7674086.stm}}</ref> He signed a new deal with the club in January 2009 to keep him contracted until 2012.<ref>{{cite news|date=7 January 2009|publisher=BBC Sport|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7815334.stm|title=Ameobi pens new deal at Newcastle|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090208035343/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/7815334.stm|archivedate=8 February 2009}}</ref>

He scored a penalty to mark his 50th goal for Newcastle on 1 February 2009 against local rivals [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] to make the final score 1–1. He scored his first ever career hat-trick in Newcastle's first home match in the [[2009–10 Football League Championship|Championship]] against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 15 August. The first two goals were diving headers, and he completed his hat-trick with a penalty, which he placed in the bottom left corner, sending the keeper the wrong way.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8194911.stm|title=Newcastle 3–0 Reading|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2009|accessdate=16 August 2009|first=Mike|last=Henson|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090817164124/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8194911.stm|archivedate=17 August 2009}}</ref> He scored in the next game in a 1–0 victory over Sheffield Wednesday<ref>{{cite news|date=19 August 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8201948.stm|title=Newcastle 1–0 Sheff Wed|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archivedate=28 January 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100128054107/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8201948.stm}}</ref> taking his tally to four goals in three games, equalling his total for the previous season.{{cn|date=October 2010}} Following these early season performances he was named the Championship player of the month for August.<ref name="potm-aug-bbc">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8252347.stm|title=Ameobi wins player of month award|date=12 September 2009|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 September 2009|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20090918124456/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8252347.stm|archivedate=18 September 2009}}</ref>

[[Image:Ameobi.jpg|200px|thumb|Ameobi playing against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in November 2010.]]
He got injured in Newcastle's 4–3 win over [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].{{citation needed|date=October 2010}} The injury kept him out for three months but on his return he scored against Coventry with a left footed strike from the edge of the box.<ref>{{cite news|date=8 December 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8391293.stm|title=Coventry 0–2 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20091218035330/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8391293.stm|archivedate=18 December 2009}}</ref> He followed this up by scoring the second in Newcastle's 2–0 home win over Middlesbrough<ref>{{cite news|date=20 December 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8420764.stm|title=Newcastle 2–0 Middlesbrough|author=Phil Dawkes |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archivedate=28 January 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100128213951/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8420764.stm}}</ref> and their 2–2 away draw with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on Boxing Day<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8425107.stm|title=Sheff Wed 2–2 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|date=26 December 2009|archivedate=15 January 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100115102556/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8425107.stm}}</ref> taking his tally to an impressive 8 goals from 9 starts.{{cn|date=October 2010}} Ameobi was subsequently sidelined with a hamstring injury but made the bench against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 29 March 2010. Ameobi appeared early in the second half as a substitute, and soon made his presence felt, firing in an angled left-footed shot off the post to give United the lead in a 2–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news|author=Catherine Etoe|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8591800.stm|date=29 March 2010|title=Newcastle 2–0 Nott'm Forest|publisher =BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archivedate=30 March 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100330054221/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8591800.stm}}</ref> On 3 April 2010, Ameobi scored the decisive goal in a 3–2 victory at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]].<ref>{{cite news|date=3 April 2010|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8594905.stm|title=Peterborough 2–3 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20100406023646/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8594905.stm|archivedate=6 April 2010}}</ref>

On 22 September 2010 Ameobi scored two goals in a surprise victory away at [[Chelsea F.C|Chelsea]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]], including the winner in the 90th minute.<ref>{{cite news|date=22 September 2010|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/9010051.stm|title=Chelsea 3–4 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=21 July 2011|archivedate=12 October 2013|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20131012012113/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/9010051.stm}}</ref> On 16 October 2010, Ameobi came off the bench to score Newcastle's first in a 2–2 draw against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9093223.stm|title=Newcastle 2 – 2 Wigan|author=Saj Chowdhury|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 October 2010|accessdate=16 October 2010|archivedate=8 February 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20110208081403/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9093223.stm}}</ref> After his good performance against Wigan, he started the next game against [[West Ham United]] alongside [[Andy Carroll]] putting in a good performance as The Magpies came from 1–0 down to win 2–1. He scored twice in Newcastle's next league game on 31 October 2010 as Newcastle crushed local rivals Sunderland 5–1 at St. James' Park. On 2 January 2011, he scored the winner in a 1–0 win at [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9324998.stm|author=Saj Chowdhury|title=Wigan 0 – 1 Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 January 2011|accessdate=3 January 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20110208080750/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9324998.stm|archivedate=8 February 2011}}</ref>

Despite suffering with a cheek bone injury in February which required him to wear a mask which impaired his vision upon his return, he was a regular starter after Christmas with the sale of [[Andy Carroll]]. He signed a contract extension to the end of the 2013–14 season on 10 August 2011. His current deal was due to expire at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/article-23977045-ameobi-pens-newcastle-deal.do
|title=Ameobi pens Newcastle deal
|publisher=London Evening Standard
|date=10 August 2011
|accessdate=10 August 2011}}</ref>

====Later career====
In the 2011–12 season, Ameobi became something of a fringe player, with the arrival of [[Demba Ba]] and later, [[Papiss Cissé]], pushing him onto the substitutes bench. But on Sunday 16 October 2011, against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]], Ameobi, a 71st-minute substitute for [[Leon Best]], scored a goal late on to make it 2–2. The next few games were an annoyance for Ameobi, with Ba finding his shooting boots and pairing well with Best and with Ameobi's inclusion in the starting line-up against Norwich ending up in a 4–2 defeat. On 4 March, Ameobi was yet again on the bench for a game against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and brought on as a substitute for Cissé he scored a 91st-minute equaliser to get Newcastle back on terms and bringing his tally to 7 goals in 12 games against Sunderland for Newcastle, a record only bettered by [[Jackie Milburn]]. His prolific goal scoring form against Sunderland has led many sections of the Newcastle support to refer to him as "The Mackem Slayer".<ref>{{cite web|title=As derby hero Ameobi prepares for his last Tyne-Wear clash, is the 'Mackem Slayer' set for one final act of Black Cat savagery?|author=Craig Hope|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=31 January 2014|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2549894/Shola-Ameobi-known-Mackem-Slayer-add-goals-Newcastle-against-Sunderland-Tyne-Wear-derby.html |work=[[Mail Online]]|archivedate=21 July 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140721055009/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2549894/Shola-Ameobi-known-Mackem-Slayer-add-goals-Newcastle-against-Sunderland-Tyne-Wear-derby.html}}</ref> His next league goal came nine months later, in a 1–0 win over [[Queen's Park Rangers|QPR]] on 22 December.

During Newcastle's [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] campaign, Ameobi scored three goals in the competition; the opening goal in a 3–0 win over [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] on 4 October 2012; the equaliser in a 2–2 draw with [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]] on 8 November 2012, and the only goal of the game from the penalty spot to secure a 1–0 aggregate victory over [[FC Metalist Kharkiv|Metalist Kharkiv]] on 21 February 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/358650/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739|title=Ameobi fires Magpies into last 16|publisher=[[ESPN]]|work=[[ESPN FC]]|date=21 February 2013|accessdate=21 February 2013|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140522194525/http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/358650/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739|archivedate=22 May 2014}}</ref>

Ameobi scored in a 2–0 win over [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] in the second round in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] (with his [[Sammy Ameobi|younger brother]] scoring the second goal) on 28 August 2013. Ameobi's next goal would come in the league when he scored the opening goal in a 2–1 home loss to [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] on 19 April 2014, and he also scored the opening goal in a 3–0 win over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. On the final day of the season and also, his final appearance for Newcastle, Ameobi was sent off for dissent in a 2–1 away loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].

On 23 May 2014, it was confirmed by Newcastle United that they would be parting company with Ameobi after 14 years of service for the Tyneside club.<ref>{{cite news|author=Anthony Marshall |url=//web.archive.org/web/20140524022515/http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140523/magpies-announce-retained-list_2281670_3831014|title= Newcastle United Announce Retained List|date=23 May 2014|accessdate=23 May 2014|publisher=[[Newcastle United F.C.]]}}</ref>

===Gaziantep BB===
On 11 August 2014, Ameobi signed for Turkish club [[Gaziantep Büyükşehir Belediyespor]] on a one-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Foluwa Shola AMEOBI Transferi|url=http://gaziantepbbspor.com/detail/238/foluwa-shola-ameobi-transferi.html|publisher=Gaziantep Büyükşehir Belediyespor|accessdate=11 August 2014|language=Turkish|date=11 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Transfer news: Former Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi signs one-year deal in Turkey|url=http://www1.skysports.com/transfer/news/12040/9417694/transfer-news-former-newcastle-striker-shola-ameobi-signs-one-year-deal-in-turkey|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=11 August 2014|date=11 August 2014}}</ref> He made his debut on 13 September, in a goalless draw against [[Kayserispor]], playing the full match and getting booked in the third minute.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kayserispor vs. Gaziantep BB – 13 September 2014|url=http://sg.soccerway.com/matches/2014/09/13/turkey/1-lig/kayserispor/gaziantep-bbk/1798677/|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal through a 35th-minute penalty in the 1–1 draw with [[Adanaspor]] on 19 September.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gaziantep BB vs. Adanaspor – 19 September 2014|url=http://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/09/19/turkey/1-lig/gaziantep-bbk/adanaspor-fk/1799669/|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref>

Ameobi left the club on 29 December 2014, citing family reasons for his departure. He made 11 appearances and scored 4 goals during his time there.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-Newcastle United striker Shola Ameobi leaves his club in Turkey to return to North East |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/ex-newcastle-united-striker-shola-ameobi-8368206|author=Mark Douglas|publisher=Newcastle Chronicle|date=31 December 2014|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref>

===Crystal Palace===
On 29 January 2015, Ameobi returned to the [[Premier League]] by signing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] until the end of the season. He was signed by [[Alan Pardew]], his last manager at Newcastle.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordon Mutch and Shola Ameobi sign for Crystal Palace|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31045809|accessdate=29 January 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=29 January 2015}}</ref> On 21 February 2015, he made his debut for the club after being substituted on for [[Joe Ledley]] in the eightieth minute against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].

==International career==
Nigerian-born Ameobi had a three-year spell with [[England national under-21 football team|England's under-21 team]], netting seven goals between 2000 and 2003.<ref name=NUFC/> Ameobi is the joint eighth highest goal scorer for the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21s]].<ref name=NUFC/>

In late 2009, Ameobi declared his interest in playing for [[Nigeria National Football Team|Nigeria]].<ref>[http://www.kickoff.com/news/12352/ameobi-wants-nigeria-call-up.php Ameobi wants Nigeria call-up] KickOff Magazine, 20 November 2009</ref> On 14 January 2011, he was announced in the Nigerian national squad for the first time, for a friendly against [[Guatemala national football team|Guatemala]] in the United States, in February.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.supersport.com/football/article.aspx?Id=392726|title=Ameobi snubs England for Nigeria|date=14 January 2010|publisher=SuperSport|accessdate=14 January 2010|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140721055311/http://www.supersport.com/football/article.aspx?Id=392726|archivedate=21 July 2014}}</ref> He withdrew from the replacement game against [[Sierra Leone national football team|Sierra Leone]] after breaking his cheekbone in a Premier League match.

On 1 November 2011, it was announced that FIFA had cleared Ameobi to play for Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15524642|title=Fifa clears Shola Ameobi, Moses to play for Nigeria|date=1 November 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 November 2011|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20121117003311/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15524642|archivedate=17 November 2012}}</ref>

In October 2012, Nigeria head coach [[Stephen Keshi]] expressed his interest in Ameobi joining the squad for the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Sky Sports|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11678/8166744/|title=Nigeria are considering drafting Shola Ameobi into Africa Cup of Nations squad|date=15 October 2012|accessdate=15 October 2012|archivedate=21 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140521070342/http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11678/8166744/}}</ref>

In November 2012, Ameobi received his second call up for the Nigeria national team against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]]. He made his debut on 14 November, appearing as a substitute in the 60th minute for former Newcastle teammate [[Obafemi Martins]]. In stoppage time at the end of the game, Ameobi laid on a pass for [[Ogenyi Onazi]] to make the score 3–1 to Nigeria.

He scored his first international goal for Nigeria on 10 September 2013, against [[Burkina Faso national football team|Burkina Faso]] in a friendly in Kaduna, Nigeria. In November 2013, he scored his second goal against Italy, in a friendly at [[Craven Cottage]].

On 12 May 2014, he was named in Nigeria's 30-man provisional squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/13/nigeria-world-cup-squad-odemwingie-amoebi-aluko|title=Nigeria World Cup squad: Peter Odemwingie returns from exile |date=12 May 2014|accessdate=14 May 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140514005931/http://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/13/nigeria-world-cup-squad-odemwingie-amoebi-aluko|archivedate=14 May 2014}}</ref>

During the tournament, Ameobi made a total of two substitute appearances for the Super Eagles, failing to score in either and ultimately seeing out his side's 2–0 exit to [[France national football team|France]] as an unused substitute. <ref>{{cite web|publisher=Yahoo Eurosport|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/players/shola-ameobi/|title=Shola Ameobi World Cup Profile for 2014 in Brazil |date=1 August 2014|accessdate=5 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140805185031/https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/players/shola-ameobi/|archivedate=5 August 2014}}</ref>

'''Daniel Owefin Amokachi''' (born 30 December 1972 in [[Kaduna]]) is a [[Nigeria]]n former professional [[football (soccer)|footballer]] of [[Idoma people|Idoma]] descent and assistant manager of the [[Nigeria national football team]].

As a player he was a [[striker]] from 1989 until 2005, starting his career with [[Ranchers Bees]] before earning notability by playing outside his native country with [[Premier League]] side [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], as well as [[Club Brugge]] and [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] before initially finishing his career in the [[United States]] with [[Major League Soccer]] club [[Colorado Rapids]]. He returned to Nigeria in 2005 to briefly play for [[Nasarawa United F.C.|Nasarawa United]], who he went on to manage before moving on to [[Enyimba International F.C.|Enyimba]]. He is now in his second spell as assistant manager of [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]].

== Playing career ==
Amokachi, nicknamed "The Bull"  was discovered while playing for Ranchers Bee by Nigerian national team coach [[Clemens Westerhof]], who brought the talented player to the [[1990 African Nations Cup]], and soon Amokachi moved to play for [[Club Brugge]] in [[Belgium]]. He competed in the new format of the Champions League, and became the first player to score in the competition, after his goal secured a 1–0 win in the opening match in the group stage against [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]]. Performing well in Belgium and at the 1994 World Cup, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] became interested in Amokachi and their manager [[Mike Walker (football manager)|Mike Walker]] signed him for a fee of £3,000,000 ($4,700,000).

He went on to win the [[FA Cup]] with Everton in 1995, famously infuriating manager [[Joe Royle]] by bringing himself on as a substitute then proceeding to score two goals in the semi-final against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]. He appeared in the final only briefly, late on, as a substitute but is remembered fondly for his beret wearing celebrations.

He remained at Everton until the end of the [[1995-96 in English football|1995–96 season]], when he was transferred to [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] of [[Turkey]] for a fee of £1.75million. He had failed to make the impact at [[Goodison Park]] that many fans had been hoping for, and had been unable to win a regular place in the first team, as [[Paul Rideout]] and [[Duncan Ferguson (footballer)|Duncan Ferguson]] were firmly established as Everton's two strikers at this stage. He did, however, stand in for Ferguson while he spent six weeks in prison during the autumn of 1995 for an offence committed in [[Scotland]] 18 months earlier.

== International ==
{{MedalTop}}
{{MedalCountry|{{NGA}}}}
{{MedalSport | Men's [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Football]]}}
{{MedalGold | [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Atlanta]] | [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|Team Competition]]}}
{{MedalBottom}}
He played many international matches for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]], and was part of the team that participated in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] and [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] and won the [[1994 African Nations Cup]]. He also helped win the Olympic gold medal in [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996]], scoring in the Gold Medal game itself against Argentina.

Amokachi sustained an injury just ahead of the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], played one game, but struggled with knee problems thereafter. After leaving Beşiktaş in 1999, his playing career more or less ended. He signed with [[1860 Munich]], but the contract was cancelled after he failed a medical test. In turn he was rejected by [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] for the same reason. Amokachi trained with French second division side [[US Créteil]], but the deal was hampered by injuries. American [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] team [[Colorado Rapids]] signed him in 2002, but seeing as he was not fit enough they released him before a single match was played. He went to play in the [[United Arab Emirates]], but was denied again due to his medical condition.

== Managerial career ==
Amokachi managed Nigerian club [[Nasarawa United F.C.]] and later [[Enyimba Aba]]. In April 2007 he quit his role as assistant coach of the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria national team]]. On 10 April 2008 Amokachi was re-appointed to Nigeria's national team, the Super Eagles, as assistant coach to [[Shuaibu Amodu]], also being assistant manager to [[Stephen Keshi]].
