'''Fernando Gabriel Amorebieta Mardaras''' (born 29 March 1985) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Middlesbrough F.C|Middlesbrough]] on loan from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]].

He played most of his professional career with [[Athletic Bilbao]], appearing in 253 official games over the course of eight [[La Liga]] seasons and scoring four goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavinotinto.com/03-11-2011/amorebieta-cumplio-su-partido-200-con-el-athletic/|title=Amorebieta cumplió su partido 200 con el Athletic|trans_title=Amorebieta played 200th match with Athletic|publisher=La Vinotinto|language=Spanish|date=3 November 2011|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/1821640/0/fernando-amorebieta/defensa-athletic/fichaje-fulham-premier-league/|title=El Fulham confirma el fichaje del defensa Fernando Amorebieta por cuatro temporadas|trans_title=Fulham confirms signing of defender Fernando Amorebieta for four seasons|publisher=20 Minutos|language=Spanish|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref>

Internationally Amorebieta played for [[Spain national youth football team|Spain]] as a youth, but later decided to represent [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] at senior level.

==Club career==
===Athletic Bilbao===
Born in [[Pedro María Freites Municipality|Cantaura]], [[Anzoátegui]], [[Venezuela]], Amorebieta met [[Athletic Bilbao]]'s eligibility standards, having been raised in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], and through his parents, both of whom hailed from the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/05/120508_athletic_bilbao_fain_binda_cch.shtml|title=¿Por qué en el Athletic de Bilbao solo juegan vascos?|trans_title=Why only Basque play for Athletic de Bilbao?|publisher=[[BBC]]|language=Spanish|date=9 May 2012|accessdate=8 July 2012}}</ref> He made his first-team debuts in the [[2005–06 La Liga|2005–06 season]], becoming an undisputed first-choice in the subsequent [[La Liga]] campaigns.

Amorebieta played in a total of 47 official matches in [[2009–10 La Liga|2009–10]], helping Athletic reach the [[Single-elimination tournament|round-of-32]] in [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League|the season]]'s [[UEFA Europa League]], as well as an eighth-place finish in the league; he collected 18 [[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow cards]] in the process, being [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] twice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/11/12/futbol/equipos/athletic/1321095019.html|title=Amorebieta se vuelve 'loco' con los grandes|trans_title=Amorebieta goes 'crazy' with big clubs|publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=12 November 2011|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref>

Amorebieta began the [[2012–13 La Liga|2012–13 season]] nursing a [[Athletic pubalgia|pubalgia]] ailment,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europapress.es/deportes/futbol-00162/noticia-futbol-amorebieta-athletic-cuatros-semanas-baja-ser-operado-exito-molestias-pubalgia-20120720143901.html|title=Fútbol.– Amorebieta (Athletic), cuatros semanas de baja tras ser operado con éxito de sus molestias de pubalgia|trans_title=Football.– Amorebieta (Athletic), four weeks out after successful pubalgia surgery|publisher=Europa Press|language=Spanish|date=20 July 2012|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref> and was later involved in a dispute over the extension of his contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deia.com/2012/12/19/athletic/amorebieta-lo-tomas-o-lo-dejas|title=Amorebieta: lo tomas o lo dejas|trans_title=Amorebieta: take it or leave it|publisher=Deia|language=Spanish|date=19 December 2012|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2013/01/30/paisvasco/1359547206.html|title=Urrutia: 'Ya no hay oferta por Amorebieta'|trans_title=Urrutia: 'We no longer have an offer for Amorebieta'|publisher=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|language=Spanish|date=30 January 2013|accessdate=9 May 2013}}</ref>

===Fulham===
On 15 April 2013, Amorebieta agreed to sign a four-year deal with [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a [[Free transfer (association football)|free transfer]] effective as of 1 July, after the expiration of his link with Athletic Bilbao.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2309345/Fernando-Amorebieta-agrees-sign-Fulham.html|title=Former Arsenal target Amorebieta agrees to sign for Fulham on free transfer|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=15 April 2013|location=London|first=Alex|last=Kay|date=15 April 2013}}</ref> The [[Premier League]] club officially announced his signing on 22 May,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/may/22/amorebieta-signs|title=Amorebieta arrives|publisher=Fulham F.C|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> and he made his debut on 14 September, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Kieran Richardson]] in a 1–1 draw against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at [[Craven Cottage]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23999576|title=Fulham 1–1 West Brom|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=14 September 2013|accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref>

Amorebieta scored his first goal on [[Football in England|English football]] on 26 April 2014, netting his team's second in an eventual 2–2 home draw with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27084885|title=Fulham 2–2 Hull|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 April 2014|accessdate=26 April 2014}}</ref> He made 26 appearances in a season which ended with relegation.<ref name=boro/>

On 6 March 2015, after returning from three months out injured,<ref name=boro/> Amorebieta was sent off in Fulham's 1&ndash;5 home defeat by [[AFC Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for bringing down [[Callum Wilson (English footballer)|Callum Wilson]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 1-5 Bournemouth|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31654572|accessdate=27 March 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=6 March 2015}}</ref> On the 25th, having played 8 matches all season, he was loaned to fellow [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] until the end of the campaign, with left-back [[James Husband]] moving in the opposite direction.<ref name=boro>{{cite news|title=Middlesbrough sign Amorebieta as Husband joins Fulham|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32050673|accessdate=27 March 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=25 March 2015}}</ref>

==International career==
===Spain===
Amorebieta was part of the [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spanish U19]] squad that won the [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|UEFA European Championship]] in [[2004 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2004]].<ref name="ATHLETIC">{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.net/web/main.asp?a=1&b=1&c=1&d=1&jokalaria=557&idi=2|title=Amorebieta|publisher=[[Athletic Bilbao]]|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> In August 2008 he was called up by new [[Spain national football team|senior team]] manager [[Vicente del Bosque]] for a friendly against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/seleccion/es/desarrollo/1155600.html|title=Amorebieta e Iraola, sorpresas en la lista de Del Bosque|trans_title=Amorebieta and Iraola, surprises in Del Bosque's list|publisher=Marca|language=Spanish|date=14 August 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> but did not leave the bench.

===Venezuela===
As early as 2006, Amorebieta expressed his interest in playing for the [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuelan national team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/720825.html|title=Fernando Amorebieta dispuesto a jugar ya con Venezuela|trans_title=Fernando Amorebieta willing to play for Venezuela immediately|publisher=Marca|language=Spanish|date=19 December 2006|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> However, according to [[FIFA]] rules at the time, he should have switched his affiliation prior to the age of 21, having previously played for Spain's youth teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/730290.html|title=Fernando Amorebieta no podrá jugar con la selección de Venezuela como quería|trans_title=Fernando Amorebieta will not be able to play with Venezuelan national team as he intended|publisher=Marca|language=Spanish|date=19 January 2007|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> FIFA removed the rule in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=652502&cc=5739|title=Age limit on players switching nations is removed|publisher=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=4 June 2009|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> and talks between the player and the [[Venezuelan Football Federation]] resumed.

Finally, on 2 September 2011, Amorebieta made his senior debut in a friendly with [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]], a 0–1 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/09/02/futbol/equipos/athletic/1314981017.html|title=Amorebieta debuta con Venezuela|trans_title=Amorebieta makes Venezuela debut|publisher=Marca|language=Spanish|date=2 September 2011|accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> On 11 October, against the same opponent but for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualifying campaign]], he scored in a 1–0 home win, which signified Venezuela's first-ever win against the ''Albiceleste'' in the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacapital.com.ar/ovacion/Gol-de-Amorebieta-y-Argentina-pierde-1-a-0-con-Venezuela--en-16-del-segundo-tiempo-20111011-0028.html|title=Venezuela hizo historia a costa de una desorientada y cansada Argentina|trans_title=Venezuela makes history at the expense of dizzy and tired Argentina|publisher=[[La Capital]]|language=Spanish|date=11 October 2011|accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref>

===Basque Country===
Amorebieta also appeared in four matches for the [[Basque Country national football team|Basque Country national team]] (a non-FIFA affiliate), debuting against Venezuela in [[San Cristóbal, Táchira]] on 20 June 2007.<ref name="ATHLETIC"/> The friendly match, a 4–3 Basque win, was the grand opening for the 43,000 all-seated [[Estadio Polideportivo de Pueblo Nuevo|Pueblo Nuevo Stadium]], after two years of construction for the [[2007 Copa América]].

'''Lorenzo Pier Luigi Amoruso''' (born 28 June 1971) is a retired [[Italians|Italian]] [[Association football|footballer]] who played for seven teams during his footballing career but is perhaps best known for his six-year spell with [[Glasgow]] side [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]. In that six-year spell, he managed to win nine major honours with the club including domestic trebles in seasons 1998–99 and 2002–03, representing them over 150 times in competitive football.

==Club career==

===Italy===
He began his career at local club, [[A.S. Bari|Bari]], in 1988, for whom he went on to make 75 appearances, scoring 8 goals. Amoruso spent 1991-1993 on loan at [[Mantova Calcio|Mantova]] and [[Pescara Calcio|Pescara]], but only featured intermittently. In 1995 he secured a move to [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]], becoming club captain and making 54 appearances. He won the [[Coppa Italia]] in 1996 and in 1997 the Florence side went on a remarkable run in Europe where they reached the semi-finals of the [[UEFA Cup Winners Cup]] only to lose out to eventual champions [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.serieaweekly.com/2012/01/player-profile-lorenzo-amoruso.html | title=Player Profile: Lorenzo Amoruso | accessdate=2013-05-02}}</ref>

===Rangers===
Following interest from [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-231566/Everton-chasing-Souness.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Jeff | last=Powell | title=Everton chasing Souness | date=30 May 1997}}</ref> Amoruso signed for [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] on 29 May 1997 for a fee of [[£]]4&nbsp;million. Whilst with the club he won the [[Scottish Premier League]] on three occasions, as well as the Scottish Cup three times and the Scottish League Cup three times. After missing most of his debut season with an Achilles tendon injury, he was installed as captain of Rangers by [[Dick Advocaat]] in 1998. After returning to the team Amoruso was booed by Rangers fans after several poor displays and tactical errors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/GO+EASY+ON+THE+AMO%3b+Gough+spares+a+thought+for+Lorenzo%27s+toil.%28Sport%29-a060933194|title=GO EASY ON THE AMO; Gough spares a thought for Lorenzo's toil|date=3 November 1998 |publisher=Daily Record|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> Amoruso also clashed with the manager several times, resulting in an eventually aborted move to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. Advocaat began to sign defenders to replace Amoruso, [[Bert Konterman]] for example and also [[Paul Ritchie (footballer born 1975)|Paul Ritchie]], but the [[Italy|Italian]] remained after his replacements failed. [[Paul Ritchie (footballer born 1975)|Ritchie]] did not make a single appearance<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-18753147.html|title=Ritchie the Maine attraction puts Ibrox flop behind him|date=9 September 2000 |publisher=The Scotsman|author=Mike Wade|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> while [[Bert Konterman|Konterman]] was criticised – particularly by his own fans – for being an expensive signing with minimal returns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Advocaat%27s+defence+of+A+SQUAD+THAT+just+can%27t+meet+great...-a0109683006|title=Advocaat's defence of A SQUAD THAT just can't meet great EXPECTATIONS; Reality check needed if you believe Rangers can be Europe's best|date=9 December 2000 |publisher=The Daily Mail|author=Peter Jardine|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-72599947.html|title=Football: BERT GETS A BASHING; Rangers 0 Dundee 2 Utd Fans go mad at top flop|date=21 April 2001 |author=David Leggit|publisher=The People|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref>

In December 1999, Amoruso issued a public apology after directing racist comments at [[Borussia Dortmund]]'s Nigerian striker [[Victor Ikpeba]].<ref>{{cite news
| title = Amoruso in race comment about-turn  
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/556706.stm
| publisher  = BBC Sport
| date = 10 December 1999
| accessdate = 24 March 2010}}</ref> Earlier that day Amoruso's denied the allegations and threatened legal action<ref name="McGarry"/> in an interview  to Corriere dello Sport (an Italian daily sports paper).<ref name="Phil Gordon">{{cite news|title=
Amoruso admits racist taunts|date=10 December 2000 |publisher=The Times|author=Phil Gordon|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Disgraceful+in+anyone%27s+language...-a0109783787|title=Disgraceful in anyone's language...|date=10 December 2000 |publisher=The Daily Mail|author=Roger Hannah|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> The denials were described as "vehement" by the Daily Mail.<ref name="McGarry">{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Clear+conscience%3b+Amoruso+on+the+defensive+in+wake+of+racist+smear.-a0109783951|title=
Clear conscience; Amoruso on the defensive in wake of racist smear|date=10 September 2000 |publisher=Daily Mail|author=Ian McGarry|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> He was later forced into a change of position, described as embarrassing by the Daily Mail and The Times,<ref name="Phil Gordon"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Guilty+Amoruso+is+forced+to+apologise.-a0109783789|title=Guilty Amoruso is forced to apologise|date=10 October 2000 |publisher=The Daily Mail|author=Roger Hannah|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> when TV footage contradicted his story. Subsequently the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] featured reports that [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] supporters' racism had increased, in support of Amoruso.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/565230.stm | work=BBC News | title=Fan's fear over 'racism at Rangers' | date=14 December 1999}}</ref>

In the [[Rangers F.C. season 2000–01|2000–01 season]], when Rangers exited the [[UEFA Champions League]] to [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] partly because of another bad mistake by Amoruso, he was stripped of the captaincy (which went to the 22-year-old [[Barry Ferguson]]). Amoruso had captained the club for two years, the first ever Catholic to do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3a+MY+HEART+WILL+ALWAYS+BE+AT+GERS%3b+Big+Amo+signs+off.%28Sport%29-a0105290758|title=Football: MY HEART WILL ALWAYS BE AT GERS; Big Amo signs off|date=13 July 2003 |publisher=Sunday Mail|author=Mark Guidi|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> He was left humiliated<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-94312194.html FOOTBALL: Advocaat tore off armband and ripped out my heart; ADAPTED from LA CONFIDENTIAL: The Lorenzo Amoruso Story by David McCarthy and Keith Jackson priced pounds 9.99]</ref> by the demotion and later accused Advocaat of trying to destroy him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Cover+story%3a+It+would%27ve+been+hard+to+play+for+a+gaffer+who+set+out...-a0123553304|title=It would've been hard to play for a gaffer who set out to destroy me|date=24 October 2004 |publisher=Sunday Mail|author=Mark Guidi|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref>

After [[Dick Advocaat]]'s October 2000 attack on what he described as "fat necks" in his squad, reports named the Italian as a probable target.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rangers need to be hungry again|date=24 October 2000 |publisher=The Daily Mail|author=Peter Jardine|accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> More errors had seen Amoruso again booed by his own teams' supporters.<ref name=blooper>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3a+THE+SEVEN+DEADLY+SINS+OF+LORENZO.%28Sport%29-a068201843|title=Football: THE SEVEN DEADLY SINS OF LORENZO |accessdate=10 July 2010 |author=Colin Duncan|publisher=Daily Record|date=13 December 2000}}</ref>
 
Advocaat was later removed as manager and Amoruso rediscovered his form under new boss [[Alex McLeish]]; winning the 2002 [[Scottish PFA Players' Player of the Year]]. After a four-match ban for spitting on [[James Grady]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/sport/Amoruso-banned-for-four-games.2411750.jp|title=Amoruso banned for four games for spitting |accessdate=10 July 2010 |author=Stephen Halliday|publisher=The Scotsman|date=19 March 2003}}</ref> he scored the winning goal in his final game for Rangers—the 2003 [[Scottish Cup 2002–03|Scottish Cup]] final—and wept as he left the pitch.

===Blackburn Rovers===
Amoruso left Rangers in July 2003 to make a £1.4&nbsp;million move to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn]],<ref>{{Cite news
| title = Blackburn sign Amoruso
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/blackburn_rovers/2997588.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 14 July 2003
| accessdate = 13 April 2008}}</ref> who wanted him as a replacement for [[Henning Berg]]. The sale was forced by Rangers' large debts.<ref>{{Cite news
| title = Rangers could lose Ferguson
| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/3150791.stm
| publisher = BBC Sport
| date = 15 August 2003
| accessdate = 13 April 2008}}</ref> His Blackburn debut came on 16 August 2003. On the pitch for the full ninety minutes, his place in the team appeared justified as he scored the opening goal after 17 minutes. In October, a knee injury kept him out of the game for five months, which, coming at the end of a run of bad form, was somewhat of a boost. As he returned and came into the team on a sporadic basis playing only eighteen times for Blackburn. His [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]] season was marred by regular injuries and he did not play any part of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season. He was released by Rovers in the summer of 2006.

In January 2008, Amoruso briefly came out of retirement to sign for [[S.S. Cosmos|Cosmos]] of [[San Marino]] on a part-time basis.<ref name="S.S. Cosmos">{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/footballeurope/news/kind=2/newsid=658233.html|title=Cosmos starstruck by Amoruso arrival|publisher=[[UEFA]] website|date=14 February 2008}}</ref>

==International career==
Amoruso represented [[Italy national football team|Italy]] at the [[1987 FIFA U-16 World Championship]] and won two caps at Under 21 level.

He was never selected by [[Italy national football team|Italy]] at full international level, which Amoruso attributed to a "strange mentality" pervading his homeland.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3a+AMO+IS+CUP+AGAINST+IT+FOR+A+CAP.-a082940659|title=Football: AMO IS CUP AGAINST IT FOR A CAP|publisher=Sunday Mail|date=17 February 2002}}</ref> He blamed [[Giovanni Trapattoni]], [[Cesare Maldini]] and [[Dino Zoff]] for failing to provide him with the call-up he felt he deserved.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3a+AMO%3a+BOB+CAN+DO+A+JOB+AFTER+HIS+CAP+CALL-UP.-a097372559|title=AMO: BOB CAN DO A JOB AFTER HIS CAP CALL-UP|publisher=Sunday Mail|date=9 February 2003}}</ref>

In 2004 Amoruso expressed a desire to play for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]], through residency. He said: "I began to feel like part of me was Scottish."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Football%3a+Blackburn+star%3a+I+may+give+Vogts+more+Amo.-a0113344682|title=Blackburn star: I may give Vogts more Amo|publisher=Liverpool Echo|date=17 February 2004}}</ref>

'''Benjamin Paul "Ben" Amos''' (born 10 April 1990) is an English [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on loan from [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. Born in [[Macclesfield]], [[Cheshire]], Amos began his career with [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]]'s youth academy, but joined Manchester United at the age of 11.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ben Amos Club Profile |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/First-Team/Ben-Amos.aspx?section=Profile |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref> He has spent time on loan at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]], [[Molde FK|Molde]], and [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]]. Additionally, Amos is an England youth international, having represented his country at every level from Under-16 to Under-21.

==Club career==

===Crewe Alexandra===
Amos was born in [[Macclesfield]], [[Cheshire]] and was a member of the [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] academy until he was released at the age of 10.<ref name="pfa">{{cite web |title=Ben Amos Profile |url=http://www.givemefootball.com/player-profiles/ben-amos |work=GiveMeFootball.com |publisher=Professional Footballers Association |accessdate=22 April 2011 }}</ref> While at Crewe, he also played for another local team, Bollington United,<ref>{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Stone |title=Manchester United's Ben Amos became goalkeeper by chance |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/manchester-uniteds-ben-amos-became-goalkeeper-by-chance-2147383.html |work=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print |location=London |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref> as a [[Midfielder#Centre midfielder|centre midfielder]]. One year,<!--Probably should specify, but the source doesn't state which.--> Amos was playing for his local team against the team at the top of the table, and they needed to win the match to win the league. Amos' team's [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] was injured during the game, and as the tallest on the team, Amos was put in goal;<ref>{{cite news |title=Amos' unlikely path to United nets |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/manchester_united/s/1387650_amos_unlikely_path_to_united_nets |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=11 July 2011 }}</ref> however, he had also been the team's regular [[Penalty kick|penalty]] taker all season, so when they were awarded a penalty, he went all the way up the pitch to take the kick. He scored, and his team went on to win the game 3–2, together with the league title. After the game, his parents told him that a [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] scout had been watching him and that he had been invited for trials.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ben Amos - Quote, Unquote |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Players-And-Staff/First-Team/Ben-Amos.aspx?section=Quote |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |accessdate=22 April 2011 }}</ref> Amos joined Manchester United at the age of 11.<ref name="pfa"/>

===Manchester United===
In his first season at Manchester United, Amos became a regular starter for the club's Under-13 team, playing in 19 out of 27 matches in the 2001–02 season.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Cliff |editor1-last=Butler |editor2-first=Ivan |editor2-last=Ponting |title=Manchester United Official Yearbook 2002 |year=2002 |publisher=Carlton Books |location=London |isbn=0-233-05016-7 |pages=207–210 }}</ref> Amos was named as an unused substitute for the Under-18 side for the first time on 8 January 2005, for a league game against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. His first appearance for the Under-18s came exactly nine months later, on 8 October 2005, coming on as a [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Danny Rose (footballer born 1988)|Danny Rose]] after starting goalkeeper [[Ron-Robert Zieler]] was sent off in a 2–0 defeat to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]]. He was regularly named as an unused substitute during the 2005–06 season – including for two [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserve team]] matches – but became a frequent starter for the Under-18s in 2006–07 after signing a trainee contract in July 2006.<ref>{{cite web |first=Olav |last=Ree |title=Ben Amos |url=http://www.gethome.no/redstat/?PlayerNo=1208 |publisher=redStat |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref> However, he missed the final of the 2006–07 [[FA Youth Cup]] with a [[dislocated shoulder]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Stuart |last=Mathieson |title=United kids can make Paul proud |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/manchester_united/s/1005/1005518_united_kids_can_make_paul_proud_.html |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |date=26 April 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2011 }}</ref>

He retained his place in the Under-18 team for 2007–08, in addition to making his debut for the reserve team against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 7 November 2007, and during the season he impressed enough to be selected to go on the first-team's 2008 summer tour of [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Gemma |last=Thompson |title=Reds head to South Africa |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2008/Jul/Reds-head-to-South-Africa.aspx |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=17 July 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref> Amos was named as a substitute for all three matches of the tour, but did not play. En route back from South Africa, United stopped off in [[Nigeria]] to play against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 27 July 2008, with Amos replacing [[Tomasz Kuszczak]] after 76 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Hibbs |title=Report: United 2 Pompey 1 |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2008/Jul/Report-United-2-Pompey-1.aspx |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=27 July 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> He made his competitive first-team debut on 23 September 2008 in a 3–1 win at home to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the [[2008–09 Football League Cup|third round]] of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd 3–1 Middlesbrough |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7626743.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> On 14 December 2008, Amos travelled to Japan with the Manchester United squad for the [[2008 FIFA Club World Cup]], having been called up as a late replacement for [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]], who had suffered a hand injury while training.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Gamba book United date |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2008/Dec/Gamba-book-United-date.aspx |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=14 December 2008 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

===Loans to Peterborough and Molde===
On 29 October 2009, Amos signed for the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] team [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on a month's [[Loan (sports)|loan]] as cover for Peterborough's suspended first-choice goalkeeper [[Joe Lewis (footballer)|Joe Lewis]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Posh sign Man Utd keeper on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/peterborough_united/8331810.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=29 October 2009 |accessdate=29 October 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101043807/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/peterborough_united/8331810.stm| archivedate= 1 November 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> He made his only appearance on 31 October in a 2–1 defeat against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Peterborough 1–2 Barnsley |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8326902.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=31 October 2009 |accessdate=2 November 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091102170403/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8326902.stm| archivedate= 2 November 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> After returning to Manchester United, Amos was again sent out on loan in March 2010, this time to Norwegian side [[Molde FK]], where he remained on loan until 30 June 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United-spiller til Molde FK |trans_title=Manchester United player to Molde FK |url=http://www.moldefk.no/index.php?page_id=16634 |work=moldefk.no |publisher=Molde Fotballklubb |date=6 March 2010 |accessdate=20 May 2010 }}</ref>

===Return to Manchester United===
Following the departure of [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]] from Manchester United to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], United manager [[Alex Ferguson]] declared that Amos would be Manchester United's third-choice goalkeeper for the [[2010–11 Manchester United F.C. season|2010–11 season]] behind [[Edwin van der Sar]] and Tomasz Kuszczak.<ref>{{cite news |title=Birmingham sign Manchester United goalkeeper Ben Foster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/birmingham_city/8673931.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=20 May 2010 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521082542/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/birmingham_city/8673931.stm| archivedate= 21 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> He made his first appearance of the season on 26 October 2010, starting in goal for United's 3–2 win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the fourth round of the [[2010–11 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Stevenson |title=Man Utd 3-2 Wolverhampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/9059505.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=26 October 2010 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

In United's final [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League group stage|Champions League group match]] on 7 December 2010, Amos was picked to start against [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] at [[Old Trafford]]. [[Pablo Hernández (footballer born 1985)|Pablo Hernández]] scored Valencia's only goal past him after 32 minutes of the match – the first goal United had conceded in the Champions League that season – as the two sides played out a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |title=Man Utd 1-1 Valencia |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/9260304.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=7 December 2010 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

===Loan to Oldham Athletic===
With the signing of Danish goalkeeper [[Anders Lindegaard]], Manchester United allowed Amos to join [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on loan for the remainder of the season on 7 January 2011,<ref>{{cite news |title=Oldham Athletic sign Manchester United keeper Ben Amos |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oldham_athletic/9348847.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=7 January 2011}}</ref> although he would continue to train with Manchester United once a week.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ben Amos still holds Manchester United ambition |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/oldham_athletic/s/1409301_ben_amos_still_holds_manchester_united_ambition |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=11 July 2011 }}</ref> He made his debut against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] the next day and kept a [[Shutout#Association football|clean sheet]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Oldham 2-0 Swindon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9344031.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=9 January 2011 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110125145459/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9344031.stm| archivedate= 25 January 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl=no}}</ref> However, three days later, he conceded all six goals in a 6–0 defeat at home to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]; he allowed [[Adam Lallana]]'s 20-yard shot underneath his body for the second goal, and he was rounded by [[Lee Barnard]] for the sixth.<ref>{{cite news |title=Oldham 0-6 Southampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9354145.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 January 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

On 15 March 2011, Lindegaard was ruled out for five weeks following a knee injury,<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United's Lindegaard ruled out for five weeks |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9426051.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref> so Amos was recalled from Oldham to cover for Edwin van der Sar and Tomasz Kuszczak.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ben Amos recalled by Man Utd from loan spell at Oldham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oldham_athletic/9425442.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

===Return to Manchester United===
Amos made his first start of the [[2011–12 Manchester United F.C. season|2011–12 season]] in a third round [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie at [[Elland Road]] against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]]. He kept a clean sheet as United cruised through to the next round winning 3–0.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leeds 0–3 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14893498.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=21 September 2011 }}</ref> He played again in the following round away at [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]], a game which United also won 3–0 and advanced to the quarter finals.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aldershot 0–3 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15346355.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=25 October 2011 |accessdate=26 October 2011 }}</ref> He was in goal again for United's League Cup game in a defeat against Championship club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 30 November. It also seemed that he had moved above last season's second choice [[Tomasz Kuszczak]] in the pecking order, but was now third choice behind [[Anders Lindegaard]] and [[David de Gea]]. He made his first [[Premier League]] start in a 2–0 home win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 31 January 2012, keeping a clean sheet on his debut.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd 2-0 Stoke |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/16695910.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=31 January 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2012 }}</ref>

On 30 May 2012, Amos signed a three-year contract extension with Manchester United, which will keep him at the club until at least 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2012/May/amos-and-scholes-sign-new-contracts-at-manchester-united.aspx|title=New contracts for Reds duo|date=30 May 2012|accessdate=30 May 2012|publisher=Manchester United}}</ref>

===Loan to Hull City===
[[File:Ben Amos 1.png|thumb|upright|Amos playing for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in 2012]]
On 31 July 2012, Amos joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] team [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amos Loan Deal Completed |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/amos-loan-deal-completed-274823.aspx |work=hullcityafc.net |publisher=Hull City AFC |date=31 July 2012 |accessdate=31 July 2012 }}</ref> Before the loan deal was completed, he had joined Hull on their pre-season training camp in Portugal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United goalkeeper Ben Amos joins Hull City |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18772920 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=31 July 2012 |accessdate=31 July 2012 }}</ref> He made his debut on 11 August 2012 in 7–6 penalty shoot-out victory over [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] in the first round of the [[2012–13 Football League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hull 1-1 Rotherham (7-6 pens) |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19124022 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 August 2012 |accessdate=12 August 2012 }}</ref> However, after 19 appearances, including two in the League Cup, Amos returned to Manchester United on 3 January 2013.

===Loan to Carlisle United ===
On 15 November 2013, Amos joined [[Football League One|League One]] team [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] on a month-long loan from Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=Amos loan deal agreed |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2013/Nov/ben-amos-joins-carlisle-united-on-one-month-loan.aspx |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013 }}</ref>

===Loan to Bolton Wanderers===

On 30 January 2015 he joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on a month's loan to provide competition for [[Andy Lonergan]] after [[Adam Bogdan]] was ruled out with an ankle injury picked up in training.<ref>{{cite news |first=Marc |last=Iles |title=Bolton Wanderers snap up Manchester United goalkeeper Ben Amos on loan|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/wanderers/11761088._/|publisher=The Bolton News|date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=United and Bolton agree loan move for Amos|url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2015/Jan/ben-amos-loaned-to-bolton-wanderers.aspx|first=Adam|last=Marshall|publisher=Manchester United|date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2015 }}</ref> On 21 February 2015 he made his Bolton debut as a substitute for the injured Lonergan as Wanderers lost 4-1 to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] at the [[City Ground]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nottingham Forest 4 Bolton Wanderers 1|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31466192|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 February 2015 |accessdate=21 February 2015 }}</ref>

==International career==
Amos is an England youth international, having played for his country at the [[England national under-16 football team|Under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|Under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|Under-18]], [[England national under-19 football team|Under-19]], [[England national under-20 football team|Under-20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|Under-21]] levels.<ref>{{cite news |title=A new revolution |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u20s/News/2010/amos-081210 |work=TheFA.com |publisher=The Football Association |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Ben Amos |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players?p=341358 |work=TheFA.com |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=8 July 2011 }}</ref> He was called up to the [[England national under-21 football team|Under-21]] squad in 2011 for their friendly match against [[Iceland national under-21 football team|Iceland]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Stuart Pearce releases five England U21s early |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9436992.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=27 March 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref> but he was an unused substitute.<ref>{{cite web |title=England vs Iceland - Team sheet |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2011/EnglandIceland/Teamsheets?p=ts&mid=147313 |work=TheFA.com |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 March 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2011 }}</ref>

==Personal life==
Amos attended [[The Fallibroome Academy|Fallibroome High School]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Our Express girls join Ryan Giggs and co for hospice midnight walk |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1316335_our_express_girls_join_ryan_giggs_and_co_for_hospice_midnight_walk |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |date=8 September 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref> where he earned 11 [[General Certificate of Secondary Education|GCSEs]] at grade C or above.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fallibroome High School |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/education/s/221756_fallibroome_high_school |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |date=25 August 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref>

'''Stephan Maigaard Andersen''' (born 26 November 1981) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] professional [[association football|football]] player, who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Danish Superliga]] side [[F.C. Copenhagen]]. He is also a full international for the [[Denmark national football team]] and was chosen to represent his country at [[UEFA Euro 2004]], the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2012]].

==Club career==

===Early years===
Starting his career at the youth teams of [[Hvidovre IF]], he moved youth setup of multiple Danish champions [[Brøndby IF]]. When he was no longer seen as a long-term prospect for the Brøndby goalkeeping position, he left Brøndby in the winter 1999, to rejoin Hvidovre. Andersen made his senior debut for [[Hvidovre IF]] in the lower league [[Danish 1st Division]], and was recognized as a big talent.

===AB===
In March 2002, Hvidovre owner, and professional goalkeeper, [[Peter Schmeichel]] chose to end his engagement in the club. Hvidovre actively sought to off-load Andersen, one of only two professional players in the squad. He was initially wanted by a number of clubs in [[Football in England|English football]], including Schmeichel's club [[Aston Villa FC]] and [[Sunderland AFC]], the club of Danish international goalkeeper [[Thomas Sørensen]]. Sunderland opted to buy [[Norway national football team|Norwegian international]] goalkeeper [[Thomas Myhre]] instead, and no other foreign offers materialized. Andersen moved to [[Akademisk Boldklub]] (AB) in the top-flight [[Danish Superliga]] championship in August 2002.

===Charlton Athletic===
He moved abroad to join English club [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] in a [[Danish krone|DKK]] 8 million [[transfer deal]] in June 2004.<ref name="brondbyswitch">Charlton Athletic (29 November 2006). [http://www.cafc.co.uk/newsview.ink?nid=30022 "Andersen set for Brondby switch"] cafc.co.uk (accessed 29 November 2006)</ref> In his first season with the London club, he only made two first team appearances. Due to an injury sustained by first choice goalkeeper [[Dean Kiely]], Andersen started the [[FA Premier League 2005-06|2005–06 season]] in the team. Charlton's poor mid-season form saw him dropped in favour of Kiely at first, then Thomas Myhre, who established himself as first choice as Charlton turned their season around. Andersen was reinstated into the lineup for the last two games of the season, when Myhre suffered an injury. In the 2006 summer [[transfer window]], Andersen looked ready to join [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] on a season-long [[loan (football)|loan deal]],<ref name=BBC1>BBC.co.uk (31 August 2006). [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/5304288.stm "Andersen makes Leeds loan switch"] bbc.co.uk (accessed 1 September 2006)</ref> but as Charlton insisted on a clause to allow the club to recall Andersen at any time during the season, the transfer fell through at the last moment.<ref name=SKYSP1>Sky Sports (1 September 2006). [http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=413557&CPID=10&clid=2&lid=4&title=Leeds+loan+collapses "Leeds loan collapses"] SkySports.com (accessed 1 September 2006)</ref> In the first half of the [[FA Premier League 2006-07|2006–07 season]], he saw the loaned-in [[Scott Carson]] become Charlton's starting goalkeeper.

===Brøndby IF===
In November 2006, Andersen signed a transfer deal to move back to Denmark to play for Superliga side [[Brøndby IF]] at the start of the January 2007 [[transfer window]].<ref name="brondbyswitch"/> He made some errors in his first time at the club, dropping against [[Odense Boldklub]]<ref>http://ekstrabladet.dk/sport/fodbold/udenlandsk_fodbold/international_fodbold/article157380.ece</ref> and [[Viborg FF]],<ref>http://avisen.dk/broendby-vandt-trods-drop_72735.aspx</ref> but was kept in the starting line-up and eventually upped his game. He helped Brøndby win the 2008 [[Danish Cup]],<ref>http://www.haslund.info/danmark/pt/200708/fina.asp</ref> and was named 2008 [[Det Gyldne Bur|Danish ''Goalkeeper of the Year'']].

===Later career===
[[File:Stephan Andersen.JPG|thumb|Andersen (right) training at Évian, 2012.]]
In August 2011 he joined former teammate [[Daniel Wass]] at [[Evian Thonon Gaillard F.C.|Évian]] in the French [[Ligue 1]] for a fee of DKK 2 million.<ref>http://onside.dk/nyheder/superligaen/avis-sa-meget-far-bif-for-stephan-a</ref><ref>http://brondby.com/article.asp?aid=67599</ref> In the summer of 2013 he signed a two-year contract with [[Real Betis]] of the Spanish [[La Liga]]. He was sent on loan to Dutch [[Eredivisie]] side [[Go Ahead Eagles]] on 30 January 2014 for the remainder of the 2013-14 season. On 19 May 2014 it was announced he would return to Denmark on a permanent deal, signing a three year contract with [[Danish Superliga|Superliga]] side [[FC Copenhagen]], the main rivals of his previous club Brøndby. <ref>http://www.tipsbladet.dk/nyhed/superliga/officielt-stephan-andersen-til-fc-koebenhavn</ref>

{{clear}}

==International career==
[[File:NED-DEN Euro 2012 (22).jpg|thumb|left|Andersen with [[Wesley Sneijder]] of the Netherlands at  Euro 2012. He kept a clean sheet as Denmark won 1-0.]]
Andersen was called up for the [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Danish under-21 national team]] in June 2001, where he immediately displaced the two-years older [[Rune Pedersen (footballer)|Rune Pedersen]]. While at AB, he reached 21 games for the Danish under-21 national team, and was the first goalkeeper to win a Danish talent award, when he was named 2003 [[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish ''under-21 Talent of the Year'']].

Following strong displays for AB, Andersen made his Danish national team debut against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in a March 2004 [[friendly match]]. It would be four-and-a-half years before he got his second cap. He was selected as a backup goalkeeper for the Danish national team squad at the 2004 European Championship, where Thomas Sørensen was preferred as the starting goalkeeper in every game. While playing for Brøndby, Andersen got his second cap in September 2008, and replaced the injured Thomas Sørensen for three games in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]]. He was included in the Danish squad for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]tournament. After the injured [[Thomas Sørensen]] was ruled out of [[UEFA Euro 2012]], Andersen replaced him as the first-choice goalkeeper for the Danish national team.

==Honours==
*[[Danish Football Player of the Year#Young Players of the Year|Danish ''under-21 Talent of the Year'']]: 2003
*[[Det Gyldne Bur|Danish ''Goalkeeper of the Year'']]: 2008

'''Trond Andersen''' (born 6 January 1975) is a former [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[association football|footballer]], who played as a [[central defender]] or [[holding midfielder]]. He played professional for [[Molde FK|Molde]], [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]], [[AaB Football|AaB]] and [[Brøndby IF|Brøndby]].

==Club career==
Andersen was born in [[Kristiansund]] and played for [[Clausenengen FK|Clausenengen]] before he joined [[Molde FK|Molde]] ahead of the [[1995 Norwegian Premier League|1995 season]].<ref>[http://www.playerhistory.com/player/2371 Trond Andersen] on [[Playerhistory.com]] {{dead link|date=February 2013}}</ref> He played for the [[Tippeligaen]] side until the summer of 1999, when he was sold to [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]], right before Molde's [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] matches against [[RCD Mallorca|Mallorca]]. Molde's head coach [[Erik Brakstad]] stated in 2011 that if the club had not sold their best player (Andersen), Molde could have advanced from the group stage of [[1999–2000 UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.rbnett.no/eliteserien/article214101.ece |language=Norwegian |title=Brakstad tror Molde kan overraske i Europa |publisher=[[Romsdals Budstikke]] |date=4 November 2011 |accessdate=4 November 2012}}</ref>

After playing for Wimbledon for four seasons, Andersen moved to [[Denmark]] to play for [[AaB Fodbold|Aalborg]] in the [[Danish Superliga]] in 2003, before being bought by rivals [[Brøndby IF|Brøndby]] in September 2005. In April 2006, he suffered a knee injury. As he had not recovered by March 2007, Andersen considered retiring from the game.

==International career==
Andersen played 38 matches for the [[Norway national football team]].<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/noo-recintlp.html Norway – Record International Players] – RSSSF</ref> He was in roster for [[2000 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 2000]]. His last international match was an April 2005 friendly match against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]].

==Honours==
