'''Patrik "Bjärred" Jonas Andersson''' ({{IPA-sv|ˈpɑːtrɪk ˈanːdəˈʂɔn|pron}}; born 18 August 1971 in [[Borgeby]]) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] former [[Association football|footballer]]. Both his father, [[Roy Andersson (footballer)|Roy Andersson]], as well as his younger brother, [[Daniel Andersson (footballer born 1977)|Daniel Andersson]], have also played professional football.

==Club career==
Starting his career in the local club, Bjärreds IF, from which he also got [[Bjärred|his nickname]], he moved on to [[Malmö FF]], a team playing in the top national league. 

In December 1992, he went professional as he moved to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] for £800,000, where he stayed for one year, making just 12 [[Premier League]] appearances. However, he is notable for being one of the first foreign signings by Blackburn Rovers, and one of the relatively small group of foreigners who appeared in the first season of the new [[Premier League]] in [[Football in England|England]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/342956.stm | title = Boom and bust the Blackburn way | publisher = BBC | date = 13 May 1999 | accessdate = 21 December 2010}}</ref>

His next step was to go to Germany in October 1993<ref>{{cite web | url = http://sklady.hostmix.pl/infopage.php?id=1281 | title = Borussia M'Gladbach 1993/94 | publisher = sklady.hostmix.pl | date = 1 February 2015 | accessdate = 1 February 2015}}</ref> and play for [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]]. There he won the [[1994–95 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] with the team in 1995, but left the team as its performance deteriorated, in 1999. The famous [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] became his next club. His time with Bayern resulted in two Bundesliga championships (in the [[2000–01 Bundesliga|2000–01]] championship season he scored the final and decisive goal against [[Hamburger SV]] in the last minute<ref>{{cite web | url =  http://www.sport1.de/de/fussball/fussball_bundesliga/artikel_104971.html | title = Vier Minuten im Mai | language = German | publisher = sport1.de | accessdate = 21 January 2010 | date = 12 May 2009}}</ref> – his only goal for the club) as well as a [[1999–2000 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] and victory in the [[2000–01 UEFA Champions League]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fussballdaten.de/spieler/anderssonpatrik/ | title = Patrik Andersson | language = German | publisher = fussballdaten.de | accessdate = 21 January 2010}}</ref> despite missing his penalty in the [[2001 UEFA Champions League Final|final]] shootout.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/champions_league/1346307.stm | title = Bayern crowned European champions | publisher = BBC Sport | accessdate = 21 January 2010 | date = 23 May 2001}}</ref> Andersson moved to Catalan giants [[FC Barcelona]] in 2001 and spent three injury-plagued seasons there.

For the 2004 season, Andersson came back to Malmö FF to play in the Swedish league again after 10 years. This year he captained Malmö FF who won their first Swedish league (Allsvenskan) title in 15 years. He has twice been awarded [[Guldbollen]] as the Swedish footballer of the year, in 1995 and 2001. After suffering yet another knee injury during a Champions League qualifier against Swiss team [[FC Thun]] on 10 August 2005,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/11/sports/11iht-world.html | title = Roundup:Doubts surround 2 league kickoffs | publisher = The New York Times| accessdate = 21 January 2010 | date = 12 August 2005}}</ref> Andersson announced his retirement from top level football on 12 August 2005. He is currently employed as the Scandinavian scout of [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web | url =  http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/7962896/Manchester-United-midfielder-Anderson-returns-to-action-for-first-time-since-cruciate-injury.html |title=Anderson makes successful return in Manchester United's £48m reserves|work=Telegraph.co.uk|date= 24 August 2010 |first=Mark|last=Ogden|accessdate= 4 September 2010}}</ref>

==International career==
Andersson earned a total of 96 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for the [[Sweden national football team|Swedish national team]], scoring three goals. He won a bronze medal in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]]. Andersson also played in the team which reached the semi-finals in the [[UEFA Euro 1992|1992 European Championship]]. He was also part of the Swedish national squad that took part in the [[UEFA Euro 2000|Euro 2000]], [[2002 FIFA World Cup]] and was a member of the Swedish squad that competed at the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in Barcelona.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Sports Reference|title=Patrik Andersson Biography and Statistics|url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/an/patrik-andersson-1.html|accessdate= 29 October 2009}}</ref> In [[2000 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 2000]], he received a red card for a hard foul on Belgium's [[Bart Goor]].<ref>{{cite web| publisher = UEFA |title = Belgium start with a bang |url = http://www1.en.uefa.com/history/season=2000/round=1458/match=64851/index.html | accessdate= 21 January 2010}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

'''Darren Robert Anderton''' (born 3 March 1972) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who spent most of his career with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] as a [[midfielder]]. He played 30 times for the [[England national football team]], scoring 7 goals.

==Career==
Anderton started his career in the Southampton Tyro League and played for Itchen Saints during a successful period for the side.  His potential was evident and he was soon scouted and playing youth football at professional clubs. Renowned as a player of huge potential, Anderton's career has been constantly frustrated by injury earning him the nickname "''Sicknote''"<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/1640891.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Anderton hands in his sicknote | date=6 November 2001 | accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref> which was coined by Portsmouth goalkeeper [[Andy Gosney]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-anderton-cheers-before-the-jeers-1157184.html |title=Football: Anderton cheers before the jeers |first=Andrew |last=Longmore |date=24 May 1998 |accessdate=2009-07-03 |work=[[The Independent]] |location=London}}</ref>

===Portsmouth: 1990–1992===
Anderton was signed as an apprentice by [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] manager [[Alan Ball, Jr.|Alan Ball]], coming to prominence at 18 when he scored at [[Anfield]] in an [[FA Youth Cup]] match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] which ended 2–2. His first team debut came against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in the second round of the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] in October 1990 as a substitute for youth team colleague [[Darryl Powell]]. Anderton made his full league debut against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in a 0–0 draw, making 20 appearances in the 1990–91 season. Under new manager [[Jim Smith (footballer)|Jim Smith]], Anderton became a regular in the attacking side of the 1991–92 season, scoring his first club goal in the season opener against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. His performances soon drew the attention of bigger clubs and after an impressive [[FA Cup]] run, during which he scored in a semi-final clash with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], he joined [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] for £1.75 million in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/famousplayers/Darren-Anderton--overnight-superstar.1396519.jp|title=Darren Anderton – overnight superstar|publisher=Portsmouth News|date=26 March 2006|accessdate=2008-12-07}}</ref>

===Tottenham Hotspur: 1992–2004===
After a slow start, Anderton settled at Tottenham, playing as a striker, forming part of an exciting attacking trio along with [[Teddy Sheringham]] and the young [[Nick Barmby]]. Two years later [[Terry Venables]] gave Anderton his [[England national football team|England]] debut against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] in 1994. Anderton soon became a regular in the national side and turned down a move to [[Manchester United]] in the summer of 1995 following an exciting season spent playing with the likes of [[Jürgen Klinsmann]] at Tottenham, a decision that he later regretted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jiggins |first=Paul |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article2006425.ece |title=I regret snubbing Utd &#124; The Sun &#124;Sport&#124;Football |publisher=The Sun |date=5 December 2008 |accessdate=2010-10-06 |location=London}}</ref>

In October 2010, 15 years after this transfer saga, Anderton revealed that he had decided against a move to Manchester United because he had been happy at Tottenham and manager [[Gerry Francis]] was not happy at the prospect of losing another key player as he had already lost [[Jürgen Klinsmann]] and [[Gheorghe Popescu]] that summer; and [[Nick Barmby]] was on the verge of joining [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/3172047/Darren-Anderton-reveals-he-could-have-taken-David-Beckhams-starting-spot-at-Manchester-United.html | location=London | work=The Sun | title=I couldve been ahead of Becks | date=8 October 2010}}</ref>

Despite missing most of the 1995–96 season through injury, Anderton played an important part in the [[1996 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 96]] England team that reached the semi-finals and included players like [[Paul Gascoigne]], [[Alan Shearer]], [[Steve McManaman]] and [[Teddy Sheringham]].  In the semi final against Germany, the match went to golden goal extra time. Anderton came within inches of putting England into the final when his shot hit the post.

Injuries then limited Anderton's international appearances considerably. He missed most of the 1997–98 season but was recalled for [[Glenn Hoddle]]'s squad for the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] in France, starting on the right wing in the first two matches ahead of an out-of-sorts [[David Beckham]]. Hoddle later said in his World Cup Diary that he thought Anderton was equally as good as Beckham at crossing and was a better defender. Hoddle said he had waited 18 months to play Beckham and Anderton together on the right side of midfield. It finally happened as [[David Batty]] was dropped and the now-focused Beckham was recalled for the third game against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] and played inside of Anderton. Anderton and Beckham were the England heroes as they both scored spectacular goals. In the second round against Argentina, England went on to lose on penalties. The following year Anderton won the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] with Tottenham, and signed a new reported £24,000-week contract in March.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/688431.stm|title=Anderton signs new Spurs deal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 March 2000|accessdate=2008-12-05}}</ref> After being sidelined during [[2000 UEFA European Football Championship|Euro 2000]] with an [[Achilles tendon]] injury,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/euro2000/teams/england/743086.stm|title=Anderton out of Euro 2000|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 May 2000|accessdate=2008-12-05}}</ref> an extended run of fitness saw Anderton vying for a permanent place in the national team again. He played in England's 1–1 draw away to [[France national football team|France]] in September 2000 and also featured against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] the following November.

In the summer of 2001 Anderton was heavily linked with a move to Liverpool but he remained at the club and his good form for Glenn Hoddle's Spurs during the early part of the 2001–02 season earned his first call-up to [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]]'s England squad for a friendly against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in November. Anderton was again selected by Eriksson for England's next game, a friendly against Holland, in February 2002. He would have started the game but was forced to withdraw through injury. One notable statistic about Anderton's England career is that his last five caps were given to him by five different managers. These were: vs Czech Republic (18 November 1998) by [[Glenn Hoddle]], vs France (10/02/99) by [[Howard Wilkinson]], vs France (02/09/00) by [[Kevin Keegan]], vs Italy (15 November 2000) by [[Peter Taylor (footballer born 1953)|Peter Taylor]] and vs Sweden (10/11/01) by [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]].

Anderton continued to struggle badly with injuries for the rest of that season, missing out on a World Cup place. That summer the new [[Leeds United A.F.C|Leeds United]] boss [[Terry Venables]] tried to recruit Anderton, but he turned down the move out of loyalty to Tottenham. In the summer of 2003 Portsmouth and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] made attempts to sign him, but Anderton opted against a move. He made a bright start to the 2003/04 season, scoring against Tottenham's bitter rivals Arsenal. However Hoddle was soon sacked and Spurs were in turmoil. Anderton remained at Tottenham until the summer of 2004. He was keen to remain at the club and was promised a new contract by [[David Pleat]] but the club, under the advice of incoming manager [[Jacques Santini]], reneged. In all, he appeared in 364 games for Spurs, scoring 51 goals. Santini went on to last a grand total of 13 games at the club. Anderton has been promised a testimonial but this is yet to materialise.

===Birmingham City and Wolverhampton Wanderers: 2004–2006===
[[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] swooped to sign Anderton on a free transfer for the [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]] season. His best moment for the Blues was scoring the winner in the 1–0 victory over Liverpool at [[Anfield]].

Anderton left Birmingham on a free transfer after one year and reunited with Glenn Hoddle at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], signing a one-year deal at the start of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wolverhampton_wanderers/4170992.stm|title=Wolves complete Anderton transfer|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 August 2005|accessdate=2008-12-05}}</ref> He played 24 times for Wolves, scoring once in the league against Sheffield  Wednesday.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/4538040.stm
|title=Sheff Wed 0–2 Wolves 
|publisher=BBC 
|date=28 December 2005 |accessdate=11 September 2009}}</ref> He also scored in a 5–1 win over Chester City in the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/4168884.stm
|title=Wolves 5–1 Chester 
|publisher=BBC 
|date=23 August 2005 |accessdate=3 November 2009}}</ref> His contract was not renewed at season's end.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wolverhampton_wanderers/4976594.stm |title=Wolves and Anderton part company  |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2006 |accessdate=2009-05-21}}</ref>

===AFC Bournemouth: 2006–2008===
On 8 September 2006, Anderton joined [[Football League One|League One]] side [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on a 'pay-as-you-play' basis, scoring a spectacular 40-yard free kick on his first team debut against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportbox.tv/football/matchcentre/matchreport.php?id=3032512 |title=Bournemouth vs Scunthorpe - Football League One - Live MatchCentre |publisher=Sportbox.tv |date=23 September 2006 |accessdate=2010-10-06}}</ref> On 10 February 2007, he scored his first career hat-trick against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. Following a pre-season friendly with Portsmouth in July 2007, Portsmouth boss [[Harry Redknapp]] heaped praise on Anderton, telling the [[Bournemouth Daily Echo]]: "In the right team and with the right players around him, I honestly think he could still be playing in the Premiership".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.thisisdorset.net/2007/8/1/127903.html |title=Cheeky One |publisher=Archive.thisisdorset.net |date=1 August 2007 |accessdate=2010-10-06}}</ref>

At the start of the 2007/08 season, Anderton was named as the new Cherries club captain by manager [[Kevin Bond (footballer)|Kevin Bond]]. Anderton spearheaded a survival bid at the end of the season, with the Cherries winning six of the seven last games, but, ultimately, a 1–1 draw with Carlisle on the final day saw Bournemouth relegated to [[Football League Two|League Two]]. Bournemouth were deducted 10 points earlier in the season for going into administration and had this not happened they would have finished in a respectable 15th.

Anderton signed a new one-year contract with Bournemouth at the start of the 2008/09 season which would have taken him past his 37th birthday. However, on 4 December 2008, Anderton announced he would retire on 7 December 2008, one day after his last game for club against [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bournemouth/7766130.stm|title=Anderton to retire from football|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 December 2008|accessdate=2008-12-05}}</ref> In his last match, versus Chester, Anderton bowed out of football with a fairytale finish, as he scored the winning goal with a spectacular volley in the 88th minute after coming on as a substitute in the second half of the game.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/3956312.ANDERTON_S_FAIRYTALE_FINISH/ | title=Anderton's fairytale finish| year=2008 | publisher=[[Bournemouth Daily Echo]] | accessdate=2008-12-06}}</ref>

==Post-playing career==
Anderton has worked as the in-studio analyst for Canadian network [[The Sports Network|TSN]]'s coverage of [[Euro 2012]]. In 2013, Anderton was unveiled as the Honorary President of Arlington Spurs [http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/supporters-clubs/arlington-spurs/], a Tottenham Hotspur supporters club based in Arlington, Virginia, USA.

'''Bruno Miguel Carvalho Andrade''' (born 2 October 1993) is a Portuguese [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]], on loan from [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].

Born in [[Viseu]], Andrade joined the academy of Queens Park Rangers at a young age, and has gone on to make a total of four first-team appearances for the club. He has also had loan spells at [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] and [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]].

==Playing career==
Born in Portugal, Andrade joined the [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] academy at the age of 13.<ref name="aldershot">{{cite news|title=QPR winger Bruno Andrade joins Aldershot Town on loan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/aldershot/9603426.stm|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=29 September 2011}}</ref> He made his debut for Queens Park Rangers against Preston North End on 20 November 2010.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9194908.stm
|title=QPR   3 - 1   Preston
|publisher=[[BBC]] 
|date=20 November 2010 |accessdate=1 May 2011 | location=London}}</ref> He then made his second appearance for the club against Blackburn Rovers in the FA Cup. He replaced [[Jamie Mackie]] who had broken his leg.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/9341924.stm
|title=Blackburn   1 - 0   QPR
|publisher=[[BBC]] 
|date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=1 May 2011 | location=London}}</ref> He made a further two first-team appearances at the beginning of the 2011–12 season, including his Premier League debut.<ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/14600485.stm
|title=Wigan   2 - 0   QPR
|publisher=[[BBC]] 
|date=27 August 2011 |accessdate=1 May 2011 | location=London}}</ref> Soon after, Andrade was loaned out to [[Football League Two|League Two]] side [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] for one month from 29 September 2011.<ref name="aldershot" /> He made a total of two appearances for Aldershot before returning to QPR,<ref name="wycombe">{{cite news|title=Wycombe Wanderers bring in QPR winger Bruno Andrade|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19888165|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=9 October 2012}}</ref> where he did not make any more appearances for the season. 

Having not made a first team appearance in over a year, on 9 October 2012 Andrade was loaned out to another League Two side, [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], on an initial month's loan.<ref name="wycombe" /> The loan went on to be extended until the end of the season,<ref>{{cite news|title=Andrade staying with Chairboys|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11065/8403818/andrade-staying-with-chairboys|work=Sky Sports|publisher=BSkyB|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=17 January 2013}}</ref> and Andrade made a total of 26 appearances and scored 2 goals in his time at Wycombe. 

Following his semi-successful loan spell at Wycombe the previous season, Andrade joined [[Football League One|League One]] club [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] on a three-month loan deal on 4 October 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stevenage: Francis Zoko and Bruno Andrade join Boro|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24401921|work=BBC Sport|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=4 October 2013}}</ref> Then in mid-January, Andrade loan spell with the club was extended for another month.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rangers duo stay with Boro|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9110029/rangers-duo-stay-with-boro|publisher=Sky Sports|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=17 May 2014}}</ref> A month after it was extended, Andrade would return to Queens Park Rangers in conclusion of Stevenage loan spell.<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR and Leicester loanees return to parent clubs|url=http://www.thecomet.net/stevenage-fc/qpr_and_leicester_loanees_return_to_parent_clubs_1_3337962|publisher=The Comet|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=17 May 2014}}</ref> In May, Andrade was offered a new contract with the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20140505150933/http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/qpr-young-guns-offered-new-7073872|title=QPR young guns offered new deals|publisher=Get West London|accessdate=17 May 2014|date=|archiveurl=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/qpr-young-guns-offered-new-7073872|archivedate=17 May 2014<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

'''Pierre-Yves André''' (born 14 May 1974 in [[Lannion]], [[Côtes-d'Armor]]) is a retired French [[Association football|footballer]]. He spent most of his career playing for [[SC Bastia]], and retired after the club suffered relegation to the French third tier following the [[2009–10 Ligue 2|2009–10 season]].

In 2003, André had a six-month loan spell at the English club [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] and successfully helped the side stave off relegation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bolton snap up French duo|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/2715341.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2003|accessdate=24 August 2011}}</ref>

'''Leon Hougaard Andreasen''' (born 23 April 1983 in [[Aidt]], [[Jutland]]) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] professional [[Association football|football]] player, who plays as a [[defender (association football)|defender]] or [[midfielder]]. He has won twenty caps and scored three goals for the [[Denmark national football team]]. He currently plays for [[Hannover 96]].

==Biography==
Andreasen started playing football at local club Hammel GF. After a stay at the very popular football academy, Hessel Gods Fodboldkostskole in Grenaa, he moved on to the youth team of [[Aarhus Gymnastik Forening|AGF Aarhus]] in 1999, where he signed his first contract in 2001. He established himself as a regular in AGF's squad for the top-flight [[Danish Superliga]] championship. He initially played as a right midfielder or right back, but eventually settled in the [[central defender]] position. He was called up for the Danish under-19 national team in May 2001, and went on to play 31 games and score six goals for various Danish youth selections.

On 1 July 2005, he moved to Germany to play for [[SV Werder Bremen]] in [[Bundesliga]] championship. Due to the injury of [[Finland|Finnish]] defender [[Petri Pasanen]], Andreasen played 12 of the first 17 league games for Werder Bremen. When Pasanen recovered in December 2005, Andreasen was often relegated to the reserves' bench for the second half of the season. In May 2006, he was selected for the [[Denmark under-21 national football team|Danish under-21 national team]] squad for the [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2006 European Under-21 Championship]]. As age restrictions were calculated from the start of the qualification matches in September 2004, he competed in the tournament at age 23. When the Denmark under-21s were eliminated in the preliminary group stage, Andreasen's youth national team career was over.

In his second season at Werder Bremen, Andreasen only played four games in the first half of the season. In January 2007, he was [[Loan (football)|loaned out]] to German league rivals [[1. FSV Mainz 05]]. He made his debut on 27 January against [[VfL Bochum]], in the [[defensive midfielder]] position,<ref>{{cite web|title=VfL Bochum vs Mainz – Bundesliga 2006/2007|work=Football-Lineups.com
|url=http://www.football-lineups.com/match/3306/ | accessdate= 8 December 2013}}</ref> and went on to score four goals in his first seven games for Mainz. Although he couldn't prevent Mainz from being relegated, his stay at Mainz was a great success. In March 2007, he was called up to the [[Denmark national football team|Danish national team]] by national manager [[Morten Olsen]].<ref>{{cite web | author = Lars Berendt | language = Danish | url = http://www.dbu.dk/news/newsShow.aspx?id=237741 | title = 22 spillere mod Spanien | publisher = DBU | date = 14 March 2007 | accessdate = 21 January 2010}}</ref> He made his debut against [[Spain national football team|Spain]], where he replaced [[Martin Jørgensen]] in the first half, before he was substituted for [[Nicklas Bendtner]] in the second half.

He joined [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in January 2008 for an undisclosed fee on a three-and-a-half-year deal that will see him at the club until the summer of 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2008/january/22/andreasen-joins-fulham | title = Andreasen Joins Fulham | date = 8 December 2013 | accessdate = 26 December 2010 | publisher = Fulham FC}}</ref>

Andreasen had limited chances to establish a place at Fulham and therefore left the club for Germany's Hannover 96 in the winter break in 2009. He initially signed on loan for 6 months and after strong performances, made a permanent move.

'''Martin Andresen''' (born 2 February 1977 in [[Kråkstad]]) is a former [[Norway|Norwegian]] football player. From 2008 to 2012, he was the manager of [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]].

==Club career==
Martin Andresen was a regular on many Norwegian national youth teams while playing for [[Moss FK|Moss]], [[Viking FK|Viking]] and [[Stabæk Fotball]] from 1995–1999. After the 1999 season, Andresen was sold to [[Premier League]] club [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] in a deal worth £1. million. But like many of the other Norwegians in the club, his stay became short and unsuccessful. After a short loan spell at [[Molde FK|Molde]], Andresen returned to his motherclub Stabæk in 2001, where he proved himself to be one of the best central midfielders in Norway. When he were in Stabæk he also gave "kokkos" to Roar Strand which Roar Strand were not very excited for, this is one of Martin Andresen's proudest moments. 

After a brilliant 2003 season, where Stabæk captured the bronze medals in the [[Norwegian Premier League]], Andresen was loaned out to the [[Premier League|Premiership]] club [[Blackburn Rovers]] for six months in 2004, from February to August, but did not sign a longer deal with the English club. Andresen once again decided to return to Stabæk to save the club from relegation from the [[Norwegian Premier League]], but despite that Andresen played even while injured, Stabæk could not save their spot in the highest Norwegian league. Andresen, not willing to play in the [[Adeccoligaen|Adeccoliga]], asked to be sold. Many clubs in Norway were interested in the newly appointed national team [[Captain (association football)|captain]], but the high price scared many away, including the champions [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]]. Vålerenga looked set to capture Andresen just before Christmas 2004, but Brann, with help from local investors signed the midfielder on 23 December 2004.

===Brann===
Martin Andresen became the most expensive transfer in [[SK Brann|Brann]] history, in a deal worth ca. 15.000.000 NOK (£1.310.000). After a disappointing first season, much ruined by injuries, Andresen made it clear that he would be "fit for fight" in 2006. In the pre-season he was appointed captain for Brann, clearly showing his importance for the club on and off the field. In 2006, Brann had their best season opening ever,{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} with Andresen filling the captain role. He also periodically captained the Norwegian national team, playing in central midfield. In 2007 Brann won the Norwegian League, with Andresen as captain. He was described as the most valuable player by many Norwegian pundits.{{who|date=May 2012}} He was also named in the Team of the Year.

===Vålerenga===
Andresen was announced as the new manager of [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]] on 6 November 2007 while still under contract with Brann for the remainder of the year. Brann terminated their working relationship with Andresen the day after. He signed a three-year-long contract with Vålerenga as player and manager. Andresen became the first player/head coach in the Norwegian top division ([[Tippeligaen]]) since [[Kjetil Rekdal]] (also with Vålerenga) in 2002.

He retired as a player before the 2010 season, but continued to play several matches for the reserve team in the [[Norwegian Second Division]]. In 2011, he played for [[Follo FK]] who were in the same division, making eight appearances for the club.

On 15 October 2012, Andresen was dismissed as manager for Vålerenga.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tv2.no/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/martin-andresen-ferdig-i-vaalerenga-3900579.html|title=Andresen ferdig i Vålerenga|language=Norwegian}}</ref>

He came out of retirement and joined [[Stabæk Fotball|Stabæk]], who had been relegated from Tippeligaen, ahead of the 2013 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nettavisen.no/sport/fotball/article3591601.ece |language=Norwegian |title=Martin Andresen gjør comeback |publisher=Nettavisen |first=Anders Modun |last=Bilet |date=18 March 2013 |accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref>

==International career==
He made his debut for [[Norway national football team|Norway]] in 15 August 2001 friendly match against [[Turkey national football team|Turkey]] and has earned a total of 43 caps, scoring 3 goals.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/noo-recintlp.html Norway – Record International Players] – RSSSF</ref>

==Private life==
Martin Andresen is an heir to the Norwegian furniture manufacturer [[Skeidar]].

He is also a keen [[contract Bridge|bridge]] player.<ref>{{no icon}} [http://bridgemagasiner.no/var/fckeditor/bridgemagasiner/file/Bulletiner/Norsk%20Bridgefestival/2003/bridgefestival_2003_stavanger_bulletin_3.pdf Norsk Bridgefestival 2003]</ref> In December 2009 he partnered Tor Helness to win one of the side events in the North American Bridge Championships in [[San Diego]].<ref>[[Daily Telegraph]] Bridge News p34 Issue no 48, 060 (dated 8 December 2009)</ref>

'''Ian Edmund Andrews'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swindon-town-fc.co.uk/Person.asp?PersonID=ANDREWSI |title=Ian Andrews |work=Swindon-Town-FC.co.uk |accessdate=8 October 2009}}</ref> (born 1 December 1964 in [[Nottingham]]) is an English former [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] in [[the Football League]] for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], and in the [[Scottish Premier League]] for [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/ianandrews.html |title=Ian Andrews |work=UK A–Z Transfers |publisher=Neil Brown |accessdate=8 October 2009}}</ref> He was [[cap (sport)|capped]] by [[England under-21 national football team|England at under-21]] level.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u21-intres86.html |title=England - U-21 International Results 1986-1995 - Details |publisher=RSSSF |first=Barrie |last=Courtney |date=10 January 2004 |accessdate=8 October 2009}}</ref> His last appearance in the League was for Bournemouth in 1996, but while working for Leicester City as goalkeeping [[coach (sport)|coach]] and [[physiotherapist]], he was an unused [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] as late as the 2001–02 season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~57563,00.html |title=Swedish Keeper Arrives |publisher=Leicester City F.C |date=5 March 2001 |accessdate=9 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~160633,00.html |title=Elliott Returns, Walker Misses Out  |publisher=Leicester City F.C |date=23 January 2002 |accessdate=9 October 2009}}</ref> In 2004 he joined [[Team Bath F.C.|TeamBath]] as physiotherapist.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teambath.com/2007/02/ian-andrews-physiotherapist/ |title=Ian Andrews / Physiotherapist |publisher=Team Bath |accessdate=9 October 2009}}</ref>

He is an alumnus of [[Manchester Metropolitan University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mmu.ac.uk/alumni/notable.php?a=4 |title=Notable Alumni in Sport |publisher=Manchester Metropolitan University |accessdate=24 November 2009}}</ref>

'''Keith Joseph Andrews''' (born 13 September 1980) is an [[Irish people|Irish]] association footballer who plays as a [[defensive midfielder]] for [[Football League One]] team [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] on loan from [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]].

Andrews began his career at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]], where he was their youngest [[Captain (association football)|captain]] for more than a century. His club career has also involved stints at [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]], as well as loan spells at [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] while he was at Wolves. While at Milton Keynes Dons he was club captain, helped secure promotion for his team with a vital goal, helped win his team the [[Football League Trophy]] by scoring in the final at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] and was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].

A full international since 2008, Andrews has gained over 30 caps for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2012]].

==Club career==

===Wolverhampton Wanderers===
Andrews began his career as a trainee at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]], progressing from their academy to the first team. He made his senior debut on 18 March 2000 in a 2–1 win at [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon]]. He continued his progress with the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] club in the [[2000–01 in English football|2000–01 season]], becoming a regular player as [[Dave Jones (football manager)|Dave Jones]] took over midway through. He went on a loan spell at Oxford United, scoring once against Swansea City.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/1016610.stm|title=Swansea 1–2 Oxford|publisher=BBC 
|date=11 November 2000 |accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref> Back at Wolves, the final match of that season saw him become their youngest captain for more than a hundred years, at 21 years old, in a game against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].

He signed a new four-year deal the following season but found himself out of the starting line-up after several new midfielders were acquired in the summer, resigning him to the substitutes bench and sporadic appearances over the next few seasons. To gain playing time, he spent half of the [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04]] season on loan at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and the latter half at [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], where he scored two league goals against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] and [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. He did however return to [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]] in between to make his only [[Premier League]] appearance for Wolves (against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]).

The midfielder returned to Wolves' team post-relegation in [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]] and gained his most appearances for the club during that season. However, he moved on at the end of his contract to join [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]. In total, he made 72 appearances for the Midlanders, scoring once in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie at [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/3585770.stm|title=Rochdale 2–4 Wolves|publisher=BBC |date=23 August 2004 |accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref>

===Hull City===
His new start with the Hull saw him sidelined again though, as he picked up an injury in only his second appearance for the team – in a match against his previous team, Wolves. He returned to the team in December after nearly four months out and featured in all but one of their remaining fixtures in what proved to be his only season for the club.

===Milton Keynes Dons===
After a single year at [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull]], he moved to [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] of [[Football League Two|League Two]] for the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] campaign where he became club captain. He lost out on promotion in the [[Football League Two play-offs#2007|play-offs]], despite scoring in the semi-final tie with [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]].

However, the next year, now under the managerialship of his former [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] team-mate [[Paul Ince]], brought Andrews success. He scored the winning goal in a match at [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] on 19 April 2008 that saw the club promoted to [[Football League One|League One]], and also scored the opening goal of their 2–0 victory over [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] with a penalty in the [[Football League Trophy]] at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7309420.stm | work=BBC News | title=Grimsby 0–2 MK Dons | date=30 March 2008 | accessdate=7 May 2010 | first=Mark | last=Mitchener}}</ref> The season ended with him being voted into [[PFA Team of the Year]] and having already won the League Two Player of the Year Award at the Football League Awards. Andrews was then named at number 38 in a ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' poll of the top 50 football league players, as well as being named the best player in League 2.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fourfourtwo.com/blogs/footballleagueawards/archive/2008/03/02/fourfourtwo-50-best-football-league-players.aspx|title=FourFourTwo 50 Best Football League Players|publisher=FourFourTwo|date=2 March 2008|accessdate=2 March 2008}}</ref> [[MK Dons]] then had a fight on their hands to keep hold of their inspirational skipper with interest from a number of [[Premier League|Premiership]] and [[Championship]] clubs. He featured in MK Dons's first three games of the 2008–09 season but then was sold to [[Blackburn Rovers]] managed by former manager [[Paul Ince]].

===Blackburn Rovers===
Andrews ended a summer of speculation over his future when he completed a transfer to [[Premier League]] club [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 3 September 2008 in a three-year deal worth and rising up to £1m depending on appearances made for the football club over the coming years.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/blackburn_rovers/7586080.stm | title = Blackburn snap up MK Dons skipper | publisher = BBC Sport | date=28 August 2008}}</ref> The move temporarily reunited him with his former [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|MK Dons]] manager [[Paul Ince]] before he was sacked as Rovers manager. He made his debut as a substitute on 6 September 2008 against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], a game in which Blackburn lost 4–1. Andrews made his home debut against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], on his 28th birthday, Arsenal went on to win the match 4–0. He scored his first goal for Blackburn in the 90th minute during a 2–2 draw with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. Due to injuries sustained by first team regulars, Andrews has featured frequently for the Rovers first team, occupying a defensive central midfield role. In July 2009, Andrews signed a new four-year deal, which will see him contracted to Blackburn until 2013. On 25 September 2010, Andrews came on for [[Steven Nzonzi]] on 66 minutes against [[Blackpool]] at [[Bloomfield Road]] in a 2–1 win for his first game of the 2010–11 campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=292977&cc=5739|title=Emerton breaks Tangerine hearts|date=25 September 2011|work=ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=8 June 2011}}</ref>
The [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11]] season was a frustrating one for Andrews as he only made six appearances in all competitions for Rovers due to injury.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.clicklancashire.com/sport/blackburn-rovers-fc/129202-blackburn-rovers-midfielder-keith-andrews-set-to-miss-rest-of-season.html | title = Blackburn Rovers midfielder Keith Andrews set to miss rest of season | accessdate = 12 August 2011 | date = 24 March 2011}}</ref>

====Ipswich Town (loan)====
Andrews agreed to a six-month loan move to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on 12 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14493110.stm | title = Ipswich Town sign Keith Andrews from Blackburn Rovers| accessdate = 12 August 2011 | date = 12 August 2011 | work=BBC News}}</ref> This loan includes an option to buy the player permanently.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.greenun24.co.uk/ipswich-town/andrews_blackburn_blast_as_he_joins_town_on_loan_1_992117 | title = Andrews' Blackburn blast as he joins Town on loan | accessdate = 12 August 2011 | date = 12 August 2011}}</ref> A day later he made his debut in a 1–0 loss to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and then 3 days later his first goal came against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]. This was followed by goals against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] and [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]]. Steve Kean, the head coach of Blackburn Rovers, hinted that Andrews' may return to his parent club in January 2012, after a successful loan spell with Ipswich. This was contrary to Andrews' ambitions, who when responding to reports that [[Paul Jewell]], the Ipswich head coach, wanted to sign him on a permanent deal, stated in an interview with the [[BBC]] that, "I don't particularly like the way I was treated at the club [Blackburn]. Not just the manager, the club in general."<ref>{{cite news|title=Ipswich Town quiet on move talks – Keith Andrews|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16290202.stm|accessdate=24 December 2011|newspaper=21 December 2011|date=21 December 2011}}</ref>

===West Bromwich Albion===
Andrews completed a late deadline day (31 January 2012) free transfer to Albion, after handing in a transfer request at Blackburn. Andrews signed a six month contract. On 12 February, Andrews scored his first goal for West Brom and their fourth against former club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]] in a 5–1 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wba.co.uk/page/News/0,,10366~2595788,00.html |title=Andrews seals late Baggies switch |publisher=West Bromwich Albion  |date=29 April 2012 |accessdate=3 May 2012}}</ref> Andrews then made it two goals in two appearances as he scored Albion's fourth in a 4–0 victory over Sunderland two weeks later. Andrews then made it three wins in three appearances as he produced another solid performance in the 1–0 win over Chelsea.

Andrews become a free agent as his West Brom contract ended at the end of the season.

===Bolton Wanderers===
Andrews signed for newly relegated [[Football League Championship]] club [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 29 June 2012 after agreeing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~2827250,00.html?|title=Andrews Signs |publisher=Bolton Wanderers  |date=29 June 2012 |accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref> He made his debut on 18 August in the away game at [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and on 22 December he scored his first goals for Bolton scoring twice from the penalty spot in their 5–4 defeat against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]]<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20738406</ref>

====Brighton & Hove Albion (loan)====
Following the permanent signing of [[Jay Spearing]], Andrews first-team place at Bolton was no longer assured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/wanderers/wanderersnews/10603410.Brighton_to_sign_out_of_favour_Wanderers_midfielder_Keith_Andrews/|title=Brighton to sign out of favour Wanderers midfielder Keith Andrews|publisher=Bolton News|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013}}</ref> On 9 August 2013, Andrews signed a season-long loan deal at fellow [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/news/article/albion-seal-andrews-loan-982531.aspx|title=Albion seal Andrews loan|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|date=10 August 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Brighton in a 1–1 draw with [[Sheffield Wednesday]] on 1 October 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24246250|title=Brighton 1–1 Sheff Wed|publisher=BBC |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>

====Watford (loan)====
On 24 July 2014, Andrews completed a move to fellow [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] joining on a season-long loan deal.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28464504</ref> Andrews made his Watford debut from the start in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] first-round tie at [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] on 12 August 2014.

====Milton Keynes Dons (loan)====
On 2 February 2015, transfer deadline day, Andrews rejoined Milton Keynes Dons on loan for the duration of the season after his loan to Watford was cut short.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/news/article/keith-andrews-loaned-to-mk-dons-2244753.aspx|title=Keith Andrews loaned to MK Dons|publisher=Bolton Wanderers F.C.|date=2 February 2015|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref>

==International career==
[[File:IrelandAlgeria2010.JPG|thumb|right|Keith Andrews (number 20) in a 2010 friendly for Ireland against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]]]] 
Andrews made his full international debut for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] on 19 November 2008, coming on as a second-half substitute and scoring a goal as part of a 3–2 home defeat in a friendly match against [[Poland national football team|Poland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=284&catid=1&Itemid=8|title=Ireland suffer defeat against clinical Poland side|publisher=FAI|date=18 June 2009|accessdate=18 June 2009}}</ref> He played his first competitive match for Ireland, being unlucky to have a goal disallowed in a 2–1 [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - UEFA Group 8|World Cup qualification]] group match victory over [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Republic of Ireland 2–1 Georgia. Jazz Hands earned his 13th Ireland cap against Brazil on 2&nbsp;March&nbsp;2010 wearing the number 8 shirt. |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/7881893.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 February 2009 | date=11 February 2009}}</ref> He was also present in Paris for [[France 1–1 Ireland (18 November 2009)]].

After being ever-present in Ireland's midfield during their 2010 FIFA World Cup qualification campaign, he missed the start of their [[UEFA Euro 2012]] campaign due to an injury-hit [[2010-2011 Premier League|Premier League]] season. He returned to the Irish squad for the [[Nations Cup (football)|Nations Cup]] games against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] and [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. He made an instant comeback to the Irish team with a good all round performance against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]].

On 7 June 2011, Andrews scored his second international goal in a 2–0 victory over four-time [[FIFA World Cup]] winners [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in a friendly game in [[Liège|Liege]], Belgium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/13662923.stm|title=Italy 0–2 Republic of Ireland|date=7 June 2011|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 June 2011}}</ref> His third international goal came in the shape of Ireland's first goal, a header, in the 4–0 victory in the first leg of the [[UEFA Euro 2012]] play-off against [[Estonia]] in [[Tallinn]], the second leg of which secured qualification for UEFA Euro 2012 with a 1–1 draw in Dublin.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/1111/estonia_ireland_report.html|last=Houston|first=Rory|title=Estonia 0–4 Republic of Ireland|date=11 November 2011|publisher=RTÉ Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/1115/ireland_quotes_players.html|title=Duff – Euro qualification an 'amazing feeling'|date=15 November 2011|publisher=RTÉ Sport}}</ref>

Andrews played every moment of Ireland's UEFA Euro 2012, until the very end of the final game when he was sent off against Italy. On 10 June 2012, in Ireland's first game of [[UEFA Euro 2012 Group C|Group C]] against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], Andrews failed to score despite having a number of clear shots on goal and actually succeeding in hitting the woodwork; Ireland fell to Croatia by a score of 3–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/euro-2012/2012/0610/324424-republic-of-ireland-beaten-in-euro-opener/|title=Republic of Ireland 1–3 Croatia|date=10 June 2012|work=RTÉ Sport|accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref> Andrews's poor luck continued in the following game as Ireland crashed out of the tournament, falling to [[Spanish national football team|Spain]] by a score of 4–0 on 14 June 2012, before he was led off the field in a rage after receiving a red card in Ireland's final group game against Italy, a game the team lost 2–0. Thus Ireland finished the campaign bottom of [[UEFA Euro 2012 Group C|Group C]] with no points, having conceded nine goals and equalling the worst performance by a team in European Championships history.<ref>{{cite news|first=Daniel|last=McDonnell|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/euro-2012/irish-news/trap-sticks-to-tired-but-trusted-formula-3140723.html|title=Trap sticks to tired but trusted formula|date=18 June 2012|work=Irish Independent|publisher=Independent News & Media|accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref> Nevertheless, ''[[The Irish Times]]'' said he was "arguably Ireland's best performer in the tournament".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/soccer/2012/0618/1224318193132.html|title=Irish nightmare completed in Poznan|date=18 June 2012|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 June 2012|quote=Andrews, arguably Ireland's best performer in the tournament, received a second yellow card a minute from time and summed up the frustration of the campaign by furiously kicking the ball away as he trudged off and stormed down the tunnel.}}</ref> Andrews was named as Irish Player of the Year for 2012<ref>http://www.lionofviennasuite.com/2013/2/4/3950930/keith-andrews-named-fai-player-of-the-year</ref>

'''Wayne Michael Hill Andrews''' (born 25 November 1977) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] in [[the Football League]] for a number of clubs, most notably for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]], [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] and [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]], and also appeared for several clubs on loan. He is of [[Barbados|Barbadian]] descent.<ref name="Barbados">{{Cite web| title = Chilvers joins Colchester| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/3787011.stm| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

==Career==

===Watford===

Born in [[Paddington]], London, Andrews began his career at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], where he made his debut as a substitute in a 2–1 win against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on 17 August 1996. He made his first league start 10 days later in a 2–0 defeat to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]].<ref name="Leeds History">{{Cite web| title = The Definitive History of Leeds United – Players – Wayne Andrews 2007| url = http://www.mightyleeds.co.uk/players/andrewsw.htm|publisher = The Mighty Mighty Whites| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Watford in a 2–0 win over [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on 3 September 1996 in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie, and scored his first league goal in a 3–2 win over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] one week later. His first season ended having scored five goals in 29 appearances in all competitions.<ref name="SB 96-97">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 1996/1997 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=126 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

After making two league and two cup appearances for the Hornets in the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98 season]], Andrews suffered a broken ankle, leaving him out of action for seven months.<ref name="SB 97-98">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 1997/1998 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=127 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="WFC Legends">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews at Watford Legends.com| url = http://www.watfordlegends.com/Wayne_Andrews.html |publisher = Watford Legends.com| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

====Cambridge and Peterborough loans====

On his return from injury, Andrews was loaned out to both [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] and [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] in the [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99 season]]. He made only two appearances for Cambridge in October 1998, before joining Peterborough in February 1999.<ref name="SB 98-99">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 1998/1999 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=128 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He made an immediate impact for the Posh, scoring four goals in a 5–2 victory over [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on his debut. He went on to make ten appearances for Peterborough, scoring only once more during his spell.<ref name="WAGU">{{Cite web| title = We Are Going Up!| url = http://www.wearegoingup.co.uk/tag/wayne-andrews/ |publisher = We Are Going Up!| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

===Non-league===

Andrews was released from his Watford contract in April 1999 and joined [[St Albans City F.C.|St Albans City]] for one season, later spending a year at [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] and then one season with [[Chesham United F.C.|Chesham United]].<ref name="Leeds History"/>

===Oldham Athletic===

In May 2002, Andrews signed for [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on a one-year deal. At Chesham, he played under [[Bob Dowie]], brother of [[Iain Dowie|Iain]], who was at the time assistant manager at Oldham.<ref name="BBC Oldham signing">{{Cite web| title = Oldham sign Holden| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oldham_athletic/1977721.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Andrews made his Latics debut on 31 August in a 2–0 defeat to [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]].<ref name="SB 02-03">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2002/2003 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=132 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Oldham on 14 September from the [[Penalty area|penalty spot]] in a 6–1 win over [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]].<ref name="Oldham 6–1 Mansfield">{{Cite web| title = Oldham 6–1 Mansfield| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/2241456.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Having scored 11 goals in 38 league appearances and with Oldham reaching the [[Football League play-offs|play-offs]], Andrews was sent off for violent conduct in the second leg of their play-off semi-final defeat against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 14 May 2003.<ref name="BBC Oldham final game">{{Cite web| title = Furlong sinks Oldham| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/3024745.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> On 16 May 2003, it was announced that Andrews had been released from Oldham, despite being offered a new contract.<ref name="BBC Oldham release">{{Cite web| title = Oldham release quartet| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/o/oldham_athletic/3034615.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

===Colchester United===

On 1 July 2003, Andrews joined [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] on a two-year contract.<ref name="BBC Colchester signing">{{Cite web| title = Colchester sign duo| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/3034730.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He made his home debut in a traditional pre-season friendly with neighbours [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], a game which ended 3–0 to Town.<ref name="Colchester 0–3 Ipswich">{{Cite web| title = Colchester 0–3 Ipswich| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/3099653.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He scored on his full debut, coming on as a substitute in a 4–3 away defeat to [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] on 23 August.<ref name="Port Vale 4–3 Colchester">{{Cite web| title = Port Vale 4–3 Colchester| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/3154627.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Andrews started the season brightly, scoring four goals in his first six matches for the U's, and also scored a goal in five consecutive games between 21 October and 15 November. He scored 14 goals in 50 appearances for Colchester in the [[2003–04 Colchester United F.C. season|2003–04 season]].<ref name="SB 03-04">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2003/2004 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=133 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

===Crystal Palace===

On 1 September 2004, immediately before the transfer deadline,<ref name="WFC Legends"/> Andrews transferred to [[Premier League]] side [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], who were managed by former Oldham manager Iain Dowie. He signed for a six-figure fee in the region of £100,000, with [[Gareth Williams (Welsh footballer)|Gareth Williams]] joining Colchester in part-exchange.<ref name="BBC Palace move">{{Cite web| title = Andrews moves to Palace| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/3617538.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> 

He made his Palace debut on 11 December 2004, coming on as a 53rd-minute substitute for [[Aki Riihilahti]] in a 0–0 draw with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].<ref name="C Palace 0–0 Blackburn">{{Cite web| title = C Palace 0–0 Blackburn| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4072023.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> Andrews made nine appearances in his first season with Crystal Palace, failing to score a goal.<ref name="SB 03-04">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2004/2005 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=134 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Andrews featured more regularly for the team following their relegation from the Premier League, making 31 appearances in all competitions, but scoring only once.<ref name="SB 05-06">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2005/2006 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=135 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> In May 2006, Andrews was released from Crystal Palace with a record of just one goal scored in 33 league games.<ref name="Palace release">{{Cite web| title = Trio released from Palace deals| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/4991554.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

===Coventry City===

On 3 June 2006, Andrews signed for [[Football League Championship|Championship]] rivals [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on a three-year contract.<ref name="Coventry signing">{{Cite web| title = Striker Andrews joins Sky Blues| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/5043708.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> His time with Coventry did not start well after suffering a fractured ankle in a pre-season friendly defeat against [[Boavista F.C.|Boavista]] on 30 July. Andrews had scored Coventry's goal in the 2–1 defeat.<ref name="Coventry injury">{{Cite web| title = Andrews suffers fractured ankle| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/5230718.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Andrews made his debut on 28 October, coming on as a substitute in the 83rd minute and scoring in the 84th away at [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] to win the game 1–0. This was to be his only goal scored for Coventry.<ref name="Coventry debut">{{Cite web| title = Barnsley 0–1 Coventry| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/6072732.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

====Sheffield Wednesday loan====

After making only three appearances for Coventry, Andrews went out on loan to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on a month-long deal.<ref name="Sheff Wed loan">{{Cite web| title = Owls seal loan deal for Andrews| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_wed/6176386.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He made nine appearances for the Owls, scoring one goal, once again scoring against Barnsley.<ref name="SB 06-07">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2006/2007 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=136 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

====Bristol City loan====

In January 2007, Andrews was sent out on loan once again, this time to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] for an initial month-long deal.<ref name="Bristol loan">{{Cite web| title = City get Coventry striker on loan| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_city/6278879.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He scored on his debut for Bristol in a 3–0 win against former club Oldham the following day.<ref name="Oldham 0–3 Bristol City">{{Cite web| title = Oldham 0–3 Bristol City| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/6258687.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He then scored in his next game during a 2–0 [[Football League Trophy]] win against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]] on 23 January.<ref name="Bristol City 2–0 Brighton">{{Cite web| title = Bristol City 2–0 Brighton| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/6282027.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> On 31 January, his loan with Bristol was extended to the end of the season.<ref name="Bristol loan extension">{{Cite web| title = Coventry tie up Lee-Barrett deal| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/6319207.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He scored one further goal for City against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in a 1–0 victory on 17 February,<ref name="Blackpool 0–1 Bristol City">{{Cite web| title = Blackpool 0–1 Bristol City| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/6349541.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> bringing his total to three goals in ten matches.<ref name="SB 06-07"/>

====Leeds United loan====

On 1 October 2007, Andrews signed for [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] on a one-month loan deal.<ref name="Leeds loan">{{Cite web| title = Leeds recruit Andrews and De Vries| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/7022052.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> He was recruited following a string of injuries and suspensions for [[Jermaine Beckford]], [[Trésor Kandol]], [[Leon Constantine]] and [[Tore André Flo]]. He made two appearances for Leeds, playing once in the league, a 1–0 win over former club Oldham, and a 1–0 win over [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] in the League Trophy. He failed to impress at Leeds and was returned to Coventry after the expiry of his deal.<ref name="Leeds History"/>

====Bristol Rovers loan====

On 24 March 2008, it was announced that Andrews was to be released at the end of his contract with Coventry City.<ref name="Coventry release announced">{{Cite web| title = Coventry to release eight players| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/7311439.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> A few days later, he signed on loan for [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] until the end of the season.<ref name="Bristol Rovers loan">{{Cite web| title = Rovers make double loan signing| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_rovers/7316468.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> Andrews lasted just 17 minutes for Bristol Rovers as he was stretchered off with an injury to his knee ligaments.<ref name="Bristol Rovers injury">{{Cite web| title = Pirates rocked by Andrews injury| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_rovers/7322272.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

===Later career===

After his release from Coventry, Bristol Rovers had looked to sign Andrews, if he proved his fitness during pre-season.<ref name="Bristol Rovers line-up">{{Cite web| title = Pirates line up fit-again Andrews| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_rovers/7493478.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> The club set a deadline for him to prove his fitness by the end of July. He had missed some of his rehabilitation from injury as Coventry had already announced he was to be released at the end of his contract with them.<ref name="Bristol deadline">{{Cite web| title = Rovers set deadline for Andrews| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_rovers/7501844.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

Following his failed trial with Bristol Rovers, Andrews began training with [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] and he was offered a contract in October 2008.<ref name="Luton singing">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews training with Luton Town| url = http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/coventry-city-fc/football-rumours-gossip/2008/10/15/wayne-andrews-training-with-luton-town-92746-22038183/| publisher=Coventry Telegraph| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref> After ten appearances and no goals for Luton, Andrews was released in January 2009.<ref name="Luton release">{{Cite web| title = Luton boosted by triple signing| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/7831971.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="SB 08-09">{{Cite web| title = Wayne Andrews – Season 2008/2009 – Soccer Base| url = http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=8950&season_id=138 |publisher = Soccerbase| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>

[[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] took Andrews on trial in February 2009, but the club did not offer him a contract.<ref name="Yeovil trial">{{Cite web| title = Striker Andrews gets Yeovil trial| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/y/yeovil/7912701.stm|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 11 February 2013}}</ref>
